headline: Braniff Filing
abstract: A rejuvenated Braniff International Corporation said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 2.2 million shares of common stock at between $12 and $15 a share. The stock offering, which would generate at least $26.4 million for the carrier, is the latest move in Braniff's attempt to return to service on March 1. Braniff shut down and filed for bankruptcy protection in 1982 and was reorganized through a $70 million buyout by the Hyatt Corporation, the Chicago- based hotel chain.

headline: People
abstract: *  John D. Hetherington elected a senior vice president of Needham, Harper & Steers/USA.     *  Andrew J. Molnar joined Intergroup Marketing and Promotions, a subsidiary of D'Arcy MacManus Masius, Bloomfield Hills, Mich., as senior vice president and creative director.     *  Vincent R. Duffy joining Ogilvy & Mather Public Relations as a senior vice president and general manager of its New York office.

headline: A Clinic That Caters To Foreign Celebrities
abstract: The Cleveland Clinic Foundation, where the President of Guinea, Ahmed Sekou Toure, died of a heart ailment on Monday, is known for having treated more dignitaries, both foreign and domestic, than almost any other clinic in the world.   Similar in its organization to other well-known medical institutions such as the Mayo and Leahy Clinics, the Cleveland Clinic differs from many other clinics in the richness and variety of services and facilities it offers to V.I.P. patients.   In recent years, the clinic has treated such dignitaries as King Hussein, Dr. Albert Sabin, who had a heart bypass operation there, and the heads or leading officials of many countries.

headline: Search by UAL's GAB Narrowed to 3 Agencies
abstract: GAB Business Services, a subsidiary of UAL Inc., is expected to announce its new agency today, having last week narrowed its search for its $2 million account to three shops: Doremus & Company, which has served GAB for 14 years; Epstein, Raboy Advertising, and Marsteller.     GAB is the world's largest claims adjustment company. UAL of Chicago is also the parent company of United Airlines.

headline: GILDER: THE PROMISE IN ENTREPRENEURSHIP
abstract: IN the supply-side wake left by Laffer's Curve, an unknown, self-    taught economist and social philosopher from Harvard and the Berkshire Hills became, almost overnight, the toast of the Reagan Administration.   The sensation was George Gilder, author of ''Wealth and Poverty.'' Mr. Gilder called his 1981 book ''a theology of capitalism''; supply-side economists saw the work as their bible, and embraced it as their own. David Stockman, calling it ''Promethean in its intellectual power and insight,'' gave copies of the book to new Administration appointees; President Reagan delivered a copy, complete with national press coverage, as a get-well present to an ailing Senator Bob Dole. At the same time, liberal critics called the book's conservative economic theories the ''loopy'' products of a ''crackpot.''

headline: Nixon Cautions on Extremes In Dealing With Soviet Union
abstract: Former President Richard M. Nixon said last night that the United States should avoid ''extremes'' in dealing with the Soviet Union.

headline: Layoff Outlook At Pratt
abstract: Executives of Pratt & Whitney, based here, said tonight that the Air Force's decision to end the company's lock on the fighter engine market could well have an effect on employment, although it was too soon to tell whether layoffs would result. Pratt's parent company, United Technologies, is Connecticut's largest employer.    The decision will hit hardest in the industrial city of East Hartford, where the engines are assembled. Parts for the engines are made in Pratt & Whitney plants in Middletown, North Haven and Southington, said Frank Giusti, a spokesman for United Technologies.

headline: RENTERS IN THE COMMODITY PITS
abstract: Getting onto the trading floor of the Board of Trade would seem to require not only an ample reservoir of courage, but a fat wallet as well. Full membership, which allows one to trade any contract in any pit, sells for $320,000 or so. Even the most limited membership fetches about $20,000.    Kevin Bulman got onto the floor for $200 a month.   Like individuals who do not have the savings to buy their dream house and thus rent from the more fortunate, commodities traders are increasingly renting memberships today. For as little as $150 a month, a trader with big dreams and a tiny bankroll can find himself jousting away in some of the newer pits.

headline: MEXICO TRIES TO EXTRADITE AN EX-POLICE CHIEF
abstract: The Government started extradition proceedings in the United States and Canada on Friday against a former Mexico City Police Chief accused of tax evasion, extortion, illegally importing contraband and possessing illegal weapons, a spokesman in the Attorney General's office said.   The extradition request for the former chief, Arturo Durazo Moreno, were turned over to the Foreign Relations Secretariat for relay to the Mexican Embassies in Ottawa and Washington, the spokesman said.   ''It is purely a bureaucratic matter now,'' the spokesman added. ''The evidence against Mr. Durazo is solid enough to warrant the extradition request.''

headline: MARINES IN LEBANON: 'HOSTAGES' IN A PLACE WHERE THE ARTILLERY DOES THE TALKING
abstract: News  Analysis    BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 23 - The United States Marine contingent in Lebanon is in a difficult predicament, in the view of some Lebanese officials, Arab political analysts and Western diplomats here.  If the marines withdraw from Lebanon in the near future, the officials believe, there will be widespread panic and chaos. In addition, they say, American credibility and interests in the Arab world will be seriously damaged for a long time to come.   They add, however, that if the marines remain - even to the end of the 18-month limit agreed on by Congress and the President - there is at this time no reason to expect that the conflict will be any closer to a solution or that the marines' exit some time in the future will be any less problematic then if they departed tomorrow.   In effect, these officials and analysts say, the marines have become hostages of the Lebanese crisis. The only way they can withdraw within a reasonable period of time and without leaving chaos and a trail of broken promises in their wake is through a constructive solution to the nine-year- old Lebanese crisis.

headline: U.S. DEFICIT IN 1985 TO BE $180 BILLION, REAGAN AIDES SAY
abstract: President Reagan will send to Congress next week a budget for the fiscal year 1985 with a projected deficit of $180 billion based on spending of $925.5 billion, Administration officials said today.   There will be no substantial reduction in the budget deficit before the fiscal year 1988, the officials said. The deficit for the fiscal year 1984, which began last Oct. 1, is projected at $184 billion, down from $195 billion the year before.    Officials said all final decisions on the 1985 budget had been made. ''We are locked up,'' one of them remarked. In a reflection of both the election year and the President's opposition to taxes, the budget will propose only about $5 billion in net reductions in nonmilitary domestic spending.

headline: MACY'S, LORD & TAYLOR TO ENTER NEW ORLEANS
abstract: R. H. Macy & Company will enter the New Orleans market, beginning in 1986, with two stores in new shopping centers, principals in the negotiations said yesterday. One of the centers will also include a Lord & Taylor store, according to the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, which is building one of the projects.     One of the Macy stores will be in a 700,000-square-foot retail center planned on a large tract in downtown New Orleans, near the Superdome. This center will be part of a multi- use, high-rise development to be known as Poydras Plaza.

headline: STRIKES DISRUPT PUBLIC SERVICES IN BRITAIN
abstract: Thousands of civil servants and municipal workers around Britain caused spot transportation stoppages and other disruptions today to protest a Government move to strip union membership from workers at a secret communications center.    The workers attended rallies in support of those among the 8,000 employees at the installation, the Government Communications Headquarters at Cheltenham in the west of England, who face dismissal after resisting the Government's decision to exclude them from union membership.   Local and national government offices were shut for all or part of the day in patterns that varied widely.   Publication of Britain's national newspapers was halted this evening when an engineering union joined the protest despite a decision by other major newspaper unions to work to insure full coverage of the day's events.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: JAPAN SHAREHOLDERS TALK BACK
abstract: Japanese stockholders traditionally have enjoyed few privileges, and the airing of complaints at company annual meetings has not been among them. But slowly, as the importance of revisions in the Japanese commercial code has come to be appreciated, things are starting to change: Japanese shareholders are talking back.    Thus, while the typical annual meeting until recently might have lasted no more that 20 minutes or so - just long enough for management to get its proposals rubber-stamped - they have become far more drawn out in recent months. Indeed, some have turned into marathons.

headline: ADVERTISING ; Hakuhodo Signs Pact With Glendinning
abstract: A ''sales promotion assistance agreement'' may sound like something new in the area of foreign relations, but it happens to be a description of the concordat entered into by Glendinning Associates of Westport, Conn., and Hakuhodo, second only in size to Dentsu among Japan's ad agencies.   Glendinning is the leader in the field of American sales promotion, which is made up of retail games, sweepstakes, coupons and the like.    According to the announcement, Glendinning will assist Hakuhodo in promotion, planning and evaluating in the Japanese market, while the Japanese will give the Yanks the scoop on the marketing and promotion environment back home.

headline: C 3 Army Suit
abstract: C 3 Inc. said a chief trial judge for the Army had found in favor of the company in regard to its suit to lift a temporary Army ban preventing C 3 from receiving new contracts. The ban involved a contract held by C 3 for operations control systems. The company said the findings are subject to review by the assistant judge advocate general.

headline: MEETING IN CAIRO A 'SURPRISE' TO ARAFAT'S FATAH ASSOCIATES
abstract: The Central Committee of Al Fatah, Yasir Arafat's faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said here today that it had been ''surprised'' by Mr. Arafat's recent trip to Cairo, but it refrained from criticizing him.   The statement, at the end of a meeting, denounced what it called a Syrian and Libyan conspiracy against the Palestine Liberation Organization. The P.L.O. and the Arab nations broke with Egypt over its peace with Israel in 1979.

headline: U.S. SAYS COPTER DID NOT AID REBELS
abstract: United States diplomats and leaders of United States-backed guerrillas fighting to overthrow Nicaragua's Sandinista Government said today that the American military helicopter that went down near the Nicaragua-Honduras border Wednesday was not in any way connected to the anti-Sandinista insurgency.    But they had different explanations of what the helicopter was doing in the area, which has been the scene of heavy fighting in the past.   The helicopter pilot, Chief Warrant Officer Jeffery C. Schwab of Joliet, Ill., was killed, reportedly by gunfire from Nicaragua after making an emergency landing only a few hundred feet inside Honduras. United States diplomats said they could not say whether the craft had been forced to land because of mechanical problem or because it had been hit by hostile fire.

headline: Advertising; Western Air Campaign
abstract: The biggest media for the $12 million ad campaign of Western Airlines that is about to break are newspapers and magazines.

headline: Data Bank; January 15, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: DEERE, FIRESTONE SHOW IMPROVEMENT
abstract: Deere & Company, citing increased efficiencies and cost reductions, yesterday reported a profit of $2 million, or 3 cents a share, in its first fiscal quarter, compared with a loss of $28.5 million a year earlier.    Deere, the world's largest producer of farm equipment, said sales in the three months ended Jan. 31 increased 3.2 percent, to $887 million, from $859.6 million.   Sales of farm equipment, which accounts for about 88 percent of Deere's business, were down 3 percent, but industrial equipment, which accounts for about 12 percent of the business, showed a healthy 39 percent gain.

headline: WHITE HOUSE REBUFFS O'NEILL ON BEIRUT
abstract: The White House said today that President Reagan had ''many options'' for taking action in Lebanon beyond the Congressional resolution that has become a focus for criticism of his policy.    A White House spokesman said that, while protection of the marines was the legal basis for the new policy of shelling anti-Government positions in Lebanon, ''the President has certain prerogatives in other areas outside the October 1983 resolution.''   The spokesman, Larry Speakes, was responding to a complaint of Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. that such shelling was ''absolutely not'' permitted by the resolution.   In addition to claiming broader powers for the President, Mr. Speakes seemed to contradict earlier statements that tied the new shelling policy to American support for President Amin Gemayel.

headline: Stocks Regain Ground; Dow Up 1.99
abstract: The stock market rose slightly yesterday in active trading, after declining in the preceding three sessions. Issues responding to specific news posted the largest price moves.    The Dow Jones industrial average finished ahead 1.99 points to 1,279.31. In the overall market, advancing stocks on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that fell by 881 to 715.

headline: Argentine Papers In Timerman Dispute
abstract: Jacobo Timerman's return to Argentina provoked a dispute in the Argentine press today over the assets of his newspaper, confiscated by a previous military Government.   The daily Tiempo Argentino said in an article that it was taking two other newspapers, Clarin and La Razon, to court for implying wrongdoings in its purchase of the offices and workshops of La Opinion, Mr. Timerman's former newspaper.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, JANUARY 24, 1984
abstract: The Economy    President Reagan will offer a budget next week projecting a deficit of $180 billion and spending of $925.5 billion for the fiscal year 1985, according to Administration officials. They said budget deficits would show no substantial decline for three years, in contrast to projections last year. The 1985 budget will propose only about $5 billion in net reductions in nonmilitary domestic spending. (Page A1.)   The Supreme Court agreed to hear a challenge to the legality of BankAmerica's purchase last year of Charles Schwab, the country's biggest discount broker. In agreeing to hear the case, the Court widened its review of the increasingly blurred boundary separating the banking and securities industries. (D6.)

headline: Black & Decker Official Resigns and Job Is Split
abstract: The Black & Decker Manufacturing Company said yesterday that its chief operating officer, Robert L. Swam, had resigned ''to pursue other interests.''    The company, which has agreed to buy the General Electric Company's housewares division for $300 million, said Mr. Swam's responsibilities would be split between two managers.

headline: SHORT-TERM GAINS FOR INDIA ECONOMY
abstract: There is an axiom here that as the monsoon goes, so, in large measure, goes India's economy. In a country where most land remains unirrigated and agriculture is the biggest sector of the economy, a short, weak monsoon can start a recession.    Last summer's monsoon was long and strong, though, one of the best in years.   Largely as a result, farm production for 1983-84 has soared to record levels, far surpassing anything India ever saw before. Stimulated by this surge, the economy - once one of the world's weakest and most precarious - has come out of the global recession growing at a brisk annual rate of 6 to 7 percent. That is enough to enable India to reach its five-year growth targets.

headline: Italian Output Declines
abstract: Industrial production in Italy fell 4.5 percent in December after a 1.4 percent rise in November, the Government reported today.

headline: TALKS ARE SAID TO PROGRESS
abstract: A Saudi Arabian mediator met today with Lebanese leaders amid reports that some progress was being made toward an agreement between Lebanon and Syria for resolving the Lebanese crisis.    Some fighting broke out, meanwhile, in and around Beirut, and a Lebanese Army brigade in West Beirut that had declared its neutrality in the current crisis came under shelling. Shells also fell into civilian areas in the heavily populated Shiite Moslem suburbs. Lebanese Christian militia units and anti-Government forces blamed one another for the attacks.

headline: SYRIA ORDERS 7 DAYS OF MOURNING
abstract: Syria declared seven days of official mourning today to commemorate the death of Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader. Offices will be open but flags will fly at half-staff, according to the official Syrian press agency.

headline: Stock Trading From Home
abstract: Fidelity Brokerage Services Inc., the discount brokerage arm of Fidelity Investments, said it is introducing a service permitting customers to enter buy and sell orders using almost any personal computer equipment.

headline: Finance Minister Leads Mexico Through Crisis On Aug. 12, 1982, Jesus Silva Herzog, Mexico's Finance Minister, told the United States Government that his country would run out of money in four days. Since then, despite foreign debts outstanding of about $86 billion, Mexico's financial health has improved markedly.
abstract: Last year, Mexico signed no fewer than 27 agreements with international banks to help restructure its public sector debt. Just last week, it completed negotiations to raise $3.8 billion, on more favorable terms than a previous loan in March, to cover its financing needs for 1984.

headline: INVENTORIES UP 0.4% AND SALES 1.3%
abstract: Businesses increased their inventories by four-tenths of 1 percent in January while sales were up a brisk 1.3 percent from December's record levels, the Commerce Department reported today.   With sales rising more than three times faster than inventories, the closely watched ratio of inventories to sales fell to a record low of 1.30. At that level, it would take 1.3 months for inventories to be sold off at the monthly pace. The December ratio was 1.31 months.

headline: U.S. IS STEPPING UP MILITARY ACTIVITY FOR SALVADORANS
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that United States military activity in Central America was being stepped up in advance of El Salvador's presidential election March 25.   Officials said the actions included new small-scale United States military maneuvers in Honduras; doubling to 1,700 the number of United States military people in Honduras, and arming United States military advisers in El Salvador with heavier weapons to protect themselves.   The officials said that small United States ground units would conduct limited maneuvers, some of which will take place in the region of Honduras between El Salvador and Nicaragua, from now until the start of a large exercise in June. The exercises are intended to intimidate Salvadoran guerrillas and their Nicaraguan backers, one official said.

headline: ABC Unit to Buy Stake in ESPN ABC Video Enterprises Inc. plans to acquire 15 percent of ESPN, the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network, from the Getty Oil Company for between $25 million and $30 million, sources familiar with the deal said.
abstract: ESPN is a cable channel that offers sports and other programming to more than 23 million households.

headline: A WRY COMPENDIUM OF COMPUTER TRIVIA
abstract: The Naked Computer, by Jack B. Rochester and John Gantz. William Morrow & Company, N.Y. 335 pages. $15.95.     COMPUTER success breeds computer imitations and computer clones. The Apple II led to the Franklin Ace. The portable Osborne I with bundled software soon found itself up against a Kaypro with similar attributes. And the I.B.M. PC sparked a mass of clones - the Compaq, the Columbia, the Corona and others. Likewise, computer writing.

headline: Peak Volume In New Issues
abstract: Initial public offerings totaled a record $12.95 billion in 1983, up from $1.45 billion in 1982 and nearly quadruple the previous record of $3.32 billion set in 1981, according to New Issues, a newsletter.

headline: LUXURY-CAR LOBBY WINS A REVERSAL
abstract: Lobbyists for expensive automobiles won a victory in the Senate Finance Committee today by turning around a 10- to-4 vote of last week that limited the depreciation deductions for cars used by businesses to $15,000.    Their success almost went unnoticed, however, because there was no new roll-call vote. The only indication of a change - until Senator Bob Dole, the committee chairman, mentioned it in passing - was the blank space on the committee's blackboard where the luxury auto restriction had been listed.   ''The lobby for the rich overwhelmed the committee,'' said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who sponsored the ceiling. Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, where the Mercedes-Benz American headquarters is based, opposed the luxury car cap. He argued that it was bad tax policy to single out cars while not covering other such items, such as jets or yachts.

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The Ingalls Shipbuilding division of Litton Systems Inc., based in Pascagoula, Miss., received an $822.4 million Navy contract, the Defense Department said. The company is to design and build the first of a new class of amphibious assault ships. In addition, the Grumman Aerospace Corporation, a unit of the Grumman Corporation, received a $323.3 million contract for 24 F-14 aircraft.

headline: Dalgety Foods
abstract: Dalgety P.L.C. said it had sold Dalgety Foods Inc., its United States frozen vegetable and fruit subsidiary, to the J. R. Simplot Company of Boise, Idaho, for nearly $46 million. Payment will be $34 million in cash and $11.6 million nominal amount of preferred stock in a new Simplot company being formed to effect the purchase. Dalgety Foods had pretax profits of about $700,000 on sales of some $100 million in the year ended June 30.

headline: Advertising; D.D.B's Upbeat Outlook
abstract: S INCE Doyle Dane Bernbach is one of the ad agencies for the International Business Machines Corporation, it was no surprise to discover an I.B.M. Personal Computer all white and shiny behind the desk of Barry E. Loughrane, president and chief executive of D.D.B's domestic operation.     Soon, he said over his morning tea, he and other executives will be able to use the computer to learn about qualifications of employees, get financial data on the company or acquire data on a particular advertising category.    He will not need it, however, to discover which agency got the most important advertising creativity awards between 1976 and 1983 or which shop won the most Effies for effective advertising. The answer is Doyle Dane Bernbach in both cases.

headline: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Romann & Tannenholz Gets Benihana Project
abstract: Rocky Aoki, chairman of the Benihana of Tokyo restaurant chain, with the help of Romann & Tannenholz Advertising, is entering the booming frozen entree market, starting in New York with a $1 million advertising budget.    The six frozen entrees will lean heavily toward Chinese, rather than Japanese, cooking.

headline: BORA LASKIN, 71, CHIEF JUSTICE OF CANADA'S SUPREME COURT
abstract: Bora Laskin, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Canada, died today in an Ottawa hospital. He was 71 years old.

headline: DEBT ACCORD SOUGHT
abstract: The Government of Raul Alfonsin, which restored democracy after eight years of a repressive military dictatorship, is struggling to pull Argentina back from the brink of financial collapse.     ''We have an economic situation of such extreme gravity that it has no precedent in Argentine history,'' said Horatio Jaunarena, Under Secretary of Defense and a member of the Alfonsin team trying to reform the structure of Argentine society.    Amid this economic crisis, the new Government faces opposition from Peronist labor unions that have been allied to the military. The Government's agonizing problem is whether it can stick to democratic means, provide the better living standards it has promised to working people and still bring inflation under control.      Backed by Business Leaders      So far, the Alfonsin administration is getting a remarkable degree of support from many business leaders, who view it as trying to lay the foundation for a more stable democratic society.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Babcock & Wilcox , a New Orleans- based unit of McDermott International Inc., an energy services company, said it had received a $31 million order from the Tennessee Valley Authority to upgrade three boilers at a plant near Drakesboro, Ky.     * Campbell Soup Co. , Camden, N.J., said it had agreed in principle to acquire the closely held Mendelson- Zeller Co., a San Francisco-based international broker of fresh fruit and vegetables, for an undisclosed amount.

headline: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE DRUSE 'DON'T FOREGT'
abstract: One chilly morning, after enduring a night of heavy shelling from the United States Marines, a young Druse leader stalked around his dingy office here, jumpy with coffee nerves, eyes streaked red. The marines said they had opened fire to silence an attack from Druse guns. But the young man with the stubby pistol jammed in the waistband of his jeans insisted that the Americans had bombarded civilian areas, and now he was talking about getting even.    ''See that guy over there,'' he said, jabbing a finger at a small boy with an automatic rifle, ''He's 11 years old. He can shoot and fight like all our children. We are fighting for our people and our land. Our people don't forget our deaths. We will let our sons know that their fathers were killed by marines, and the sons will go on for 10 generations killing marines. The marines are going to be killed by the families of the people they have killed. Our people won't forget.''

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Bank of Boston Corp.  said it had completed the acquisition of Casco- Northern Corp., a bank holding company in Portland, Me., for about $55 million in adjustable-rate preferred stock.     * DWG Corp ., the Miami-based holding company controlled by the financier Victor Posner, said it had increased its stake in Axia Corp., a maker of metal products, to 1,690,295 shares, or 28.3 percent, through the purchase of 776,200 shares from Guardian Industries and Guardian's G.I.C. Financial Services Corp. subsidiary.     * Diagnostic/Retrieval Systems Inc., a display systems company in Oakland, N.J., said it had agreed in principle to buy the shares outstanding of Precision Echo of Santa Clara, Calif.

headline: Iran Is Persecuting Bahais Anew, U.S. Says
abstract: The State Department accused Iran today of renewed persecution of Bahais and said more than 550 members of the religious faith were in prison.   Alan D. Romberg, the State Department spokesman, said about 180 were arrested in November and December, most of them former elected members of Bahai organizations that disbanded in September after their activities were banned by Iran's chief revolutionary prosecutor. Mr. Romberg said 70 more Bahais were arrested Jan. 1-3.

headline: Braniff Filing
abstract: A rejuvenated Braniff International Corporation said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 2.2 million shares of common stock at between $12 and $15 a share. The stock offering, which would generate at least $26.4 million for the carrier, is the latest move in Braniff's attempt to return to service on March 1. Braniff shut down and filed for bankruptcy protection in 1982 and was reorganized through a $70 million buyout by the Hyatt Corporation, the Chicago- based hotel chain.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1984
abstract: The Economy    The projected budget deficits are ''totally unacceptable,'' the President said in his annual Economic Report. While stressing that the deficits must come down, Mr. Reagan also said most major action must wait until after the November election. The report also encourages free trade, supports Federal Reserve policies to curb inflation and urges in broad terms a revision of the tax system. (Page A1.) The report said farm support policies were costly and masked serious problems in that sector. (A12.)    White House economic advisers differed over whether the $100 billion reduction in deficits sought by Mr. Reagan over the next three years as a ''down payment'' would be sufficient. In Congressional hearings, David A. Stockman tried to deflect a Democratic move to widen budget cuts, while Martin S. Feldstein said Mr. Reagan's plan was insufficient. (A16.)

headline: ZHAO EMPHASIZES TAIWAN'S ROLE AS MAIN BLOCK TO U.S.-CHINA TIES
abstract: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China, in the last public appearance of his visit to the United States, warned yesterday that ''sustained development'' of relations between China and the United States depended on ending disagreement between the two countries over Taiwan.   ''Two possible futures lie ahead for Sino-U.S. relations,'' Mr. Zhao said. ''One is steady and sustained development of our friendly relations and cooperation.'' The other, he said, is ''stagnation of our relations at the present level with frequent frictions and even setbacks.''

headline: 5 Morgan Executives Headed for Shearson Five members of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company's international investment unit here, including a senior vice president, Karl Van Horn, 48, and Herschel Post, 44, a member of the senior management group for institutional investment, have left to form the core of a new seven-man Shearson/American Express investment subsidiary.
abstract: ''Morgan has been a victim of its own success,'' said Mr. Post, who will be chief operating officer of American Express Asset Management Holdings. Mr. Post described Morgan's problem as one of too many talented young executives with too little room to advance.   Mr. Post and Mr. Van Horn, who will be chief executive officer, were joined in their resignations by Bernard Rattray, 38, an analyst of American investment markets; Mark Tapley, whose specialty is technical analysis of global developments, and Chilton Thomson, 42, a specialist in European equities. The team will be rounded out by Robert Kugler, who has spent the last 12 years as portfolio manager of the Japan Fund, and Seth Strickland, 45, who has been vice president of institutional equity sales at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

headline: 'STAR-WARS' DEFENSE HAS A FUTURE
abstract: A YEAR ago President Reagan announced a ''vision of the future'' in which defensive weaponry would make the nightmare of nuclear holocaust obsolete. Since then his ''Star Wars'' speech has inspired furious debate about whether powerful lasers placed in orbit could shoot down enemy missiles, how much such a system would cost, and whether it would trigger yet another round in the arms race.   Because space-based lasers are still largely imaginary from an engineering standpoint, none of these questions are likely to be answered soon. George Keyworth, the President's science adviser and an expert on lasers, has judged that the hardware is at least 20 years away. To answer the question of how programs to build a laser defense system would translate into jobs means gazing into a crystal ball that could be shattered at any time by myriad political forces.

headline: Data Bank; January 8, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: PATENTS; Radiation Shield
abstract: A transparent plastic material containing lead, which provides a shield from low-intensity radiation, was patented this week for Arthur D. Little Inc. of Cambridge, Mass.

headline: EGYPT PREPARING TO FACE A THREAT
abstract: Egypt took special precautions today after reports that Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, might order a mass march across the frontier to press his goal of a merger with Egypt, security officials here said.   Colonel Qaddafi staged such a march in the early 1970's. At that time, President Anwar el-Sadat had the demonstrators rounded up just inside Egypt and sent them back by truck.

headline: THE 3 PROTAGONISTS
abstract: The struggle for control of Warner Communications Inc. will provide an arena for three of the country's toughest and most closely watched entrepreneurs.    On one side, apparently, stands Rupert Murdoch, an Australian publishing executive with a penchant for being both secretive and sensational. On the other is the flamboyant Steven J. Ross, whose vast Warner entertainment conglomerate has been badly battered of late, and Mr. Ross's most recent ally, Herbert J. Siegel, a scrappy, high-living investor and chairman of Chris-Craft Industries who has never given up his romance with the movie business.    For Mr. Murdoch, buying up to 49.9 percent of Warner - as he announced yesterday he plans to do - would be the greatest gamble yet in a career of risky ventures. For Mr. Ross, who built Warner into a major force in the entertainment industry, it would be a battle for control of his company. And for Mr. Siegel, who seemed to come to Mr. Ross's rescue last month, it would be an avenue back into the movie business.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Stanley Steemer Moves   Stanley Steemer International of Dublin, Ohio, which operates a chain of franchised carpet-cleaning establishments, has moved its advertising account from Columbus, Ohio, to Cleveland and Meldrum & Fewsmith.

headline: PATENTS; CONTROLLING SATELLITES IN SPACE
abstract: WASHINGTON   A N improved method of controlling communications satellites has been invented for the RCA Corporation. Patent 4,424,948, assigned to the company, was granted this week to three technical staff members.

headline: FARM CREDIT BANK
abstract: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation announced yields yesterday for $2.547 billion of bonds divided into six- and nine- month maturities.

headline: Aminoil President Adds Title of Chief Executive
abstract: J. B. Coffman, president and chief operating officer of Aminoil Inc., has been named chief executive, effective April 1. Aminoil, a subsidiary of R. J. Reynolds Industries, is one of the largest independent petroleum exploration and production companies.    Mr. Coffman, 58, succeeds George E. Trimble, 63, who remains chairman. Mr. Coffman retains his title as president.

headline: U.S. PLANS LARGEST EXERCISE OF YEAR IN CARIBBEAN
abstract: The Defense Department announced today that a joint Navy, Marine Corps, Air Force and Army maneuver, the largest military exercise of the year in the Caribbean, was scheduled to begin April 20 and continue for 15 days.   The announcement came as United States and Soviet warships cruised between Cuba and Central America, with American ships keeping close surveillance on the Soviet ships after a Soviet submarine collided with the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk in the Sea of Japan on Wednesday.   In Honduras, a small United States ground unit was ready to begin training with Honduran soldiers in the first of several maneuvers that officials said were intended to intimidate leftist guerrillas as El Salvador approaches its presidential election on Sunday.

headline: Sony Picks Marschalk; Borden's Drake at Venet
abstract: The biggest account news on this side of the country Friday was from Marschalk, which picked up the Sony Corporation business that was with Backer & Spielvogel - about $7 million worth of it.    The second-biggest news was from Venet Advertising, which has been tapped by Borden Inc. to handle all of its Drake Bakeries products, which are distributed only along the East    Out along our Western rim, there were a couple of happy shouts.

headline: HUSSEIN REBUKES U.S. ON ARMS DEAL
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan said today that his country needed American weapons and military aid ''very badly,'' but that he would search for arms elsewhere if the terms of the transfers were demeaning to his country.    ''If the dignity of my country is in jeopardy, then thank you very much, we don't need the arms,'' the King said.  ''If the price is that the dignity of Jordan will be affected, then it's too big a price to pay.''    The 48-year-old ruler made his remarks in an interview today with The New York Times and in an appearance through satellite linkup on ''Face the Nation,'' the CBS News interview program.

headline: India and Pakistan To Discuss Peace Treaty
abstract: India and Pakistan, which have fought each other in three wars over 35 years, will discuss proposals for detente in May, the Indian Government announced today.   The announcement came after the foreign secretaries of the two nations concluded talks on better relations.

headline: Mrs. Thatcher's Son Takes Job Promoting Cars in U.S.
abstract: Mark Thatcher, the 30-year-old son of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, has taken a $65,000 job promoting British Lotus sports cars in the United States.

headline: Briton Urges Investor Help
abstract: Britain needs a law to protect investors by expanding the regulatory powers of professional associations, according to a study issued today by the Department of Trade and Industry.   The 18-month investigation by Prof. L. C. B. Gower, who advises the department on corporate law, concluded that the idea of creating a body like America's Securities and Exchange Commission was neither politically feasible (because of opposition from the London financial community) nor necessary.

headline: Two Propose Gas Pipeline
abstract: The ANR Pipeline Company, a subsidiary of the American Natural Resources Company, and the Northern Natural Gas Company, a subsidiary of Internorth Inc. of Omaha, announced today that they are seeking Federal approval for a $1 billion, 663-mile pipeline to carry Canadian natural gas to the Northeastern United States.   The proposal, filed with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, would be contingent on elimination of Canadian border price controls on natural gas, according to an ANR Pipeline spokesman, William J. Curnow.

headline: 3 TOP AFGHAN MILITARY MEN REPORTEDLY REPLACED
abstract: A Western diplomat today quoted reports from Afghanistan as saying that President Babrak Karmal had recently replaced at least three top military men in an attempt to halt the reverses suffered by his soldiers in fighting with Moslem insurgents.   While there has been no official announcement in Kabul, the Afghan capital, the diplomat said the reports of the shake-up were accepted as accurate by Western embassy officials.   Speaking at a regular briefing of reporters here on developments in Afghanistan, the diplomat said the shake- up followed a six-hour meeting that President Karmal reportedly held with senior party and Defense Ministry officials on Jan. 8 to express dissatisfaction with the conduct of the war against the Moslem rebels.   The Western source said nearly 50 Afghan Government troops were killed on Jan. 13 in an ambush by the insurgents near Kabul. He also reported a series of assassinations of party officials and regime followers in the capital last week, including that of a Soviet military official.

headline: HealthAmerica Agency
abstract: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners has become agency for the HealthAmerica Corporation of Nashville.

headline: Sikh Strike in Northern India
abstract: Indian authorities deployed nearly 50,000 troops across Punjab today to guard against possible violence during a strike by Sikhs demanding autonomy for the wealthy northwestern state. The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi also ordered all bus and train services canceled and educational institutions closed Wednesday throughout Punjab.

headline: Bankers Trust Net Up 33.5% The Bankers Trust New York Corporation reported yesterday that it had fourth-quarter net income of $67.8 million, an increase of 33.5 percent over the $50.8 million earned in the comparable period of last year. Per share net income rose 29 percent, to $2.18, from $1.69.
abstract: A number of special factors bolstered earnings in both quarters. In the latest period the bank reported an after-tax gain of $16.1 million from sales of lease financing residuals and securities obtained through loan workouts.

headline: Credit Arranged By Port Authority The arrangement of a $150 million revolving credit facility for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in support of its commercial paper program was announced by the Marine Midland Bank. The two-year credit renews the $100 million facility the bank arranged last November to support the sale of the Port Authority's tax-exempt commercial paper.
abstract: Besides Marine Midland, which is the lead bank, other banks participating are the Bank of New York, First Jersey National Bank, First National State Bank of New Jersey, National State Bank and United Jersey Bank.

headline: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Ford Expects Record Year
abstract: The Ford Motor Company's earnings for 1983 are likely to hit record levels, Philip Caldwell, the company's chairman, suggested today.   In a speech to the Detroit Economic Club, Mr. Caldwell said, ''When the major auto companies release their 1983 financial results in a few weeks time, you will discover that they will stand in comparison with some of the best years we have ever had.''

headline: Horizon/Meamco
abstract: The Horizon ad agency of Athens, specialists in advertising in the Middle East, which recently bought out its Foote, Cone & Belding partner, has now merged with Meamco (Middle East Advertising and Marketing Corporation) of New York.

headline: MURDOCH DISCUSSES PLANS FOR WARNER
abstract: The Australian publisher Rupert Murdoch told bankers here today that if he decides to wage a proxy battle for control of Warner Communications Inc., its aim would be to preserve the value of Warner's movie operations.   Mr. Murdoch's companies already own 7 percent of Warner's 65.4 million outstanding common shares, the largest single block, and the companies initially termed the purchases an investment only.

headline: Joint Maneuvers in Poland
abstract: Soviet, Polish and East German troops carried out military maneuvers in the west and northwest of the country today, the Polish press agency said. The agency did not say when the maneuvers began, when they would end or how many troops were involved.

headline: House of Fabrics
abstract: James A. Nathan, president and chief executive of RB Industries, a furniture maker, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had increased his holdings in House of Fabrics Inc. common stock to 345,000 shares, or 5.4 percent. He said he had acquired the shares for investment.

headline: Carter in Australia
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter arrived in Sydney today for a weeklong private visit.

headline: Argentine Prelate Says Pope Plans Visit in Island Dispute
abstract: Pope John Paul II will visit Argentina to bring to a close his mediation effort in the Beagle Channel dispute with Chile, Juan Carlos Cardinal Aramburu of Buenos Aires said today.

headline: PLANT USE AT 79.9%, HIGHEST SINCE '81
abstract: Factories operated at 79.9 percent of capacity in January, the highest level since the summer of 1981, with auto makers continuing to lead the recovery from recession, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.    The gain from December of seven- tenths of one percentage point was the 14th consecutive increase since the recession ended in November 1982, the report said.

headline: RETAILERS HOPEFUL ON FIRST HALF
abstract: America's retailers concluded their annual convention in New York yesterday, expressing strong confidence about the year's first six months but some trepidation about the second.    Interviews and speeches by some of the 12,000 retailers at the annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association reflected concern about the course of interest rates and whether consumers would delay purchases until after the Presidential election.   As James R. Williams, president of the group, put it during a news conference, ''For the next six months, business will be pretty good, but the second half is uncertain, mainly because of the public's uncertainty whether things might change in Washington.''    Optimism for Half    But for the first half, at least, the merchants were very optimistic.

headline: 2 Companies Cut Distillate Prices
abstract: Two major oil companies announced yesterday that they had lowered prices of wholesale distillates, the product used in heating oil, kerosene and diesel fuel.    The Exxon Company U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, lowered its wholesale distillate prices between 1 and 3 cents a gallon in the Northeast.

headline: Advertising; Esquire Plans 1984 Register
abstract: WHAT can Esquire magazine possibly do to follow the record-breaking 50th anniversary issue and the Nov. 7 party that it engineered into media-event status?    It will be the 1984 Esquire Register issue, due out next December, in which the magazine ''as the Voice of Authority for the baby-boom generation'' will identify those people - all under 40 - it considers to be the future leaders in all major fields.

headline: People
abstract: *  Stephen Bayer has joined Chiat/ Day New York as a senior vice president.     *  J. David Wilson named publisher of ComputerFun magazine, published by Viare Publishing.

headline: Study on Seabrook Unit
abstract: The Central Maine Power Company, 6 percent owner of the financially troubled nuclear project at Seabrook, N.H., said Friday that it would ask the Maine Public Utilities Commission to allow the company's $48 million investment in the second reactor to be recovered from ratepayers. A consultant's study prepared for Central Maine Power estimates the cost of Seabrook 1 at $4.8 billion and Seabrook 2 at $5.5 billion - a total of $10.3 billion. But in Manchester, N.H., a Public Service spokesman, Myra Rivera, reiterated the company's support for both reactors.

headline: Sharon Asks Portfolio In Israeli Government
abstract: Ariel Sharon, smarting from being rejected for a high immigration job on Wednesday, today lashed out at his colleagues in the governing Herut Party for denying him a portfolio in the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.   The war hero has been a Minister Without Portfolio, a largely honorary post, since he was ousted as Defense Minister in February 1983 at the recommendation of an inquiry commission.

headline: PROS AND CONS OF DEFEASANCE
abstract: Thanks to some creative accounting blessed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Wall Street has a new product that it is eagerly peddling to corporate clients.   The name is somewhat forbidding - ''in-substance defeasance'' - but the pitch is easy: pay off large amounts of old, cheap debt with smaller amounts of new bonds that pay high interest rates and, through some accounting magic, report extra profits and clean up the balance sheet.   ''You could see a couple billion dollars of it done in early 1984,'' said John H. Erdman, a principal at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''I can tell you there's a lot of talk about it.''   Corporate Cash Use Questioned    The issue, however, is whether this new financial maneuver is a poor use of corporate cash and another example of short-term accounting gimmickry to dress up one quarter's profits at the expense of a carefully developed corporate strategy for generating long-term profits. In some cases, analysts think so.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Acro Energy Corp., a producer of solar energy panels and related products, said a subsidiary of Phoenix American Inc., a management service of limited partnerships, had agreed to buy $25 million of solar energy equipment from Acro over a two-year period.     *  Graco Inc., a Minneapolis-based producer of specialized pump and spray equipment, said it had started negotiations to sell its consumer products division to a group of investors, including certain employees of the division and another unidentified company, but no terms were disclosed.     *  Great American Industries, a diversified producer of rubber products, said it had agreed to purchase 230,000 shares of International Seaway Trading Corp., a marketer of imported footwear, from shareholders including Seaway's chairman, Nathan Gerdy, and his family, for $9.25 a share, and said the transaction would make it Seaway's majority shareholder.

headline: The U.N. Today; Feb. 6, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Commission on Trade Law, Working Group on the New International Economic Order - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: U.S. MONEY POLICY ASSAILED IN PARIS
abstract: Finance Minister Jacques Delors of France said today that Western Europe ought to think about imposing penalties on the export of capital to the United States if the Americans did not restrain the rise of the dollar on international markets.    ''Irritation is at its height,'' Mr. Delors said.   Speaking here before a group of Western European Socialists, he said he was not proposing curbs on the flow of money, but he added:   ''If the speculative illness of the dollar continues, shouldn't Europe take measures to hinder the flight into the American currency?''

headline: S.E.C. Disclosure Complaints
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed more than a dozen complaints in its pursuit of corporate officials who are purportedly late in disclosing their transactions in their companies' stock.   The 13 complaints bring to 25 the number lodged in the past two weeks.

headline: TREASURY PROPOSES A RESCUE LOAN FOR ARGENTINA
abstract: Officials of the Treasury Department said today that it had proposed a short-term rescue loan that would let Argentina make overdue interest payments to American banks.    If the overdue interest is paid by midnight Saturday, this would free the banks from declaring their Argentine loans to be nonperforming. If the banks do have to make such a declaration, it would reduce their earnings.    But some Administration officials doubted that the negotiations could move that quickly.

headline: Swiss Voters Uphold National Conscription
abstract: Swiss voters upheld the national draft today, a firmly anchored tradition that all able- bodied men must be ready to take up arms in defense of their Alpine homeland.   They rejected by an overwhelming majority a proposed amendment to the federal Constitution that would have introduced a civilian national service as a substitute for objectors to the now compulsory service in the country's army of militiamen.

headline: MORE WOMEN OWNING BUSINESSES
abstract: The number of small businesses owned by women has risen in recent years, but the earnings of those companies still lag far behind those owned by men, according to a new study by the Small Business Administration.   The study, part of the annual report on the State of Small Business scheduled to be released next month, found that women-owned businesses were increasingly cropping up in all areas of the economy, although they were still heavily concentrated in retailing and services.   Frank Swain, the agency's chief counsel for advocacy, said in an interview that there had been ''a general growth in the number of women- owned businesses in every type of business sector, even manufacturing.''

headline: LPG/Pon Gets Nickelodeon
abstract: Entertainment Company has assigned the consumer and trade promotion of the Nickelodeon cable network to LPG/Pon, the entertainment subsidiary of Lois Pitts Gershon that already serves MTV Music Television, the other service of Warner Amex.  Nickelodeon, which carries programming for kids, was formerly served by Scali, McCabe, Sloves, and bills around $3 million. It has a potential reach of 19 million households and last fall began taking advertising.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Ford Motor Credit Notes at 12% Rate A $100 million issue of the Ford Motor Credit Company's 12 percent extendable notes with a final maturity of 1999 will be offered today at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
abstract: Every five years, note holders may redeem their securities or renew them at a new interest rate to be announced at that time. The notes were rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBBx by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: First Armed Robbery In Iceland Is Reported
abstract: Two messengers carrying $70,000 to a bank could not believe they were the victims of Iceland's first reported armed robbery until the man who accosted them fired a warning blast from his shotgun.

headline: Honda Ohio Expansion
abstract: The Honda Motor Company plans a $240 million expansion of its Marysville, Ohio,   automobile plant that will increase its annual production in   the United States to 300,000   cars by 1988, the Japanese auto   maker said today.  Employment at the plant,   which makes Accord automobiles and Honda motorcycles,   will gradually rise to 2,500 after   the expansion, Bob Watson,   vice president and plant manager at Marysville, said at a   news conference.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Cahners Publishing Co.  of Boston, the United States publishing arm of Reed International P.L.C., of London, said it had acquired two magazines, Interior Design and Corporate Design, from Whitney Communications Corp.; terms were not disclosed.     *  Firestone Tire and Rubber Co.  of Akron, Ohio, said it would phase out its involvement in the private-brand segment of the tire business and concentrate on marketing Firestone brand tires and Dayton and Road King brand tires.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: American Express   ($ 21,900,000)   -

headline: Winn Is Opposed
abstract: The International Controls Corporation said it had rejected an offer from Winn Enterprises to be acquired for $21 a share.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; 2 Officers Resign From Petro-Lewis
abstract: Two officers resigned yesterday at the Petro-Lewis Corporation, the Denver-based oil and gas company that last month wrote off $12.8 million and withdrew the offering of a new oil income fund. Petro-Lewis is the country's largest seller of oil and natural gas income funds - limited partnerships holding oil and gas producing properties - and one of the biggest producers in the United States.   Jerry L. Record, 44 years old, resigned as executive vice president, a position he has held since coming to Petro-Lewis about three years ago, to become president and chief executive of World Mail Center, an overnight mail forwarding concern. And Michael R. Starita, 52, president of the company's Petro-Lewis Securities Corporation partnership marketing subsidiary, took early retirement after 14 years with the company to ''become more active in his role as director of a group of local banks.''

headline: IRAN ACCUSES IRAQ OF CHEMICAL WAR
abstract: Iran charged again today that Iraqi forces were using chemical weapons in their attempt to retake an artificial island that Iranian forces seized in southern border marshlands two weeks ago.   An Iranian military communique, broadcast by the Teheran radio and monitored here, said Iraq had ''resorted to the use of chemical bombs'' in the area of the island of Majnoon north of the Iraqi port of Basra.    The Iranian communique said that more than 2,000 Iraqi soldiers had been killed or wounded in fighting in the area in the last three days. It said dozens of Iranian soldiers had been wounded by chemical weapons and had been taken to treatment centers.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Empire Group, packagers of the Empire State Municipal Exempt Trust, a fund of tax-free municipal bonds, to Isidore & Paulson.     * Small Computer Company, a manufacturer of data base software, to Berger, Stone & Partners.     * Science 84 magazine to Grey & Rogers, Philadelphia.

headline: Freeze Raising Insurers' Costs
abstract: The severe freeze that swept most of the United States last month may cost the insurance industry almost $600 million in claims, according to securities analysts, who are lowering their earnings estimates for most major insurers. The claims range from burst water pipes in homes and offices to disruption of business operations.

headline: Japan's Trade Surplus Rises
abstract: Japan had a trade surplus of $20.46 billion in 1983, its largest and nearly three times the 1982 surplus, the Government reported today.   In a preliminary estimate of 1983 trade, the Finance Ministry said the figure included a record $18.14 billion surplus with the United States.

headline: Kidnapped Executive In Japan Manages to Flee
abstract: Katsuhisa Ezaki, a candy company executive, worked loose the ropes on his hands and feet and fled today, 65 hours after kidnappers had seized him from his bathtub and demanded a ransom of cash and gold.

headline: BYRD CALLS FOR MARINE PULLOUT
abstract: Top Senate Democrats, led by Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the minority leader, called on President Reagan today to take whatever steps were necessary to remove the United States marines from Lebanon.   Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, also renewed his criticism, saying Mr. Reagan still had not justified the marines' presence. ''If I had my way I'd get them out soon, right away,'' Mr. O'Neill, a Massachusetts Democrat, told reporters.

headline: NIGERIAN RULER TELLS DIPLOMATS WHY HE TOOK OVER
abstract: Nigeria's new leader, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari, met with foreign diplomats today to give the reasons for the military coup Saturday that overthrew the elected Government of President Shehu Shagari.    According to diplomats and reports on the Lagos radio, General Buhari, a 41-year-old armored brigade commander and former Petroleum Minister, told the diplomats that the system of government that had been in effect since the military handed over power in 1979 had not been ''real democracy.''   He said this West African country, a leading oil producer, had been ''enslaved by a handful of people who had been sharing the wealth among themselves and who were determined to stay in office at any cost.''   The general said that ''thuggery and bribery'' had been the decisive factors in elections this summer and that the continuation of such activities would have led Nigeria to ''economic collapse and political chaos.''

headline: Accounts
abstract: * New York City Fair Housing Administration to Avrett, Free & Ginsburg, for its 1984 public service campaign.

headline: VW Brazil's 1983 Loss
abstract: Volkswagen do Brasil S.A. said today that it posted a net loss in 1983 of about $5.7 million. The company had a profit of about $1.8 million in 1982. Volkswagen said a sharp drop in sales in the second half had helped to cause the loss.

headline: ST REGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: USF&G CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 4 Refused Asylum in Greece
abstract: The Socialist Government has refused political asylum to a family of four Rumanian refugees and will repatriate them to their country, the conservative opposition disclosed Friday in Parliament.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
abstract: Flow General Fills Post of President      Robert E. Wengler, who directed a turnaround of Flow General Inc.'s applied sciences division in 1983, has been elected president of Flow General and named to the newly created office of chief operating officer. He fills a post vacated by Joseph E. Hall, who resigned as president and chief executive in March 1983 because of what the company called ''an honest philosophical difference with the board of directors.''   Flow General, which is based in McLean, Va., offers biomedical products and services and produces communications and testing equipment. It has been struggling to reverse losses it attributed to ''debilitating debt'' and ''unproductive and costly legal difficulties'' arising from some of its technical service contracts. With Mr. Wengler's appointment, the company has replaced both its chairman and president in the last year. Last March, Grant C. Ehrlich was named chairman and chief executive, replacing Thomas C. Bazemore, who retired.

headline: Peugeot Output Gains
abstract: Production at Peugeot's Talbot plant at Poissy has reached 90 percent of capacity after a monthlong strike over layoffs, a company spokesman said today. The plant is expected to reach full capacity on Tuesday, he added.

headline: Arafat Returns to Tunis
abstract: The Palestine Liberation Organization leader, Yasir Arafat, returned to his Tunis headquarters today after visits to Iraq, Kuwait and Yemen. The Palestinian press afency Wafa said Mr. Arafat met with P.L.O. officials in Yemen on Friday night to discuss events in Lebanon. There was no immediate word on the P.L.O. chief's next moves.

headline: Comsat May Sell Its Interest
abstract: The Communications Satellite Corporation said today that it has been discussing the idea of reducing or selling its one-third interest in Satellite Business Systems.   The Washington-based Comsat said that recent discussions with the other two partners in Satellite Business Systems over ways to make it more competitive had included talk of ''new business combinations that might alter the form or extent of Comsat's interest in S.B.S.''   Comsat's partners are the International Business Machines Corporation and the Aetna Life and Casualty Company.   Three Years of Losses    Satellite Business Systems was formed to build and operate an advanced, high-speed satellite network. While revenues have grown, the unit has reported losses of more than $120 million in each of its three years of operation, despite a $711 million investment by the three partners.

headline: REAGAN NAMES BUSH TO HEAD DELEGATION TO MOSCOW
abstract: President Reagan designated Vice President Bush today to lead the United States delegation to funeral of Yuri V. Andropov.    The President instructed Mr. Bush to convey ''to the new Soviet leadership our hope for an improved dialogue and cooperation which can lead to a more constructive relationship between our two countries.''   At the same time, Mr. Reagan called on the Soviet Union's leadership to ''join in peaceful purpose for all mankind.''

headline: STERLING BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REGULATOR'S FEARS FOR THRIFT UNITS
abstract: The Federal official who regulates savings and loan associations, under widespread attack for a proposal to restrict the placement of deposits by money brokers, has privately told members of Congress that the thrift industry is in worse financial condition than is generally realized.    Edwin J. Gray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, has warned that three dozen thrift institutions, including some large ones, are in danger of failing, according to Congressional aides and officials at other regulatory agencies.    Mr. Gray, whose proposed regulation is opposed by the Treasury and Justice Departments and large parts of the financial sector, has argued that payouts to savings and loan depositors by the Federal deposit insurance fund could run well over $1 billion unless the Government cracks down on the deposit brokers. The corporation has some $6.3 billion of reserves and by law can borrow more from the Treasury.

headline: SHULTZ EMPHASIZES U.S. IS READY FOR EFFORT TO IMPROVE RELATIONS
abstract: President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz told Soviet leaders today that during this period of transition in Moscow the United States wanted to reaffirm its desire ''for a constructive and realistic dialogue'' with the Soviet Union.   Although some thought was given to having Mr. Reagan lead the American delegation to the funeral of Yuri V. Andropov, the White House said late today that Vice President Bush would head the delegation. (Page 7.)   In Santa Barbara, Calif., Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said that Mr. Reagan, in a message of condolences, called on the Kremlin to ''join in peaceful purpose for all mankind.''

headline: ISRAELIS REPORTED UNLIKELY TO JOIN THE FRAY IN BEIRUT
abstract: Israeli officials and Western diplomats said today that Israel was unlikely to come to the aid of President Amin Gemayel with any major military operation.    Limited action, such as air strikes or naval bombardment of Shiite Moslem and Druse positions, would be undertaken by Israel only in coordination with the United States, officials in Jerusalem said. They said Israel would not act alone, and they denied reports that Israel had urged the Reagan Administration to take steps to bolster the Gemayel Government.   There has been no official Israeli Government reaction to the reverses of the Lebanese Army by Shiite militia in mainly Moslem West Beirut. One official here explained that while Israel favored the continuance of President Gemayel in office, it would do him no good to have Israel say so in public.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Table Talk   Fast-food sales are normally one of the first consumer sectors to bounce back when a recession ends and more people are willing to loosen their belts and their purse strings. But the recovery, accompanied by unusually high unemployment,has not been a normal one for the industry, which is only now beginning to tote up impressive sales.  ''The first priority of many consumers when the recovery began was to buy cars and other big-ticket items,'' says Michael Culp, restaurant industry analyst at Prudential- Bache Securities. Families, particularly those with more than one wage earner, are just beginning to flock to the fast-food chains now, Mr. Culp says.  Thus, he expects the leading chains' profits to surge by 20 percent this year, compared with more modest growth of 12 percent in 1983 and 9 percent in 1982.   Another phenomenon affecting industry revenues is an increasing willingness by diners to move up from the average $3 meal at a fast-food chain to one costing $4 or $5, ''provided the shop offers a quieter and more esthetically pleasing ambiance,'' Mr. Culp adds.

headline: SHULTZ IS GLOOMY ON LEBANON CRISIS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was unable to report any progress in President Amin Gemayel's efforts so far to end the political crisis in Lebanon.   Testifying before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Mr. Shultz seemed gloomy about the prospects for Mr. Gemayel to form a broadly based government as urged by the Reagan Administration.   In a separate appearance before the Foreign Affairs Committee, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said President Reagan ''was not giving up'' in Lebanon, despite plans for a pullback of American marines there, and would soon submit the first request for funds for military aid to Lebanon. Mr. Weinberger said no figure had been decided, but he estimated that it would be $250 million to $300 million in a supplement to the current fiscal year's military aid bill. (Page 7.)

headline: Tentative Yields Set On New M.A.C. Bonds
abstract: The Municipal Assistance Corporation is selling $200 million of bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The bonds were tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 9 3/4 percent for the 2008 maturity, falling to 9 1/2 percent in 1999 and 8 3/4 percent in 1994.

headline: Jordan Accuses Libya Of Attack on Embassy
abstract: The Jordanian Foreign Ministry said agents paid by the Libyan Government stormed Jordan's Embassy in Tripoli, Libya, today and burned it to the ground.   The Jordanian report said Ambassador Sami al-Shamaylah and members of his staff were inside the building at the time of the attack and managed to escape ''with extreme difficulty.''

headline: Raymark Cutback
abstract: The Raymark Corporation said it plans to reduce its staff by 40 because of reduced sales and to sell its headquarters here. Raymark, which makes friction materials, industrial products and rivets, said its headquarters would move to smaller facilities in the area.

headline: Yugoslav Leaves Capital
abstract: President Mika Spiljak of Yugoslavia left for Los Angeles today after two days of meetings in Washington with President Reagan and other United States officials. Mr. Spiljak used his final day in Washington for meetings with Vice President Bush, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and members of the House Foreign Affairs and Senate Foreign Relations Committees.

headline: ANOTHER GANDHI SEEMS TO TAKE A LIKING TO POWER
abstract: On the day before Mohandas K. Gandhi was assassinated in 1948, so the story goes, three women from Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's family dropped in for a friendly visit. One was Nehru's daughter, Indira. While the women and the Mahatma chatted, Indira's 3-year- old son, Rajiv, played with the great man's feet, decorating his big toe with a garland of flowers.   The tableau fraught with dynastic symbolism is turning out to be more prophetic than anyone might have guessed. For as Nehru's daughter prepares for an election that is viewed as likely to extend her rule as India's Prime Minister into a third decade, her son has clearly emerged, after three years in politics, as the second most powerful figure in the country.

headline: HONDURANS SAID TO CHANGE COPTER STORY
abstract: United States Embassy officials and the chief of the Honduran armed forces said today that two Honduran military officers have admitted they fabricated a report that a United States helicopter forced down by Nicaragua last week was following a flight plan that included stopping at a village near the Nicaraguan border.   The officers' report, which the embassy said involved a false flight plan, contradicted both official United States and Honduran versions of the circumstances surrounding the helicopter's flight.   Gen. Gustavo Alvarez Martinez, chief of the Honduran armed forces, said, ''I disavow what these men said.'' He called the confusion over the incident ''quite a lamentable moment.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: American Express Co.  said its Shearson/American Express Inc. unit had agreed in principle to acquire Columbia Group, a privately held mortgage finance firm, for an undisclosed cash price.     *  Beatrice Foods, Chicago, said it had agreed to sell its Shedd's margarine business to the U.S. holding company of the British-Dutch Unilever Group, and that the sale would result in an after-tax gain of about $45 million.     *  Computer Input Services Inc., a Philadelphia-based company, filed a plan of reorganization with bankruptcy court officials, and said that part of the plan calls for the transfer of substantially all of its business and assets to a newly formed subsidiary of CDI Corp., an engineering and technical services company.

headline: Fannie Mae Offers Mortgage Debt
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday offered $200 million of 13 percent mortgage-backed securities at a price of 98 26/32, to yield 13.06 percent, through various securities dealers.    The securities are a kind of pass- through security in which monthly payments of principal and interest from a pool of home mortgages are passed through to investors. Principal and interest payments begin May 25.

headline: STRIKE SHUTS TIMES OF LONDON
abstract: The Times of London failed to appear for the second straight day today because of a dispute between management and a print union over the dismissal of 750 clerical workers. A spokesman said publication of The Sunday Times was also in doubt.

headline: Velveeta at Burnett; JVC Shifts to SSC&B
abstract: The reassignment by Kraft of the Velveeta cheese brand to the Leo Burnett Company, from J. Walter Thompson, topped the recent list of campaign switches; it will probably bill more than $15 million.    Other account changes included the official announcement of the JVC Company of America, the United States marketing arm of a Japanese audio equipment company, that it was going to SSC&B after having been served by Marsteller.

headline: U.S. Criticized On the Deficit
abstract: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned today that the United States economic recovery might begin to evaporate next year if the Reagan Administration did not cut the huge Federal deficit.   The 24-nation group said in a critical report on the American economy that interest rates would remain high and unemployment would be a persistent problem unless the Administration acted.

headline: Manville Proposal Might Dilute Stock
abstract: The Manville Corporation said that, in connection with its Chapter 11 reorganization proceedings, an alternative concept proposed by a creditor is being discussed among creditor groups, equity representatives and company representatives. The proposal contemplates a potentially significant dilution of the company's equity securities.

headline: U.S. CUTS LIST OF DUTY-FREE IMPORTS
abstract: The Reagan Administration, responding to protectionist pressure, has cut deeply into the list of goods that developing countries are permitted to sell in the United States without paying a tariff.    The action was taken under the Generalized System of Preferences, which allows 140 nations to export more than 3,000 products to America duty-free.    In announcing the Presidential decision today, Bill Brock, the United States special trade representative, said that imports valued at $11.9 billion last year were being excluded from the zero-duty preference list.    For the first time since the program began in 1976, the total of excluded trade exceeds the value of trade that receives the duty-free treatment - $10.8 billion last year.

headline: KISSINGER PANEL REPORTED TO BACK AID FOR THE NICARAGUAN GUERRILLAS
abstract: A Presidential commission on Central America will recommend continued American aid to insurgents seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government, three commission members reported today.    But they said the report will assert that such aid will become less necessary as the Nicaraguan Government halts its assistance to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador and makes progress toward internal democracy.   The three members said the report treats aid to Nicaraguan rebels as an important way to promote negotiations for a regional settlement in Central America and not as a way of trying to overthrow the Government in Managua.   More Aid Called Necessary    The report, still private and not scheduled for delivery to President Reagan until Wednesday, also asserts that El Salvador needs six times as much military aid for 1984 and 1985 as Congress has appropriated.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Texaco Planning to Sell Record Eurobond Issue
abstract: Texaco Inc. said today that it planned to sell $800 million in 10-year convertible bonds to investors outside the United States in what would be the biggest such issue ever in the Eurobond market.   Proceeds would help Texaco, the nation's third-largest oil company, restructure its debt following the $10.1 billion takeover of the Getty Oil Company last month.

headline: Briton Plans a Rival To People Express
abstract: - Richard Branson, a record company executive, said today that he plans to start a low-fare airline to rival People Express for trans-Atlantic business.   Mr. Branson, 33 years old, who made millions after he pioneered discount mail-order records in Britain, said he expects to carry 185,000 passengers between London and New York in the first year on his no-frills airline, Virgin Atlantic.

headline: IMITATION GOODS COSTLY TO THE U.S.
abstract: The Federal Government, taking its first hard look at the economic effects of international counterfeiting of brand-name products, says bogus merchandise has cost American workers at least 131,000 lost jobs and American companies $6 billion to $8 billion in lost annual sales.   A study by the United States International Trade Commission found that beyond the economic loss was a threat to consumer health and safety as a result of defective drugs, farm chemicals, automobile and aircraft parts and other products moving through the marketplace under false colors.   The counterfeited goods, which include copies of such brand-name products as Levi Strauss jeans, Capitol recordings of the Beatles and Cross pens, are manufactured abroad and sold both in the United States and in foreign countries.   The commission, a Government fact- finding agency that investigates trade matters, stressed in its 221-page study:   ''The quality difference can be of particular importance in some industries to the health and safety of the consumer, as is the case for defective auto parts, ineffective or nonsterile drugs and pharmaceuticals, and ineffective agricultural chemicals.''

headline: REAGAN DEFENDS LEBANON POLICY, CITING SYRIA AS 'STUMBLING BLOCK'
abstract: President Reagan asserted today that it was ''unfair'' to say his policies had failed in Lebanon, despite the military and political disarray of the Government there.    Mr. Reagan accused Syria of being the ''stumbling block'' to a peaceful reconciliation of the warring factions in Lebanon.   In an interview with writers specializing in women's issues, Mr. Reagan also said the attacks on the forces of President Amin Gemayel were a function of the ''success'' rather than the failure of United States policy, which has included military participation with France, Italy and Britain in a force in Beirut.   'It's Very Obvious'    ''I think it's very obvious that those attacks began because the multinational force was contributing to success, and a success that certain elements don't want,'' he said. ''And so they centered on trying to drive the multinational force out of Lebanon. And to me, this is a kind of significant admission that we were having some success.''

headline: Data Bank; March 25, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: FRENCH TROOPS ARE STAYING FOR NOW
abstract: France is keeping its troops in Beirut for now and has made no decision on withdrawing them, French officials said today.    Although the Government has clearly indicated that it wants a United Nations force to replace its 1,270 men in Beirut, the officials said the French units remained at their posts today although their patrols were halted.   With the United States, Britain and Italy reducing the size of the international force in Lebanon, French officials were guarded in discussing the Government's intentions. The French seemed to want to demarcate their policy and actions in Lebanon from the other countries' to maintain the widest berth possible for diplomatic maneuvering in the Middle East. This is a reflection of France's historical and cultural involvement in Lebanon, which is considered here as part of the French- speaking community.
