headline: Sears Unit to Buy Fixed Mortgages The Sears Mortgage Securities Corporation announced plans to purchase 15-year and 30-year conventional fixed-rate mortgages yesterday.
abstract: The program has 30- , 60- and 90- day delivery periods with maximum loan amounts based on loan-to-value ratios.

headline: Economic Scene; Andropov and His Legacy
abstract: K ONSTANTIN U. CHERNENKO takes over the leadership of the Soviet Communist Party at a time when its hopes are rising that the late Yuri V. Andropov found ways to break the stagnation into which the Soviet economy had lapsed in the last years of the Brezhnev regime.    Those hopes are based partly on the improved economic performance in 1983, Mr. Andropov's one full year in office. Soviet industrial output increased 4 percent, compared with a gain of only 2.9 percent in 1982. Labor productivity in industry rose 3.5 percent last year. Mr. Andropov pushed up productivity by imposing tougher discipline on both workers and managers, however, and most economists view the gains from his crackdown on loafing, absenteeism and corruption as a one-shot improvement, which Mr. Chernenko cannot extend.

headline: Russian Priest Dismissed
abstract: The newspaper Turkmenskaya Iskra of Ashkhabad in Central Asia has reported that the Rev. Pyotr Rassokha, a Russian Orthodox parish priest in the Turkmenian city of Mary, had been dismissed for stealing collection money, selling unlicensed candles and indulging in illegal religious activities.

headline: Comshare, I.B.M.
abstract: Comshare Inc. said it had reached an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation to supply I.B.M. with software that would be jointly marketed by the two companies. The so-called decision- support software, which allows managers to perform such functions as budgeting, statistical analysis and information retrieval, runs on I.B.M.'s mainframe and personal computers.

headline: COMMODORE EXECUTIVE RIFT DENIED
abstract: The chairman of Commodore International Ltd. denied yesterday that a dispute with directors had led to the unexpected resignation late Friday of Jack Tramiel, Commodore's hard- driving and mercurial founder.     ''Jack has been working unceasingly here, and he was just tired,'' Irving Gould, the chairman, said in a telephone interview. ''But the company is now more than just Jack. If we have made a wrong decision here, the bottom line will show it - but based on the current momentum of the company we are confident that is not the case.''

headline: TEXT OF SHULTZ'S STATEMENT ON LEBANON AND MIDEAST TALKS
abstract: Following is the text of a statement read by Secretary of State George P. Shultz to reporters at the State Department today:    It has been a time of fast-moving events in the Middle East and I wanted to say a few words about where we are and what our objectives are.   In Lebanon, we face a new situation brought about by military pressures against the legitimate Government. This Syrian-sponsored violence against the Government has presented us with difficult choices in view of the legislative and other constraints under which our forces are operating. We are nonetheless proceeding:     - To provide material support to the Lebanese Armed Forces as circumstances permit;     - To respond to those who attack or threaten the safety of our personnel; and     - To redeploy our Marine detachment onto ships.

headline: Advertising
abstract: Cable May Be Helping Magazines      LIKE any skeptic pinching himself   because he can't believe good   news, the Magazine Publishers Association has gone back into the field to verify three previous consumer research studies that showed archrival network television's audiences shrinking after cable was introduced into the picture.    And the new, more extensive study done by Audits and Surveys did indeed verify that finding, and also that in a number of cases magazine reading in fact increased when homes got wired for cable.   ''Magazines become a viable alternative to make up for network erosion,'' said Marianne Howatson, vice president, marketing, for M.P.A. The electronic medium is a deadly enemy of magazines, since its drains off so much of the advertising spending, which is the life blood of both.

headline: Technology in Spain
abstract: The Government plans to channel $600 million into Spain's technology sector to expand production and reduce dependence on imports, Industry Minister Carlos Solchaga said today.

headline: LINDNER GETS 45.4% OF UNITED BRANDS
abstract: The American Financial Corporation increased its stake in United Brands Inc. to 45.4 percent from 29.3 percent, the two companies said yesterday.    They said American Financial, a Cincinnati-based financial holding company headed by Carl H. Lindner, had bought 2.21 million United Brands common shares and 33,130 preferred shares.

headline: Offer for Grand Central
abstract: Grand Central Inc., which operates mass merchandise retail stores in five Western states, said Saturday that it had agreed to be acquired by Fred Meyer Inc. of Portland, Ore., for $11 per share of common stock, or about $26 million.

headline: WEST BANK ARABS URGE ARAFAT-HUSSEIN UNITY
abstract: A delegation of prominent West Bank Arabs today urged Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chief, to devise a joint approach with King Hussein of Jordan on negotiations with Israel over the fate of the West Bank.    The delegation met this evening with Mr. Arafat to present the group's plea in a petition, despite Israeli warnings that meeting with Mr. Arafat was forbidden.  The delegation was said to include Elias Freij, the Mayor of Bethlehem.   The Israeli authorities did not specify what action would be taken against those who violated the ban. But a senior Israeli military official said on Monday that if Israel received word of such meetings, ''we will deal with it on its merits.''

headline: TAX BURDENS INCREASE IN THE NEW YORK AREA
abstract: The savings many Americans will realize on their Federal income tax returns this year will be partly offset by higher state and local taxes.     Throughout the country, many state and local governments, hard- pressed by a cutback in Federal revenue-sharing, have sought to compensate by enacting major tax increases. And many of those increases will be reflected on 1983 state and local personal income tax returns.    ''States are in a scramble to get additional revenues,'' said William Katz, a partner at Ernst & Whinney, an accounting firm. ''And even if they haven't raised rates, states are getting more aggressive in seeking revenues.''

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Banca Nazionale de Lavoro, Italy's largest bank, issued $100 million of seven-year floating-rate depository receipts through Credit Suisse.     * Hyponex Corp. , a manufacturer of organic lawn and garden products, filed a $30 million offering of subordinated debentures due April 15, 2044, through Salomon Brothers.      Common Stock     *    * American Motors Corp.  filed an offering of 12 million common shares at $5.37 1/2 through Lazard Fr eres.

headline: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAEL RENEWS SEARCH FOR OIL
abstract: The Israelis, having relinquished to Egypt the oil and gas fields they discovered in the Sinai Desert, are stepping up their search for oil at home.  So far, the biggest discovery in this new campaign was made by American and Israeli prospectors who found oil late last year in the sterile Negev Desert between Arad and the Dead Sea.   The American partner in the venture, with about a one-third interest, is Isramco, a 15-month-old company that went public last August. Principals of the company include Joseph Elmaleh, who owns a 21.1 percent stake through Southern Shipping and Energy, which he controls. The other major partner is the Jerusalem Oil Exploration Company, known as J.O.E.L., associated with Isramco, which has about a one-third interest. Most of the rest is controlled by companies that worked on the project.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Associated Dry Goods Corp. , a diversified retail chain, has appointed Donald E. Ray president and chief executive of its Sibley, Lindsay & Curr division.     *  Combustion Engineering Inc., Stamford, Conn., a diversified energy company, has elected Charles E. Barnett vice president and general counsel.

headline: C.I.A. LINK DENIED
abstract: A gunman, firing five times at close range, shot and wounded the United States consul general in Strasbourg today as he left his home there.    The diplomat received what doctors called ''superficial wounds.''   A group calling itself the Lebanese Armed Revolutionary Factions took responsibility for the attack on the envoy, Robert Onan Homme, 43 years old, who has been the consul in Strasbourg since 1981. A note mailed at noon today to Agence France-Presse by the group said, ''Mr. Homme was already well known for his activities as a member of the C.I.A.''   He Deals With Common Market    Officials at the American Embassy in Paris said Mr. Homme was not with the Central Intelligence Agency but was a career diplomat and political officer whose main task was representing the United States at the European Economic Community's institutions in Strasbourg, notably the European Parliament.

headline: NEW DIRECTOR OF U.S. RIGHTS PANEL CALLS FOR MAJOR CHANGE OF COURSE
abstract: The new staff director of the United States Commission on Civil Rights today recommended major changes in its programs. She said the changes could show possible adverse effects of affirmative action, racial quotas, court-ordered busing and bilingual education.    The staff director, Linda Chavez, selected Mark R. Disler, a lawyer with the Justice Department, to be general counsel to the commission. Mr. Disler has served for 15 months as an aide to William Bradford Reynolds, the Assistant Attorney General for civil rights, and worked on several legal briefs that were harshly criticized by the old commission.   Mr. Disler described himself as a conservative Republican and said that he, like President Reagan, opposed mandatory busing, quotas and other ''racial preferences.''

headline: WESTLANDS DIVERSIFIED BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Merrill Lynch
abstract: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. announced an agreement with Safeway Stores and National Transaction Systems, which handles the processing of cash machines in Safeway stores, to permit the Cash Management Account Visa cards of the securities firm to be used in some of those stores. The cards will be usa ble in machines in 54 Safeway stores in southern California beginning in March and in another 50 stores in northern California later in the year. Plans call for a maximum of $500 to be withdrawn in each transaction, and a fee of $1 per transaction.

headline: FOR THE FLIER'S FAMILY, HECTIC DAY IN SPOTLIGHT
abstract: ''Oh God, it's unbelievable,'' Marilyn Goodman said early yesterday on learning that her son, Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., was being released in Syria. ''I just need more details.''   By yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Goodman, a bank teller who lives in Queens, had received more details, and she and her other two sons, Martin, 19 years old, and Tyron, 24, were on their way to Washington.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Laura Scudder Account    Keye/Donna/Pearlstein in sunswept Beverly Hills, Calif., has become the agency for Laura Scudder's snack foods, produced in nearby Anaheim, Leonard Pearlstein, managing director, reported yesterday. The client, previously owned by Pet Inc., is now independent. It used to do its advertising in-house.

headline: TOP ECONOMIC ADVISER FINDS GROWTH AT 6%, EXCEEDING FORECASTS
abstract: The chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers today predicted an annual growth rate for the national economy this winter that is considerably higher than what the Administration and most private economists were expecting just a month ago.    The chairman, Martin S. Feldstein, told the National Association of Manufacturers that the rate for the first quarter would be 6 percent, up from 4 to 5 percent expected earlier.   It is unusual for the Administration to predict a quarter's rate of economic growth so early. In two weeks the Commerce Department will make the first official estimate in its ''flash'' report.   But 6 percent growth is consistent with what many forecasters have predicted recently in light of unexpectedly strong growth in housing starts, automobile sales and industrial production.

headline: EX-BATUS OFFICIAL JOINING CALVIN KLEIN
abstract: Robert J. Suslow, former chairman of the Batus Retail Division of Batus Inc., was named yesterday to be president of a new corporate entity for the Calvin Klein fashion business. The 50-year-old Mr. Suslow will also be an equity partner in the privately held company, which has annual sales of $500 million.   The announcement by Mr. Klein and Barry Schwartz, his longtime partner, of Mr. Suslow's appointment ends months of conjecture about where he might land after an abrupt announcement of his resignation from Batus in March 1983. A month ago, asked about persistent trade reports that he would be joining the Calvin Klein operation, Mr. Suslow said: ''It's absolutely not true. It will never, never happen.'' Telephone calls to Mr. Suslow's Manhattan home yesterday were not returned.

headline: Citicorp Unit Plans Eurobond LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) - Citicorp International Bank Ltd. said its parent holding company was raising 30 million European currency units through a six-year 10 5/8 percent Eurobond.
abstract: Banque Nationale de Paris is lead manager of the par-priced bond, along with Citicorp International. The borrower can call the issue after three years at 100 3/4 percent, with this premium declining by 1/4 percent each year to par.   Issued in the name of the Citicorp Overseas Finance Corporation, the bond matures Feb. 15, 1990.

headline: FOR HIM, REALTY IS A NOBLE CALLING
abstract: LONDON GERALD Cavendish Grosvenor spent the first part of March slogging around the muddy, frigid English countryside in the Territorial Army, Britain's version of the Army Reserves. It's the only two weeks in the year when the Duke of Westminster takes orders.    Although there are members of the British aristocracy who have fallen on lean times, the 32-year-old Duke isn't one of them. He controls an international property empire that, by most estimates, makes him a billionaire and Britain's richest man.    The heart of the empire is the Grosvenor Estate, encompassing half of Mayfair and nearly all of Belgravia, London's most expensive residential and shopping districts. The Duke inherited not only the land, which has been in his family for three centuries, but also most of the apartments and shops in these neighborhoods, roughly equivalent in status to New York's Sutton Place or Gramercy Park.

headline: Ex-Officer of Time Unit Joins Maritime Data
abstract: Larry T. Pfister, who was a vice president at Time Inc.'s Video Information Services, has joined the Maritime Data Network Ltd. in the newly created posts of president and chief executive.   Mr. Pfister, 47, has spent a good deal of his career in the teletext and videotex areas, technologies that have developed more slowly than expected.    Time Inc., for example, recently ended its teletext operation, where Mr. Pfister worked. ''It was the conclusion of a two-year field test,'' Mr. Pfister said, ''and the conclusion was that the market isn't quite ready for it yet.''

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Leukemia Treatment   The Department of Health and Human Services received a patent this week for a method of treating leukemia.

headline: Pillsbury Realignment
abstract: The Pillsbury Company said yesterday that it had formed a new executive office. Winston R. Wallin, who was the company's president, becomes vice chairman.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Banque de Paris Names Chief for California Unit      The Banque National de Paris, which took over the Bank of the West in 1980, has named one of its senior executives to head the San Francisco bank. Directors appointed Michel Larrouilh, who has served with Banque National in posts around the world, to succeed Moss McKenzie as president and chief executive.

headline: Former Aide Sued By Media General
abstract: Media General Inc. and its subsidiary, Media General Broadcast Services, filed suits in Federal and state courts in Memphis against the subsidiary's former president, William B. Tanner, and others. Mr. Tanner was also dropped as a consultant to the subsidiary, said Alan S. Donnahoe, vice chairman and chief executive of Media General, a communications and financial services company based in Richmond.    Media General said its suit, filed in U.S. District Court, related to what it said were misrepresentations made when it acquired the William B. Tanner Company in July 1982.

headline: COSTA RICA IS GATEWAY FOR ILLEGAL U.S. IMMIGRANTS
abstract: Hundreds of Taiwanese and Cuban immigrants have been entering the United States using Costa Rican passports, either forged or obtained under false pretenses, according to Government officials and businessmen here.   According to the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Carlos Gutierrez, several known international terrorists have also been caught with Costa Rican passports or travel documents.    In addition, foreigners trying either to conceal political pasts or facilitate business travel have purchased legal or bogus Costa Rican passports, officials here say. These foreigners include Libyans, Iranians, mainly relatives and associates of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, and Nicaraguan supporters of the assassinated dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

headline: ON CAMPUS: AMOS TUCK
abstract: In mid-January, when the thermometers here drop below zero and stay there, the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College is probably the coldest of the nation's top business schools.     Tuck, founded in 1900, is also the country's oldest graduate school of management, and among the smallest: Last fall's entering class had only 143 students, though that will be increased to 160 next fall. Its faculty, including visiting professors, numbers 46.

headline: ROLLINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: K Mart Is Buying Associated Hosts
abstract: The K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest non-food retailer, has agreed to take over the Associated Hosts Inc. restaurant chain for $80 million in stock, the two companies announced today.   ''It's another one of K Mart's attempts to diversify,'' a K Mart spokesman, Barbara Palazzolo, said.

headline: Death Toll Rises to 5 In Chilean Protests
abstract: A teen-age girl died today from a gunshot, raising to five the death toll from anti-Government protests Tuesday.

headline: State Fines Charter Unit The New York State Insurance Department said yesterday that it had imposed a $100,000 fine on the Charter Company's New York life insurance unit for making investments in violation of state law. The department said the investments were illegal when they were made, although changes in state law would make some of them acceptable today. It also said they had not had a ''material impact'' on Charter's soundness.
abstract: Last year, the Charter Company, through insurance subsidiaries in New Jersey and New York, was the largest issuer of single-premium deferred annuities.   With a single-premium deferred annuity, an investor pays a lump sum, and his money is invested, accumulating interest tax-free until repayment begins.

headline: Louisville Gas
abstract: The Louisville Gas and Electric Company said it disagreed with the Energy Systems Research Group, Boston consultants to the Kentucky Public Service Commission, that work on a $680 million coal-fired plant for the utility could be delayed until 1991 because of available power from other utilities.

headline: U.S. WARSHIPS AND JETS POUND LEBANON TARGETS
abstract: The Defense Department said tonight that United States warships had laid down naval gunfire and mounted air strikes at targets in Lebanon after American marines at the Beirut airport had come under attack.   The Pentagon, in a sketchy announcement, said that five-inch guns had been fired from the frigate Garcia, and that planes from the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy conducted air strikes to support the marines ashore. One marine was reported wounded, not seriously, by unnamed attackers.   Spokesmen for the Pentagon said that the targets had been rocket sites in the Shuf Mountains east of Beirut and that the attacks had been defensive responses to fire directed at the marines at the airport. In the past, such announcements have said that specific targets had been attacked to retaliate for shots at the marines or naval reconnaissance planes.

headline: Test-Tube Birth in Israel
abstract: A 29-year-old Israeli woman gave birth today to this country's first ''test tube'' twins, the fifth such twin birth in the world, doctors said. The twin girls, weighing four pounds and five and a half pounds, were delivered at Tel Aviv's Sheba Medical Center.

headline: ARMS TALKS OPEN WITH SOVIET TAUNT
abstract: The Soviet delegate to the 40-nation disarmament conference here accused President Reagan today of seeking to mislead world opinion with ''pompous appeals for a Soviet-American dialogue.''   Alluding to the President as ''someone over the ocean,'' the Soviet delegate, Viktor L. Israelyan, charged that Mr. Reagan was seeking through his arms policies to ''change the strategic balance in the world in favor of the United States.''   This and other attacks made by Mr. Israelyan at the opening session of the 1984 United Nations Conference on Disarmament were denounced by the American delegate, Louis G. Fields. He called them a ''landmark in personal attacks against governments and particularly against the President of the United States.''

headline: A BANKING RESTRICTION WILL END
abstract: C. Todd Conover, the Comptroller of the Currency, said today that he would not renew a moratorium, due to expire March 31, on the granting of national bank charters to securities firms and other non-banking businesses. However, Mr. Conover's office said his letting the moratorium lapse did not necessarily mean he would begin to grant such charters.    In response to Mr. Conover's announcement, the Federal Reserve Board repeated that it opposes any general expansion of the so-called non-bank banks.

headline: 2 Agencies Pick Up Account Assignments
abstract: Two other account assignments affect Tromson Monroe Advertising and HBM/Creamer.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: POLITICAL SNUB IS INFURIATING SWISS WOMEN
abstract: Swiss women refer to Dec. 7 as Black Wednesday, the day the Swiss Parliament soundly rejected the first woman ever to stand for the country's seven-member ruling Federal Council.    The vote has enraged women of all political persuasions and has set off a political crisis, the first in almost a quarter of a century, in the normally stable Swiss Government.   The woman rejected was Liliane Uchtenhagen, 55 years old, of Zurich, one of Switzerland's most prominent politicians. Mrs. Uchtenhagen was proposed as one of the two candidates of the Social Democratic Party. Traditionally in Switzerland, Parliament elects the candidates offered by each of the four ruling parties.

headline: EMPIRE SAVINGS OF TEXAS IS SHUT DOWN
abstract: The Federal agency that regulates savings associations today shut down the Empire Savings and Loan Association of Mesquite, Tex., which it said was insolvent and had obtained more than 85 percent of its deposits, or about $262 million, from money brokers, nearly all of it in 1983.   The closing this morning by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board came as a House subcommittee began a hearing into a regulation proposed by the board and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that would effectively curtail the use of brokered deposits by banks and thrift institutions. The proposal has come under heavy criticism from the banking and brokerage industries and the Treasury and Justice Departments.   The shutdown of Empire Savings appeared to support the contentions of Edwin J. Gray, the bank board chairman, that money brokering poses a threat to the thrift industry and to the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which will make payments to Empire depositors of up to $100,000 per account.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THATCHER INTERVIEW
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview Friday with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, as recorded by The New York Times:      Q. You expressed quite candidly, I thought, displeasure over the Grenada episode.   A. All of this was comparatively sudden. Our Deputy High Commissioner had been in Grenada on the Sunday asking about the safety of our people, ''No, they will soon be able to get out, they're perfectly all right.'' ''Do you want intervention?'' ''No, your people, I think, will be able to get out within the next two or three days; the airport will be open.''    Q. So you thought it was a mistake.

headline: SYRIA FREES FLIER, ATTRIBUTING STEP TO JACKSON'S TRIP
abstract: The Syrian Government today released Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., the United States Navy flier its forces captured in central Lebanon a month ago after shooting down his plane.    The Syrian Foreign Ministry said the release was in response to ''the human appeal of the Rev. Jesse Jackson'' and ''also to the demands'' of the United States. The Foreign Ministry termed the release a contribution toward ''creating circustances that would facilitate the withdrawal of American troops from Lebanon,'' and it expressed the hope that the United States would now take steps ''to end its military involvement'' there.

headline: Sohio Quits Shale Project CLEVELAND, Feb. 26 (Reuters) - The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has announced that it is pulling out as a partner in the $2.5 billion Paraho-Ute oil shale project in Utah.
abstract: The action follows Friday's announcement that Sohio and two partners in another Utah venture, the White River oil shale project, have withdrawn their application with the Synthetic Fuels Corporation for Federal financial aid.

headline: Ogilvy & Mather Adds Another Sears Account
abstract: Having removed its Sears Business Systems Centers account from the N. W. Ayer advertising agency in January, Sears, Roebuck & Company announced yesterday that it was assigning the business to Ogilvy & Mather, Chicago.    Sears Business Systems, which has been spending about $6 million a year on advertising, with half of that being handled in-house, left Ayer's Chicago office when Ayer's New York office picked up the $60 million J. C. Penney national advertising account.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: Polish Union Activist Is Found Dead on Farm
abstract: A 33- year-old Solidarity activist was found dead under mysterious circumstances a week ago, and a Roman Catholic Bishop is reported to have called the death a murder.   The body of the dead man, Piotr Bartoszcze, was found Feb. 11 at the bottom of a drainage pit on a farm near his home outside the northern city of Inowroclaw, the police said Friday.

headline: U.S. Says It Seeks To Bolster Sudan Forces
abstract: The United States said today that it was seeking ways to strengthen the military forces of the Sudan against what it called ''increased security threats,'' but denied Ethiopian charges that a big arms airlift to the Sudan was under way.   The Sudan has accused Ethiopia of aiding rebels in the southern part of the country and of attacking Sudanese territory.

headline: Rooney Pace Buys Stake in Norlin Rooney Pace Inc., a New York securities firm, has purchased 18.5 percent of the Norlin Corporation, a maker of musical instruments, Rooney Pace said in a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Rooney, Pace also said it might seek ''significant influence over the company.''
abstract: Norlin has filed a complaint in United States District Court in New York protesting the stock purchase.    The investment firm said it had bought 281,850 Norlin shares at prices ranging from $28 to $36 a share between Dec. 23 and Jan. 12. Yesterday Norlin shares closed at $34.25, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Newcomer Steers United Merchants    United Merchants and Manufacturers, the old-line textile and apparel company, has not been heard from much since its Robert Hall retail division faltered and put the company into bankruptcy proceedings in the mid-1970's.    The company emerged from those proceedings in 1978 and has been struggling to find its direction. In January 1982, it named Uzi Ruskin president and chief operating officer and last week, Mr. Ruskin put United Merchants back in the business news.

headline: Colombia Rebels Free American Held 5 Months
abstract: Leftist guerrillas who kidnapped Russell M. Stendal in Colombia on Aug. 14 have freed the 28-year-old American missionary and farmer, the United States Embassy said today.

headline: ROUTING 'CUTE' FRAUDS AND 'BOOK-COOKERS'
abstract: THE S.E.C.'s battle against insider    trading is making big headlines   these days. Yet insider trading accounts for less than 10 percent of the agency's enforcement program. A much greater percentage of its staff resources - S.E.C. officials estimate at least 40 percent - is being devoted to investigating and prosecuting companies and managers who send false financial reports to their shareholders.

headline: Stable OPEC Course Urged
abstract: An OPEC committee, as expected, recommended today that the group maintain the oil price and production policies established a year ago, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cut prices for the first time ever.   Analysts cited three factors that have enabled the OPEC to hold the line on prices in a traditional season of sluggish oil demand and at a time when some of its members are seeking to raise their production ceilings:     - A threat that fighting in the Iran- Iraq war could lead to closing the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow Persian Gulf passage through which 20 percent of the non-Communist world's oil supply sails.

headline: NAP to Dissolve Its Odyssey Unit
abstract: Odyssey, which started the home video game market 13 years ago but could not dominate it, has stopped making its computers and cartridges.

headline: A.T. & T. SETS JOINT VENTURE
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed in principle to form a joint venture to provide telecommunications services to multi- tenant office buildings.    The joint venture would provide such items as switchboards, discount long-distance service, electronic mail and computer processing.

headline: BENN, LABOR LEFTIST, IS VICTOR IN ELECTION FOR PARLIAMENT SEAT
abstract: Tony Benn, leader of the opposition Labor Party's left wing, easily won a special parliamentary election Thursday in this central England mining town.   Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's ruling Conservative Party finished third, behind the centrist alliance of the Liberal and Social Democratic Parties.

headline: Mauritius Expels Libyan Diplomats
abstract: Prime Minister Aneerood Jugnauth of Mauritius said today that his country expelled Libyan diplomats Friday, adding that the action was taken because the Libyans were interfering in the island's affairs.   Mr. Jugnauth said at a news conference, ''The situation had become so intolerable and our decision was taken so as to safeguard the dignity and sovereignty of our country.''

headline: Suriname's Army Fails To End Bauxite Strike
abstract: Suriname's Army today failed to end a strike in the country's vital bauxite industry apparently aimed at toppling the military ruler, Desi Bouterse, the Dutch news agency A.N.P. reported.   Soldiers occupied the Suralco bauxite plant near Suriname's capital, Paramaribo, but withdrew after several thousand workers made clear they were determined to continue their three-week-old strike, the agency reported.

headline: LEBANESE AND SYRIAN PRESIDENTS CONFER
abstract: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon arrived here today and conferred with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria over the fate of Lebanon.    The visit took place amid extraordinary security precautions and heightened political tension in the Syrian capital.   Syrians disclosed no details of the meetings between Mr. Gemayel and Mr. Assad, but they said the discussions had gone ''very, very well.''   President Gemayel's visit, his first to Damascus since coming to power in September 1982, reflects his decision to acquiesce to Syrian demands that he scrap the May 17, 1983, Israeli-Lebanese agreement on the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon.

headline: Chicago Utility
abstract: The Commonwealth Edison Company said in its annual repport that its five- year construction budget through 1988 is $5.25 billion, a decrease of $200 million from the amount budgeted for the five years through 1987.

headline: AROUND THE WORLDPeruvian Legislator Injured in Protest
abstract: The 81-year-old legislator who heads the Peruvian Communist Party was said to be in a coma tonight after he was hit by a tear-gas grenade in disturbances marking a 24-hour strike.   Senator Jorge del Prado was in critical condition after being hit in the chest by the grenade fired by security forces, Senator Enrique Bernales said.

headline: Polish Bishops Cite Continued Social Tension
abstract: Poland's 27 Roman Catholic bishops pledged today to continue their struggle against domestic oppression but combined the statement with an appeal to Poles to cooperate with the Communist authorities.   The bishops' statement was made after a two-day conference presided over by Jozef Cardinal Glemp.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: A System To Help Robots See     WASHINGTON  A NEW vision system for robots enables the machines to grasp objects that may be in unexpected positions. Joseph A. LaRussa obtained patent 4,437,114 this week for the visual aid, assigning it to the Farrand Optical Company, Valhalla, N.Y.   Robots are widely used to perform repetitious tasks, such as on an assembly line.

headline: CASTRO DENOUNCES REAGAN IN SPEECH
abstract: Fidel Castro, marking the 25th anniversary of the Cuban revolution, used unusually strong terms to denounce the Reagan Administration in a speech here Sunday night.      The 57-year-old Cuban leader said the United States was under the leadership of ''Nazi-fascist barbarians'' who have been ''blinded by their own stupidity.''   He called the United States-led invasion of Grenada a ''monstrous crime'' and charged that President Reagan was leading the world toward nuclear holocaust.   He singled out the installation of new medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe as an example of President Reagan's ''warlike hysteria'' and said their deployment would produce ''a necessary and just response'' from the Soviet Union, Cuba's main ally.

headline: Kidnappers in Italy Free Girl
abstract: The 8-year-old daughter of an Italian tour company operator, kidnapped from her private school two months ago, has been freed after payment of a reported $2.1 million ransom. The police said the ransom was paid Sunday. The gang released Federica Isoardi late Monday in front of a parish church outside Savona, a Ligurian coastal city near France and about 60 miles from her hometown of Cuneo.

headline: MCGRATH SPEAKS KINDLY OF MERGERS
abstract: J. Paul McGrath, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, today described as exaggerated the fears of people who assert that large corporate mergers consume capital and who therefore want to restrict them by law.    ''Mergers do not appreciably lessen aggregate savings,'' Mr. McGrath said in a speech before the National Association of Manufacturers.   It was his first speech on merger policy since his rejection last month of a proposed combination of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation. He is negotiating with the companies to see if their merger plan can be amended to meet the Government's objections.

headline: KOHL SEEKING U.S.-SOVIET SUMMIT TALKS
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has decided to press President Reagan and the new Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, to hold a summit meeting that he hopes would lead to a resumption of talks on limiting nuclear arms, a high aide to the West German leader says.   According to one of the Chancellor's closest advisers, who accompanied him to Moscow for the funeral of Yuri V. Andropov, Mr. Kohl urged the new Soviet party chief to meet soon with the American President but received no response. On a visit to Washington early next month, Mr. Kohl will make a similar appeal to Mr. Reagan, the aide said.   The adviser reported that the Russian leader, in his meeting with Mr. Kohl, said ''all Soviet offers are still on the table'' regarding nuclear arms reduction but did not indicate whether Moscow expected the Geneva negotiations on medium-range and strategic arms to resume soon.

headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Fall in Waste Concern Stock
abstract: I N the first week of January, shares of Waste   Management Inc. plummeted 7 3/4 points, to 38 5/8,   after company executives forecast flat earnings for the fourth quarter of 1983, thereby surprising analysts who had expected higher profits. Then, last week, the stock of the nation's largest waste disposal concern remained under pressure, touching a 52-week low at 37 1/8 before staging a slight recovery.   Yesterday, Waste Management fell 1/4, to 39 1/8, on the New York Stock Exchange. Its record price of 61 7/8 was established last February. In 1975, the stock sold as low as 1 3/8.

headline: DRUGS AT U.S. BASES AN ISSUE IN BRITAIN
abstract: The use of drugs by American servicemen stationed in Britain has been thrust into the continuing debate over United States nuclear weapons based in this country.    Two articles this week in The Times of London, Britain's most prestigious newspaper, have called attention to drug abuse at United States Air Force bases including Greenham Common, where the first cruise missiles were installed late last year, and the nuclear submarine base at Holy Loch in Scotland.   One article, spread across four columns on page 1, was headlined ''Quarter of Europe's U.S. Troops on Drugs.'' It was based on a 1982 Pentagon study and on more recent developments at the 11 major American bases here.

headline: IMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VATICAN IS REPORTED TO HAVE FURNISHED AID TO FLEEING NAZIS
abstract: Allegations of Vatican involvement in the escape of Nazi war criminals after World War II have emerged in statements by a French Nazi-hunter and a declassified State Department report.    According to Serge Klarsfeld, a Paris lawyer who has specialized in tracking down fugitive Nazis, Walter Rauff, a former SS colonel wanted for the mass gassing of Jews in mobile death vans, told in 1962 of having been given refuge in Vatican City convents for 18 months after the war.   Chile, which has harbored the 77- year-old Mr. Rauff for more than 25 years, is now facing growing demands for his expulsion. Yesterday Israel made a formal request to Chile for Mr. Rauff's extradition. And Simon Wiesenthal, the Vienna-based Nazi-hunter, and a Los Angeles institute affiliated with him said the State Department had recently taken an interest in the case.   Historian Obtains Report    The formerly top secret State Department report, dated 1947 and never officially made public, called the Vatican ''the largest single organization involved in the illegal movement of emigrants,'' including Nazis. The report was obtained by a historian of the Holocaust, Charles R. Allen Jr. of Manhattan, who made it available to The New York Times.

headline: Electronic Data
abstract: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said it had received a contract valued at more than $350 million over eight years to undertake a computer systems integration project for the Navy. Electronic Data said its primary subcontractors are the International Business Machines Corporation and Cullinet Software Inc.

headline: ADVERTISING ; Name Changes Grew For Companies in 1983
abstract: More corporations changed their names last year than in any of the 14 years that Anspach Grossman Portugal has been tracking such things.

headline: GENIAL ENVOY FROM VATICAN: PIO LAGHI
abstract: Archbishop Pio Laghi was named yesterday by Pope John Paul II to be the Vatican's Ambassador to the United States. He has become known as an artful church diplomat in the 32 years he has served as a papal representative abroad.  Formal diplomatic ties between the United States and the Vatican were restored on Jan. 10 after more than a century of unofficial relations. President Reagan's appointment of William A. Wilson as the United States Ambassador to the Holy See was confirmed and Mr. Wilson was sworn in on March 9.   Archbishop Laghi, a genial man, is known within the church as an exceptionally intelligent prelate with an informal demeanor and a polished approach to diplomacy. One Roman Catholic official said the Archbishop's urbanity ''represents what is best about the Vatican diplomatic service.''

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: The Big Push to Save    While it may be wishful thinking to ask consumers to save more, what with all the Christmas bills they face, that's just what all kinds of financial institutions are doing. But if the buoyant retail season just ended showed anything, it is this: Americans will probably save less of their disposable income in 1984 than they did in the past two years.   The reason? ''Americans traditionally save less when they sense good economic times ahead, and more when they worry about their jobs and the economy generally,'' says Philip Braverman, chief economist at Briggs, Schaedle & Company, Government securities dealers.  In 1981, when the latest recession took hold, the annual rate of savings jumped to 6.6 percent of disposable income from 6 percent the year before. It then declined to a cyclical low of 4 percent in the second quarter of last year, Mr. Braverman says, and rose to 5 percent in the last quarter of 1983.

headline: ROLE IN BEIRUT IS CALLED UNLIKELY FOR U.N. FORCE IN SOUTH LEBANON
abstract: The possibility that United Nations troops stationed in southern Lebanon will be sent to Beirut seems unlikely at this time, according to United Nations officials here.    France has taken the lead in pressing for establishment of a United Nations force to take over from the dwindling number of Western soldiers in the Lebanese capital, where units from the United States, France, Britain and Italy were initially deployed.   The small British contingent in Beirut pulled out almost two weeks ago and the evacuation of the Italian force was completed today. The United States Marines are moving to vessels of the United States Sixth Fleet offshore. The French contingent will remain, for the time being, according to President Francois Mitterrand.

headline: Threat of Rate Rise Depressing Prices;  U.S. Deficits Cause Worry
abstract: Sentiment that 1984 will bring higher interest rates seems to have gained ground recently, as seen in the steady decline of note and bond prices over the last six trading sessions.     Statements and testimony last week by Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, contained no surprises for the credit markets. But interest rates rose anyway, as many market participants agreed with Mr. Volcker's assessment that Federal deficits cast a shadow over hopes for a sustained, non-inflationary economic expansion.    ''Once again, concern is mounting that the fundamental incompatibility of huge budget deficits and an inflation-fighting monetary policy will soon be sending interest rates higher,'' Irwin Kellner, chief economist of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, notes in the latest issue of Financial Digests.

headline: United Satellite Expands Service WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) - United Satellite Communications Inc. announced it was expanding its satellite-to-home TV service to five new markets: Washington, D.C.; Baltimore; Richmond; Cincinnati, and Harrisonburg, Va..
abstract: United Satellite inaugurated the nation's first satellite-to-home TV service last November in Indianapolis and has since extended service to Terre Haute, Ind.; South Bend, Ind.; Fort Wayne, Ind., and Chicago. Using relatively small satellite antennas, subscribers are able to receive TV programming directly from an orbiting satellite.   United Satellite is a joint venture whose major investors include the General Instrument Corporation and the Prudential Insurance Company.

headline: BUILDING OUTLAYS ARE STEADY
abstract: Spending for new construction held steady in November after declining the previous month, the Commerce Department reported today.   The value of new construction put in place last month was $271.9 billion at an annual rate, the same as October, which had been 4.7 percent below September.

headline: Market PlaceSteve Lohr More Gains Seen in Japan TOKYO
abstract: B Y tradition, stock trading begins here each year only after a hand-clapping ceremony on the floor of the exchange. Thousands of people take part, from scruffy floor traders to kimono-clad women, all trying to invite prosperity. This year, they must have done something right.   On Monday, the widely followed Nikkei-Dow Jones average broke above 10,000 yen for the first time in history. Despite fluctuations, further gains are expected. Fueling the optimism are recent upward revisions of forecasts for Japan's economic growth this year and surveys concluding that corporate earnings will rise sharply in 1984.

headline: FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Federated Fills Post
abstract: Norman S. Matthews, 51 years old, executive vice president of Federated Department Stores, was elected yesterday as a vice chairman and a director. The company has two other vice chairmen, Donald J. Stone and Will M. Storey.

headline: Technology; Audiotex: Data By Telephone
abstract: MOVE over videotex. Here comes audiotex.  Videotex, in which people retrieve information using computers or specially equipped television sets, has not really caught on, partly because most people do not have computers. But virtually everyone has a telephone. So now many companies are trying to offer information services using electronic voices.    Such an idea is not entirely new. Dial-it services have long provided callers with time, weather and other information. But those systems usually use tape recorders and give everyone the same message. The new electronic systems allow the computer to respond to requests made by punching buttons on a tone telephone keypad.

headline: Work and Family
abstract: To the Editor:    ''Dealing With Dismissal'' (Feb. 26) drew attention to counseling spouses of dismissed executives. Unfortunately, it deals with only half the problem.

headline: Ralston Sets Rules To Bar Takeovers
abstract: The Ralston Purina Company, the St. Louis-based maker of foods for people and pets, obtained stockholder approval at the annual meeting for two rule changes to help ward off any unfriendly takeover attempts.

headline: U.N. Says 5 Million Children Die of Hunger in Africa Yearly
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that nearly five million African children die each year and another five million are crippled for life because of malnutrition and hunger.   Mr. Perez de Cuellar cited the figures at two separate meetings - one with delegates of African countries and another with representatives of potential donor nations - aimed at increasing awareness of the economic and social problems of African nations.   The Secretary General, who will visit West Africa soon, said the conditions there involved acute deprivation.

headline: ADVERTISING B. & B. Elects a New President
abstract: Roy J. Bostock, who has been with Benton & Bowles since he started in business in 1964, has been elected president.

headline: U.S. DOCTORS BELIEVE ANDROPOV HAD FAILING KIDNEY WHEN HE TOOK OFFICE
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov probably had a failing kidney when he took office 15 months ago, and his health was apparently also harmed by long-term complications of diabetes, American physicians said yesterday.   The physicians offered their assessment on the basis of an official Soviet medical report issued by Tass, the Soviet press agency.   Diabetes often destroys the kidneys over a period of years, and Mr. Andropov's death was attributed by Moscow to kidney failure.   In revealing that Mr. Andropov had been receiving kidney dialysis therapy since February 1983, when his kidneys stopped working, Tass offered the first glimpse of some of the details of the Soviet leader's ordeal that incapacitated him for much of his term in office.

headline: INDIA FARMERS SEEK TO SHARE IN THE PEANUTS
abstract: A movement to give Indian farmers greater control over the marketing of their products and a bigger share of the profits is gaining ground in the western state of Gujarat, and the region's wealthy middlemen and retailers are beginning to feel the pinch.    Under the leadership of Verghese Kurien, a champion of India's producer cooperatives, peanut farmers in Bhaunagar and four other districts of Gujarat began banding together in 1979 in an effort to break the hold of the area's powerful oil millers and traders on the peanut industry.   Their cooperative is part of a growing network of village units that are seeking to restructure the region's economy, which revolves around peanut production.   In Bombay, 200 miles south of the village of Rajpara, a wealthy oil miller told a visitor recently that he was pulling out of the peanut processing business because he thinks the cooperatives will eventually control the trade. The oil miller, Tulsidas Tanna, predicted this would happen because of the support the cooperatives receive from the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

headline: U.S. SETS TRADE CURB FOR DIGITAL
abstract: The Commerce Department has quietly imposed major restrictions on the Digital Equipment Corporation to control the export of its computers, several months after one of the company's most sophisticated machines was seized en route to the Soviet Union.   The move requires Digital to go through the time-consuming task of obtaining individual export licenses from the Commerce Department before it can ship any of its computers to West Germany, Norway or Austria. All three countries are considered prime ''diversion points,'' where a major computer system can change hands quickly and be smuggled into Eastern bloc nations.    Digital, the world's second-largest computer maker after the International Business Machines Corporation, is also being required to furnish the Government with detailed information about all of its overseas customers for its sophisticated line of VAX computers, and how those customers intend to use the equipment. The VAX is suitable for numerous military applications.

headline: Sale by Arco Set
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company said it plans to sell certain aluminum facilities and as a result will report a one-time net book loss of $200 million to $300 million.

headline: A.&S. to Drop Budget Outlets
abstract: Abraham & Straus, one of the New York area's largest department store chains, has decided to close its five budget, or basement, operations during the next year.

headline: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; Market Slide: Impact Spreads
abstract: Election years are supposed to be good for the securities markets, but 1984 is proving to be an exception. At the start of the year, there was a brief run-up in the stock market, with the Dow Jones Industrials almost reaching 1,300 on Jan. 9. But that was the top. Since then, there has been a steady grinding down of values, with the Dow at ¸,134.63 yesterday.   The new in the credit market has been just as dour, as interest rates and bond yields have pushed upward. This week the rate of three-month Treasury bills got up to 9.15 percent compared with 7.93 percent a year ago, and the rate on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 12.06 percent companred with 10.62 percent a year ago.

headline: Florida Offering
abstract: A $125 million issue of the Florida Power and Light Company's 12 7/8 percent bonds, rated A-1 and due in 2014, is being offered at a price of 99 1/4, to yield 12.97 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. At the time of pricing, the bonds yielded 114 basis points (hundredths of a percentage point) more than 30- year Treasury bonds.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: YOUNG PEOPLE IN EAST EUROPE TURN INCREASINGLY TO CHURCH
abstract: Across Eastern Europe, there are signs of a religious renewal.     The pattern is as uneven as the patchwork of Roman Catholic, Protestant and Orthodox faiths that crisscrosses the six junior partners of the Warsaw Pact, and it is colored by the struggles between the countries and various churches that occurred both before and after the imposition of Communism in the late 1940's.   Particularly in Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland, clergymen and scholars say growing numbers of people are turning to - or turning back to - churches that, under Marxist theory, should be on the road to extinction. In cities in Bulgaria and Rumania, there are reports of increased churchgoing, but few signs of a major revival.   Not a Mass Movement    With the exception of Poland, where the Roman Catholic Church is the guardian of national aspirations, the movement of renewal is not a mass phenomenon. Rather, active Christians are normally a minority in societies that have become secularized through industrialization, Communist propaganda and persecution.

headline: BUILDING SPENDING RISES 1.4%
abstract: Spending for new construction rose 1.4 percent in January from December, with advances in the housing industry and revived industrial development offsetting a small decline in Government building projects, the Commerce Department said today.    This put spending in January at an annual rate of $281.8 billion, compared with $277.8 billion in December.

headline: LEBANESE AT CONFERENCE DISCUSS POLITICAL SHIFTS
abstract: Delegates to the Lebanese reconciliation conference began detailed talks today on a program of national political changes.    Participants at the Lausanne talks, which began Monday, said that now that everyone had had two days to express strong feelings and strike uncompromising poses for their constituencies back home, Syrian ''horse trading'' had got under way. The Syrian Vice President, Abdel Halim Khaddam, is the ultimate arbiter of how much each side will give and receive, they said.   After a brief morning session attended by President Amin Gemayel, the eight Lebanese factional leaders and the Syrian and Saudi observers, the conference broke up for private consultations that were expected to continue into Thursday.

headline: BANKS RESIGNED TO CUTBACKS
abstract: The nation's major banks have become resigned to the likelihood that some of them will have to report sharp earnings declines in the first quarter as the result of their loans to Argentina.     And most believe that even if the Federal Government finds a way to bend the accounting rules, as hinted yesterday by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, it would make little difference because bank-stock analysts and the investing public have accepted the earnings cutbacks as fact.   ''A rose is a rose is a rose,'' a New York banker said. ''Any change in the accounting rules won't change the reality.''

headline: Japan Jobless Rate Hits 2.6%
abstract: Unemployed workers in Japan increased by 200,000 in 1983, to 1.56 million, the Prime Minister's office said today.

headline: ;  Harris Offering
abstract: The Harris Graphics Corporation said it had filed for an initial public offering of three million common shares.

headline: Shoe-Import Quotas Asked
abstract: Management and labor in the shoe industry joined forces today to ask the Government for protection against imports, which accounted for a record two- thirds of the domestic market in 1983.    A petition seeking import quotas was filed by the Footwear Industries of America and by two unions, the United Food and Commercial Workers and the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers, representing the bulk of the 133,000 domestic workers in direct manufacturing.

headline: WEINBERGER FAULTS MARINE MISSION
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger visited the marines aboard ship today and told them that they had been given ''one of the most miserable jobs ever assigned.''   Speaking to 700 troops on the deck of the helicopter carrier Guam in the calm Mediterranean off Lebanon, he said there was no way they could have fulfilled the mission, given the constraints under which they operated.   ''There might be some people who would overlook the kind of job that you did,'' said Mr. Weinberger, who flew to the Guam by helicopter from Larnaca, Cyprus.   ''The President does not want that to happen because he and I and all of us feel a very deep respect for people who have to do a very dirty, very dirty, disagreeable and miserable job, and frankly a job that simply cannot be done unless people working on the political and diplomatic and all the other sides are able to work out those agreements.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Accounts     * Palm Bay Importers to Kornhauser & Calene for its line of Cavit wines.     * Youthwear division of Cluett Peabody & Company to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.

headline: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (S. C.) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Israelis Worry About an Iran Victory
abstract: Both Israeli military intelligence specialists and civilian analysts expressed concern today over Iran's current offensive into Iraq and the apparent intensity of the fighting.   A civilian specialist at the Center for Strategic Studies at Tel Aviv University said he thought that if Iran should win the war, "the fire will spread and there will be Iranian troops with the Syrians" in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley.   An intelligence officer at Israeli Defense Force headquarters said Israel had monitored the Iranian-Iraqi war since it started in September 1980 because "a victory by either side increases our military problems."   On the whole, professional military men here appeared inclined to accept the Iraqi statement that Iraq had stemmed the Iranian offensive and won a major victory in the southern sector near the Iraqi oil port of Basra. But these sources conceded that the Iraqi statements, like those by Iran, could not be verified because neither side has allowed foreign military attaches or independent reporters to visit the battlefields.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: GENEVA PARLEY AGREES ON A RADIO PLAN
abstract: Representatives of 120 nations meeting here agreed today to set up a new system for allocating the world's overcrowded high-frequency radio waves among broadcasting stations.    The move was portrayed partly as an effort to help developing countries communicate more effectively with the rest of the world.   The 120 countries, at the end of a monthlong meeting organized by the International Telecommunications Union, the United Nations body that regulates broadcasting, also set a 20- year timetable for the introduction of a new high-frequency broadcasting technique, known as single sidebar broadcasting, which is designed to relieve airwave congestion.

headline: NAVAL AIDE QUESTIONS PRESS
abstract: A senior Navy officer said today that the customary rules under which the press has covered combat failed to recognize change in the technologies of communication and in the attitudes of the war correspondents themselves.   The officer, Capt. Brent Baker, a member of a Pentagon panel that is studying changes in the rules, said the possibility of broadcasting directly from battlefields without a military censor could jeopardize national security and the lives of soldiers. He said the correspondents now assigned to cover wars were not as experienced as their predecessors in recognizing when their reports might endanger a military mission.

headline: WITH CELEBRITIES' HELP, FUGAZY FINDING A NICHE
abstract: A golf bet with the entertainer Bob Hope and some advice from Terence Cardinal Cooke helped transform the Fugazy International Corporation from a simple but successful travel agency into a complex and still successful transportation company.    At least that is the way the company's 59-year-old chairman, William Denis Fugazy, tells it. In the past six years, Fugazy International has expanded its international travel business to include a large fleet of limousines, vans, cars, buses and helicopters.   And now he is moving into the car service business with Fugazy Express. Set up two years ago, it is designed, he said, ''to put 6,000 private cars on the streets of New York City within five years in competition with medallion taxis.'' Mr. Fugazy describes it as both a business venture and a minority aid program.

headline: Alfonsin Links Debt, Inflation
abstract: Argentina wants to pay off its $45 billion foreign debt but needs time to get inflation, now at a level of 450 percent, under control, President Raul Alfonsin said in an interview published in Newsweek magazine.  Separately, Venezuelan officials negotiating the country's $35 billion foreign debt will meet with creditors this week in New York, Finance Ministry sources said. The issue of another 90-day moratorium on debt payments, after the current grace period expires April 30, is likely to be addressed.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: REAGAN CALLED FIRM ON TROOP TALKS
abstract: President Reagan has decided not to change the Western negotiating position on reducing troops in Central Europe, according to Administration officials.    The Western position has been that agreement on data about troop levels on both sides must precede any troop withdrawals, and the officials said President Reagan had decided to keep to this position despite recent Soviet concessions on the issue of on-site inspection and despite pressure from West European allies.   Since last summer, the officials said, Moscow has been developing a proposal for small Soviet and American troop withdrawals from Central Europe, to be verified by ''permanent'' stationing of inspectors on either side and by other on-site means.   West Germany, in particular, has been urging a test of Moscow's offer. Britain has opposed this despite Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's recent calls for intensifying East-West contacts.

headline: MITTERRAND LEAVING PROBLEMS BEHIND ON VISIT TO U.S. TODAY
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand, pressing a policy of economic austerity,  has become the least popular French President since the Fifth Republic was established in 1958.   Opinion polls showing that a majority disapprove of his handling of affairs reflect almost no personal animosity, but a sense that life has become harder and its future uncertain.   After the publication last week of more negative economic statistics, Mr. Mitterrand's visit to the United States, starting Wednesday, seems almost a respite from his domestic problems.   The latest statistics illustrate the difficulties the Government has in creating jobs and maintaining buying power. Unemployment accelerated in February, rising faster than the 9.8 percent rate of last year; inflation, running at 9.2 percent in 1983, remains at the same level, or more than twice as high as for France's main trade competitors; disposable income declined last year, and the national debt grew.

headline: Bell Atlantic's New Markets
abstract: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said it had acquired an interest in a Denver-based mobile telephone and paging company that would allow it to enter those markets outside its own Middle Atlantic region. Bell Atlantic is one of the seven regional companies created by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

headline: GTE Will Invest $1 Billion in Sprint
abstract: The GTE Corporation said it planned to invest $1 billion in its Sprint long-distance phone and satellite operations this year.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Jan. 24, 1984   GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Council for Namibia - 3 P.M.   Commission on Trade Law - Working Group on New International Economic Order - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: MOSCOW IS SAID TO TIGHTEN CURBS ON RELIGION
abstract: The Rev. Michael Bourdeaux, a specialist on religion in Communist countries, said Wednesday in New York that there had been ''an absolute decline in degree to which religious liberty is permitted'' in the Soviet Union.   Father Bourdeaux made the comment in accepting the 1984 Templeton Prize for progress in religion.

headline: Professor From M.I.T. Moving to Wall Street One of the financial world's best- known academics is leaving the ivory tower for the dollars-and-cents world of Wall Street. On Feb. 6, Fischer Black, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will become a vice president-trading and arbitrage at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
abstract: Mr. Black, in a telephone interview yesterday from Cambridge, Mass., said some of his colleagues were surprised by his decision. ''But the better they know me, I think the less surprised they are,'' he said.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS
abstract: Yen's Strength Sends Dollar Broadly Lower       By The Associated Press    The Japanese yen continued to climb against the dollar in hectic trading yesterday, reaching its highest level in more than two years. It helped push the dollar lower against most other leading currencies.   Gold continued to benefit from the dollar's decline, rising to a five- month high. The late quote at the Republic National Bank in New York was $404.50 a troy ounce, up $3.50 from Friday.

headline: FABERGE ACCEPTS MCGREGOR'S OFFER
abstract: Faberge Inc., which had previously announced acceptance of a $30- a-share leveraged buyout arrangement with the New York investment bankers Gibbons Green Van Amerongen Ltd., announced yesterday that it would accept a $32-a-share offer made last Friday by the McGregor Corporation, the marketer of Botany 500 clothing.     The earlier deal had a value of $169 million, while the McGregor transaction is valued at $180 million.

headline: ON THE MANAGEMENT FRONTIER AT YALE
abstract: NEW HAVEN WHEN Yale's School of Organization and Management opened its doors in September 1976, Kingman Brewster Jr., then the university's president, presented it with its own coat of arms.    The shield's abstract design depicted two conference tables - one gold, one silver - surrounded by dots of gold and silver. At the bottom was the motto ''Novus Ordo Seclorum'' - ''A New Order for the Ages.''   Yale's was not to be just another business school. This was to be a place where leaders would be trained for both the public and the private sectors - the gold and the silver - a place where the interaction of government and business would be stressed.

headline: THE UNFRIENDLY SKIES OF DEREGULATION
abstract: WITH deregulation on its side, the fledgling airline Pacific Express seemed to have everything going for it when it took to the air two years ago. Such upstart airlines would proliferate and flourish, the thinking went, even taking on large carriers in major markets.    But for Pacific Express and about a dozen other carriers started since decontrol in 1978, the vision of the major airlines as cumbersome dinosaurs, unable to respond effectively to competition from feisty young fare cutters, has proved myopic.   Indeed, six years after deregulation, a new pattern is finally emerging in the airline industry. The pattern is that of a three-tiered industry with the major airlines - the strongest are United, American, Delta and Northeast - on top, dominating many of the most lucrative routes. They are co-existing more or less peacefully with a cadre of older, well- established regional airlines, among them Piedmont, Ozark, USAir and PSA. Most of the upstarts begun since 1978 are on the third tier, scrambling now for the leftovers.

headline: Naugles Cutback
abstract: Naugles Inc.'s chairman, Harold Bulter, said the company planned to announce ''moves the company is making relative to slowing its growth, eliminating the sale of franchises and closing down and subletting about 35 restaurants.'' In over-the-counter trading today, Naugles was the biggest percentage loser, dropping $2.50, to $10.75 bid.

headline: U.S. AND BRITAIN BAR CONCESSIONS TO MOSCOW ON ARMS
abstract: The United States and Britain agreed today not to offer any concessions to persuade the Russians to resume negotiations on arms control, American and British officials said.    They said that arms control would be discussed with the Soviet Union in Stockholm in coming days, but that they did not feel that the way to begin negotiations was to offer concessions in advance.   Secretary of State George P. Shultz conferred at length with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Foreign Secretary, during a one-day stopover here on his way to the East-West conference to be held in the Swedish capital.   Mr. Shultz gave the British leaders advance copies of the speech President Reagan is to deliver in Washington on Monday in which he will call for more constructive relations with Moscow. But American officials traveling with Mr. Shultz stressed that Mr. Reagan's speech should not be interpreted as meaning there would be a dramatic shift in Administration policy on specific issues separating the two countries.

headline: New President At Pizza Time Financially troubled Pizza
abstract: Time Theater Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., this week replaced its president of less than two months with Henry C. Montgomery, 48 years old, who joined the company as executive vice president and chief financial officer at the end of January.  Before joining Pizza Time Mr. Montgomery served as executive vice president of the Micropro International Corporation, a software company in San Rafael, Calif.

headline: Warsaw Pact Maneuvers
abstract: Warsaw Pact troops began winter maneuvers today in western Czechoslovakia along the border of West and East Germany, diplomatic sources said. Czechoslovak, Soviet and Hungarian troops were taking part in the maneuvers.

headline: TechnologyAndrew Pollack ; A Document That Can Talk
abstract: like films. Whenever someone started reading a    document, a voice would speak up, adding further explanation. In addition, instead of scribbling comments in the margins, the reader could touch a spot on the paper and speak his comments, which would then ''stick'' to the paper and be heard by anyone who touched that spot in the future.    This new concept in communications is known as a multimedia document or compound document. Of course, it cannot be done with paper documents, but it can be done with computerized documents. Sophisticated new communications systems are being developed that allow voice and text, as well as images, computer data and graphs, to be combined into the same electronic message.

headline: 2 Charged in Hamburg In 'Hitler Diary' Fraud
abstract: The Hamburg prosecutor has filed fraud charges against two West Germans accused of peddling the bogus Hitler diaries to Stern magazine, a spokesman said today.   Konrad Kujau, a dealer in Nazi artifacts, and Gerd Heidemann, a former Stern reporter, were formally charged with carrying out the hoax to defraud $3.6 million from the magazine's owner, Gruner-Jahr publishers.

headline: Italian Police Arrest 5 In Bulgari Kidnapping
abstract: The police arrested four Sardinian shepherds and a man from the southern region of Puglia today and charged them with the kidnapping of two recently freed members of the Bulgari jewelry family, the authorities said.   A police spokesman said that investigations were continuing and that two more people could be involved in the kidnapping gang.

headline: Egypt and Morocco Reported Ready to Restore Relations
abstract: King Hassan II of Morocco and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt have agreed to restore diplomatic relations that were severed when Egypt signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979, authoritative sources said today.   The sources said that the agreement was ''in principle'' and that no date had been fixed for the resumption of relations.   They said it was not certain the agreement would be made public in a joint communique to be published Friday at the end of Mr. Mubarak's four- day official visit to Morocco.

headline: The U.N. Today March 22, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Working Group on International Standards of Accounting and Reporting - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Storage Technology Ends Mainframe Plan
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation said yesterday that it had abandoned a two-and-a-half year effort to build an innovative, mainframe computer and would take a substantial write-off for the fourth quarter of 1983.    The computer, the first for the manufacturer of disk and tape drives compatible with large International Business Machines computers, was being developed under a partnership between Storage Technology and some 300 to 400 investors. A company spokesman said that ''significant program delays'' and the ''need for substantial sums'' to complete the project led to the decision.

headline: BUSINESS AND THE FAMILY; 'FLEX-TIME' WEAVES JOB AND FAMILYY
abstract: NO one thinks it unusual when Sarah Shipley, a senior applications analyst at the Control Data Corporation, takes a work break to change her 9-month-old daughter, or when she fixes lunch for her 3-year- old daughter and reads her a story. That's because Mrs. Shipley works at her home in Dallas on what is known as a flex-time schedule. Back in April 1981, Control Data's Dallas office installed a computer terminal in Mrs. Shipley's home so she could continue her work as a programmer while she raised her family.    This isn't a common occurrence at Control Data, but it does indicate the company's willingness to be flexible to accommodate a valued employee. Other companies also allow employees leeway in arranging their work schedules to accommodate family needs - so they can be at home when children leave for school, for example, or home when the youngsters return.

headline: Continental In Sydney
abstract: The Transport Workers Union has defied a court injunction and banned the servicing of Continental Air Lines planes at Sydney Airport. A union spokesman said the action, which took effect Sunday, would stop Continental's Sydney flights.

headline: TOP CHITTENDEN OFFICER TO RUN FOR GOVERNOR
abstract: Hilton A. Wick, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chittenden Corporation, a bank holding company in Burlington, Vt., announced yesterday that he would resign April 1 to seek the Republican nomination for Governor of Vermont.    Mr. Wick, 64, said: ''I've been on the periphery of politics since the early 1950's and worked for a number of candidates from time to time. In recent years people have urged me to run for Governor, and I decided if I was ever going to do it, now was the time.''

headline: Grey Adds Chef Saluto; Ogilvy Ends Miller Bid
abstract: Grey Advertising, the Jeno's agency since 1983, when it picked up the frozen food line, has been assigned yet another product from the client.

headline: British Petroleum
abstract: The British Petroleum Company said that it had completed the sale of 9.75 percent of its interest in the Forties oilfield in the North Sea.

headline: Chevron in Sudan
abstract: Chevron, a unit of the Standard Oil Company of California, is to resume oil exploration in southern Sudan after more than a month's suspension because of rebel attacks, the official Sudan news agency said.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 2, 1984:

headline: Money Fund Assets Climb
abstract: Assets of the nation's money funds climbed in the week ended Wednesday to their highest level since June 1983, but short- and long-term yields declined, the Investment Company Institute and Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.   Total assets rose $1.9 billion, to $168.02 billion, the institute said, the largest weekly increase in 15 months.

headline: Afghan Army Reported To Recapture District
abstract: Afghan Government officials say their army killed more than 100 anti-Marxist guerrillas over the weekend and recaptured a strategic eastern district bordering Pakistan.

headline: Market Place; Fund Tactics That Did Well
abstract: T HE president of the T. Rowe Price Growth    and Income Fund, L. Gordon Croft, has not   lost faith in common stocks, but he likes corporate bonds, too. As portfolio manager for the Baltimore-based mutual fund, he raised its allocation for bonds to 20 percent from 5 percent during the final quarter of last year.    ''We're now up to 23 percent in bonds, typically subordinated debentures, and during the first quarter of 1984 we'll probably increase that to about 25 percent,'' he said this week. ''Bond yields are very competitive with our projected return from the equity market.''

headline: New Mexico Sale
abstract: The Public Service Company of New Mexico said it had sold its 28.8 percent interest in the San Juan IV coal-fired generating unit to the M-S-R Public Power Agency for about $171 million in cash. M-S-R is a California organization composed of the cities of Santa Clara and Redding as well as the Modesto Irrigation District. Public Service said some proceeds from the sale would be used to pay off its short-term debt, which totals about $97 million.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: Merrill Lynch to Offer $250 Million in Notes    Merrill Lynch & Company is offering $250 million of extendable notes due in 1999 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The notes are offered at a price of 99.9, with an initial coupon of 11 1/8 percent to yield 11.21 percent to March 31, 1985.

headline: BULGARIA IS A LAND OF GRATITUDE TOWARD RUSSIANS
abstract: Czar Alexander II sits securely astride his horse in the center of this Balkan capital, a monument to the Russian whose soldiers freed Bulgarians in the 19th century from 500 years of Ottoman rule.    A few blocks away, there is a statue of a lumpy, helmeted figure in a greatcoat carrying a machine gun, a monument to the Soviet soldiers of World War II.   Throughout Eastern Europe, the Russians are known in official pronouncements as the ''liberators.''
