But here, the word ''liberators'' refers to the Czar's soldiers of the Russian- Turkish War of 1877-78.

headline: FEW ISSUES ARE SCHEDULED FOR WEEK
abstract: Few new bond issues are scheduled this week, giving dealers in tax-exempt and Treasury securities a chance to distribute the heavy supply of government issues brought to market during December.    In the Treasury market, the weekly sale of three- and six-month bills will be held today, because of the holiday yesterday. Late Friday, outstanding three- and six-month issues were bid at rates of 8.96 percent and 9.156 percent, respectively.

headline: IRAQI STAND BACKED BY ARAB LEAGUE MEETING
abstract: The foreign ministers of Arab League countries tonight condemned Iran for refusing to enter into negotiations with Iraq and indirectly called on all nations to take no actions that would help the Iranians in the war.     Conference sources said that the cautious language of the resolution was a response to Iraq's request that the Arab nations call on Iran's major suppliers of necessary supplies and services to halt such trade.   Iraq, which called the extraordinary one-day Arab League meeting held here today, was reported to have urged its supporters to promise such suppliers that they would make up to them all losses in Iranian petroleum that a cutoff in their economic relations would entail.

headline: STOCK CHOICES FROM MIDWEST
abstract: O NE increasingly popular approach to investing is to pick companies doing a substantial amount of business abroad. The expectation is that the strong dollar will eventually weaken, and that this, in turn, will increase corporate profits after adjustments for currency translations.     But do not count Elliott L. Schlang, a senior vice president of Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc. in Cleveland, among advocates of this strategy. ''I now avoid companies with significant foreign exposure,'' he said. ''There are enough unpredictable factors in buying any stock so that I want to immunize myself from possible risks overseas.''

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Philippine Utility Gets A Loan of $100 Million       By Reuters    The American Express International Banking Corporation announced a $100 million credit facility for the National Power Corporation of the Philippines to finance a pressurized light water nuclear power plant. The unit of the American Express Company said $80.7 million was drawn yesterday.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Pinning Down the Job Trend    As the economy expands, economists are grappling with how many new jobs are being created. Despite the upswing, Joseph W. Duncan, chief economist at the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, expects the number of new job openings in 1984 to decline to 3 million from last year's 4 million. Kathryn Eickhoff, executive vice president of Townsend-Greenspan & Company, says that 1984 is likely to be just as strong as 1983, perhaps even stronger.   What is significant, by Mr. Duncan's reckoning, is that large companies, which did relatively little hiring in 1983, are now increasing their work forces.

headline: KREMLIN CONCEDES ONE POINT ON A CURB ON CHEMICAL ARMS
abstract: The Soviet Union said today that, if chemical weapons were banned, it would allow continuous verification of the actual destruction of its declared stocks. The Russians had previously offered only spot checks.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1984
abstract: The Budget    President Reagan's 1985 budget includes only small cuts in spending and small increases in taxes, leaving a projected deficit of about the same $180 billion magnitude of last year and this. In his Budget Message to Congress, the President asked for cuts in domestic spending for the rest of the decade, a delay in major tax increases and more money for the military. (Page A1.) The $305.7 billion military budget includes 15 contracts worth more than $1 billion each that have been awarded to 10 companies. (D2.)   Democrats, sharply critical of Mr. Reagan, proposed spending cuts and tax increases that they said would reduce deficits by at least $200 billion over three years. That would be more than double the long-term reductions proposed by the President. (A1.)

headline: PRAVDA PARODIES REAGAN'S 'JIM AND SALLY TALE'
abstract: At the end of his speech on Soviet-American relations on Monday of last week, President Reagan introduced two imaginary Americans, Jim and Sally, who meet two Russians, Ivan and Anya.   After bantering about their ambitions, hobbies, children and problems, the Soviet and American couples find they're really not all that different.   Pravda picked up the story over the weekend, lavishing on Jim and Sally the same sarcasm and scorn with which Mr. Reagan's speech has been treated in the press here.

headline: Brazil Reaches Loan Accord
abstract: Commitments for all four parts of a new financing package for Brazil, including $6.5 billion in fresh loans, have been received from the country's international creditor banks, Affonso Celso Pastore, president of the central bank of Brazil, and William R. Rhodes, a senior vice president at Citibank and chairman of the country's bank advisory group, announced yesterday.   The announcement culminates an effort that began last October, when Brazil and the bank advisory group informed the international financial community of the debt-ridden country's 1984 financing needs.    In a joint statement, Mr. Pastore and Mr. Rhodes said the package would be signed by creditor banks at the Pierre Hotel in New York today.

headline: CREDIT SURCHARGES HELD UNLIKELY BY RETAILERS
abstract: Retailers said yesterday that they would not impose a surcharge on credit sales, in the wake of the lifting of the ban on such charges. To do so, most said, would hurt credit sales, which represent at least 50 percent of their total business - and probably would draw strong, adverse reaction from consumers.     As the law barring merchants from charging extra for credit purchases expired yesterday, a spot-check among both large and small retailers found virtually no positive sentiment for such an action.   ''We are not considering a surcharge,'' a spokesman for Bloomingdale's, New York, said, ''but we don't think that the matter of not charging or charging for a credit sale should have been regulated in the first place. That should be left to the marketplace.''

headline: Sumitomo's Swiss Plan
abstract: Sumitomo Bank Ltd. said today that it was contemplating the purchase of a controlling interest in the Gotthard Bank of Switzerland. Analysts said the acquisition would give Sumitomo access to the Swiss franc bond market.

headline: 4 BASQUE COMMANDOS KILLED IN HARBOR AMBUSH
abstract: Spanish security forces have wiped out what they described as a five-man commando team of Basque terrorists who were trying to slip into Spain from southern France by rubber boat. The action came in a dramatic police ambush Thursday night in the harbor of the northern town of Pasajes San Juan.    Four of the terrorist suspects were shot and killed as they tried to land shortly after 11 P.M. in the small boat with a 60-horsepower outboard motor. A fifth was captured unhurt.

headline: Shell Expected To Reject Bid
abstract: The Shell Oil Company is expected to reject as inadequate a $5.2 billion takeover bid from the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Wall Street analysts said yesterday. They said the rejection was expected soon after a Shell Oil board meeting today.

headline: MOVING INDUSTRY'S REVIVAL
abstract: The country's major moving companies are expected to begin slowly phasing out the price cutting and discounting that kept them rolling through the recession. The economy's improvement has meant that people are now moving nearly as often as they did four or five years ago, before the recession hit.    And in their scramble to compete with one another in this newly healthy business environment, the companies say they are emphasizing customer service as much as pricing. So, for example, the Bekins Van Lines Company says it will pay its customers $100 a day for every day it is late with a shipment. And United Van Lines has what it calls a ''golden umbrella'' program that, for a small premium, replaces damaged goods at full current market value.

headline: SUDDENLY, NEW RESOLVE TO CONFRONT THE DEFICIT
abstract: The Federal Reserve said it would keep doing what it has been doing - keeping a lid on inflation while trying to slow the economy's growth to a speed it might maintain for the balance of the 1980's.  But the Fed chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said he was not going to modify his plans if a force he cannot control - the biggest Government budget deficits in history - set off a paralyzing rise in interest rates or even another recession. With that, hundreds of thousands of investors canceled their bets on a healthy economy and the stock market plunged.    The market heard the Fed, and the Government heard the market. In the span of the week, the Fed and the market awakened Congress and the Administration to the issue in a way that a year of wrangling never did.

headline: IRAQI ASSAILS U.S. ACCUSATION OVER USE OF POISON GAS
abstract: Iraq's Defense Minister denounced the United States today for charging that Iraqi forces had used ''lethal chemical weapons'' against Iranian troops in recent fighting.   Accusing the United States of ''political hyprocrisy'' in making such a charge against Iraq, the official, Gen. Adnan Khairallah, said Iraqi forces had enough conventional war materiel to expel Iranian troops.   General Khairallah announced at a news conference that Iraqi forces had begun a major drive to dislodge Iranian troops occupying Majnoon, an artificial island in the marshes north of the southern Iraqi port of Basra.

headline: EARLY-VOTE PLANS ADOPTED IN ISRAEL
abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Government suffered a major defeat tonight when Parliament gave preliminary approval to three motions scheduling elections in May or June.     The bills now go to committee, where Mr. Shamir's governing coalition is expected to delay action on them to give the Government time to submit its own measure next week setting an election date this fall.   The final date for elections is expected to be determined within a week.   The Government had lobbied desperately for days to hold back the move toward early elections.

headline: Norwest Offering Its First Eurobond LONDON, Jan. 31 (Reuters) - The Norwest Corporation, a bank holding company in Minneapolis, is offering a $50 million seven-year Eurobond, the lead manager, Salomon Brothers International, said. The issue, priced at par, matures on Feb. 15, 1991, and is callable in the fifth year at 101 percent, with the premium falling by five-tenths of 1 percent each year to par. Payment is due Feb. 21.
abstract: This is the first Eurobond for Norwest, which is offering it in the name of a subsidiary, the Norwest Overseas Capital Corporation. Norwest's outstanding debt is rated double-Ax by Standard & Poor's and double-A by Moody's Investors Service. Fees total 1 7/8 percent.

headline: President Resigns Posts at Pittston
abstract: The Pittston Company yesterday announced the resignation of Hendrik J. Hartong Jr. as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Hartong also resigned as a director.   On Jan. 1, Nicholas T. Camicia, who was chairman and chief executive, turned over the company reins to an outsider, Paul W. Douglas. Mr. Douglas, 57 years old, had been president of Freeport-McMoran Inc., a natural resource company based in New York. Mr. Camicia, 67, remains chairman of the board's finance committee.

headline: TURKEY, IN A GESTURE , WILL TRIM ITS CYPRUS FORCES
abstract: The Government announced today that it would withdraw 1,500 of its troops from Cyprus over the next two months as a good-will gesture to open the way for a resumption of peace talks between Turkish and Greek Cypriots. Turkey is estimated to have 25,000 troops on the island, which it invaded in 1974.   The announcement followed a declaration Monday by Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader, who offered to place the Varosha section of Famagusta under United Nations control and reopen Nicosia airport.

headline: SECURITY PACT BEING WORKED OUT BY MOZAMBIQUE AND SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Mozambique and South Africa announced today that they intended to enter into a formal security agreement.   The announcement came at the end of a day of talks here between high- level delegations from the black Marxist-Leninist Government of Mozambique and the rightist white Government of South Africa.   The one-day meeting follows talks between officials of the two countries Jan. 16 on ways to achieve peace and security after years of hostility.

headline: S.E.C. LISTS THAYER SUIT WITNESSES
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday listed several prominent businessmen that it intends to call as witnesses in its case against Paul Thayer, the former Deputy Secretary of Defense. Mr. Thayer has been charged with helping eight individuals make $1.9 million by illegally providing them with insider information.    The S.E.C., in a filing with the Federal District Court in Manhattan, also provided new details involving the commission's case. Included, for example, are names of the members of a backgammon group that the commission maintains traded information among themselves..   Among the 21 individuals the S.E.C. said it intends to call as witnesses are Harry J. Gray, chairman of the United Technologies Corporation; Thomas G. Pownall, chairman of the Martin Marietta Corporation; August Busch 3d, chairman of the Anheuser- Busch Companies; Jake Butcher, whose Tennessee banking empire collapsed last spring; Burt Lance, who was President Jimmy Carter's budget director, and Brynn Thayer, Mr. Thayer's daughter.   None of these individuals has been charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with violating any laws.

headline: MITTERRAND SEEKS THE FUTURE IN SILICON VALLEY
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand began a three-day visit to California today that was expected to focus on enterprises that in the French view have pioneered a revolution in technology.   Mr. Mitterrand, who flew to Davis by helicopter this afternoon to visit an experimental community using solar power, sees California as the center of a technological revolution of crucial importance to France's own economic future, according to his aides.   They said that Mr. Mitterrand, who held two days of official talks in Washington last week, sees his three-day stay here as an opportunity to meet leaders in such fields as computer chips and information systems.

headline: Advertising; Magazine To Levy, Flaxman
abstract: MARLENE JENSEN, the new publisher of CBS Publications' Mechanix Illustrated, has decided to assign the magazine to Levy, Flaxman & Associates, a new member of the downtown creativity league.    While the agency has been getting at least its share of business since Richard Levy founded it back in November 1979, Mechanix Illustrated will be memorable because it is the first piece of new business the agency has got since it showed the gumption a week ago to move out of high-rent, high-image midtown and down to 104 Fifth Avenue, near 16th Street.    Dick Levy, president, and Richard Flaxman, executive vice president, took the occasion of the move to announce a mixed bag of other accounts that have come in since the fall: Integrated Resources, Tokyu Sportswear and the International Salt Company.    And, while Mechanix Illustrated came in partly as a result of a referral by an executive at Playboy Enterprises whose Games magazine is an L.F.& A. client, the Integrated Resources landing had an assist from an admiring public relations man and Tokyu Sportswear arrived largely because of a good word from a headhunter.

headline: TORIES FEAR THEY'VE LOST THEIR ZIP
abstract: Despite the continuing popularity of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, her governing Conservative Party has begun to slip in the opinion polls and a number of party leaders say they are starting to fear that the Government is running out of steam.    In the parliamentary recess that began Dec. 22, when the House held its final session and the Cabinet its final meeting of 1983, the dominant topic for political gossips is likely to be: Have the Tories lost their way and, if so, why?   Only a little more than six months ago Mrs. Thatcher and her party won a sweeping victory in the general election, with a majority more than ample to see her through a second full term. She remains the dominant figure in British if not in Western European politics. And yet the latest public-opinion poll, taken less than two weeks ago by Market and Opinion Research International and published in The Sunday Times of London, shows the Conservatives only one percentage point ahead of Labor, 40.5 to 39.5, with the Liberal- Social Democratic alliance trailing at 18 percent.

headline: ADVERTISING;
abstract: New Zealand Interest Added by Foote, Cone      Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, whose flag already flies over outposts in Melbourne and Sydney, Australia, has now planted its colors in Auckland, New Zealand. It has done it by acquiring ''a substantial minority interest'' in an agency named Mainstream Advertising.    F.C.B. has 61 full-service offices in 31 countries.

headline: MANILA PANEL IS TOLD THE MILITARY BARRED AQUINO BACKERS AT AIRPORT
abstract: Minutes before Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was slain last summer at the airport here, the military barred his relatives and friends from the gate where his plane was about to arrive, a citizen's investigating commission was told today.   This testimony was given by former Senator Salvador Laurel, the head of the United Nationalist Democratic Organization, a coalition of 12 opposition parties. He testified before the commission under protest, saying he seriously doubted the capacity of the panel to arrive at findings contrary to the Government's version of the slaying.

headline: FASTER BRITISH CHECK-CLEARING
abstract: British banks on Thursday will begin using a new computer system billed as the fastest, most secure answer yet to the problem of how to speed the check- clearing process.   The Clearing House Automated Payments System, or Chaps as it is known, is the result of a decade of study and development work that, by some estimates, has cost its participants up to $30 million.   The system is expected to extend same-day clearance of large checks, now available only in London's financial district, to millions of individual and corporate customers thoughout Britain. Eventually, it would permit same-day clearance of checks long after the current 3 P.M. deadline.

headline: Coastal Offer Includes Stock
abstract: The Coastal Corporation, which is offering $68 a share in cash, for 18.75 million shares, or 45 percent, of the Houston   Natural Gas Corporation, said   yesterday that it planned to offer securities valued at ''not   less than'' $60 a share for the   rest, other than the 5 percent it   owns.  Coastal gave no details, but   analysts valued the securities   at closer to $55 a share.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Mortgage-Backed Issue From Prudential Realty    Prudential Realty Securities, a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company, is offering today $272 million of mortgage-backed bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers and Prudential-Bache Securities.    The bonds, which are backed by a pool of mortgages previously owned by the insurance company, are offered in three different maturities, including zero-coupon bonds due in 1996.

headline: PRETORIA DISPLAYS NEW MISSILE CAPTURED IN ANGOLA
abstract: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 28   - The South African Army says that during its latest invasion of Angola it captured a new type of Soviet missile that it asserts has not been seen in the West in its entirety.   The ground-to-air SA-9 system was said to have been seized in a battle that started Jan. 2 in the town of Cuvelai, 125 miles north of the border between South-West Africa and Angola.   ''This is the first complete system that has fallen into the hands of the West,'' Col. Julius Kriel, director of South African Air Force intelligence, said when the missile and its launching system was displayed to reporters here Friday. Colonel Kriel declined to say whether the missile system had also been shown to Western military attaches based in South Africa.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Buffton Corp, an oil and gas company based in Fort Worth, said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire all the operations of Flo Control Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash.     * Damson Oil Corp.  said it had received about 16.9 million shares, or 97 percent, of Dorchester Gas Corp. common stock in response to its $24- a-share tender offer.

headline: Professor Missing in Beirut
abstract: An electrical engineering professor at the American University of Beirut, Frank Regier, disappeared today, and university officials said he may have been kidnapped. ''I believe he has been abducted,'' Samir Thabet, the university's acting president said. The professor, who is 50 years old, is married to a Lebanese, Mary Hananina, a mathematics professor at the university.

headline: Firestone Tire Plans Divestiture
abstract: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said its board had approved a plan to divest the company of its businesses in steel products, phone products and passenger-restraint systems. It said the combined sales of the three businesses are about $450 million a year.

headline: Helms Suing Ex-Partners
abstract: J. Lynn Helms, who resigned as the head of the Federal Aviation Administration in December after questions were raised about some of his prior business activities, has filed a $225 million lawsuit against several former business partners.   The suit, which was filed in Federal District Court in Miami on Monday, contends that Mr. Helms provided more than $1.5 million to the defendants but that they ''fraudulently and corruptly misused the funds'' as well as Mr. Helms's ''good name.''

headline: Patents; Special Camera Filter
abstract: WASHINGTON    JEREMY GERBER, a 17-year-  old high school senior in Chappaqua, N.Y., was granted a patent this week for a camera with a special filter that enables the photographer to diminish the color he sees through the eyepiece and know what the picture will look like in black and white.   Mr. Gerber had been taking school courses in photography and was often not satisfied by the final print because colorful scenes yielded only disappointing shades of gray.

headline: NEW NATO STUDY SAYS SPENDING BY SOVIET ON MILITARY HAS SLOWED
abstract: A new NATO report says Soviet military spending has slowed over the last seven years and asserts that previous Western estimates have exaggerated Moscow's arms buildup.   The report, prepared by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Economic Committee, concludes that since 1976 Moscow's defense outlays have grown at less than 2.5 percent a year after inflation, compared with 4 to 5 percent in the early 1970's.   The new report shows that previous NATO estimates of growth in Soviet arms spending were overstated. Last year's report said real annual growth of at least 4 percent was continuing.

headline: Vice President for Panama
abstract: The National Assembly met in special session today and approved Carlos Ozores Typaldos as Panama's Vice President. Mr. Ozores fills the spot left vacant when Jorge Illueca was sworn in as President Feb. 13. Mr. Illueca became President after Ricardo de la Espriella resigned unexpectedly, citing ''personal reasons.''

headline: Data Bank; February 26, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: CETUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OFFICIAL VERSION OF AQUINO KILLING IS CONTRADICTED
abstract: The Philippine Government's statement that the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was slain last summer on the airport tarmac was challenged by an airport worker at a hearing today.   The worker, 24-year-old Fred Viesca, testified that, on hearing a shot at the Manila airport on the date of the killing, last Aug. 21, he caught a ''fleeting glance'' of Mr. Aquino falling from the stairway of an airliner that had just brought him home to the Philippines after several years of exile in the United States.   Military witnesses had told the inquiry panel that Mr. Aquino was shot in the back of the head after he had reached the tarmac.

headline: U.S. AIDE STARTS DRIVE FOR NAMIBIA SETTLEMENT
abstract: The United States began a new diplomatic drive today for a settlement in South-West Africa linked to a withdrawal of Cuban troops from neighboring Angola.    Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, opened negotiations at an elegant wine farm homestead near Cape Town, where he met South Africa's Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha. There were no official statements before the talks, and officials said no announcements would be made today. The talks may continue into Saturday.

headline: Market Place; Stock Trading: Signs of Vigor
abstract: THE stock market started and finished last    week on a strong note. Friday's performance   was the best, with the Dow Jones industrials climbing 16.96 points, to 1,184.36. The week's gain amounted to 44.60 points.   The rally of 15.60 points on Monday was overdue, according to some analysts, because the Dow plunged 31.72 points the previous week, paring the prices of many issues to seemingly attractive levels. There was a bit of substance - a decline in the basic money supply figures - and a lot of hope behind the market's rebound Friday. On the latter score the Reagan Administration and Republican lawmakers agreed on a plan to cut the budget deficit by $150 billion over three years. But it is unclear how that plan will fare in Congress.

headline: ROBOTS IN THE BARN
abstract: -D2 and C-3PO - those lovable humanlike robots from the ''Star Wars'' movies - won't be taking the place of Joe the hired hand anytime soon.    But robotics research is advancing at a rapid clip these days in replacing much of the drudgery of farm work.  ''There's a lot of research going on in automated, computer-controlled farm systems,'' said Mark Purschwitz of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers in St. Joseph, Mich. By 1990, he said, some of these new systems will be coming to market.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: Allied Stores Corp.  has appointed Jack N. Curtis chairman and chief executive of its Cain-Sloan division in Nashville, and has named Ronald Lane president of Cain-Sloan.     *  ATV Systems Inc., Santa Ana, Calif., has named Philip J. Gomez, chairman, to the additional post of president, replacing Frank Gleason, who becomes executive vice president.

headline: TRUCKERS IN FRANCE EXPAND THEIR ROAD BLOCKADES
abstract: The French police said today that truckers, ignoring a Government warning, had expanded their road blockades to almost every main highway in the country.    With traffic halted or slowed at 240 points, access cut off to cities such as Toulon and Nancy, and some industries shut down for lack of parts, the Government described the protest action, now in its seventh day, as ''inadmissible.''   The blockades began when French trucks were unable to enter Italy because of a French customs agents' strike on the Alpine border. Caught for days on the road, their cargoes spoiling, the drivers rebelled. They demanded that the Government reimburse them for time lost because of the strike and for insurance and fuel taxes.

headline: Advertising
abstract: Finesse: Expensive Marketing      ONE of the more crowded and competitive groups in the world of consumer product marketing - and one that demands an unusually high investment in advertising - is composed of the things people put on their faces, skin and hair. Top-selling cosmetics, perfumes and hair care products often command advertising budgets that exceed 10 percent of the revenues they generate. And anyone brash enough to introduce a new product into this field had better be ready to spend much more than that for early marketing and promotion.    Little wonder, then, that Chicago's Helene Curtis Industries has become one of Madison Avenue's big spenders. Since introducing its Finesse line of women's hair care products two years ago, its advertising budget has mushroomed from $4 million a year to a projected $30 million in 1984. ''It's the most dramatic increase I can remember,'' said Carl Spielvogel, chairman of Backer & Spielvogel Inc., which has the Finesse account.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE Atari Realignment Of Management Set
abstract: Atari Inc., the troubled unit of Warner Communications Inc., announced a realignment of management yesterday ''to position the company for future growth.''   Although Atari, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., lost $500 million in the first nine months of last year, its chairman and chief executive, James J. Morgan, has said that the company expects to make a profit in 1984.    Mr. Morgan, 41 years old, a former marketing executive at Philip Morris who took over at Apple last summer, said the new alignment would strengthen the company ''for years to come'' and would ''minimize bureaucracy and duplication of efforts.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, JANUARY 30, 1984
abstract: The Economy    Fourth-quarter 1983 corporate profits are up 25 percent over the 1982 level, economists predict. But they also think these profits could be level with, or below those, of the third quarter. This would indicate stagnation in the rate of economic recovery. (Page D1.)

headline: THERE'S REAL ACTION IN SIMULATION FIELD
abstract: It all started in 1929 in the basement of the organ factory that Edwin A. Link's father ran. Using an organ's bellows to blow air against the bottom of a suspended box, Mr. Link found that he could approximate the motion of an airplane in flight. And the flight simulator was born.    Now, more than half a century later, flight simulation involves the highest of high technology. The box has become a capsule with video screens and speakers, and the organ bellows is now a set of hydraulic legs that look much like giant shock absorbers. For almost every make of big aircraft there is at least one corresponding simulator either in use or on order - among them the new Boeing 757's and 767's, and the Cobra and Apache helicopters.

headline: REAGAN'S REQUESTS FOR LATIN AID RUN INTO NEW TROUBLE IN CONGRESS
abstract: President Reagan's effort to hasten Congressional approval of emergency arms and economic aid for Central America ran into new and serious difficulty today.   A quick maneuver in the Senate left arms aid for anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua and for the armed forces of El Salvador in legislative doubt. The House Foreign Affairs Committee refused to include any Central America aid in next year's foreign aid bill, and Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said Mr. Reagan's handling of the aid issue had demonstrated that he was ''unfit'' for national leadership.   By the end of the day the Central American aid package, a series of bills and amendments that constitute one of the Administration's major foreign policy initatives, appeared to be in deeper trouble than ever.

headline: New G.P.U. Lineup For Nuclear Plants
abstract: The General Public Utilities Corporation said yesterday that it had elected John F. O'Leary as chairman of its nuclear power subsidiary, which operates the Three Mile Island plants. Mr. O'Leary is a former Deputy Secretary of the Energy Department.   William G. Kuhns, G.P.U.'s chairman, said the election completed the separation of the management of the nuclear subsidiary from that of the company's other utilities.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: People     *  Peter W. Evans named executive vice president of HBM/Creamer, Boston.     *  William Lower, Gregory Weinschenker, Jon Tracosas, Joanne Laine, Susan Read, Linda Kaplan, Arnold Chase and  E. Donald Challis have been elected senior vice presidents of J. Walter Thompson USA.

headline: NAVY SECRETARY SAID TO FAVOR REPRIMANDS IN BEIRUT BLAST
abstract: The Secretary of the Navy has recommended that military officers be reprimanded for command failures associated with the Oct. 23 truck-bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut, Reagan Administration officials said today.    They said the recommendation, which was submitted to Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today, called for the issuance of disciplinary letters. The officials said more severe forms of punishment, including courts-martial, were precluded by President Reagan last month.   The officials declined to say whether the recommendation by the Secretary, John F. Lehman Jr., covered both Navy and Marine officers or how high in the chain of command the reprimands might reach.

headline: Yugoslav Road Crash Kills 6
abstract: Six people were killed and 25 injured when a bus and a truck collided near the central Yugoslav town of Banya Luka today, the official Tanyug press agency said.

headline: Pratt & Whitney
abstract: The Dutch Air Force has grounded about 30 of its 93 General Dynamics Corporation F-16 fighter planes because of a defect in the engine cooling system, the Defense Ministry said. A spokesman said a team of experts from the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney group, makers of the engines, arrived here today to inspect the planes.

headline: Dollar Is HigherIn Europe
abstract: The dollar was slightly stronger in European trading today, but dealers said it was difficult to identify a trend in view of the holiday closure of trading in the United States.    The market was stagnant, and a large order could have moved rates significantly either way, one dealer said.

headline: STRONG SALES SEEN IN '84 FOR APPLE'S MACINTOSH
abstract: More than 600 business computer buyers put Apple Computer Inc.'s new Macintosh through its paces at a trade show here this week.    After 40 minutes on the machine, Robert Dieter, an executive of the Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of San Diego, was still not sure which microcomputer maker would get the big order he expects to place for Home Federal's 160 branches. But, he said, ''Whatever it is has to be easy to use, and this is easy to use.'' And he added, ''I'm impressed.''

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; U.S. Savings and Loan In Eurobond Offering
abstract: The first Eurobond offering by a United States savings and loan association collateralized by Government National Mortgage Association certificates was announced yesterday.   The offering of $100 million American Savings International 12 percent guaranteed bonds due in April 1989 was underwritten by Salomon Brothers International Ltd., Bear, Stearns International Ltd. and Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. in London. They are not sold in the United States.

headline: CONCERN FOR BID HURTS GULF STOCK
abstract: Gulf Corporation shares plunged $4.50 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $64.75, in very heavy trading, reflecting persistent concern that Congress might block Gulf's takeover by the Standard Oil Company of California.    A total of 4.6 million Gulf shares changed hands, and the stock led the Big Board's most active list.    Meanwhile, the Bankers Trust Company, in response to a question, said last night that it had been ready to raise the money for a competing offer for Gulf that would have sidestepped the mounting political opposition.    The financing would have been for a leveraged buyout by the investment house of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. Because political opposition to the Gulf-Socal merger has focused on concentration within the oil industry, a leveraged buyout in which none of the funds came from other big oil companies could take the edge off this opposition, analysts said.

headline: People Express
abstract: People Express Airlines Inc., which last month agreed to lease three airplanes from a Boeing Company subsidiary, announced another two-year lease for an additional used 747-100 airplane. People Express said it also has the option to purchase the airplane, scheduled for delivery by the spring of 1985, for $16.5 million. People Express, which began low-cost service in 1981 and now flies to about 20 cities in the United States and to London, said it had not determined on which routes the aircraft would be used.

headline: KOHL URGES A U.S.-SOVIET PARLEY BEFORE NOVEMBER
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl urged today that a United States-Soviet summit meeting be held before the Presidential elections.   Mr. Kohl said the change in the Soviet leadership after the death of Yuri V. Andropov had improved the prospects for better Soviet-Western relations, adding, ''I, in particular, am in favor of making use of the opportunity, and we should not wait until after the American elections.''   Mr. Kohl, speaking on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' said he would raise the issue of a summit meeting during talks with President Reagan Monday at the White House. The Chancellor suggested President Reagan relax his conditions for a meeting with the new Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko.

headline: JUDGE BACKS MERRILL IN TEAMSTERS VALUATION
abstract: A Federal judge in Chicago has said that Merrill Lynch & Company acted properly when it determined that the assets of an insurance company being purchased by a teamsters health and welfare fund were worth $10.75 million.    The Labor Department and the teasmters fund argued that the assets of Amalgamated Insurance Services Inc. were worth no more than $2 million and that Merrill Lynch had acted improperly in reaching its figure.    ''I can only come to one conclusion,'' Judge Hubert Will said late Tuesday after listening to more than seven hours of arguments from attorneys representing the Labor Department, the Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Health and Welfare Fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and Merrill Lynch.

headline: FOES OF SANDINISTAS CALL VOTING LAW UNFAIR
abstract: The Sandinista-dominated Council of State gave final approval Thursday night to a law that will govern elections set for Nov. 4. But opposition leaders said today that the law would not give them an equal chance to compete.    Sandinista leaders said the election would show that they retain strong popularity among the people. But spokesmen for opposition parties and business groups said the law gave unfair advantages to the Sandinistas and did not offer rival candidates sufficient access to radio and television.

headline: U.S.I.A. PLANS SATELLITE NEWS PARLEYS
abstract: The United States Information Agency said today that it planned to use communications satellites to enable reporters around the world to question Reagan Administration officials in Washington or wherever they happened to be. It said the system would be called Worldnet.    The plans were discussed at a briefing on the U.S.I.A.'s proposed budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The Reagan Administration has recommended a 28 percent increase in the agency's budget, increasing it to $849 million from $665.2 million.

headline: ON THE CORPORATE BOOKSHELF
abstract: Ever wonder ow licrative computer book publishing has become? Take a stroll into the McGraw-Hill Book Store in midtown Manhat- tan. It's as if an avalanche had struck What started as a modest computer book section a few years ago has grown to fill one-quarter of the store's shelves and has sprawled out onto the carpeted floor in intimidating, though neat, piles.

headline: MARCOS TO ALLOW REVIEW OF POWERS
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, in a new gesture to his political opponents, said this week that he would submit his powers of decree to a review and possible abolition by the new Parliament to be elected in May.    The President's decree powers allow him to order summary arrests and detention without trial,   Speaking in an interview here Friday, the Philippine President also said he expected that the incoming legislators, who will hold their first session in June, could rescind a constitutional amendment permitting him to proclaim laws without reference to the legislative process.   The 75-minute interview yesterday in Mr. Marcos's stately, book-lined office in Malacanang Palace, Manila's White House, began on the sensitive topic of the 66-year-old President's health, a subject of much speculation and rumor, including unconfirmed reports that he suffered from a serious kidney ailment. The truth, he said, is that a World War II shrapnel splinter that was thought to have lodged in a kidney was found in the bladder instead and has been removed.

headline: HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL AT 75
abstract: It was five years ago that the president of Harvard University broke the carefully nurtured academic quiet here, publishing a commentary on business education that many considered a slap at Harvard Business School's time-honored teaching methods and the direction of its research.    New demands on American business executives, suggested the president, Derek C. Bok, meant the school should place greater emphasis on teaching ethics and on instilling in its students - mostly future managers in American corporations - a greater appreciation of how corporations and the Government interact. And Mr. Bok questioned whether the school had grown overly reliant, in both teaching and research, on its celebrated case-method approach.    Broader Approach Was Urged    While the method uses real-life examples of corporate decision-making, he wrote, it ''does not provide an ideal way of communicating concepts and analytic methods.'' Instead, he advocated a broader approach that would teach business theory and principles first, and then test them against the case studies.

headline: ADVERTISING ; Co-Creative Directors For Young & Rubicam
abstract: Alexander Kroll, president of Young & Rubicam, America's largest agency, is turning over his title of worldwide senior creative director to Frazier Purdy, who is starting his 30th year at the agency. And replacing Mr. Purdy as creative director in New York, the agency's headquarters and biggest office, will be Frank DeVito, an art director, and John Ferrell, a copywriter.

headline: SOO LINE RAILROAD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VACU-DRY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FIBER-OPTIC GLASS, THE LONG PULL AHEAD
abstract: Analytical and physical chemists are working on techniques that will reduce the impurities in a glassy substance made of fluorine to an amount measured in parts per trillion.   Materials scientists and mechanical engineers are devising ways to draw this highly unstable glass into fibers with diameters that vary no more than a thousandth of a millimeter over a distance of hundreds of kilometers.  Optical physicists and electrical engineers are experimenting with ways to transform electical impulses into laser beams that can course through this incredibly clear glass fiber across continents and under oceans without being diminished through refraction.  The variety of skills needed to develop - and, ultimately, to manufacture, install and repair - fibers made of this substance, called halide glass, exemplifies the interdisciplinary nature of the work being done at the forefront of the rapidly advancing field of fiber optics. And the job outlook for these various disciplines is good: The United States market for new fiber-optics systems is expected to more than quadruple in the next five years.

headline: FOR SOME, IT'S NOW PHONE REPAIRS BY MAIL
abstract: After Nancy Moore and Roger Engels were married, Mr. Engels wanted to return the telephone he had been renting in his old house. The couple, who live in Fredericksburg, Va., found that the nearest A.T.& T. Phone Center Store that would accept such returns was in Springfield, a suburb of Washington, D.C., more than 40 miles away.   So the couple drove to Springfield one Saturday recently, only to arrive in midafternoon just after the store had closed for the day. Mr. Engels kept the phone in the trunk of his car and eventually managed to bring it in when returning from Washington's National Airport after a business trip.    ''It's been fairly frustrating,'' Miss Moore said.    Such frustrations have increased since the breakup of the Bell System on Jan. 1. By many accounts, the impact has been felt most by those outside the major cities, who now have to travel long distances to obtain some services.

headline: BRITISH RACE IS ON IN MICROCOMPUTERS
abstract: Just as in the United States, leading computer companies in Britain are homing in on the booming microcomputer market. In the process, solid homegrown competitors, several of which hope to become high-volume international players, are confronting the American companies.   The center of attention is the lucrative business segment for personal computers. Sinclair Research Ltd., a world leader in inexpensive home computers, is about to enter the fray with its first business computer, the unabashedly named Quantam Leap.

headline: FRENCH FIRE ON SPANISH BOATS
abstract: A gunboat warned two Spanish fishing vessels to get out of French waters today and opened fire when they refused. Government sources said nine fishermen were wounded.

headline: GULF WELL FAILURE SEEN BY PICKENS
abstract: T. Boone Pickens, the chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, stepped up his attack on the management of the Gulf Oil Corporation, predicting that a key Gulf drilling project in Alaska will fail.

headline: APPLE COMPUTER LOSES SALES-MARKETING AIDE
abstract: E. Floyd Kvamme, 46, one of the most senior executives in California's Silicon Valley, has resigned from Apple Computer Inc.     The change marks the second job switch in 14 months for Mr. Kvamme, who was long considered to be one of the most deeply rooted of executives in the highly mobile world of Silicon Valley. He joined Apple after spending 16 years at the nearby National Semiconductor Corporation.

headline: MEXICO RELAXES RULES ON FOREIGN OWNERSHIP
abstract: In a qualified invitation to businesses based abroad, Mexico said today that it would allow majority foreign ownership for certain companies. The law generally requires 51 percent Mexican capital in foreign-held subsidiaries.    The Government offered exceptions in 34 categories of industry, including farm machinery, food processing equipment, textile manufacturing equipment, high-powered motors and generators, large turbines and turbocompressors, telecommunications, computers, pharmaceuticals, synthetic resins and plastics, photographic equipment, advanced biotechnology and motorcycles.

headline: People
abstract: *  Thomas Crotty appointed an executive vice president of Sudler & Hennessey.     *  Kenneth Probst elected executive vice president, and  Madeline Betsch a senior vice president, of Campbell- Mithun, Minneapolis.

headline: REAGAN CALLS SALVADOR AID FOES NAIVE
abstract: President Reagan, facing a Senate debate on his request for new military aid for El Salvador, today denounced as ''naive or downright phony'' those who express concern for human rights ''while pursuing policies that lead to the overthrow of less-than-perfect democracies by Marxist dictatorships.''    In remarks at the White House, the President called on Congress to approve his $93 million aid request, arguing that it was needed to protect Central America from a takeover by the Soviet Union and its ''roving wolf'' of a proxy, Cuba.   With White House officials expecting a Senate floor vote on the aid request as early as Wednesday, Mr. Reagan spoke of what he called the Soviet threat in the hemisphere and depicted the issue of aid to the Salvadoran armed forces as vital to overall foreign policy.   ''If we don't give friends so close to home the means to defend themselves against Soviet-supported insurgents, who will trust us anywhere in the world, especially in the faraway Middle East and Europe?'' the President asked a sympathetic gathering of Cuban-Americans at the White House.

headline: Calet, Hirsch & Spector Gets Thermos Carafe
abstract: Thermos, a subsidiary of the Household International Corporation that has made its name in picnic products, has annouced a $6 million marketing program for a new brand of coffee carafes. James E. Freeman Jr., vice president for marketing, said the move would ''bring the company inside after 75 years.''

headline: Dow Jones Link
abstract: Dow Jones & Company, a business news service company and publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said it had bought stock in the CDEX Corporation of Los Altos, Calif., for an undisclosed price. The company develops and markets software used by businesses and consumers. Late in 1983 Dow Jones purchased stock interests in two other software companies - Software Ventures Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., and Planning Economics Software of Boston.

headline: Phone Pact With Japan
abstract: The United States and Japan agreed today to extend for three more years their 1980 arrangement for purchases of American-made telephone equipment by the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.    The new accord, according to the spokesman, who asked not to be identified, includes acceptance of bids at Nippon's office in New York and acceptance of bids in English. These steps are intended to increase purchases in the United States.

headline: Kissinger Anticipates Soviet Peace Offensive
abstract: Henry A. Kissinger said today that he expected ''a peace offensive'' by the Soviet Union as a result of the death of Yuri V. Andropov.   Mr. Kissinger, speaking on the Cable News Network, said this would give the United States a chance to reopen talks with the Soviet Union without either side having to admit giving ground.

headline: IRAN-IRAQ CONFLICT IS SEEN AT NEW CRITICAL JUNCTURE
abstract: Military   Analysis    LONDON, Feb. 17 - Intelligence analysts here say the Iranian-Iraqi war shows signs of having reached another critical phase, with Iran pressing an offensive for which it has apparently gathered half a million men.  The drive, started at midnight Wednesday in the area of the Iranian border town of Mehran, has reportedly caused acute concern in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other Persian Gulf countries because of what they see as a threat to their security.   The Iranians continue to say they are advancing in heavy fighting, but the Iraqis say they have thrown back the invaders. Military analysts here emphasize that it is difficult to verify battlefield reports since Western military attaches and reporters are barred from the fronts.

headline: Texas Rate Rise
abstract: The Texas Utilities Company said a subsidiary, the Texas Utilities Electric Company, had filed for a $304.2 million, or 8 percent, rate increase. The utility serves north-central, east and west Texas.

headline: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week
abstract: Monday    None Tuesday    Retail SalesJan.    Consumer Installment CreditDec. Wednesday    Industrial ProductionJan.

headline: Lindner Has More American General
abstract: The American Financial Corporation has raised its holding in the American General Corporation, an insurance holding company based in Houston, to the equivalent of 10,582,768 common shares, or 13.9 percent of the total outstanding, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.    American Financial and its chairman, Carl H. Linder, told the S.E.C. that the company had purchased 4,042,423 preferred shares and 1,371,211 warrants to buy American General common stock at $24.25 a share at any time until Jan. 4, 1989. On the New York Stock Exchange today, American General closed at $20.25, down 12.5 cents.

headline: MORE COLLEGES TAKING THE HIGH-TECH ROUTE
abstract: THE University of Minnesota, hit with a $25 million budget cut from the State Legislature this year, nonetheless allocated additional resources to its Institute of Technology for new programs and an increased salary scale that pays top engineering professors $75,000 a year.   At George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., near Washington, where the student population has grown in 12 years from 3,000 to 15,000, faculty members are being recruited to staff the new industry-sponsored ''centers of excellence'' in information technology and engineering.  Meanwhile, faculty initiative in research and development at the Polytechnic Institute of New York has generated so much income and so many donations of machinery from industry and state government, said its president, George Bugliarello, that the school was able to set up it own institute, called the Metropolitan Technology Center.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  Dr Pepper Co., a soft drink concern in Dallas, said plaintiffs in suits relating to its acquisition by Forstmann Little & Co. agreed to dismiss the litigation if the proposed merger is approved by Dr Pepper's shareholders and if no offer on more favorable terms is made to shareholders.     * Marine Midland Bank said it had completed its acquisition of Public Financial Management Inc,, a Philadelphia-based provider of financial advisory services to state and municipal governments.

headline: Advertising; A Booklet To Educate Managers
abstract: ADVERTISING: To know it is to love it.  That's the thinking behind an undertaking of the American Business Press that it hopes will make its membership less susceptible to the vagaries of the economy.    The American Business Press, an association of trade press publishers, was prompted by the results of a survey of top corporate managements that shows, in industrial companies especially, a lack of understanding of, and confidence in, advertising. And without such confidence, the A.B.P. has learned, the people with the final word on advertising budgets frequently will cut them as soon as a recession begins to have its effect on corporate profits.

headline: U.S. IS A TARGET AS 10 NATIONS SIGN ACID RAIN PACT
abstract: Environment and Health Ministers from nine European countries and Canada signed an agreement today committing their governments to reduce sulfur emissions by at least 30 percent in the next decade to limit environmental damage from acid rain.   The signing ceremony was the highlight of a two-day conference intended to generate the pressure of public opinion on both the United States and Britain to join what was referred to repeatedly as the ''30 percent club.'' All the countries taking part here - Austria, Canada, Denmark, West Germany, Finland, France, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland - had individually adopted the 30 percent reductions and some, such as Canada, have committed themselves to 50 percent cutbacks on the l980 levels of sulfur emissions.

headline: Brazil's Navy Chief Resigns
abstract: Minister of the Navy Maximiano Eduardo da Silva Fonseca resigned today, becoming the first high-level official of President Joao Baptista Figueiredo's military Government to step down. Admiral Fonseca, 64 years old, resigned for ''personal reasons,'' according to an announcement from the presidential palace. He was a member of President Figueiredo's original Cabinet.

headline: Market Place; I.R.A. Prop Under Stocks
abstract: M ONEY pouring into Individual Retirement Accounts, or I.R.A.'s, provided fuel for the stock market's strong performance in the opening months of last year. But if equities continue to decline in 1984 and thereby stir disenchantment with growth-oriented investments, the I.R.A. prop to stock prices - for the time being, at least - could be substantially weakened.    The Fidelity Group in Boston provides one window on developments, since it has more than 300,000 I.R.A. accounts with a total value in excess of $1 billion. ''So far, we haven't noticed any material change in account preferences,'' Roger Harris, a marketing executive at Fidelity, said yesterday. ''In January 1983, we took in $65.4 million in I. R.A. money, and the amount in January 1984 was $81 million. Meanwhile, the portion going into our aggressive-growth mutual funds remained at around 78 percent.

headline: Talking Businesswith Brian Freeman, financial adviser The Workers' Bid for Conrail The prospects for the Dep will have to wait and see what these railroads propose. However, I would not envision purchase by either of them because that would be counter to the interest of the public, rail service in the Northeast and the employees. The whole purpose of the Government investing $7 billion since 1976 was to maximize service. Acquisition by either of the railroads would result in a substantial reduction in service, competition and employment because of substantial overlap between Conrail and the other railroads.
abstract: Q. Some Transportation Department officials have said the unions' offer was not good   enough. Is there a bias there against your bid?     A. I don't think they have reached a decision- making point so I can't answer the question. What we put on the table is an initial offer and, while we think it would result in the best transaction for everyone, we are flexible. One never puts their bottom line on the table in the first instance.

headline: PUNJAB CENSURE MOVE DEFEATED
abstract: Opposition Parliament members tried unsuccessfully today to censure the Government for its handling of violence in Punjab state, forcing Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to defend her tactics and policy.   Mrs. Gandhi's defense of her policy came after opposition lawmakers charged the Government with trying to put off a solution in Punjab, which has been rocked by 19 months of protest and violence.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Gold, Back to Normal     While gold bugs have always fed on adversity, most of their meals in the last few years have been at their own expense. The reason: In recent times the metal has failed, time and again, to respond to the sort of negative political and economic developments that the bullion market traditionally thrived on.   But now it seems that the pendulum of market sentiment has swung back again. For example, the metal, which a year ago traded at more than $500 an ounce and which had fallen to just below $370 at year- end, has risen in recent weeks, and last week was hovering around $400.  Analysts have attributed the turnabout to heightened fears about inflation and the worsening Middle East situation - the very kinds of news developments that the bullion market had been ignoring until only a few weeks ago.  ''What we are seeing is a basic change in gold market psychology, one that is peculiar to this trade,'' says Jeffrey A. Nichols, precious metals research director at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''Given the nature of the market, sentiment could just as easily reverse itself overnight.'' So does the recent price rise portend a rosy outlook for bullion prices? ''Investors in any market believe what they want to believe,'' Mr. Nichols says.

headline: PENTAGON NEWS PANEL HEARS TESTIMONY
abstract: Executives of seven of the nation's largest news organizations testified today before a Pentagon panel, saying repeatedly that the press could be trusted to keep military secrets and that the Government had a responsibility to inform the public through the press.   The testimony was unusual not because of its message but because it was given by news organizations that have in the past hesitated to detail their procedures for covering events. ''We have never testified before anyone,'' said one witness, Benjamin C. Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post.   The panel was created after the invasion of Grenada, when military commanders, supported by the Secretary of Defense and the White House, barred reporters from the first two days of combat. The press and other groups protested the curbs, and the panel was formed to draft principles or guidelines for combat coverage.

headline: Data Bank; January 1, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  European Investment Bank's $130 million issue of 11 5/8 percent Eurobonds was priced at 99.5, through Nikko Securities Co. Buyers have a choice of maturities: Seven-year bonds will be redeemed at par, to yield 11.73 percent; fifteen-year bonds will be redeemed at 113, to yield 12.05 percent.     *  General Cinema Corp., a soft-drink producer and theater chain operator, filed for an offering of $80 million of subordinated debentures due in 2009, through Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. The debentures are exchangeable for shares of R. J. Reynolds Industries common stock held by General Cinema.

headline: G.E. UP 10.5% IN 4TH QUARTER
abstract: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter rose to a record $579 million, or $1.27 a share, up 10.5 percent from earnings of $524 million, or $1.15 a share, a year earlier.     John F. Welch, chairman, said that ''exceptionally strong performance by consumer-related businesses such as major appliances, appliance motors and components, silicones and plastics'' helped the earnings.    He added that there were also strong earnings from such high-technology sectors as medical systems, aerospace and aircraft engines.

headline: Careers; The Rise Of Imaging Sciences
abstract: SUBSPECIALTIES in science and engineering have been developing rapidly. Astro science, robotics engineering and genetic engineering are all relatively new, for example. And now there is imaging - not to be confused with imagining.     Imaging is a word that will soon be popular in many technical fields because it blankets areas like photography, television, computer graphics, graphic arts, digital imaging, remote sensing, aircraft and satellite surveillance, map making, newspaper printing and robotic vision.

headline: LOST HEADS AND FINANCE FOR TOTS
abstract: Move over, Jane Fonda . . . Spinnaker Software, which makes educational programs for the home, plans to introduce a program named ''Aerobics'' for Commodore and Atari computers. A colorful female cartoon character appears on the screen, twisting, bending and running in sync with a funky tune that plays over the computer's speaker. ''We had some great bugs to work out,'' said William H. Bowman, Spinnaker's chairman. During the character's first try at neck exercises, ''her head separated from her body and flew across the screen,'' he said.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.01     An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond   Buyer.   Aa Utility Bonds*13.75     Salomon Brothers' estimate for   new long-term issues.

headline: Japan's View Of Yen's Rate
abstract: The swift recovery of the United States economy and the strength of the dollar are causing the low exchange rate for the yen, the Japanese ambassador to the United States said today.    ''There are no grounds, nor is there any truth to the suspicion, that Japan is manipulating the yen to keep its value artificially low,'' Yoshio Okawara told the Economic Club of Detroit.

headline: CORPORATE-GIANT LIST CHANGES
abstract: Vigorous economic growth throughout 1983 has shaken up the rankings of the nation's 25 largest nonfinancial corporations. And, as a result of regulatory changes and merger decisions, the list of America's biggest companies is almost certain to undergo even more dramatic change this year.    As in years past, the names of big oil companies continued to dominate the overall rankings in terms of revenues and net income. But after a second consecutive year of soft prices, the petroleum industry's grip on the top spots has weakened.

headline: Crocker Purchase
abstract: The Crocker National Bank said it purchased a 90 percent interest in the Philadelphia Overseas Finance Company as part of its strategy to expand its involvement in import-export trade and related financing. Crocker said the company's management team will remain in place, but the name will be changed to the Pacific Overseas Finance Corporation.

headline: EX-U.S. ENVOY CALLS CHERNENKO DULLARD
abstract: Americans who have met Konstantin U. Chernenko, the new Soviet leader, say they were not particularly impressed with the caliber of his mind or his command of information.    The Americans gave their impressions in interviews today after it was announced that Mr. Chernenko had been chosen General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.   Malcolm Toon, a former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, said Mr. Chernenko struck him as ''a dullard'' at a dinner held in Vienna in 1979 to mark the signing of a strategic arms limitation treaty.   ''The only impression I formed,'' he said, ''is that he was a dullard.''

headline: ARA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Floating-Rate Eurobond Notes
abstract: New floating-rate note issues dominated the Eurobond market with banks in particular attracted by the high-quality liquid appeal of these bonds, dealers said.

headline: WESTCHESTER THEATER CASE
abstract: Fifteen months ago, a Federal prosecutor said in open court that ''the real culprit'' in a stock fraud and kickback scheme was Steven J. Ross, chairman of Warner Communications. To date, however - after two company executives have pleaded guilty and a third has been convicted after a trial - no charges have been filed against Mr. Ross.     The United States Attorney's office for the Southern District of New York, which is handling the case, said this week that the investigation was continuing and declined to comment further.    Geoffrey Holmes, a vice president and spokesman at Warner Communications, said, however, that, ''to the best of our knowledge,'' there is no active investigation. Mr. Holmes added that Mr. Ross, who has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing, had not been asked to testify before any grand jury about the matter and that ''there have not been any communications between the United States Attorney's office and Steve Ross in almost two years.''

headline: Money Fund Yields Higher
abstract: Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday that yields on the 252 money market mutual funds that it surveys rose further in the week ended Wednesday.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Jacksonville Financing Has Zero Coupon Bonds    A $500 million financing for the Jacksonville, Fla., Electric Authority was tentatively priced by underwriters led by Shearson/American Express Inc. The sale included $218.7 million face amount of zero coupon bonds due in 2014 offered at a price of 4.663, or $46.63 per $1,000 bond, to yield 10 1/4 percent to maturity, as well as 10 1/8 percent bonds due in 2012 offered at par.   The municipal utility's serial bonds were tentatively priced to yield from 6 percent in 1985 to 9 3/4 percent in 1998, while 10 percent bonds due in 2004 are offered at par, and 7 1/4 percent bonds due in 2013 are offered at slightly more than 77, to yield 9.60 percent.

headline: Earthquake Rocks Delphi
abstract: An earthquake struck central Greece today, damaging homes near the ancient shrine of Delphi but causing no injuries, police here said.

headline: WEST GERMAN POLICE REPORT ABDUCTION OF G.I.
abstract: A 21-year-old American soldier stationed at a south German missile base has been kidnapped, the police in the state of Baden-W"urttemberg said today.   Police officials said the soldier, identified as Specialist 4 Lyiam Fowler, telephoned his wife this morning to say that he had been abducted while driving near the base at Mutlangen, where nine Pershing 2 missiles were deployed in November.   The soldier was reported to have said that he would be slain by the six people holding him if West German opposition to missiles was not publicized by American news organizations within 72 hours, the police said.

headline: U.S. PILOT KILLED BY 'HOSTILE FIRE' ON HONDURAN TRIP
abstract: A United States Army helicopter pilot was killed Wednesday in Honduras by hostile fire ''from the direction of the Nicaraguan border from a person or persons unknown'' after he made an emergency landing, the Defense Department said.    Wednesday night, the Nicaraguan Defense Ministry issued a communique in Managua saying its military units along the border fired on an ''unidentified military helicopter'' over Nicaraguan territory that was later forced to land 200 yards inside Honduras, The Associated Press reported. The communique did not refer to the killing of the American pilot.   A Pentagon spokesman, Lieut. Col. Thomas Jones, said this morning that he had no comment on the communique.

headline: A BIG CANADIAN JACKPOT IN SOCAL, MOBIL DEALS
abstract: If the Standard Oil Company of California and the Mobil Corporation win their respective takeover battles for the Gulf Corporation and the Superior Oil Company, a big part of both jackpots will lie in Canada.    Both Canadian subsidiaries of the target companies, Gulf Canada Ltd. and Canadian Superior Oil Ltd., are exceptionally well regarded by the investment community. Gulf's Canadian assets are valued at $3.3 billion (Canadian), representing its 60 percent stake in Gulf Canada, while Canadian Superior's worth is estimated at $1.5 billion to $2 billion.

headline: Advertising; Insurance Programs Marketed
abstract: W ITH crime high in the consciousness of the nation, Continental Insurance has gone to market with three new programs intended to remove at least the economic portion of people's fears.     There are the Missing Child Assistance Plan, the Crime Victim Assistance Plan and the Fraud/Theft Assistance Plan, policies that will cover most of the expenses entailed. The last mentioned, for example, in addition to $50,000 for emergency health services, will include provisions for witness reimbursement, medical expenses for a good Samaritan, legal liability and a reward of up to $5,000.

headline: Alexander's Stock
abstract: Heavy trading in the common stock of Alexander's Inc. has raised the possibility of a substantial increase in holdings of a large stockholder or of the entry of a major new investor, according to sources in the financial community. Alexander's operates 15 stores in the metropolitan area and owns valuable real estate.

headline: U.S. AND BRAZIL SIGN PACT RESUMING MILITARY TIES
abstract: The Reagan Administration agreed today to provide Brazil with sophisticated technology for its fast-growing arms industry.    The agreement re-establishes a military relationship with Brazil that was suspended seven years ago during the Carter Administration in a dispute over human rights.   As part of a package of agreements concluded during the visit here of Secretary of State George P. Shultz, the United States and Brazil also settled past differences over the supply of fuel for Brazil's nuclear power station.

headline: Oil, Gas Deal For Madison
abstract: The Madison Fund Inc. and the Inspiration Resources Corporation agreed yesterday to transfer certain oil and gas properties of Inspiration and of Danville Resources to Madison in exchange for common stock. The transaction, which will more than double the size of Madison, is subject to the approval of several boards.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Head of Mesa In Washington
abstract: T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, met today with Senator J. Bennett Johnston, the Louisiana Democrat who is drafting a bill to curtail oil-industry mergers.   Mr. Pickens leads a group that had accumulated a substantial holding in the Gulf Corporation, and he has urged the use of royalty trusts by Gulf and others in the industry Senator Johnston has called Mr. Pickens a corporate ''liquidator'' and said he preferred that the Standard Oil Company of California acquire Gulf.

headline: RATE RISE SEEN IF DOLLAR FALLS
abstract: The strength of the dollar throughout 1983 attracted strong foreign demand for dollar-denominated securities and helped keep interest rates and inflation lower than they would otherwise have been. Many analysts, however, say that may not continue through 1984.    Foreign trade is a small part of the American economy compared to other economies, but many analysts say that currency developments in 1984 could be crucial to the course of interest rates, inflation and the economy.   ''Foreign competition and the strong dollar have been the main force holding inflation in check,'' Albert M. Wojnilower, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, said in a recent speech. ''Were we producing here, above and beyond our present output, the extra goods we have been importing,'' he said, the economy would already be showing signs of overheating.

headline: CHINA SAID TO JAIL EX-U.S. ATTORNEY
abstract: Two years ago, Hanson Huang, a Hong Kong-born, Harvard-trained lawyer and a former partner in a major New York law firm, disappeared from his hotel room while on an extended visit to Peking.   Mr. Huang, who had earlier taught law in China, was assumed to be under arrest. But until recently, nothing was known of his fate, either by relatives in Hong Kong and the United States or by friends who knew him at Harvard.   Inquiries made by these friends by mail to the Chinese authorities went unanswered. Members of Mr. Huang's family, hoping that by remaining quiet they might enhance his chances of being released, did not seek publicity for him or petition the Chinese Government for information about him.

headline: 34 WORLD BANK NATIONS SET $9 BILLION AID LIMIT
abstract: Thirty- four nations attending a World Bank meeting here agreed today to contribute $9 billion over the next three years to the poorest countries, but remained deadlocked over the amount to be given by each, officials said.    The total of $9 billion, which would be distributed through the International Development Association, represents a victory for the United States, which at earlier negotiating sessions in Paris and Tokyo had resisted attempts by most other countries and the World Bank to lift the total to $12 billion. The I.D.A. is an affiliate of the World Bank.

headline: DANISH PREMIER WINS VOTE BUT FAILS TO GAIN A MAJORITY
abstract: Prime Minister Poul Schluter's Conservative People's Party scored significant gains in today's national election, but his four-party coalition was denied a working majority in Denmark's Parliament.   While the election clearly demonstrated Mr. Schluter's personal popularity, it was not expected to advance his chances of getting a tough austerity budget through Parliament.   Lack of support last month for the budget, which cuts deeply into public spending in a nation that has one of the most advanced social welfare systems in Western Europe, forced the election, Denmark's seventh in 13 years.

headline: LIFE IN WEST BEIRUT COMES FULL CIRCLE
abstract: Seventeen months after the Israeli Army forced the Palestine Liberation Organization out of West Beirut and suppressed the coalition of Lebanese Moslem leftist militiamen aligned with the P.L.O., events here have come full circle.   The old Moslem-leftist crowd that ruled West Beirut in the heyday of the Palestine Liberation Organization was putting itself back in charge, led by the Druse and Amal militias. Their Kalashnikovs came out from under mattresses, and their old checkpoints were set up again, manned as usual by gunmen wearing three different kinds of uniforms.   Posters of the slain Druse leader Kamal Jumblat were already being pasted back on cars and buildings around West Beirut before the end of today. The clique of leftist party leaders will undoubtedly dust off their old tables at their former hangout in the Bristol Hotel coffee shop, where the Druse leader, Walid Jumblat, in jeans and his black leather jacket, used to hold court in a corner booth.

headline: URUGUAY BREAKS UP PLANT SIT-IN
abstract: Soldiers stormed a factory today and routed 600 workers holding a sit-in as the conflict between Uruguay's military Government and organized labor appeared to worsen.   The Government, saying that a 24- hour general strike Wednesday was highly effective across the country, banned the union confederation that organized it.   But union spokesmen dismissed the move as a sign of weakness and said the confederation, which claims to represent 90 percent of the nation's work force, would defy the dissolution order.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Cannon Group , a motion picture company in Hollywood, began offering through E.F. Hutton & Co. $30 million of its 9 percent convertible subordinated debentures due March 15, 2009.     * Norwest Financial, a financial services company based in Des Moines, announced the public offering of $50 million of its 12 3/4 percent senior notes, series 1991. Maturing July 1, 1991, the notes are priced at 99.625 percent, plus accrued interest, to yield 12.841 percent.

headline: Army Is Returning Green Berets to Asia
abstract: The Army will soon return its elite Special Forces to the Far East for the first time in a decade, the service announced Friday.   About 150 Green Berets belonging to a new company in the Special Forces will begin moving to Okinawa from Fort Bragg, N.C., this month, with the rest of a new battalion to follow in September, the Army said. The last Green Berets were withdrawn from Asia after the Vietnam War.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Cattle Treatment   A treatment for the highly contagious ''pink eye'' disease that afflicts cattle has been developed at the University of Illinois College of Veterinary Medicine.

headline: T.W.A.'S CHALLENGE TO UNIONS
abstract: Now it is C. E. Meyer Jr. at Trans World Airlines who is trying to convince skeptical and resistant unions of the need for contract concessions to revive his groggy airline.     Frank Lorenzo at Continental chose bankruptcy and Frank Borman at Eastern used the threat of it to get the concessions they said they needed.   But Mr. Meyer, in a rare interview the other day, described a strategy that he said was more like the one American Airlines successfully pursued. It is a steady, crushing, bear hug and a pledge to keep the carrier flying without unions if necessary.    'Harder and Harder Choices'    T.W.A., about to be spun off from the Trans World Corporation, is looking for $93 million in concessions from its flight attendants and machinists. And Mr. Meyer, the carrier's president and chief executive officer, says he will simply confront them ''with harder and harder choices.''

headline: Coleco Hires Executive To Head Its Adam Unit
abstract: Charles Winterble has been hired from Commodore International to take charge of electronic products deveopment at Coleco Industries.   In that post, Mr. Winterble will be responsible for Coleco's computer products, and he will report directly to Arnold C. Greenberg, president and chief executive officer.

headline: Pickens Offers Details on Gulf
abstract: T. Boone Pickens Jr., the   Texas oilman who is trying to   break up the Gulf Oil Corporation, yesterday proposed that   about half of Gulf's assets,   worth several billion dollars,   be spun off to shareholders. In a letter to Gulf directors,   Mr. Pickens proposed that by   next June 30, at least 50 percent   of Gulf's proven domestic oil   and natural gas reserves be   given to shareholders in the   form of a royalty trust.

headline: WORLD ATTENTION TURNS TO CHERNENKO'S HEALTH
abstract: As the normal rhythms of life returned to the Soviet capital after Tuesday's burial of Yuri V.
