Andropov, whose death came after months of medical problems, Western diplomats began to raise questions about the health of the new Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko.    At the funeral, the new party chief, who is 72 years old , appeared to be short of breath. This was noted among the foreign dignitaries attending the rites, one of whom, Dr. David Owen, the leader of Britain's Social Democratic Party, is a physician.   On his return to London, Dr. Owen said in a radio interview about Mr. Chernenko:   ''He has got what we call emphysema, which is shortness of breath. It is not a good illness to have. It tends to be something which brings on heart disease.''

headline: ; Murray Ohio Names President as Its Chief
abstract: The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, makers of bicycles and power mowers, said yesterday that it had named John Anderson as chief executive to succeed William H. Hannon, who continues as chairman.     Mr. Anderson, 59, had been president and chief operating officer. His titles will now be president and chief executive. G. Cromer Smotherman, 58, executive vice president, succeeds Mr. Anderson as chief operating officer.

headline: CHIP MAKER INDICTMENT HELD NEAR
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation is expected to be criminally indicted by a Federal grand jury here, on the ground of inadequate and fraudulent testing of as many as 26 million chips used in weapons and other military equipment, according to a Justice Department source close to the investigation.    Government and industry experts estimate that the chips may have found their way into every type of electronic device used by the military, from walkie-talkies and jeeps to battleships and fighter aircraft.   2-Year Investigation    For the last two years, the Defense Department and Justice Department have been investigating semiconductor manufacturers that supply the Government. National Semiconductor, with sales last year of $1.2 billion, is the latest and largest target of that investigation. It has already been suspended once as a Government chip supplier during the investigation.

headline: Haitians Select Rubber-Stamp Assembly
abstract: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 12 (AP) - Haitians voted today for members of a 59-seat National Assembly that was dissolved a year early as part of a Government overhaul by President-for-Life Jean-Claude Duvalier.   The legislative assembly is a rubber- stamp body for resolutions by President Duvalier, 32 years old.

headline: SEEKING A NARROWER MANDATE
abstract: When James C. Miller 3d took over as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission in October 1981, he was a man with a mission: to end what he perceived as the agency's adversarial relationship with the business community and to return the commission to a narrower mandate in consumer protection and antitrust regulation.   The approach, part of the Administration's general push for deregulation and promotion of free-market principles, has succeeded all too well as far as some of Mr. Miller's Congressional critics are concerned.    A subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which has jurisdiction over the F.T.C., will call Mr. Miller to testify Monday and ask him to defend what panel members see as a systematic gutting of the function Congress intended the agency to perform.   Aides said Mr. Miller could not be interviewed today because, in addition to formally announcing his latest proposals on advertising in a speech, he was preparing for the Monday testimony. He was also busy with an appearance tonight on the Public Broadcasting Service's McNeil-Lehrer News Hour.

headline: MANVILLE REPORTS LOSS OF $5 MILLION IN QUARTER
abstract: The Manville Corporation reported yesterday that it had operating earnings of $1.2 million in the fourth quarter of 1983. But after deducting funds to make dividend payments on preferred stock, the company posted a loss equivalent to 21 cents a share in the fourth quarter.     For the quarter a year earlier the company reported a loss of $96.8 million.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * American Hospital Supply Corp . said it was raising $50 million (Canadian) through a 10-year retractable Eurobond with a 12 3/8 percent coupon and par price for the first five years. The lead manager is Wood Gundy Ltd.     * GTE Finance N.V., a GTE Corp. subsidiary, said it was raising $50 million in European currency units with an eight-year Eurobond through Orion Royal Bank Ltd. Maturing April 10, 1992, the bond carries a 10 7/8 percent coupon and par price, with payment due April 9.

headline: Computer Plan in Japan
abstract: Japan will nearly double public spending, to $22 million in the fiscal year beginning April 1, on a project to develop a computer capable of speaking in several languages, Government officials said today.

headline: AND NOW, TELEVISED RECRUITING
abstract: ''WANT to be on the cutting edge of the new technology? Intrigued by analog signal processing? Or maybe you'd like to hear about our top- flight software-engineering team? If you answer yes,you may be the sort of person our company needs. Right now, we can't see you, but you can see us, so relax, watch the TV screen, and let us answer some of your questions.''   Approaches of this kind may well take place when college recruiters from high- technology companies gather in Washington for a nationally broadcast teleconference Oct. 9 and 10. The purpose of this meeting will be to recruit college students for positions at high-technology concerns. As one company representative put it, ''It will be a new high-tech way for high-tech companies to hire high-tech people.''

headline: 10 Die in Sri Lanka As Troops Fire at Crowd
abstract: Sri Lanka Air Force troops fired on a Tamil crowd in a northern town today, killing at least 10 people and wounding 25, official sources said.   A Defense Ministry communique said the slayings had occurred at Chunnakam, 200 miles northwest of Colombo.

headline: C.D. Rates Are Steady For the third consecutive week, average interest rates on money market accounts nationwide were unchanged at 8.49 percent, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.
abstract: Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, called the rates ''surprisingly stable. This is the longest period of little or no movement since we began tracking rates more than a year ago,'' he said.

headline: THE HIGH-TECH WAVE IN DISCLOSURE
abstract: WASHINGTON AMONG the busiest people at the    Securities and Exchange Commission are the legions of couriers who wait in the agency's corridors for copies of new tender offers or merger filings, and then race off with them to law offices or brokerage houses. But six months from now, if all goes according to plan, the S.E.C. will be taking its first steps toward an electronic filing and retrieval system. Instead of couriers, computers will do the scurrying.

headline: BRITISH LABOR FIREBRAND: KING OF THE COAL MINERS
abstract: ''One of the goals stated in our constitution is the abolition of capitalism,'' said Arthur Scargill, the president of the National Union of Mineworkers, ''so nobody should be surprised if we take militant stands.''    Mr. Scargill, the 45-year-old son and grandson of coal miners, is perhaps the most radical of key British trade union leaders. He is regularly reviled (and, he says, misrepresented) by the British newspapers. But he is also one of the most magnetic figures on the British left, capable of filling halls anywhere in the country; on a Sunday morning in January, with Yorkshire buried under two feet of snow, he drew 900 to a meeting near Cudworth.

headline: SENATE STUDY QUESTIONS A BUILDUP BY PENTAGON IN HONDURAS
abstract: Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that the Pentagon ''may be trying to subvert the Congress'' by building ''a military infrastructure in Honduras that is far beyond anything necessary for the military exercises being undertaken there.''    Senator Sasser, who is the ranking minority member of the Appropriations Committee's Military Construction Subcommittee, said a Senate staff investigation indicated that ''there is real evidence that our military is building airfields and other infrastructure to support a very large and possibly permanent United States military contingency there.''   He added, ''The construction going on down there has not been authorized by Congress.''

headline: ARGENTINA SETS LIMITS ON PROSECUTING THE MILITARY
abstract: President Raul Alfonsin won a political victory today when the Senate approved a bill limiting prosecutions of the military for the thousands of people killed and tortured in an antisubversion campaign in the 1970's.   The limits are a key to efforts by Mr. Alfonsin to prosecute former military leaders while protecting the armed forces as an institution. He was inaugurated two months ago after eight years of military rule, and his advisers have said vengeance could destabilize the country.   The bill reinforces the jurisdiction of military courts and provides protection for most servicemen who followed orders. As a guarantee against leniency by the military courts, the bill imposes review by civilian appeals courts.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Gannett Rochester Newspapers to Blair Advertising, a subsidiary of BBDO International.     * Samna Corp., Atlanta, a word-processing software company, to Gearon Hoffman Goransson, Atlanta.

headline: U.S. SAID TO BE LIMITED IN WAYS IT CAN AID IRAQ
abstract: The Reagan Administration has concluded that the defeat of Iraq by Iran would be a major setback to American interests but that there is little the United States can do to help Iraq directly, Administration officials said today.   The officials said a National Security Council study completed two months ago determined that despite concern here about Iraq's ability to continue to battle the Iranians, there should be no drastic change in American policy.   When the study was begun last fall, one official said, there was considerable anxiety in the Administration that Iraq was about to collapse. But in thelast month or so, he said, the situation has become calmer and a balance seems to have been struck between Iran and Iraq in the conflict that began in September 1980.

headline: Arrow Electronics
abstract: Arrow Electronics said today that it had filed a registration statement covering an offering of $60 million of subordinated debentures due in 2004. It said it expected the debentures to be offered later this month by Bear, Stearns & Company and L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

headline: RIO GRANDE IN TALKS WITH SUITORS
abstract: Rio Grande Industries, a railroad holding company with minor interests in trucking, real estate and computer time sharing, said yesterday that it was holding preliminary talks with other companies on being acquired.     Henry H. Livingston, the railroad analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, said the company most likely to bid for Rio Grande was the Southern Pacific Company, which recently merged with the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway Company.   Rio Grande, which has its headquarters in Denver, said it was uncertain whether any proposal would result from the talks, or if any bid would be at a premium over the current market price.

headline: Washington Watch; Fed Search Nearly Over
abstract: WASHINGTON   T HE White House, which is running late in its   search for a woman to succeed Nancy Teeters as one of the seven members of the Federal Reserve Board, is only a week or two away from sending a nomination to the Senate, according to insiders. The term of Mrs. Teeters expired Jan. 31, but she is continuing to serve until a successor is confirmed.    The front runner, according to some accounts, is Susan Schmitt Bies, 36 years old, an economist who is the treasurer of the Tennessee National Corporation in Memphis, which owns the First Tennessee Bank.    Senate Republicans, however, report that some White House officials are backing Annelise Anderson, 45, a strongly ideological conservative who served in the Office of Management and Budget in 1981-83. Her husband, Martin Anderson, served in the Reagan White House and has been actively promoting his wife's candidacy at the White House - which he visited only last Thursday - and among Senate Republicans, whose votes would be needed to confirm the nomination.

headline: Former Owner Returns To Whitney-Fidalgo Sam Rubinstein, who sold his Seattle fish processing company to the Japanese a decade ago, had expected to spend much of this winter golfing and playing tennis.
abstract: Instead, he has returned as chairman, president and chief executive of the company, Whitney-Fidalgo Seafoods Inc.    Mr. Rubinstein, 66, had sold Whitney in 1973 to a major customer, the Kyokuko Company Ltd. of Japan. ''But it has experienced considerable trouble recently,'' he said, including unpredictable fish runs, a botulism scare that hit the Alaskan salmon industry in 1982, and an oversupply of frozen salmon that brought a near- collapse of the market in Japan.    ''Kyokuko asked me to come back and help them out,'' he said, noting he did not leave the company's helm until 1977. ''I feel I owe this to Kyokuko, as my experience with them was one of the most fun parts of my life.''

headline: THE EUROPEAN BALANCING ACT
abstract: LONDON    G ENERALLY speaking, economic debate in both Europe and the United States focuses on the same basic issues. There is one enduring dispute in Europe, though, that rarely appears on the American scene: the battle over the proper balance between public and private ownership of industry.   Thanks to Europe's economic problems in the last decade, that debate has heated up again in most European nations. The recession and the industrial restructuring generated by it have led to state takeovers of numerous companies to prevent the job losses that would come with bankruptcy. At the same time, the economic troubles have persuaded millions of European voters that there are limits to how many social services they can afford to support. The result has been that politicians promising to limit Government spending have steadily gained power.

headline: SHIFTS AT CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS
abstract: David G. Taylor, vice chairman and chief financial officer of the Continental Illinois Corporation, today was named chairman and chief executive of the troubled bank holding company, succeeding Roger E. Anderson, 62, who retired under pressure from a group of independent directors.   Analysts said the move represented an attempt to end nearly two years of turbulence that began at Continental following the bank's tremendous losses from its association with the defunct Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City. Continental has been suffering from anemic profits and low morale. It has been losing market share to its rivals, and management attention has been diverted by brush fire after corporate brush fire.

headline: LUNDY ELECTRONICS & SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MOSCOW ISSUES A LAW ON OFFICIAL SECRETS
abstract: The Soviet Union has promulgated a new law providing prison terms for anyone passing economic, scientific, technical or other ''official'' secrets to foreigners.   The measure, which was published in the Gazette of the Supreme Soviet and which went into effect Wednesday, was added to existing laws against passing military or state secrets.   Western diplomats here said the newness of the measure made it difficult to assess the impact or breadth of the new law. But the Russian word for ''official'' used in describing information that could not be passed, ''sluzhebnaya,'' generally refers to anything associated with one's work and could encompass much of the information that a Soviet citizen might come across in his or her work.

headline: 5 European States Fault Ex-Regime in Turkey
abstract: The European Commission on Human Rights said today that five Western European nations had gathered enough evidence to indict Turkey's former military regime on charges of torturing prisoners and other violations of human rights.

headline: New Managing Editor Named For Foreign Affairs Quarterly
abstract: Peter Grose, a senior fellow in Middle Eastern studies at the Council of Foreign Relations, has been named managing editor of its quarterly Foreign Affairs, effective April 1, the council announced yesterday.   Mr. Grose, 49 years old, is a graduate of Yale University and author of the recent book ''Israel in the Mind of America.''

headline: MARCOS FAULTS U.S. ROLE IN PHILIPPINE POLITICS
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that Americans had ''no business'' in Philippine politics nor any say about who this country's President should be.   In a nationally televised campaign speech, Mr. Marcos ridiculed Filipino opposition leaders who go ''begging'' in the United States for an end to United States support of his Government.   Mr. Marcos spoke in the northern city of Baguio before a crowd estimated by Government television at 50,000 people. He urged supporters to vote for his ruling New Society Movement's candidates in the May 14 election to the 200-seat National Assembly.

headline: Morgan Guaranty Will End Survey
abstract: After almost 63 years, The Morgan Guaranty Survey, one of the nation's most erudite economic monthlies, will halt publication with the January issue, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has announced.   ''It wasn't an easy decision for anyone,'' said Milton W. Hudson, head of the bank's economic analysis department. Mr. Hudson, who had been in charge of the publication since 1951, said the bank had considered dropping the monthly for more than three years.

headline: SEEKING TO RESTORE THE MAGIC OF VW
abstract: WOLFSBURG, WEST GERMANY BEFORE dawn each day, a Volkswagen employee pulls up to Carl H. Hahn's white stucco villa in a suburb of Wolfsburg and delivers one of the company's shiny new cars - a different model each morning. Mr. Hahn test drives the cars as he commutes to work.     That's a new and unusual routine for the chairman of Volkswagenwerk A.G., the giant auto maker. A chauffeured limousine goes with the job, but Mr. Hahn has put that perk aside for a while to make what he undoubtedly considers better use of the morning commute to VW headquarters, five miles from his home in a Wolfsburg suburb.    Even when he travels abroad, the 57-year-old chairman pursues his new, hands-on interest in the driving qualities of various cars. In Detroit, for example, he'll rent a Ford or Plymouth at the airport. In Tokyo, it's usually a Mazda or Toyota.

headline: AMID BABEL IN BRUSSELS, TOUGH TALK
abstract: The European Community is like a big multinational corporation whose board of directors meets only four times a year and whose chief executive officer changes every six months.    When the directors - the heads of the 10 member governments - assemble for their quarterly meetings, as they did here this afternoon, the agenda is always too long and the mood is often uncomfortably tense. Only if thorough and skillful preparatory work has been done do the national leaders have much chance of success, and even then they sometimes fail.   These two-day sessions follow a ritual as elaborate and as unchanging as a Japanese tea ceremony. Each gathering begins at midday Monday with a business luncheon, followed by a group photograph and a first four-hour work period. Then comes an elaborate dinner in some splendid hall - tonight's took place in the Salle Gothique of the Ch^ateau Val Duchesse, where much of the 1957 Treaty of Rome, creating the Common Market, was drafted - with the leaders talking informally afterward.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: People     *  David M. Levi appointed president and chief executive officer of Promotion Works, the sales promotion subsidiary of Campbell-Mithun, Minneapolis.     *  Tina Santi Flaherty joining the GTE Corporation, Stamford, Conn., as vice president for public affairs.

headline: I.C.I. Feed Deal
abstract: Imperial Chemical Industries is discussing the sale of its Pruteen animal feed technology to the Soviet Union, an I.C.I. spokesman said.

headline: Yields Rise For C.D.'s
abstract: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit and money market deposit accounts climbed nationwide yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.   The Monitor's national index of six- month C.D.'s, based on a survey of 50 major institutions in the five largest area markets, was 9.68 percent, up from 9.56 percent last week.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: March 12, 1984   GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Special Committee on Enhancing the Nonuse of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.   ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Population Commission Preparatory Committee for the International Conference on Population - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Intergovernmental Working Group of Experts on International Standards of Accounting and Reporting - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: U.N. OFFICIAL ASSERTS CHINA WASTES HALF OF ITS FOOD OUTPUT
abstract: China could export large quantities of food to needy nations if it did not waste almost half of its food supplies because of antiquated storage methods, the head of the World Food Council said today.   The official, Canada's Agriculture Minister, Eugene Whelan, who visited China in his capacity as head of the council, said China wasted almost 50 percent of its food for lack of proper post-harvest storage of soybeans, corn and other grains.

headline: U.S. URGED TO RECONSIDER UNESCO MOVE
abstract: The Secretary General of Unesco, in a letter to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, has expressed the hope that the United States ''after reconsidering the whole situation, will decide to remain in Unesco'' and give it ''full and whole- hearted cooperation.''   In his first public response to the announcement Dec. 29 of Washington's intention to withdraw from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, its Secretary General, Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, ''emphasized the need to maintain the universality of the Organization.''   While sometimes delegates ''express opposing points of view,'' Mr. M'Bow said, and may ''endeavor to gain acceptance for those positions,'' this made it only ''more essential to seek out the common ground on which consensus can be reached.''

headline: Nigeria Gives OPEC Pledge
abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has received a pledge from Nigeria's new rulers that the African member country will support OPEC's price structure, the organization's news agency reported today.   The pledge appeared to respond to speculation by many oil industry experts that Nigeria, which is under pressure to raise cash to reduce a huge foreign debt, might undercut the OPEC price structure to increase its share of the world oil market.

headline: INCENTIVE STOCK OPTIONS SUBJECT TO NEW TAXES
abstract: Many executives endowed with incentive stock options may soon discover that these most cherished of company perks, already eroded by new Federal laws, are being subjected to higher state taxes as well. Sometimes, the state tax bite is worse.    In leafing through 1983 income tax return booklets, executives who work in New York City will learn that the state and city have quietly followed the lead of the Federal Government in taxing some individuals who exercised incentive stock options last year. Even executives who escape Washington's alternative minimum tax on such options may find themselves facing state and city tax obligations.

headline: EX-GRENADIAN INFORMER STILL BACKS THE CAUSE
abstract: The small, solidly built man of 20 said he had been an informer for the People's Revolutionary Government of Grenada and was proud of his contribution to the revolution.   The Government, headed by Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, was ousted days before the United States invasion Oct. 25, and the one-time informer, Claude James, is now an idler without a job. He now sees, he said, that the leaders of Mr. Bishop's Government made errors.   But Mr. James added, ''From what I have learned, I know a revolution never dies.''

headline: Christina Onassis Married
abstract: Christina Onassis, 33 years old, heiress to a Greek shipping fortune, was married today to Thierry Roussel, 31, a French businessman.

headline: AMBIVALENCE ON THE DOLLAR
abstract: The recent sharp rise in the value of the dollar is bolstering American imports of goods from Western Europe. This gives a modest boost to depressed European economies and lessens earlier fears that the higher cost of some of Europe's imports would prevent an economic upturn.     The higher the dollar soars, however, the more European monetary officials and bankers worry that it may suffer a dangerous fall later in the year and that such a fall might knock the whole world back into recession again.   European central bank governors agreed at their monthly meeting in Basel, Switzerland, last Monday that they do not have the resources to stem the dollar's surge by selling dollars in foreign- exchange markets.

headline: WESTERN EUROPE ENDS INDUSTRIAL TRADE CURBS
abstract: The last barriers to complete industrial free trade between 17 West European nations disappeared today.    The result is a single free trade area covering the 10 members of the European Economic Community and the 7 members of the European Free Trade Association. The 17 countries together have a combined market of some 310 million consumers, which is about 25 percent bigger than the American domestic market.   The free trade area came into being at midnight with the ending of an agreement first signed in 1972. That accord progressively eliminated all industrial trade barriers between the Common Market and the seven E.F.T.A. countries - Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Portugal, Sweden and Switzerland.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Head of Vector Resigns
abstract: A co-founder of the loss-plagued Vector Graphic Inc., Lore Harp, announced her resignation yesterday as president, chief executive and a director.   Bernard Horn, a former vice president of Xerox, was named president and chief executive of the computer company, which he will join April 2.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, JANUARY 20, 1984   The Economy    The F.C.C. voted to delay until 1985 imposing access charges on telephone users for links to long-distance networks. The commission cited pressure from the public and Congress. As a result, A.T.& T. will probably cancel much or all of the rate cuts of 10 percent to 15 percent that it had planned on long-distance services. The agency's decision was praised by the White House. (Page A1.) It was a partial victory for the host of A.T.& T.'s smaller competitors seeking a share of the long-distance market. (D4.)

headline: SALVADOR GUERRILLAS SAID TO FREE 162 SOLDIERS CAPTURED LAST WEEK
abstract: Guerrillas who overran an army base have released 162 of the soldiers they captured, according to religious workers and other residents of this village north of the installation.    Fewer than a dozen soldiers, most of them middle-ranking officers, were said to be still in guerrilla hands. A priest here said he expected them to be released soon.   The base, in the northern province of Chalatenango, was held by the rebels for 12 hours before they withdrew last Friday. It was the first of two major defeats for the Salvadoran military in three days. On Sunday rebels routed guard troops and destroyed the heavily fortified Cuscatlan bridge that linked four eastern provinces with the rest of the country.

headline: ISRAELIS POISED AT POST NEAR SYRIANS
abstract: A mountain peak here about 6,000 feet above sea level serves as the eyes and ears of the Israeli military.    The radar dome above the concrete headquarters reaches to Damascus, the Syrian capital, and beyond. To the northeast, the northern reaches of the Bekaa, Lebanon's strategic valley, lie dappled in sunlight and shadow. To the northwest loom the Shuf Mountains, and on a clear day Beirut is visible. To the southeast, Mount Hermon clothed in snow overlooks both Syria and Lebanon.

headline: Data Bank; March 4, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: REPORTS OF INSIDER TRADING
abstract: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.   The reports of changes follow:  NEW YORK EXCHANGE      EG&G INC.

headline: SOVIET JOINS ETHIOPIA IN CRITICIZING U.S.
abstract: Konstantin U. Chernenko pledged continued aid to Ethiopia today and joined the visiting Ethiopian leader, Mengistu Haile Mariam, in accusing the United States of interfering in African affairs.   At a dinner for Mr. Mengistu, who arrived today on a three-day visit, Mr. Chernenko also said the United States was posing as a champion of peace while disregarding Soviet peace initiatives and waging an undeclared war against Nicaragua.   The welcome given Mr. Mengistu and the attacks on the United States were seen as attempts to balance what some diplomats viewed as setbacks to Soviet influence in Africa in the form of the recent accords between South Africa and Mozambique and Angola.   The Soviet position is that the agreements reflect South Africa's recognition of the strength of the two black- ruled countries.

headline: Market Place; Searching For Secure Investment
abstract: G IVEN the recent problems with Washington Public Power Supply System bonds, Baldwin-United annuities and utility stocks destroyed by nuclear plant cost overruns, where should conservative investors put their money? Even the ultimate ''widow and orphan'' stock, American Telephone and Telegraph, has been split into eight unknown issues.    Analysts at six of the national securities firms catering to the public were asked how they would invest $75,000 to $100,000 for the security- conscious person seeking steady income and some capital appreciation.       Agreement among analysts is rare, and that is what makes a market. In this case, however, the general feeling was that only 30 percent to 50 percent of the portfolio should be in stocks, including select utilities, a few A.T.& T. spinoffs and other relatively stable issues. The rest of the money, these analysts said, belongs in fixed-income securities, primarily intermediate-term Treasury issues, and the balance in a money market mutual fund.

headline: Advertising; An Agency Devoted to High Tech
abstract: T HE Muir Cornelius Moore agency's clients bunch up in the   financial services, high technology and health care fields. And the way William P. Muir, the 43-year-old chairman and chief executive, tells the story, that is just the way he planned it.    He said he made those plans just prior to the agency's founding in 1976, when he was between formal jobs and serving as a consultant.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: S.E.C. Commissioner Returning to Law Firm Bevis Longstreth, a Wall Street lawyer who has been serving as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced yesterday that he had decided to return to his old law firm, Debevoise & Plimpton.     ''I looked at a lot of different things and I decided to come back here,'' Mr. Longstreth said. ''It provides me with the best opportunity to remain active and continue to say something about the intersection of government and business. I did that as a commissioner and it's somewhat addictive.''

headline: ECONOMY IS LOOKING UP IN MONTREAL
abstract: After years of bad economic news, things may be improving in this largest French-speaking city outside Paris. The Banque Nationale and Bell Canada are building shining office towers, the stock market is gaining on Toronto's, and the lines at the unemployment office seem shorter.     There are still signs of an unhappy economic past, of course. The ponderous Sun Life Building - once the largest office building in the British Commonwealth - is now only partly occupied, squat testimony to the many companies that have joined Sun Life in an exodus to Toronto.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Commodore Fills Tramiel's Position    Commodore International Ltd. said yesterday that Marshall F. Smith had been named president and chief executive to succeed Jack Tramiel, who resigned suddenly Friday after having put Commodore at the top of the home computer market.    Mr. Smith, 54 years old, is president and chief executive of Thyssen- Bornemisza Inc., formerly Indian Head Inc., a diversified industrial company. Mr. Smith was named president of Indian Head in 1974 before it became a unit of Thyssen- Bornemisza N.V. of the Netherlands, one of Europe's biggest industrial corporations.

headline: SOVIET BUILDUP IN FAR EAST CAUSING U.S. CONCERN
abstract: Military   Analysis      The Navy has stepped up its surveillance of Soviet military bases at Cam Ranh Bay and Da Nang in Vietnam, according to United States and Asian military officials and diplomats.  The action comes at a time of growing concern in the United States, Japan and some Southeast Asian capitals over the expansion of Soviet land, sea and air power from Vietnam north to Siberia.   The Soviet Navy, American officials emphasize, has maintained major forces at Vladivostok and other Far Eastern ports since the end of World War II. But these ports, while well positioned for operations against Japan or China, are distant from the South China Sea and the shipping lanes that run from the Persian Gulf and the Middle East to Japan.

headline: ANOTHER GAMBLE FOR THE PRITZKERS
abstract: Marylin Bender writes on business from New York.             N EXT Thursday at Dallas/Fort Worth Regional Airport, a phoenix is scheduled to rise from the ashes of bankruptcy. After a hiatus of nearly 22 months, Braniff's 727's, their jellybean-colored exteriors repainted in a red, white, blue and silver design, will begin service to 18 United States cities.    Among the passengers aboard the inaugural flight to Chicago, his home town, will be Jay A. Pritzker, 61, chairman of Braniff, who saved the airline just as it seemed headed for final liquidation. Even before the sun rises that same day, his 88-year-old father, Abram N. Pritzker, will be on Braniff's first flight to New Orleans. He will be checking out other Pritzker businesses, including the Superdome sports arena.

headline: Home Loan Rates Down
abstract: Interest rates on home loans offered by lenders declined in February for the sixth consecutive month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.    These were the average rates last month:      - 13.71 percent for fixed-rate loans of at least 25 years' maturity with the loan making up 75 percent of the purchase price - up from January's 13.85 percent.      - 11.88 percent for adjustable-rate mortgages with limits on how much the rate can be raised - down from 12 percent.      - 12.24 percent for adjustable-rate loans with no limits - down from 12.33 percent

headline: LONG ON CONFIDENCE
abstract: FELIX FLORES has one overriding principle about stock market investing - go short-term. It's hard to argue with him, because such a strategy paid off handsomely last year. The business manager for KMGG- FM, a Los Angeles radio station, he turned a $3,000 investment into $6,000 between March and June. It was the first time the 27-year-old Mr. Flores ever bought stocks and thus he fits into the New York Stock Exchange's category of new young investors who have entered the market recently with modest portfolios.

headline: A PRICE 'GUARANTEE' IN NUCLEAR UNIT BID
abstract: The Washington Public Power Supply System received a proposal today from three large contractors who want to complete - for a firm or ''fixed'' price - a nuclear unit on which construction halted last summer. The contractors said they could ''absolutely guarantee'' to do the job for less than the $1.5 billion the system budgeted for completing the unit.   It would be the first time since the 1960's that anyone has offered to bring a nuclear reactor on line for a specific price. Inflation and regulatory changes have led to soaring costs, and delayed plants nationally.

headline: BIG IRANIAN OFFENSIVE IS THOUGHT TO HAVE STARTED
abstract: The military high command announced today that Iranian forces were about to begin a major offensive. An informed Iraqi source said the announcement meant the offensive was under way.    The sector in which Iranian troops were said to be staging their attack was not specified by the military command. Iraqi commanders have said in recent briefings that Iranian forces were massing east of the southern city of Basra. A foreign journalist now in Basra reported that the port city of more than a million people was still being shelled frequently.

headline: IRISH QUICKLY HAND TERRORIST TO BRITISH
abstract: The Irish police today extradited Dublin's most-wanted terrorist, captured Saturday after a shootout with police, to British authorities in Northern Ireland.    The extradition sets an important precedent in London-Dublin relations. Until now, the Irish courts and government have balked at extraditing fugitives from Northern Ireland who held that their crimes were politically motivated acts against the British Government and its security forces. The condition has antagonized relations between Dublin and London and has led British loyalists in the province to assert that the Irish Republic was a sanctuary for terrorists.

headline: U.S. TELLS ISRAELIS IT WILL AGAIN SEEK JORDANIAN FORCE
abstract: The Reagan Administration has told Israel that it intends to try again to supply Jordan with equipment for an 8,000- man force for use in emergencies in the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said today.   The latest plan is similar to last year's effort to supply equipment worth $220 million to Jordan through secret financing in the Defense Department budget. That effort was blocked by Congress.   This time some changes are planned that Administration officials said they believed might make the deal possible. One reason is that Israel now seems willing to reserve judgment on the arrangement; another is that the secrecy is expected to be ended.

headline: Barclays Net Off 12% in '83
abstract: Barclays Bank P.L.C., one of Britain's big four clearing banks, said today that increasing taxes and debt payments caused its profits to decline 12 percent in 1983, to $428 million.

headline: 8,000 U.S. Marines Set Sail For 3-Week NATO War Games
abstract: About 8,000 United States marines sailed today for a three-week NATO exercise in the North Atlantic.   Most of the marines left Morehead City today in amphibious ships, a Navy spokesman said.

headline: From Sales at Mattel To Owning Intellivision
abstract: Terrence E. Valeski, senior vice president of marketing and sales at Mattel Inc., says that until two weeks ago, he was not aware that Mattel's troubled electronics division was for sale. Now he is about to become chairman and president of the spunoff unit.   Mr. Valeski, 37, is the head of a small group of investors who agreed last week to pay $20 million for the rights to the Intellivision name and all the unit's finished goods and work in progress and development. The new company will not assume liabilities or take over receivables.

headline: BRAZIL IS STUDYING USE OF HERBICIDES
abstract: Brazilian officials have begun investigating whether the use of herbicides to clear a strip of jungle for a power transmission line may have played a role in the deaths of 40 settlers in the Amazon region two years ago.   Farmers in Tailandia and other communities close to the power line in the state of Para were reportedly affected by some epidemic or poisoning between December 1981 and June 1982, but the extent of their problems has only recently become known.   The high-voltage transmission line was laid in the late 1970's and early 80's from the Sobradinho dam on the Sao Francisco River to Belem in an effort to reduce the condumption of costly petroleum products in Para state.   Tailandia settlers said in newspaper interviews that, after bathing in nearby streams, members of their family fell ill, with some slipping into a coma and dying days later. Some women reported spontaneous abortions, headaches, stomach pains and swollen joints.

headline: TRUDEAU DECLARES HE'LL STEP DOWN AS PRIME MINISTER
abstract: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced today that he had decided to resign after more than 15 years as head of the Canadian Government. He said it was ''the appropriate time for someone else to assume this challenge.''   Mr. Trudeau, 64 years old, whose fondness for the dramatic gesture has been as characteristic of him as the red rose he habitually wears in his lapel, made his announcement during a paralyzing snowstorm and while Parliament was in recess. But he did not do so in any public appearance.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  The Export Development Corp. of Canada's $150 million issue of 11 1/8 percent Eurobonds due in 1989 was priced at par through Credit Suisse/ First Boston Ltd.     *  Chrysler Corp.  said its Chrysler Financial Corp. unit had filed for $300 million of medium-term notes with maturities of up to six years from the date of issue. The notes are to be offered through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Mitterrand's E.E.C. Plea
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France urged the 10 nations of the European Economic Community today to make compromises to facilitate reforming the nearly bankrupt community.   ''I am working hard for the success of the European Community,'' President Mitterrand said after a luncheon meeting with Prime Minister Wilfried Martens of Belgium, and the Belgian Foreign Minister, Leo Tindemans.

headline: AIRBUS WINS SUPPORT FROM BRITISH ON A230
abstract: The last piece needed for Airbus Industrie to formally commit itself to building the A320, a new 150-seat aircraft, fell into place today when Britain announced it would provide $370 million in loans toward British Aerospace's initial costs in the project.   Earlier commitments from the West German, French and Spanish Governments to invest in the $2 billion project had made it likely that it would have been undertaken even without British participation, but British Aerospace's agreement to make the wings has made the 1988 delivery target feasible.   The A320 will give Airbus Industrie, an international consortium, the only all-new plane in the market for medium-range jets. But McDonnell Douglas is competing for the same market with its 150-seat DC-9-80, a modernized version of its DC-9, which has been in service for about two years, and the Boeing Corporation has a 140- seat 737-700, an improved version of the 737, which it is now test-flying.

headline: P.S.C. CALLS AREA PHONE SERVICE POORER
abstract: The quality and reliability of telephone service in the New York City area has worsened in the last year, according to the State Public Service Commission. The deterioration, which has become of increasing concern to the commission, is only partly related to the breakup of the Bell System, according to commission reports.   Preliminary figures supplied by the state agency indicate that customers reported far more trouble with the New York Telephone Company's system in the last three months of 1983 than in the comparable period in 1982. And the agency says that trouble reports have been increasing in the last several years.

headline: SHORT-TERM RATES OFF SLIGHTLY
abstract: Credit markets turned in a mixed performance yesterday, with short- term rates falling slightly, while yields on long-term bonds were about unchanged.     ''The markets continued to suffer from a general lack of investor presence,'' said Maria Ramirez, a financial economist at Merrill Lynch Economics. In addition to the heavy supply of recently auctioned Treasury notes and bonds, market participants said, prices would have a hard time rising because many investors fear that the strong growth of the economy and some measures of the money supply might cause the Federal Reserve to adopt a slightly tighter monetary policy in coming weeks.    In the money markets, the fear of a Fed tightening has caused rates to rise recently, despite small declines in yesterday's trading. At yesterday's auctions of new Treasury bills, rates were the highest since early September, with the three-month issue averaging 9.13 percent, up from 9.04 percent a week ago and 8.87 percent Jan. 30, while the six-month issue averaged 9.28 percent, up from 9.16 percent a week ago and 8.97 percent on Jan. 30.

headline: Handcrafts Unit
abstract: The Greyhound Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Armour Handcrafts Inc. unit to a group of investors headed by J. Keith Louden of New York.

headline: ANALYSTS FAVOR LOWES CORP.
abstract: -priced    issue on the New York Stock Exchange, has   given up some ground this week along with many other equities. Yesterday, its shares fell 1 1/2 points, to 191, after dropping 5 3/4 points Monday.   But Loews rose 6 1/4 points last week after trading at a record price of 200 1/2. And since mid-August, when it sold at 152, the stock has performed far better than the general market.   Loews is classified as a multi-industry company, or a conglomerate, in Wall Street's terminology. Its varied operations range from cigarettes and insurance to consumer finance and hotels and theaters.

headline: NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Article 158151 -- No Title
abstract: A Presidential commission is moving toward agreement on a recommendation that the United States give $1 billion a year in economic and military aid to Central America over the next 10 to 15 years, commission officials said today.   If the aid package now under discussion is finally approved, it would roughly double the current level of $482 million in economic and military aid to El Salvador, Honduras and Costa Rica, and would signal a major long-term American commitment to support the region.    At present, aid has been cut off to Nicaragua and Guatemala. The commission would continue the ban on aid to Nicaragua, but it is unclear what it would do for Guatemala.

headline: SUDAN ASKS ACTION BY U.N. IN BOMBING
abstract: The Foreign Minister of the Sudan called on the Security Council today to condemn Libya for its aerial attack earlier this month on the town of Omdurman in which five people were killed.   Mohammed Mirghani Mubarak said that on the morning of March 16 a TU-22 bomber from the Libyan military base at Kufra attacked ''civilian targets,'' dropping five bombs on the most heavily populated town in the Sudan, and then returned to Libya. Mr. Mubarak said that ''Libya's act was one in a chain of aggression against the Sudan.''   Libya's Foreign Minister, Ali A. Treiki, said that there was not ''a single piece of evidence'' against Libya and that the charges were ''baseless.'' Mr. Treiki added that the Sudanese allegations were ''fabricated'' by the Sudanese Government to justify the dispatch of American Awacs surveillance aircraft.

headline: SOHIO WRITE OFF 2 BEAUFORT TRACTS
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said yesterday that it would take a fourth-quarter after-tax write-off of $163 million after having failed to find oil in what was considered a promising tract off Alaska's North Slope.   The company said it was writing off its interest in two tracts in the Beaufort Sea, most of its interest in two other tracts and its investment in a man-made gravel island used to drill a test well that turned out to contain salt water and only small traces of oil and natural gas.   Following Sohio's announcement, the British Petroleum Company announced from London that it was taking a write-off of about $:100 million, or about $142 million, in the fourth quarter for certain of its leases over the Mukluk Basin.

headline: Data Bank; February 19, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: U.N.'S RIGHTS BODY PROBLEM FOR WEST
abstract: When Nguyen Thuong of Vietnam took the floor in Geneva a few days ago to complain about human rights violations around the world, he seemed to embody one of the most difficult quandaries of the United Nations.   Mr. Thuong was speaking at the annual six-week session of the Human Rights Commission, which finished its work last week. He praised Argentina for saying it would respect human rights, he denounced Guatemala and El Salvador for ''crimes against humanity'' and he contended that the United States was trying to impose ''imperialist domination'' in Central America.

headline: Trade Gap in Denmark
abstract: Denmark's balance of trade swung to a deficit of $134 million in February after a surplus of $76 million a year earlier, the Government's Bureau of Statistics said in a preliminary report today. It was Denmark's third consecutive monthly deficit.

headline: Zambia's Capital Rocked By Student Riots
abstract: More than 2,000 students rampaged through Lusaka today, stoning pedestrians and overturning cars to protest the arrests of their union leaders, police and student sources said.   The police said several passers-by were injured and seven vehicles badly damaged in the riot, which capped several weeks of tension between the students and the administration at the University of Zambia.

headline: Bell Divestiture a Boon For Interline Executive
abstract: For Paul J. Lee, divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has been a personal boon.     ''Judge Greene really helped my career,'' Mr. Lee said yesterday. referring to Harold H. Greene, the Federal judge who oversaw the breakup of the Bell System.    Mr. Lee, 47, is president of Interline Communications Services Inc., a newly formed unit of U S West, one of the seven regional operating companies formed in the Bell breakup. U S West, based in Denver, is the parent of Mountain Bell, Northwestern Bell and Pacific Northwest Bell.

headline: Farm Bond Sale Due Next Week
abstract: The Federal Farm Credit Banks yesterday announced plans to sell about $1.3 billion of new bonds next week.

headline: Article 218821 -- No Title
abstract: In the $305.7 billion military budget presented to Congress today, the Administration asked for $107.6 billion in authority to order weapons and equipment.    Of the total, $32.8 billion would be spent in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 if Congress approves. Another $95.8 billion would be spent from funds appropriated by Congress in the past.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Careers; Wanted: Law Firm Managers
abstract: THERE is a new type of business    executive in growing demand -   the law firm administrator - and management recruiters are having a field day filling requests for such nonlegal expertise.    In the old days, even as recently as the 1960's and 1970's, law firms usually assigned one partner to spend part or all of his or her time managing the organization's business. The duties included sending out bills and collecting payments; buying equipment ranging from law books to paper clips, and managing the nonlegal staff.    Today, computer-age complexities have increasingly caught up with law firms. Many already use computer terminals for word processing, research and accounting. Teleconferencing is also on the rise to speed communication and reduce travel, as is the use of electronic mail.

headline: American Equity
abstract: American Equity Investment Trust said it had entered into a memorandum of understanding with George K. Baum Properties Inc. to sell all of its assets, including 18 real estate projects, some mortgage receivables and other items for $62.4 million. The sale is contingent on, among other things, the buyer's inspection of the assets and a definitive agreement by April 30. In over- the-counter trading today, American Equity jumped $1.75, to $20.50 bid.

headline: JAPANESE OFFICIAL IN U.S. FOR TALKS WITH BUSH
abstract: Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe arrived here today for meetings with Vice President Bush and other Cabinet officers as part of a continuing effort to resolve differences in military and economic policies between Japan and the United States.   A senior State Department official, in a briefing for reporters, outlined topics for discussion but indicated that no new agreements were expected except for a renewed accord intended to increase American companies' access to Japan's telecommunications market.   The other issues were expected to fall into a negotiating pattern that has evolved over the last 25 years, in which Washington puts pressure on the Japanese to make concessions and Japan concedes enough to resolve the issue with the least political cost at home.

headline: GEMAYEL NOTIFIES FOES HE WILL END PACT WITH ISRAEL
abstract: Bodies of more than 100 civilians were found by Druse militiamen in a village where they said a massacre occurred five months ago. Page A11.           BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 16 - President Amin Gemayel sent word to his Syrian-backed opponents tonight that he would cancel the 1983 agreement with Israel in exchange for their agreeing to enter reconciliation talks with his Government.   Senior Government officials said he acted after coming to realize that the United States could not save his deteriorating regime with military support. They said Mr. Gemayel directed Foreign Minister Elie Salem tonight to take an eight-point plan signed by the President to Saudi Arabia, which sponsored the plan.

headline: Tonka Dismisses Aide
abstract: The Tonka Corporation announced yesterday that it had dismissed L. Martin LeBus, its senior vice president and chief financial officer, because he ''made an apparently unauthorized and improper investment of $2 million of company funds.''   A woman who answered the phone at Mr. LeBus's residence in Minnetonka, Minn., said that he would not comment on his dismissal or on the allegations by Tonka, a toy manufacturer based in Spring Park, Minn.

headline: INDIAN CAR INDUSTRY MOVES INTO THE FAST LANE
abstract: The scene at an automobile showroom in downtown New Delhi recently seemed more reminiscent of the United States than India.   ''Leg room? It's got plenty of leg room,'' a salesman told a prospective customer, while half a dozen others peered under the hood. Women scanned the interior. Everyone kicked the tires.

headline: 2 GREEK NEWS EXECUTIVES GUILTY OF LIBELING WRITER
abstract: A Greek court sentenced the publisher and the editor of Greece's largest newspaper today to four months in jail for libeling the author of a book that characterized them as Soviet ''agents of influence,'' a court spokesman said.   The defendants, Alexander Filipopoulos, the editor of Ethnos, and George Bobolas, its publisher, were given the option of paying $360 fines instead of serving jail terms.   At the same time, the author, Paul Anastasiades, a Cypriot-born journalist, claimed and was granted symbolic damages of $10.   Mr. Anastasiades, 33 years old, sued Mr. Filipopoulos and Mr. Bobolas on the ground that they libeled him in an Ethnos article describing his book, ''Take the Nation in Your Hands,'' as a ''pseudo-book.''

headline: CITICORP SHAKES UP CHICAGO
abstract: The executives sent here six weeks ago by Citicorp to merge the $4 billion First Federal Savings and Loan Association into the bank holding company have barely unpacked, but already there are signs of the changes they promise to bring to banking here.   In a series of moves aimed at building the ailing thrift unit into a major banking force in Chicago, Citicorp officials have cut its mortgage lending rates, raised deposit rates and aggressively promoted a wide range of new and traditional services. At the same time, a well-coordinated advertising and public relations blitz has kept Citicorp's name before the public as First Federal's new owners.   The moves appear to be paying off. Citicorp officials say that First Federal's mortgage loan applications are up sharply and that new deposits are on the rise. And competing bankers concede that Citicorp has quickly won high visibility in the Chicago market.

headline: PARTIAL VICTORY FOR SMALLER COMPETITORS
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday handed a partial victory to the host of smaller competitors battling the giant American Telephone and Telegraph Company for a share of the long-distance market.     The commission's new plan would require those companies, which include the MCI Communications Corporation and GTE-Sprint, to pay 55 percent less than A.T.& T. does for a connection to the local telephone company's switching center.   Under the previous F.C.C. plan, the discount would have been either 22 percent or 35 percent, depending on whether one accepts the viewpoint of the competitors or the commission.    The decision will help the competitors keep their rates below those of A.T.& T., which is necessary if they are to recruit customers. The companies had contended that the earlier F.C.C. plan could put them out of business.

headline: Sale of Cuban Debt
abstract: A subsidiary of the American Express Company, the Trade Development Bank, sold about $1.75 million of Cuban debt to the National Bank of Canada, a small bank in Montreal, to allow a rescheduling of Cuba's debts to proceed, a Credit Lyonnais spokesman said today. American Express said Monday that requests for United States Treasury approval to take part in the rescheduling had been refused. Credit Lyonnais, which led the commercial bank debt talks, announced agreement on rescheduling terms on Dec. 23, but said signature would be delayed for a few days because of a problem not related to the restructuring.

headline: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF 2.4 MILLION SHARES
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest was off 1.2 percent, or 2.4 million shares, in the month ended Jan. 13, to 203.2 million shares. The record of 205.6 million shares was set last month. The short interest for the period a year earlier totaled 127.3 million shares.   In the latest period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange fell 1,002,161 shares, to 14.4 million shares.    A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale.

headline: Moscow Calls for Talks To Curtail Maneuvers
abstract: The Soviet Union said today that it was ready to negotiate agreements on limiting military maneuvers in Europe, one of the goals of the 35-nation conference here on security and disarmament.   Western delegates pointed out that, in presenting the Soviet proposals, Oleg A. Grinevsky, the Soviet chief delegate, did not say whether Moscow would accept observers to verify such agreements.

headline: ORDER CUT BY I.B.M. JOLTS STOCKS
abstract: A major supplier of disk drives for a model of International Business Machines' Personal Computer announced yesterday that I.B.M. had reduced its orders for the data storage devices.    The news set off a flurry of selling in the stock of the disk drive manufacturer, the Miniscribe Corporation, and raised concern about whether I.B.M. was experiencing slackening demand or production problems for its computer. Although I.B.M. said there were no problems, its stock and that of many of its suppliers tumbled anyway.

headline: REBEL SAYS VOTE ISN'T A TARGET
abstract: A spokesman for the insurgents in El Salvador said today that the national election Sunday ''will not be a military target'' for guerrillas.    The spokesman, Ruben Zamora, thus took issue in an interview here with recent warnings by the State Department and the Salvadoran Government that insurgents might be planning to terrorize voters and disrupt the election.   Mr. Zamora said that 70 to 90 of El Salvador's 251 municipalities were in guerrilla hands. ''There will be no election there,'' he said.

headline: Iraqi Planes Attack Iranian Positions
abstract: Iraqi warplanes today mounted their first attack on Iranian positions in a month, striking at troop concentrations in the central sector of the Persian Gulf war front, the High Command said.   The Iraqi jets mounted heavy attacks, scoring ''direct and effective hits'' and suffering no losses, it said in a communique.   The last Iraqi air raid was on Dec. 15, against the city of Ilam in southwestern Iran and the border town of Dehloran in what a military spokesman said was retaliation for bomb blasts in Kuwait on Dec. 12.

headline: Rally in a Brazilian City Asks Direct Elections of President
abstract: Tens of thousands of people staged a peaceful rally here Friday demanding that Brazil abolish its electoral college system and return to direct elections of the President.

headline: Texas Company Loses Chairman to Thrift Unit
abstract: The American Century Corporation of San Antonio said yesterday that its board had accepted the resignation of John H. Roberts Jr. as chairman and chief executive.     Mr. Roberts said he was resigning to devote full time to the management of the Summit Savings Association, a savings and loan institution in Plano, Tex., that he recently bought.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * American General Corp.  said its NLT Corp. unit would redeem all of its outstanding 8.80 percent notes due May 1, 1985, on April 27, 1984, at a price of 104.302 percent.     * Beneficial Corp.  said it had filed for a shelf offering of up to $500 million in debt securities on terms to be determined at the time of sale.     * Genrad Inc.  announced the signing of a $100 million revolving credit and term loan agreement with Bank of New England, Citibank, Chase Manhattan Bank and Security Pacific National Bank.     * Nordstrom Inc. , a specialty retailer in Seattle, said it was offering $50 million of 13 1/8 percent notes due March 15, 1994, at 100 percent of their principal amount through the First Boston Corporation.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Portable Cabin   An automobile mechanic who likes to travel with his family invented a portable cabin.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Executives
abstract: * Belding Heminway Co., a manufacturer of industrial threads and specialty fabrics, has elected to its board Louis J. Lefkowitz, former Attorney General of New York State.   * Communications Corp. of America, Dallas, an independent telecommunications company, has named W. Ronald Castleman vice president of administration.

headline: AMERICAN IN BONN FINDS CLOUD IN NATO'S FUTURE
abstract: Ambassador Arthur F. Burns conceded to an audience in Hamburg last year that he found diplomacy ''a universe inordinately filled with gossip, emotion and even suspicion - a world in which perception of facts often obscure facts themselves.''   With a touch of nostalgia, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said that by comparison, international finance was a familiar terrain of ''relative order and predictability.''   In two and a half years on the job here, Mr. Burns, 79 years old, has lived through the unpredictabilities of a power transfer from Chancellor Helmut Schmidt to Chancellor Helmut Kohl and an emotional debate over American missiles and national security.   A wrenching time for many West Germans, the experience has not ruffled the American envoy's inclination to intellectual orderliness and candor - traits that have delighted, and sometimes startled, Bonn's political class.

headline: U.S. Plans D-Day Statue
abstract: Ambassador Evan Galbraith today accepted a parcel of land in Normandy for a statue to be erected to commemorate the D-Day landing of United States forces at Utah Beach in World War II. The parcel of 30 acres is at the village of St. Marie du Mont, where the Fourth Infantry Division landed in 1944.

headline: A FED GOVERNOR PONDERS THE PAST
abstract: WASHINGTON T   HE Board of Governors of the   Federal Reserve is losing one of   its more frequent dissenters - Nancy Hays Teeters. The 53-year-old economist, who has spent more than 25 years in Washington working for such agencies as the Office of Management and Budget and the Council of Economic Advisers, was the first women to serve as a Fed governor.    Mrs. Teeters was appointed by President Jimmy Carter in 1978, when she was chief economist for the House Budget Committee, and was seen as one of the more liberal members of the Fed. In her more than five years on the board, she often disagreed with monetary policy decisions, particularly when she thought the Fed was pushing interest rates too high.    However, despite her dissents, she generally went along with the central bank's tight monetary policy of the early 1980's, having decided that the less stringent Fed policies of the 1970's had not been successful in curbing inflation.

headline: SOCAL SEES DANGER IN A MERGER CURB
abstract: The head of the Standard Oil Company of California warned today of ''potentially fatal'' consequences for the company and its stockholders if the Government imposed a moratorium on oil industry mergers along the lines of a bill sponsored by three Senators.    George M. Keller, Socal's chairman, testifying before a crowded hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said that his company's plan to acquire the Gulf Corporation in the biggest merger on record represented a binding agreement.   ''Once the antitrust clearance process is completed,'' Mr. Keller said, ''we are legally obligated to purchase the Gulf shares for $13.2 billion in cash. If the bill is enacted after our purchase, its retroactive nature would create the most complex legal and financial dilemma in corporate history.''

headline: LTV POSTS PROFIT IN FINAL QUARTER
abstract: The LTV Corporation, a diversified manufacturer with interests in aerospace, energy and steel, said today that it had a profitable fourth quarter but still lost $180.7 million in 1983.    In the final three months, the company earned $7.5 million, or 4 cents a share, contrasted to a loss of $98.1 million in the 1982 period.

headline: LOEWS PURSUING MULTISCREEN CONCEPT
abstract: A construction crew is burrowing deep into the ground at the northeast corner of Broadway and 84th Street as part of the initial stages of construction for a six-auditorium cinema complex being built by the Loews theater chain.   The 22,000-square-foot theater, to be known as Loews 84th Street, is expected to be completed in time for Christmas releases and is rising on property adjacent to Loews Quad, the four-screen movie house the company owns and operates on Broadway at 83d Street. The new theater is being built on a site that includes a hotel, which the Loews Corporation owned for several years, and a former parking lot that the company acquired once the multiscreen movie house was planned.   Loews 84th Street is the company's first ''sixplex'' in Manhattan and the second multiscreen theater to be constructed by Loews Theaters Inc., a division of the Loews Corporation. Loews 34th Street Showplace, a 1,600- seat triplex between First Avenue and Second Avenue, opened in 1981.

headline: Japan Reports 682 Suicides In Burning of Homes in 1983
abstract: Last year 682 Japanese committed suicide by setting fire to their homes, the Fire Defense Agency reported today.   All deaths by fire in Japan totaled 1,825 in 1983, the agency said.   Arson was blamed or suspected in 7,560 fires, and cigarettes were linked to 7,238, an agency spokesman said.

headline: Atari Licensing Pact
abstract: Atari Inc., a subsidiary of Warner Communications, said it had agreed to license products from Androbot Inc., a robotics company headed by Atari's founder, Nolan Bushnell. The companies also agreed to a joint marketing effort involving unspecified products, Atari said.

headline: FOES OF GEMAYEL DROP DEMANDS THAT HE RESIGN
abstract: Syria's key Lebanese allies tonight dropped their demands for the resignation of President Amin Gemayel.     Officials here said the move cleared the way for carrying out an accord between Mr. Gemayel and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to end Lebanon's strife.   The demands that the Lebanese President resign - which had come from Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader, and Nabih Berri, the Shiite Moslem leader - had been seen as a major obstacle to agreement on the framework of a Lebanese peace accord.   In Beirut today, officials said Mr. Assad and Mr. Gemayel had reached an understanding on how to achieve a political solution to the conflict. On Thursday, Syria's official press agency said that after two days of talks, Mr. Gemayel and Mr. Assad were in ''complete agreement on the ways and means of reinforcing Lebanon's Arab identity, unity and independence.''

headline: Death Toll Rises to 63 In Riot in Nigeria
abstract: The death toll in what the authorities believe to have been a Moslem fundamentalist riot in the northern Nigerian city of Yola has risen to 63, officials said today. A police statement in Lagos said 4 of those killed were policemen.   The statement said 429 ''fanatics'' had been arrested so far and that ''the whole area is under control and life has since returned to normal.''

headline: Taxing Social Security
abstract: LIKE it or not, a lot of Americans may find that they are not the only ones benefiting from their Social Security benefits. For the first time, the Federal Government will be getting a cut as well. Starting with 1984 returns, recipients may have to declare up to one half of their benefits as taxable income. The very well-to-do will have little escape, but those on the margin, may be able to shift income from municipal bonds into other investments, such as higher yielding corporate bonds.   ''The Government has adopted the outlook that if you already have a lot of tax-exempt income, it wants some of your Social Security benefits back,'' said Joe DeFur, vice-president in the Direct Investments Group of Prudential-Bache Securities.

headline: RELIEF STALLED AS DROUGHT RAVAGES NORTHEAST BRAZIL
abstract: A severe drought, now in its sixth year, is causing widespread devastation across northeastern Brazil, but bureaucratic problems and a feeling of national embarrassment appear to be standing in the way of much-needed international assistance.    Although this poor and semiarid region has long suffered dry spells, the present disaster in nine states in the northeastern bulge of Brazil is considered the worst in the country's recorded history, with almost total loss of crops in the area in the last year. Foreign aid experts here are comparing the harm done to human life and nature to that caused by the current great drought in sub-Saharan Africa.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Dean Witter Recruits A Top Morgan Analyst     John A. Mendelson, one of Wall Street's top technical analysts, has left Morgan Stanley & Company to join Dean Witter Financial Services.    Mr. Mendelson, 43, will head Dean Witter's market analysis group.

headline: CUSTOM SOFTWARE: THE PERFECT FIT
abstract: NORMAN BROWN is a farmer who bought a computer and now designs software for other farmers - thousands of them. ''Our office is right across from the cows and the pigs and the corn,'' said the founder of FBS Systems in Aledo, Ill., one of the first and most successful of software houses catering to farmers and agribusinesses.    Since he and his wife set up the business in 1981, after having taught themselves programming through a ''how-to'' manual, they have developed 12 packages that calculate inventories of crops and livestock, get daily commodity quotes, and do a range of other highly farm specialized tasks.   Representing a customized, or vertical, market that is growing fast, the Browns, along with other American farmers, are expected to spend a total of more than $425 million on microcomputers and data processing between 1983 and 1987, according to industry analysts.   Farming is one of many occupations ''discovered'' only recently by vertical programmers. ''By my calculations there are 9,954 vertical markets, each capable of receiving a distinct vertical software package,'' said Thomas L. Arnett, editor of the monthly F&S Computer Vertical Market Industries Letter.

headline: 11.2% JUMP IN STARTS OF HOUSING
abstract: Construction of new homes and apartments surged 11.2 percent in February, to an annual rate of 2.2 million units, the highest level in nearly six years, the Commerce Department reported today.   The sharp rise, from a January base that was revised upward, means that housing, like some other segments of the economy, is showing unexpected strength in the face of high interest rates.    Among other encouraging data yesterday, the Producer Price Index rose only four-tenths of 1 percent in February, after jumping six-tenths of 1 percent in January, despite upward pressure from food and fuel costs. And industry operated at 80.7 percent of capacity in Febuary, the 15th consecutive rise and the first time since September 1981 that the rate has topped 80 percent. (Page 31.)

headline: Castle & Cooke
abstract: The United Financial Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it intends to increase its stake in Castle & Cooke Inc. to more than 15 percent of the company's outstanding shares. United Financial already owns 5.4 percent of the food-products company's shares. Castle & Cooke, which is trying to buy the Dr Pepper soft-drink company, said in a separate statement that it had retained Kidder, Peabody & Company to assist it in restructuring its real estate holdings and development activities ''with a view to realizing their value to Castle & Cooke and its shareholders.''

headline: New Suriname Strike Blacks Out the Capital
abstract: Striking electricity workers blacked out Paramaribo today, shutting down most offices, schools and government communications in spreading labor protests against the regime of Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse.   Utility workers, chanting anti-Government slogans, took over the main electricity plant and forced soldiers guarding it to flee, the police said.

headline: Thrift Unit Recovery
abstract: Net after-tax income of federally insured thrift institutions in 1983 was about $2.1 billion, a sharp turnaround from the $1.1 billion loss in 1982 and record $1.7 billion loss in 1981, according to preliminary Federal Home Loan Bank Board data. The board chairman, Edwin J. Gray, released the preliminary figures during testimony before the House Committee on Appropriations.

headline: Beatrice Foods Assigns Its Agencies of Record
abstract: The Beatrice Foods Company in Chicago, which in November announced the seven ad agencies that would benefit from the consolidation of its ad assignments from more than 100 agencies, made the agency-of- record assignments for the seven yesterday.    Agencies of record get a small percentage of the 15 percent media commission for placing advertising for it.

headline: 2D ENGINE VICTORY EXPECTED FOR G.E.
abstract: The Navy is expected to announce shortly that it will turn to General Electric for a jet engine for an advanced version of its F-14 fighter, a plane that until now has been powered by an engine built by the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group of the United Technologies Corporation.    The Navy decision would be another blow to Pratt & Whitney, a major employer in Connecticut, which only last week saw the Air Force decide to give a major share of its tactical fighter jet engine production to General Electric.    A source at the Naval Air Systems Command said today, ''There will be a change in manufacturer.'' But the terms of any new contract - for example, whether it would cover existing planes or new production - were unknown.

headline: Nigeria Curb On Currency LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 11 (Reuters) - Nigeria's military Government has imposed stringent new foreign exchange controls, banking officials said today.
abstract: They said central bank officials told commercial and merchant banks about the new regulations on Tuesday.

headline: Phone Access Fees Estimated
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long-distance competitors   will face an estimated 45 percent increase this spring in the   fees they pay for local phone   connections, an industry official said today.  Gary Tobin, a spokesman for   MCI Communications, said the   company was projecting an increase of fees ''from $235 per   line per month to somewhere   between $335 and $355 per   line.''

headline: GERMAN CAR OUTPUT UP
abstract: West German manufacturers produced 4.167 million motor vehicles last year, up 2.6 percent from 4.062 million in 1982, the Auto Industry Association said today.

headline: 2d Executive Leaving Flying Tiger Position
abstract: John Flynn resigned as president of Tiger International Inc.'s air cargo operations, the company said yesterday. He was the second person to leave the post since June.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: MARATHON WILL BUY HUSKY UNIT
abstract: The Marathon Oil Company and Husky Oil Ltd. of Canada announced yesterday that they had reached a definitive agreement for Marathon to buy Husky's United States subsidiary, the Husky Oil Company, for $505 million in cash.    Since Marathon Oil is a wholly owned subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, the step would further increase U.S. Steel's holdings in the oil business.   S. R. Blair, chairman of the board of Husky Oil Ltd., said in an interview that the company was making the sale ''because we perceived on opportunity this year to convert our petroleum properties, which were not contributing much to our income, into cash.''

headline: FOOD FOR ETHIOPIA BRINGS U.S. DISPUTE
abstract: A dispute has arisen between the Reagan Administration and Congress over Administration assertions that food donated by the United States and other countries to fight famine in Ethiopia is being diverted by that country's leftist Government to commercial markets.   In an interview, two officials of the Agency for International Development contended that proceeds from the sale of donated food were being used by Ethiopia to buy Soviet military equipment for Ethiopia's civil war in two northern provinces, Eritrea and Tigre.   Representative Howard Wolpe, a Michigan Democrat who heads the House subcommittee on Africa, called the diversion charge baseless. He said, ''It is in total conflict with all the reports from the U.S. Embassy in Ethiopia and all the relief agencies.''

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Medical Care Bonds Priced A $40 million financing for   the New York State Medical   Care Facilities Financing Authority was tentatively priced   by underwriters led by Morgan   Stanley & Company with yields   of 8 percent for bonds due in   1994, 9 1/4 percent for bonds due   in 2004 and 9 1/2 percent for   bonds due in 2024.

headline: PATENTS; A TALKING DASHBOARD
abstract: A voice warning device to alert occupants of a motor vehicle to problems was patented this week for Japan's Nissan Motor Company.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Ex-Natomas Head At Investment Bank
abstract: ''I thought it was time for me to start a new career,'' Dorman L. Commons, former chairman and chief executive of the Natomas Company, said yesterday.    Mr. Commons, at age 65, has joined A. G. Becker Paribas, the securities and investment banking firm, as a managing director.

headline: DOW DECLINES 6.28 AS TRADING SLOWS
abstract: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in the slowest trading of the year, with energy and transportation issues the biggest losers.
