The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the loss column throughout the session, closed 6.28 points lower, at 1,165.20. On Friday, it had climbed 12.04 points, buoyed by favorable economic developments.

headline: Customs Officials Dismissed By New Nigerian Government
abstract: Nigeria's military Government said today that it had dismissed 240 customs officials for serious misconduct, including falsifying and forging documents and bribery.

headline: The U.N. Today March 23, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: People
abstract: *  Alexander Brody, president and chief executive of the DYR agency, elected to the board of Beatrice Foods, Chicago.

headline: Wines of California For the French Visitor
abstract: Guests at the White House dinner Thursday for President Francois Mitterrand were served smoked Columbia River salmon with cucumber sauce, tenderloin of veal with truffle sauce and a selection of California wines.   President and Mrs. Reagan were hosts at the dinner, in the State Dining Room, joined by Mr. Mitterrand and his wife, Danielle, and several dozen figures from the arts, news outlets and the Administration.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *  American Medical International Inc., a Beverly Hills, Calif., operator of hospitals, said it was discussing with the Creighton-Omaha Regional Healthcare Corp. a possible affiliation with Creighton University's 539- bed St. Joseph Hospital.     *  Conagra Inc.  of Omaha said it would close its Buffalo flour mill permanently Thursday because it had been unprofitable for some time.

headline: Jailed Polish Unionist Reported Critically Ill
abstract: A jailed Solidarity activist, Janusz Palubicki, is in critical condition after almost eight weeks on a hunger strike, opposition sources said today.

headline: REAGAN MAKES PLEA FOR U.S. JEWS' SUPPORT ON ARMS SALES TO JORDAN
abstract: President Reagan appealed to American Jews today to support his plans to supply advanced military equipment to Jordan. He said such assistance ''does not threaten Israel'' and helps deter Syria from trying ''to dominate the region.''   In a speech to the Young Leadership Conference of the United Jewish Appeal, Mr. Reagan spoke out for the first time against the movement in Congress to block the proposed sale of new shoulder-fired Stinger antiaircraft missiles and other equipment to Jordan. The opposition to the sales is backed by Israel and American Jewish groups.

headline: Reagan Likens Quest Of Peace to Olympics
abstract: President Reagan urged today that world leaders pursue peace as hard as athletes strive for excellence in the Olympic Games.   ''Leaders in government have an obligation to strive for cooperation every bit as hard as our athletes who reach within for the greatest efforts of their lives,'' Mr. Reagan said in a written response to questions submitted by the Yugoslav newspaper Oslobodjenje.   ''The United States has no higher priority than peace, as exemplified by the Olympic spirit,'' he said.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive of the Rich's department store chain, has taken a leave. The parent company of Rich's, Federated Department Stores Inc., said he had been granted ''a sabbatical to pursue personal interests.''    Chairman of Rich's Takes a 'Sabbatical' The departure of Mr. Questrom, who is 42 years old, touched off a series of management changes. James M. Zimmerman, 39, president of Rich's, which is based in Atlanta, will become the new chairman and chief executive. Merwin F. Kaminstein, 48, chairman of Filene's of Boston, will join Rich's as president.

headline: Koppers Seeking Bar to Takeovers
abstract: The Koppers Company said its directors are asking shareholders to approve antitakeover measures at its annual meeting in April.

headline: Heating Bills Found to Rise
abstract: Heating bills for the average resident using natural gas jumped 27 percent for December and January from the period a year earlier, largely because of frigid weather, according to a study released by the Citizens-Labor Energy Coalition, a consumer group.    The survey, released Sunday, showed an average 21 percent rise in consumption of natural gas because of the colder-than-normal winter temperatures.

headline: RATES DOWN ACROSS THE BOARD
abstract: After more than two months of trading dominated by rising interest rates and weak investor demand, the credit markets did an about-face yesterday as interest rates fell in all sectors amid signs of improved demand for this week's auctions of Treasury notes and bonds.     By late in the day, rates for outstanding Treasury bills were lower by as much as an eighth of a percentage point, with the three-month issue bid at 9.64 percent. In the long-term bond market, the bellwether 12 percent Treasury bond due in 2013 rose 5/8 point on the day, to an offered price of 96 7/8, to yield 12.40 percent. Early in the day, the 12 percent bond traded as low as 95 27/32, to yield 12.54 percent.

headline: Norwegian Says Arrest Of K.G.B. Spy Hurt Ties
abstract: Prime Minister Kare Willoch said today that the arrest of a high-ranking civil servant who admitted spying for the K.G.B. had put a serious strain on relations with the Soviet Union.   ''The Soviet Union has to carry the full responsibility for this,'' Mr. Willoch said at a news conference after a closed-door meeting with several Cabinet ministers.

headline: CANADIAN SENATE: A JOB THAT'S NOT TAXING
abstract: The nine prizes just awarded and the nine more to be given out include yearly payments of at least $61,425 until the age of 75, office staffs, free postage, free haircuts, free massages, travel allowances, subsidized lunches and tax exemptions, and there is no limit on earning money elsewhere.   These are not the payoffs in a Canadian lottery; they are the benefits that go with appointments to the Senate, Canada's upper house of Parliament, whose 104 nonelected members need do nothing more than show up once or twice a year to collect their pay.   With Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau heading into what is almost certainly the final phase of his final term, he has in the last months started to fill longstanding vacancies in the Senate with nominees who, though diverse in backgrounds, share a loyalty to Mr. Trudeau's Liberal Party. Several of them have served as his close aides.

headline: CAPE TOWN HUTS: HUMBLE, IMPERILED, BUT HOME
abstract: Armed with a little ingenuity, a person who wishes to live here, albeit unlawfully, in a slum called Crossroads, can construct a home of wooden planks, fiberboard and green or black plastic sheeting in about three hours.    Armed with a crowbar, and supported by a colleague with a shotgun, an official carrying out policies opposed to the building of new, illicit shanties can reverse the process in about three minutes.   Usually, those who construct the gimcrack houses are black and those who flatten them are white. This week, shortly before the opening of a session of the all-white Parliament that has been billed as a herald of change, the flattenings began again after a pause of about two months.

headline: 53 Missing After Attack On Boat From Vietnam
abstract: Bands of pirates attacked a boat carrying refugees from Vietnam, robbing, raping and kidnapping the women and forcing the men overboard, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.   A spokesman, Leo Davico, said 33 refugees were feared drowned and 20 women kidnapped in the attack, one of two that occurred last month after the boat left Vietnam carrying 60 refugees.

headline: GTE, UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS GAIN
abstract: -distance telephone system and the disposal of certain businesses, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter increased 13 percent on an increase in revenues of 16.1 percent.    GTE, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said that net income in the the latest three months rose to $269 million, or $1.39 a share, from $238 million, or $1.31 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. revenues advanced $3.6 billion, from $3.1 billion   On a continuing operations basis, income in the fourth quarter showed an increase of 21.5 percent, to $249 million, from $205 million in the 1982 fourth quarter, before the inclusion ofa $36 million special credit related to a tax matter in California.   For the full year, GTE said that net income increased 14.4 percent, to $956 million, or $5 a share, from $836 million, or $4.70 a a share, in 1982. Revenues were 11.2 percent higher, to $12.9 million, from $11.6 million.

headline: Shultz to Meet Canadian
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet Canada's Secretary for External Affairs, Allan J. MacEachen, in Washington next Sunday and Monday, the State Department announced today.

headline: TEXACO CHANGES CHARACTER
abstract: For more than a decade, Texaco Inc. has been known as the most conservative, slow-moving, and tightfisted of the nation's major oil companies.

headline: Marine Killed in Auto Crash
abstract: A United States marine who spent three months on duty in Beirut was killed in a traffic accident while on liberty in Israel's northern port city of Haifa, a police spokesman said today.

headline: UNIONS LOSE AS HIGH COURT BACKS COMPANIES IN BANKRUPTCY FILINGS
abstract: The Supreme Court, in a sharp setback for organized labor, ruled unanimously today that a bankruptcy court may free a company from its union contracts without requiring proof that the company would otherwise face imminent failure.   Ruling on another aspect of the case, the Court voted, 5 to 4, that, once a company has filed a bankruptcy petition, it may unilaterally breach its collective- bargaining agreements with labor unions while awaiting the bankruptcy court's formal permission to do so.   The decision grew out of the 1980 bankruptcy filing by the Bildisco Manufacturing Company, a New Jersey building supply concern. The decision, applying to companies that request reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code, seems likely to encourage the use of the bankruptcy law by companies seeking relief from high labor costs.

headline: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MACY'S NET RISES 12.9%
abstract: R. H. Macy & Company, continuing its strong trend of recent years, said yesterday that its earnings rose 21.9 percent in its second quarter, to $97.5 million, or $1.93 a share, from $80 million, or $1.60 a share, the year before.    Sales increased 21.3 percent in the period, which ended Jan. 28, to $1.31 billion, from $1.08 billion.

headline: Ag-Chem Acquired
abstract: United Agri Products of Omaha, a subsidiary of Conagra Inc., has acquired Ag- Chem Inc., a Middle Atlantic agricultural chemicals distributor based in Girdletree, Md. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: 'NONUSE OF FORCE' OFFERED TO NATO
abstract: Western diplomats attending the East-West security conference in Stockholm say the Soviet Union is sending signals about how the Soviet-American negotiations on nuclear arms could resume.    According to one of the diplomats, discussions with Soviet officials have produced ''evidence of a link'' between Soviet interest in a statement renouncing the use of force and a resumption of the talks on limiting strategic and medium-range nuclear missiles, which broke up late last year.   The diplomat said it would be up to West to decide whether to test ''a number of fairly explicit hints'' from the Russians. The Soviet suggestion is that if the United States, as leader of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, were to say publicly that it would consider a statement on nonuse of force, this would provide ''a favorable element'' toward restarting the talks.

headline: Advertising ; At Esty, The Drums Are Quiet
abstract: IF you have ever heard of the William Esty Company, it is not the    company's fault.    It may be billing at the rate of about $575 million and its 14 clients may be among the world's best-known advertisers, but it is still worthy of the sobriquet ''the Sphinx of East 42d.''    With that in mind, it was not surprising to learn that back in December the agency named its first chief operating officer and almost immediately the president - who did not get the title - resigned. Yet nothing reached the public prints. In January a new executive creative director was named and that was also given the silent treatment.

headline: AN UNSETTLING SHIFT IN BIG OIL
abstract: TEN years ago, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries clamped an embargo    on oil and sent petroleum prices soaring, the world's major oil companies scoured the globe, spending billions of dollars drilling for the precious commodity.   In the past 10 weeks, the major companies have again been in a rush to spend billions - but this time to buy up their sister oil companies. Three of the world's largest producers - Royal Dutch/Shell, Texaco and Standard Oil of California - are set to spend $28.5 billion on these takeovers. Although they still spend billions on drilling new wells, not a cent of the staggering new outlay for acquisitions is directly aimed at searching for new reserves.    For the domestic oil industry, the snowballing merger movement marks a major turning point. After the whirlwind decade of the 70's, dominated by OPEC's gyrations, the industry has reached a slow- growing maturity. Domestic reserves are shrinking, prices and profits have weakened, refining and marketing operations are suffering from huge overcapacity.

headline: Death Squad in El Salvador Threatens to Kill Journalists
abstract: A right-wing death squad threatened today to kill journalists who ''collaborate'' with leftist Salvadoran guerrillas.

headline: Top Bid for Dr Pepper Is Dropped
abstract: Castle & Cooke Inc., head of the DPCC Acquisition Corporation, said yesterday that it had ''reluctantly'' withdrawn its languishing offer to buy the Dr Pepper Company for $24 a share, or $581 million.     The announcement all but handed victory to Forstmann Little & Company, a little-known Wall Street firm that has been trying to take the big soft-drink company private at $22 a share, after one of the most vitriolic takeover battles in the industry. Dr Pepper called a special stockholders meeting for Feb. 28 to vote on the deal.

headline: PETRO-LEWIS POSTS LOSS OF $2.3 MILLION
abstract: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, citing the impact of a $12.8 million write- off of expenses related to the company's Yield Plus Fund II limited partnerships, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $2.3 million in the second fiscal quarter of 1984, which ended Dec. 31. This contrasted to earnings of $9.2 million, or 38 cents a share, a year earlier.    Petro-Lewis, an oil and gas company based in Denver, said revenues in the period fell 10.3 percent, to $83.1 million, from $92.6 million.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: *  BMC Industries, St. Paul, a maker of precision electronic interconnect components and systems, has appointed Charles J. Burns senior vice president and chief financial officer.     *  Circus Circus Enterprises Inc., Las Vegas, Nev., an operator of hotel- casinos, has named Glenn Schaeffer to the new position of senior vice president for corporate development.

headline: NEW YORK AREA HAS NOT BEEN LEFT BEHIND
abstract: ALMOST from the time New York City emerged as a manufacturing center, a classic pattern emerged in the way young businesses took shape and grew. In the last seven years, one entrepreneur, Elazar Rabbani, has followed this pattern to a tee: He came up with a salable idea and turned to family members, his brother Shahram and his brother-in-law Barry W. Weiner, to help him find a market niche and financing.    The partners set up their company in one of Manhattan's manufacturing centers - gritty, loft-lined Hudson Street in the lower West Side. Their business grew. Their work force increased from 5 to 80 and their stock, which went on sale in June 1980 for $6.25 a share, now sells, after several splits, for the equivalent of $150.

headline: WHAT PRESIDENT REAGAN HAS SAID ABOUT THE MARINES' ROLE IN LEBANON
abstract: Following are statements by President Reagan on the United States role in the multinational force in Lebanon:  Sept. 21, 1983 - ''The mission that   the multinational force was   created for has not changed. But   from the very first, I said we will   never send our men any place   where they will not be allowed to   defend themselves if they come   under attack, and that recently   has happened, and they have   been defending themselves.''   (Meeting with regional journalists.)

headline: LEBANESE LEADERS BICKER OVER NEW PROPOSAL FOR POLITICAL CHANGES
abstract: Lebanon's eight main factional leaders debated a new Syrian-sponsored proposal tonight for national reconciliation, but their talks collapsed into bickering when Christian leaders refused to make any substantial concessions to their Moslem compatriots, conference sources said.    The talks are expected to resume Tuesday.   ''There continues to be disagreement,'' said a Government spokesman, Michel Samaha. ''The differences are over the distribution of powers.''

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 30, 1984:  MONDAY Armstrong WorldConsol FreightwaysBlack & DeckerLouisana-Pacific Corp  TUESDAY Amer BrandsKennametal IncBorden IncKoger PropertiesBucyrus-EriePacific LumberGulton Indus   WEDNESDAY Carter Hawley HalePanhandle EasternGeneral FoodsVeeco InstrumentsIngersol-Rand   THURSDAY Chemed CorpMercantile StoresColumbia Gas SystOmnicare IncGulf States UtilsThriftimart Inc  FRIDAY Sterling DrugWash Water PwrWarnaco Inc

headline: Swedes, Hunting a Sub, Drop Depth Charges
abstract: The Swedish Navy dropped 10 depth charges today on what it suspects was a foreign submarine lying off the Karlskrona naval base in southern Sweden, a military spokesman said, but there was no indication the navy hit its target.

headline: Reagan to Meet With Pope
abstract: President Reagan tentatively plans to meet with Pope John Paul II in Fairbanks, Alaska, on May 2 when the two leaders cross paths on trips to or from the Far East, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said today.

headline: Advertising; Four-A's Focuses on The World
abstract: When 879 people interested in advertising find their way to this luxurious but hard-to-get-to oasis for a three-day meeting, it must mean that business is good and the winter is bad.    And at the 65th annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, one of the favorite topics of conversation this morning - by those few not starting their day with a job - was the dire weather prediction for the East on Friday.   The meeting, the first national gathering of the organization in southern California and the best attended in its history, focused as the association does every five years or so on international advertising, which is where the big multinational agencies are expecting to get their major growth in the future.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  Allied Corp.  announced that it had signed a letter of intent with a joint venture formed by Leo D. Phillips & Co. of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and a unit of JMB Realty Corp. of Chicago for the sale and partial leaseback of Allied's Bendix Center property in Southfield, Mich.     *  Alltel Corp., a company formed in October by the merger of Mid-Continent Telephone Corp. and Allied Telephone Co., said it would spend $138 million in 1984 to improve services.

headline: DOW OFF 7.33 POINTS, TO 1,139.76
abstract: Stock prices fell yesterday for the fourth day this week in light trading. The news of a sharp drop in the unemployment rate only heightened fears of tight money and an increase in interest rates.     The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.33 points, to 1,139.76, ending the week nearly 32 points below last Friday. The average advanced 3.46 points Thursday after slipping 27.85 points earlier in the week.

headline: MELLON'S 4TH-PERIOD NET ROSE TO $53.6 MILLION
abstract: The Mellon National Corporation, which yesterday became the first major banking company to report its fourth-quarter earnings, said its net income amounted to $53.6 million, or $2.01 a share, in the period.     These earnings were not comparable with last year's, when Mellon posted net income of $31.8 million, because the latest figures include the net income of three companies acquired by Mellon during 1983 while last year's figures were not readjusted to take these acquisitions into account. The three acquisitions were the Girard Company, which had been the 66th-largest banking concern in the United States, with assets of $4.8 billion; the CCB Bancorp Inc., with assets of about $500 million, and Mortgage and Trust Inc., a private mortgage banking firm that did not disclose its earnings.

headline: Irving Bank Stock Trading Trading in the stock of the
abstract: Irving Bank Corporation continued heavy yesterday, but the   price dropped to $63, down $5   from Tuesday's record high.  Rumors continued to circulate that Irving might be the   subject of a takeover attempt,   but many investment bankers   said they did not think that was   the reason for the recent run-up   in the price of Irving's stock.

headline: Uniroyal Income By Reuters
abstract: Uniroyal Inc. expects to report net income of about $2 a share for 1983, up from 78 cents a share, or $25.6 million in 1982, Joseph P. Flannery, chairman, said. The 1983 earnings will include gains of about $14.8 million from the exchange of common shares for debt, including about $9.2 million attributable to the fourth quarter. Uniroyal, as a result of a five-million- share public offering and the stock- for-debt swap, now has about 33.5 million shares outstanding, up from 26.7 million in 1982.

headline: People
abstract: *  Lee F. Reiser Jr.  has been named a corporate vice president and director of marketing development at Beatrice Foods.     *  C. L. Bowerman has been elected vice president, marketing, for the Phillips Petroleum Company.     *  Peter Farwell has been appointed executive vice president of Carl Byoir & Associates.

headline: Maclean Hunter
abstract: Maclean Hunter Ltd. of Toronto, Canada's biggest communications company, purchased a 25 percent interest in Barden Cablevision Inc. for $230,000, according to Don Barden, president of Barden Cablevision. The purchase gives the Canadian company veto power over Barden decisions, but Mr. Barden said that he would remain president of the company. Barden Cablevision has been awarded the franchise for Detroit's $150 million cable television system, but the Detroit Cable Television Commission said the city's agreement would not be affected by the ownership changes.

headline: Fisher Foods
abstract: Fisher Foods Inc. said Carl H. Lindner, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Financial Corporation, would be nominated as chairman of Fisher, an operator of supermarkets. Fisher said Mr. Lindner was one of four officers designated by American Financial for election to Fisher's seven-man board of directors at its annual meeting on May 15. Last week, Fisher said a proposed stock purchase by American Financial would raise its stake in Fisher to 35 percent, from 18 percent.

headline: Exiled Ex-Premier of Grenada To Return Home, Aide Says
abstract: The exiled former Prime Minister, Sir Eric Gairy, plans to return to Grenada on Saturday for the first time since he was deposed nearly five years ago, an aide said today.   The aide, Oliver Raeburn, chairman of the Grenada United Labor Party, said party officials were planning a big reception for Sir Eric, the party leader.

headline: Thousands of Youths Riot in Hong Kong
abstract: Thousands of teen-agers rampaged through the streets of Kowloon, the mainland city of Hong Kong, on Friday night, attacking policemen, burning and overturning cars and looting shops, the police reported.   At least 34 people were injured, some seriously.

headline: PHONE ACCESS FEE DELAYED UNTIL '85
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission, citing public pressure, voted today to delay until 1985 the imposition of monthly charges to connect homes and small businesses to the telephone system.    The so-called access charges would have been paid to local telephone companies so they could collect more for local service. Until now, the commission says, local charges have been kept artificially low because they have been subsidized by high long-distance charges.   To reflect the end of the subsidy, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the main long-distance carrier, planned to cut long-distance rates. But today it said the F.C.C. action ''could prevent'' the scheduled reduction of 10 to 15 percent.

headline: Deere Official at Cornell
abstract: Curtis W. Tarr, vice president for management development at Deere & Company, the farm equipment manufacturer, has been named dean of the Cornell University School of Management. Mr. Tarr, who is 59 years old, succeeds David A. Thomas, who is retiring after 31 years at Cornell. From 1963 to 1969, Mr. Tarr was president of Lawrence University in Appleton, Wis. He received his bachelor's and Ph.D. degrees at Stanford, and an M.B.A. at Harvard.

headline: Ex-Argentine Leader Seeks Military Trial
abstract: Former President Reynaldo Bignone, charged with complicity in the presumed murder of two Communists, will demand that his case be transferred from a civilian to a military court, court sources said today.   The 55-year-old retired army general, who was arrested Tuesday, will maintain that a civilian judge lacks the authority to try him, the sources said.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: 25 on French Plane Hurt By Chad Airport Bomb    PARIS, March 10 (UPI) - Two bombs exploded aboard a French passenger jet today during a stopover at the Ndjamena airport in Chad, wounding 25 people, officials here said.   Diplomats in Paris said the DC-8 of the airline Union des Transports Aeriens had been destroyed by the second bomb, which exploded 20 minutes after the first and after the 100 people aboard were evacuated.

headline: PHILIPPINE ELECTION ALREADY STIRRING DISPUTES
abstract: Although the campaign for the May parliamentary elections is scheduled to begin next Saturday, the Government and its political foes are already skirmishing in the battle for votes.    President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who heads the ruling New Society Movement, led off on the Government side this week with two statements defending his authoritarian decree powers, a key issue. Without these powers, he said, the Government could be paralyzed by legislative bickering.

headline: Market Place; Bullish Outlook On Josephson
abstract: IT is difficult to make a clear-cut case for purchasing shares of Josephson International Inc.,    analysts acknowledge. But that is precisely why now may be the time to buy, they add.   Josephson is not an easy company to understand. In its annual report, it calls itself a ''creative service company,'' but those services are all over the map. It owns International Creative Management Inc., which is one of the two largest talent agencies in the United States, representing entertainers as diverse as Culture Club and Isaac Stern, the concert violinist.

headline: Retailers Are Cautioned
abstract: Although buoyed by the best Christmas season in years, retailers at a national convention in New York were warned yesterday that their high expectations for 1984 could be adversely affected by unusual volatility in the economy.     The year will be less predictable on a quarter-by-quarter basis, and inflation will probably rise at a somewhat faster rate than in 1983, Leif H. Olsen, chairman of the economic committee of Citibank, said yesterday.   Speaking to 1,000 retail executives at the annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association, Mr. Olsen declared: ''Total personal consumption expenditures for 1983 increased by 5.5 percent in real terms and more than 10 percent in money terms. That ranks with one of the best of the first-year recoveries. However in 1984, we expect spending to rise about 3 percent, somewhat less than the average performance in the second year of economic recovery.''

headline: NATO LEADER'S LANGUID AIR MASKS IRON RESOLVE
abstract: Lord Carrington, the former British Foreign Secretary, who will take over as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization this year, uses understatement, humor and languor to mask an underlying seriousness, commitment and determination.    One of his favorite remarks is that things are never as bad as people say they are. It sprang to his lips again in an interview last week. But he left little doubt that he believes things are bad enough both within NATO and between NATO and its adversary, the Warsaw Pact, to give him plenty of work when he starts his new job in Brussels in July.

headline: LISBON OFICERS CLUB: COUP MAKERS OR BREAKERS
abstract: Inside the Fortress of Good Success, an aging concrete structure on the banks of the Tagus River here where the guns have not sounded in years, the walls are decorated with posters from the Portuguese revolution of almost a decade ago.    The posters capture the explosion of joy when army officers took over the streets of Lisbon with red carnations in their gun barrels. They depict soldiers and farmers, marching arm in arm toward a glorious future. They extol the Armed Forces Movement, the group of junior officers who overturned 47 years of dictatorship, as ''the sentinel of the people.''   The fortress is not a museum. It is the headquarters of a new organization in the Portuguese Army called the Association of the 25th of April, founded as a ''cultural association'' to ''consecrate and spread the spirit of the liberating movement'' that began with the coup on April 25, 1974, which ushered in democracy.

headline: ISRAELI ARMY TO QUIT URBAN AREAS FOR NEW POSITION CLOSER TO BORDER
abstract: Officials said today that Israel was planning for a long-term occupation of a zone in southern Lebanon, in view of the Lebanese Government's decision to cancel a security accord with Israel.    Final decisions on the zone's boundaries have not been made. But officials said the army would pull back from its positions at the Awali River to a line closer to the Israeli-Lebanese border and would move out of such major population centers as the coastal city of Sidon. The move would decrease the number of Lebanese civilians under Israeli control to about half of the current 500,000 to 600,000.

headline: MONEY SUPPLY UP $3.8 BILLION
abstract: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose by $3.8 billion in the week ended Jan. 11.     The increase, although unusually large, had been widely expected. Interest rates after the 4:15 P.M. announcement were virtually unchanged from earlier in the day.    By late in the day, three-month Treasury bills were bid at 8.98 percent, up from 8.88 percent a day earlier. Among longer-term issues, two- year notes that will be auctioned next Tuesday were offered by dealers to yield 10.64 percent, up from 10.625 percent, while 12 percent bonds due in 2013 were offered at 102 1/2, down 3/8 point, to yield 11.69 percent.

headline: FORMER LEGAL ADVISER TO SOLIDARITY FACING A TRIAL
abstract: A criminal case was started today against a onetime legal adviser to the Solidarity union who had written an open letter to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski that criticized the treatment of a fellow lawyer.    The former Solidarity adviser, Wladyslaw Sila-Nowicki, said in his letter that the authorities had trumped up a case against his colleague, who was involved in an investigation of police misconduct. It also accused the Government of covering up police misbehavior in two cases. The letter was made public last week.

headline: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER IS PLANNING STOCK SALE
abstract: The International Harvester Company said today that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed secondary stock offering of 12.5 million common shares. It also said it did not expect to earn a profit in the current fiscal year, which ends Oct. 31.

headline: Trading Halted In Tymshare
abstract: Trading in the shares of Tymshare Inc., operator of one of the nation's largest data-transmission networks, was halted on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon pending an announcement. Tymshare, which earlier was close to a merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, was rumored yesterday to be a target of Honeywell Inc. Tymshare stock last traded at $15.25, up $1.50.

headline: WHEN FEAR PAYS A VISIT TO A CARIBBEAN PARADISE
abstract: -A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, Feb. 11 - The month of February appeared to be off to a happy start in this busy island in the French West Indies. Carnival season was getting into swing, cruise ships were arriving almost daily and the resorts were full of tourists. Then the bombers struck.   In St.-Francois in the early morning hours of Feb. 4, an explosion ripped a hole in the Meridien, a leading Guadeloupe hotel, sending visitors, choking on acrid smoke, into the night and leaving an incongruous scar on the gentle tropical landscape. More or less simultaneously, another explosion and fire destroyed a discount department store on the edge of the island's international airport.

headline: German Steel Output
abstract: West German raw steel production fell to 39.3 million tons in 1983, down four-tenths of 1 percent from 1982, the Statistics Office said today.

headline: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Australian Strikes Ebb
abstract: Australia lost fewer working days because of strikes last year, the Government said today. For each thousand employees, 249 working days were lost to strikes in 1983, down from 396 days per thousand in 1982 and the least since 1967.

headline: Iraq Says It Sank 5 Iranian Ships
abstract: The Iraqi military said today that its forces had sunk five Iranian vessels and shot down a Phantom jet fighter in a battle in the northern end of the Persian Gulf.   An Iraqi military spokesman, reading a communique over Baghdad radio and television stations, said the battle took place at noon today after a convoy of Iranian vessels was spotted sailing north toward Bandar Khomeini near Khor Moussa Creek.

headline: REAGAN IS SAID TO FIND BREACHES BY SOVIET OF AGREEMENTS ON ARMS
abstract: President Reagan has determined that the Soviet Union has committed ''violations or probable violations'' of some terms of several arms control agreements or obligations, a senior State Department official said today.   In a briefing for reporters, the official said that despite these instances of Soviet failure to live up to agreements, ''the President has not concluded that we should give up our search for serious arms control agreements.''   The President's determination came after a months-long study that was ordered by Congress after some conservative members disclosed possible Soviet failures to live up to agreements.   A Major U.S. Effort    The announcement of the results of the study came as the Administration prepared a major effort to convince Soviet leaders and the public in the United States and Western Europe that it is sincere in trying to reach new accords with Moscow despite the chill in relations.

headline: Seneca Debt Pact
abstract: The Seneca Oil Company said it had reached agreement with its bank and major trade creditors on a debt restructuring that would allow it to continue operating without diluting shareholder equity. The company said bank creditors had deferred interest due on $49.4 million of debt from Nov. 1, 1983, through Oct. 31, 1985. Seneca said it would try to attract new investment and equity capital.

headline: ;  DuPont Official Named Bell Canada President
abstract: Robert J. Richardson, an executive vice president of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and a member of its executive committee and board of directors, has decided to go home again. Mr. Richardson, who was born in Ontario, will return to his native land to become president of Bell Canada Enterprises.    The 55-year-old chemical engineer will retire from Du Pont and its board of directors on May 7 to become head of Bell Canada, the telecommunications giant, the next day. Mr. Richardson said he was leaving Du Pont in favor of the Canadian company ''mostly for personal reasons.'' He said: ''I always intended to retire in Canada. I have property there.''

headline: ANDROPOV SAID TO GAIN AUTHORITY IN SHUFFLE OF REGIONAL PARTY AIDES
abstract: Although Yuri V. Andropov has been out of public view for five months, the ruling Communist Party has been pressing on with a shake-up of regional party chiefs. The development is interpreted by Western diplomats as a measure of Mr. Andropov's continuing political power.    At least 19 of the 150-odd regional first secretaries, the top authorities in the Soviet Union's provinces and other major civil divisions, have been replaced in a round of party elections closely supervised by Moscow. Fifteen other regional chiefs were dismissed or transferred previously under Mr. Andropov's leadership, for an overall turnover of more than 20 percent.

headline: Israeli Held in Killing O a P P
abstract: An Israeli has been charged with throwing a grenade that killed a peace activist and wounded 10 others during a demonstration outside the Prime Minister's office, the police said today.

headline: C.D. Rates Down a Bit In Week Interest rates on certificates of deposit dropped slightly around the nation in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.
abstract: The Monitor's nationwide index of six-month certificates, based on a survey of 50 major institutions in the five largest markets, declined one basis point, to 9.19 percent, from 9.20 percent in the previous week. The rate, which was 9.25 percent two weeks ago, appears to have stabilized in the last three months.

headline: POSNER BIDS FOR ROYAL CROWN
abstract: Victor Posner, the financier, yesterday proposed a leveraged buyout of the Royal Crown Companies at $40 a share in cash, only hours after the company announced an agreement with its own managers to take it private at $37 a share.    The actions were the latest in a running battle between Royal Crown's management and Mr. Posner, who owns 27 percent of the Atlanta-based company, one of the last small, independent soft-drink makers.   Mr. Posner said his offer to Royal Crown's shareholders is contingent on the cancellation of a sale of two million preferred shares by the company to the management group. The group, which already owned 18 percent of the company, bought the preferred shares yesterday for $10 million, or about $5 a share. The shares carry three votes apiece, giving the management group voting control of the company. Typically, preferred shares have no voting power.

headline: Market Place; Broker Stocks Downgraded
abstract: I N the first year of the bull market, from August    1982 to August 1983, brokerage stocks ranked as   the best performer among 89 groups monitored by Standard & Poor's. The brokerage group soared 254.8 percent, compared with a 57.4 percent gain for the S.& P. 500-stock index.   But it is been a vastly different story since last summer, when the bull market began to acquire certain characteristics of a bear. And few groups demonstrate this change better than shares of publicly owned brokerage houses. Between June 30, 1983, and Wednesday of last week, the brokerage group plunged 38.2 percent, compared with a decline of only 3.4 percent for the S.& P. index.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;  Dean Witter Executive Joins Oppenheimer Francis H. M. Kelly, chairman of the investment policy committee at Dean Witter Reynolds, has joined Oppenheimer & Company as director of research, Oppenheimer announced yesterday.
abstract: Mr. Kelly, 46, succeeds Burton Fingerhut, 40, an outdoors enthusiast who after 19 years has left the firm to go hiking the world over. Mr. Fingerhut was among Oppenheimer executives who profited in the sale of the firm to Britain's Mercantile House.   Mr. Kelly arrived on Wall Street 22 years ago via London.

headline: New Suriname Cabinet Plans Liberalizing Steps
abstract: An interim Government charged with repairing Suriname's economy and restoring press freedom was sworn in today in Paramaribo, the Dutch news agency A.N.P. reported.

headline: Report on Mark Denied
abstract: West Germany's central bank today denied a newspaper report that said central bankers in the United States, Germany and other countries were ready to prevent the dollar from falling under an exchange rate of 2.50 West German marks. The West German newspaper Neue Presse, quoting informed central bank sources, had said that the German central bank considered a dollar exchange rate of 2.60 marks ''ideal.''

headline: Della Femina Picks Up 3 Metromedia Accounts
abstract: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, which is not now nor ever has been the ad agency for Ronald Reagan's re-election campaign, has, however, become agency for three units of Metromedia with billings of more than $4 million.

headline: Leyland Truck Layoffs
abstract: BL P.L.C., the former British Leyland, said today that it was laying off more than 1,000 truck workers because 1983 sales, particularly exports, fell far short of target. A BL spokesman said the Leyland Trucks unit, which has a total work force of 9,500, sold only 11,000 trucks in 1983 versus a target of 20,000. Exports were down 50 percent from 1982, it said.

headline: Schedule Is Light for Debt Securities
abstract: The supply of new debt securities scheduled for sale this week is relatively light in all sectors.    After three auctions last week totaling $16.25 billion, Government securities dealers have no new Treasury note or bond issues to bid for this week, although payment is due on Wednesday for last week's issues.    Prior to today's regular auction of Treasury bills, the outstanding three- month bill was bid late Friday at 9.04 percent, while the outstanding six- month issue was bid at 9.14 percent.

headline: PENNZOIL, GETTY PACT IS REPORTED
abstract: In a venture that would give them 100 percent ownership of the Getty Oil Company, the Pennzoil Company and Gordon P. Getty have joined forces to buy the 48 million Getty shares they do not control for a reported price of $112 a share, or $5.4 billion, Wall Street sources said last night.     The agreement followed two days of meetings of the company's 16- member board that involved Sidney R. Petersen, chairman of Getty Oil; J. Hugh Liedtke, chairman of Pennzoil; Gordon Getty, trustee of the Sarah P. Getty Trust, and Harold M. Williams, president of the J. Paul Getty Museum.    The sources said all four parties had agreed to the transaction, which would end a feud over control of the company that has pitted management of Getty Oil against the heirs of its founder, J. Paul Getty.

headline: INCO HAS LOSS
abstract: Asarco Inc., a major producer of copper, silver and zinc, reported yesterday that it increased its earnings in the fourth quarter, largely because of several nonrecurring gains. Inco Ltd., the world's largest nickel producing company, reported another large loss.

headline: U.N. CHIEF AFFIRMS TERMS FOR SENDING A FORCE TO LEBANON
abstract: The United Nations' position on the replacement of the multinational force in Lebanon with United Nations troops remains unchanged despite President Reagan's announcement of the redeployment of American Marines back to their ships, United Nations officials said here today.   A spokesman for Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said that the United Nations is ''available and ready'' to participate in any peacekeeping effort in Lebanon if four conditions are met.

headline: Information Displays Stake
abstract: A group led by Leonard Levy, a private investor, said it and Mr. Levy now own 20.9 percent of Information Displays Inc. Mr. Levy said he personally owns 18.3 percent of the company, a Armonk, N.Y., maker of computer systems.    Information Displays, which has about 3 million shares outstanding, was bid at $10, up 12.5 cents, today in over-the-counter trading.

headline: OUTCOME OF BASQUE VOTE: GOING FROM BAD TO WORSE?
abstract: A new element of instability has crept into the Basque government as a result of the elections Sunday for a regional parliament. How this will affect the long and tortuous process of coming to terms with separatist terrorists in that northern region of Spain is difficult to determine, officials say.  The party that has governed for the last four years, the moderate but still intensely regionalist Basque Nationalist Party, or P.N.V., made a strong showing but nonetheless lost an effective working majority.    Officials say this means that the party and its articulate leader, Carlos Garaikoetxea, will either have to form an open coalition with one of the minority parties or try to govern on an issue-by-issue basis.

headline: U.S.-India Phone Plan
abstract: India proposes to spend about $12 billion on telecommunications in the next five years, according to an American official who heads a trade mission here.   Donald V. Earnshaw, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce, said today that the United States was negotiating an agreement on exchanges with India's telephone industry.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: People     *  Robert Fudge and  John Mead have been elected senior vice presidents of SSC&B Inc.     *  Paul Walter elected a senior vice president, creative director, at Ogilvy & Mather, Los Angeles.

headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS
abstract: COTTON AND ORANGE JUICE POST SHARP PRICE RISES          By The Associated Press    Prices of cotton and orange juice futures were sharply higher yesterday on the Cotton Exchange in New York amid concern about supplies.    The orange juice rally followed unconfirmed reports of increased prices for frozen orange juice concentrate from Brazil, analysts said.    Ernest Simon, a cotton analyst in New York wth Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said cotton prices responded to a report from the Agriculture Department that farmers intended to plant 10.7 million acres of cotton this year, less than the 12 million that analysts had expected.

headline: NUCLEAR PLANT SUCCESS STORY
abstract: When the Florida Power and Light Company raised its rates last September to cover the cost of a new nuclear reactor here, the increase caused little commotion. The Miami-based utility's 2.5 million customers received bills 4 percent higher, raising the average monthly rate to $67.21.     But what was taken in stride by Florida consumers has become the focus of great jubilation, and in some cases great consternation, among utility managers around the country. For Florida Power and Light, which provides electricity to two-thirds of the state, has demonstrated that it could do what nobody else seems capable of: It has built a nuclear plant on schedule.

headline: WEST EUROPE AND JAPAN EXPRESS REGRET
abstract: Allied governments in Western Europe and Asia issued official expressions of regret today at the death of Yuri V. Andropov, and some indicated they would send their leaders to his funeral as a gesture to strengthen East-West relations.    Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, who did not attend the funeral of Leonid I. Brezhnev in November 1982, said he would go to Moscow. In London, the national news agency, Press Association, reported that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who was represented at the Brezhnev funeral by her Foreign Minister, might attend the ceremonies for Mr. Andropov.   There was particular interest in the main Western capitals during the day about whether President Reagan would travel to the Soviet Union. In Bonn, Foreign Ministry officials, talking to a reporter before it was announced that Vice President Bush would go to the funeral, made clear they would welcome such a gesture.

headline: Japan Asked To Act on Yen
abstract: The United States has asked Japan to draw up within a month a broad program to liberalize Japanese capital markets and make the yen a more widely used currency in international transactions, a senior American official said today.   Beryl W. Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, spoke after two days of talks here with Japanese officials, the first meeting of an official group established during President Reagan's visit to Japan last November to examine issues related to the dollar-yen exchange rate.

headline: NIGERIAN MERCHANTS WELCOME COUP
abstract: The merchants of the Oke-Arin market, one of the best places to shop for most anything here, are a varied lot. They include members of all the country's major ethnic groups. There are old men in traditional dress, teen-aged boys in U.C.L.A. T-shirts, and nursing mothers. There are some who speak fluent English with a lilting accent and others who know only the language of their own tribe or region.    With such diversity, it thus comes as something of a surprise to a visitor to discover the extent to which the merchants appear to agree on one subject: the coup that last Saturday ousted the elected Government of President Shehu Shagari and replaced it with a military regime headed by Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari.

headline: Cambodian Insurgents Report Raid on City
abstract: Guerrillas supporting the ousted Pol Pot regime said today that they had driven Vietnamese occupation troops out of western Cambodia's most important city.

headline: POLISH CARDINAL IS BACK HOME TO FACE FUROR OVER CRUCIFIXES
abstract: Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, returned home today from a South American tour to face a conflict with the Communist authorities over the removal of crucifixes from public school classrooms and a revolt from parishioners demanding that he rescind the transfer of a pro-Solidarity priest.    In the industrial suburb of Ursus, nine people were back on a hunger strike tonight to protest the transfer of the pro-Solidarity priest, Father Mieczyslaw Nowak, from St. Joseph the Worker Church. The church was filled again for a brief protest mass.

headline: MRS. THATCHER SAID TO SEE NO WAY FOR BRITAIN TO KEEP HONG KONG
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has concluded that there is no chance of Britain's retaining administrative control over Hong Kong after 1997, the year that the lease on part of the colony is due to expire, Government officials said today.    But while saying that Mrs. Thatcher had already made a decision, the officials said they could neither confirm nor deny a report in The Sunday Times of London to the effect that Britain told the Chinese in mid-December, on the personal instructions of the Prime Minister, that it was prepared to drop its original insistence on retaining administrative control for an indefinite transition period in return for Chinese promises of a capitalist future for Hong Kong.   The officials said they agreed with independent British experts on the Far East that the account given by the newspaper could well be correct.

headline: NAZI-HUNTER TELLS OF HER EFFORTS
abstract: Beate Klarsfeld, a pursuer of Nazis who recently went to South America to campaign against sanctuary for war criminals, said yesterday in New York that Paraguayan officials had assured her they would arrest and deport Josef Mengele, the former Auschwitz doctor, if they could find him. But she said the officials, the Minister of the Interior and the head of the Supreme Court, asserted that he could not be found.   Mrs. Klarsfeld said it was the first such assurance from the Paraguayan Government, which she said has protected the Nazi fugitive since his arrival from Argentina in 1960. Survivors say Dr.  Mengele conducted medical experiments on prisoners at Auschwitz and selected new arrivals to be put to death in the gas chambers. He is wanted for trial in West Germany.

headline: Midlands Rejects Proposal on Stock
abstract: The Midlands Energy Company said its board had rejected a proposal to buy back 14 percent of its shares from the Evmar Oil Corporation for $33 a share. Midlands said its directors had authorized Kidder, Peabody & Company ''to seek a financial alternative that might result in the sale of the company at a price substantially higher than the current market price.''

headline: Police Keep Marchers From Entering Manila
abstract: Policemen backed by fire engines stopped several thousand anti-Government demonstrators marching into Manila today to protest a national referendum held Friday on constitutional amendments.

headline: FALL OF EAST SIDE EXPRESS
abstract: After an anxious week of uncertainty, an agreement has been reached to sell the East Side Express to a Brooklyn publisher, it was learned yesterday.    According to members of the weekly's staff, J. Frank Griffin, who publishes a string of weekly newspapers, agreed to buy the assets for $50,000. Mr. Griffin, who could not be reached for comment last night, is expected to operate the upscale, trendy paper in a lower key and with a new staff.    The current staff said that Clay Felker, the editor, had made a counteroffer, which was rejected by Leonard Stern, the owner, and that as far as the staff was concerned the fate of the newspaper they had nurtured was sealed.    For many weeks, there were reasons to believe that the latest version of the paper could succeed.    Fast and Sassy Style    Mr. Felker, the highly regarded creator of New York magazine, had gathered a sophisticated staff from publications such as Vanity Fair, Life and The Washington Post. He seemed to have solid financial backing, first from an experienced magazine publisher and later from Mr. Stern, the wealthy chairman of the Hartz Mountain Corporation.

headline: C.I.T. FACTORING OFFICIAL GOES TO BANKERS TRUST
abstract: Marvin Nadler, president and chief executive officer of the Meinhard- Commercial Corporation, has joined the Bankers Trust Company as chief executive of its factoring division. At Meinhard-Commercial, a subsidiary of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, Albert Camhi was named to succeed Mr. Nadler.     Mr. Camhi, 44, previously was president of C.I.T.'s other factoring venture, William Iselin & Company. He is succeeded there by James A. Barry Jr., 41, who had been an Iselin vice president and senior account executive.

headline: ISRAEL BOMBS 4 SITES IN LEBANON AND PATROLS PART WAY TO CAPITAL
abstract: Israeli planes bombed targets in the mountains east of Beirut today, and Israeli officials announced that a patrol of armored vehicles had advanced nearly half the distance from the Israeli line to the capital before withdrawing.    Israeli officials indicated that the patrol had been undertaken between Monday night and today.   The Israeli military action came amid signs that President Amin Gemayel was seriously considering another proposal for a political settlement of the crisis here and that it would include scrapping of the May 17 peace accord between his country and Israel, as a previous plan did. Key Christians Oppose Move    Mr. Gemayel has been under increasing pressure from Syria and Syrian-backed opposition groups in Lebanon to break the agreement. Today, however, key pro-Israeli Christian leaders said they would oppose any move to abrogate the accord, further complicating Mr. Gemayel's delicate political position.   The air attacks came at about 10:30 A.M. Ten Israeli fighter jets struck at sites in the Shuf Mountains while other planes circled above them. Syrian antiaircraft guns fired on the bombers, but Israel's Defense Ministry said all planes returned safely.  Beirut radio stations said the Israelis hit sites at Bhamdun and the nearby towns of Ain al Jadida, Bikh Shtay and Mansuriya.

headline: The U.N. Today March 19, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: 8,000 MARCHERS PROTEST PHILIPPINE ELECTIONS
abstract: About 8,000 anti-Government demonstrators approached to within 20 miles of Manila from both the north and south today in marches to promote a boycott of May 14 parliamentary elections.   The two columns of marchers, who have been on the road for four days, planned to converge Wednesday in a rally at the capital's Rizal Park near the United States Embassy.

headline: SOUTHWEST FOREST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHRIS-CRAFT GETS 19% OF WARNER
abstract: The battle for control of Warner Communications Inc. took a turn against the Australian publisher Rupert Murdoch yesterday when Chris- Craft Industries announced that it had acquired 15.2 million shares of a new preferred Warner stock, representing approximately 19 percent of Warner.     The purchase, made minutes after the Federal Trade Commission approved the deal, effectively reduced Mr. Murdoch's holding in Warner.    But almost simultaneously, the commission approved the application from News International, Mr. Murdoch's holding company, for permission to purchase up to 49.9 percent of Warner's stock. Both transactions were subject to antitrust clearance under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act.

headline: PUBLIC POMP AND PRIVATE YAWNS AS RUSSIANS VOTE
abstract: The Soviet Union held national elections today, an event rich in civic ceremony but entirely lacking in suspense.   All across the Soviet Union, loudspeakers above red-draped polling places began blaring patriotic songs at 6 A.M. Red flags and banners fluttered over the streets, and all newspapers appeared with bold red headlines across the top proclaiming: ''Everyone to the elections!''   Television news showed helicopters flying ballot boxes to remote Arctic settlements and ships at sea, and even the three cosmonauts orbiting the earth aboard the Salyut space laboratory came on the telecast to announce their votes and their endorsements of everything that the new Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, had proposed in his campaign speech two days earlier.   Mr. Chernenko, the new party leader, and his wife, Anna Dmitriyevna, cast their ballots in central Moscow. Polling officials welcomed him with carnations, and he greeted them with a jovial ''S prazdnikom!'' or ''Happy holiday!''  Woe to Tardy Voters    Every hour, radio announcers broadcast what they called results - 75 percent of eligible voters had cast their ballots by 11 A.M., 89.42 percent by noon, and by 6 P.M., four hours before polls were to close, the figure was already at 99.59 percent.

headline: Sinclair's New Personal Computer
abstract: Sinclair Research Ltd., the pioneer in Britain's thriving home computer industry, introduced a new computer designed to retail here for just over $550 and to outperform leading personal computers such as the I.B.M. PC and the Apple IIe.   Sir Clive Sinclair, chairman of the company, said that he hoped to sell more than one million units, the volume already achieved by the company's less expensive ZX81 and Spectrum models.

headline: Trans-Atlantic Cable System
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it and seven other companies had filed applications with the Federal Communications Commission to construct the first trans-Atlantic cable system that will use fiber-optic technology.

headline: MOSCOW SAYS GROMYKO CRITICIZED U.S. POLICY IN TALKS WITH SHULTZ
abstract: The Soviet Government press agency Tass said today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had ''resolutely denounced'' American policies in his meeting with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and had demanded ''practical actions'' to substantiate the Americans' declared search for international stability.   The Tass dispatch from Stockholm, where Mr. Gromyko met with Mr. Shultz, was issued while the five-hour meeting was still under way. It appeared to reflect a prepared statement Mr. Gromyko may have brought with him rather than the substance of the discussion.   The dispatch was characterized by the same criticism of United States policies as Mr. Gromyko's earlier speech at the European security conference. Tass said that, ''from the Soviet side,'' the conversation was ''conducted in a totally frank and principled manner''- implying both that the United States was less than frank or principled, and, in the parlance of Soviet communiques, that the Soviet tone at the session was combative.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 14, 1984   The Economy    The 0.2 percent drop in retail sales in February was not entirely unexpected, given the sharp rise in January of 3.3 percent, the largest since May 1975. The economy continues strong, analysts said, although they warned that purchases of more expensive items such as cars and appliances could slow if interest rates rise. (Page D1.)    Unwelcome corporate takeovers would be curbed under a bill to be proposed by Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. But mergers would be helped by the S.E.C., which wants regulatory and legislative changes that would facilitate such acquisitions. (D1.)

headline: PRIME MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: French Truckers Want Some Respect
abstract: It was just before noon. A nasty wind from the north snapped at the men standing alongside the trucks parked across the highway. Loulou from Aulnay - reddish sideburns, burgundy leather jacket, yellow cowboy boots - came forward and explained just what would happen if the Government used force to break up the drivers' blockades that are paralyzing the French road network.   "First, we run away," Loulou said. Big laughs from his truck driver friends standing around the blockaded Autoroute du Nord, just outside the Paris city limits.

headline: SYRIA WARNS U.S. NOT TO CONTINUE NAVAL SHELLING
abstract: A senior Syrian official said today that Syria would not continue to exercise ''self-restraint'' if American shelling of its positions in Lebanon persisted.    ''There has been no fire from the Syrians,'' said the official, Farouk al- Sharaa, acting Minister of Information. ''At this stage we are still exercising restraint. But self-restraint is limited; it can't go on forever.''

headline: NITZE DOUBTS SHIFT BY SOVIET
abstract: Paul H. Nitze, who was the chief United States negotiator at the talks on medium-range missiles in Europe, said today that he saw no evidence the new Soviet leadership was prepared to resume the talks.   For the new Kremlin leadership under Konstantin U. Chernenko to return to the talks, Mr. Nitze said, ''would require a change of policy which I haven't seen any evidence yet that Chernenko would be prepared to bring about.''   He added, ''I don't see any serious possibility of the Soviets deciding that this is the time to resume'' the negotiations.

headline: The U.N. Today; Jan. 10, 1984
abstract: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: KUHLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Test to Screen Phone Calls
abstract: The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania said it was planning a trial of a new service that would give telephone customers the ability to screen out unwanted calls and to know who was calling them.  The company said the service would be offered in the Harrisburg area, which has 100,000 customers, for one year starting May 20.

headline: PICKENS STILL FAVORS TRUSTS
abstract: A big winner in the proposed merger of the Gulf Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of California is T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company. He heads an investment group that has accumulated 22 million Gulf shares, or 13 percent the total, at an average price of $44 a share.     Mr. Pickens, 55 years old, had proposed late last year, after his group had purchased just over 8 percent of Gulf's shares, that the Pittsburgh company's oil and gas properties be spun off in a royalty trust. This form of trust does away with the ''double taxation'' on corporate earnings and dividends, but also reduces oil companies' control over the cash they generate.

headline: Sakharov Is Reported In Failing Health
abstract: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and rights activist, is in failing health, under constant surveillance and occasional harassment, and barred from receiving visitors in his exile in Gorky, a friend who visited him secretly said yesterday.   The friend, Natalia Gesse, a retired 70-year-old editor, said in an interview in New York that she saw Dr. Sakharov in the Volga River city last December and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, in Moscow a month ago, just before emigrating to the United States.   Both Dr. Sakharov, 62 years old, and his wife, who is 59, complained of heart ailments, Mrs. Gesse said, and Miss Bonner, who was a member of the now- disbanded Helsinki human rights group, ''feels very bad, her lips grow blue, and she looks terrible.''

headline: REMARKS BY 3 LEADERS AT FUNERAL
abstract: Following are excerpts from the speeches made by General Secretary Konstantin U. Chernenko, Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov today at the funeral of Yuri V. Andropov, as translated and distributed by the Soviet press agency Tass: Chernenko Speech    The passing away of Yuri Vladimirovich Andropov has evoked deep sorrow in the hearts of Soviet people. A glorious son of the Communist Party, an outstanding political figure, a person of great soul and kind heart has departed from life. Yuri Vladimirovich devoted all his strength till the very last day in the cause of the party and people.   His remarkable qualities as a Communist-Leninist - faithfulness to Communist ideals, unbending will, modesty and business ability, concern for a working man - all this won him immense prestige in the party and people. A leader of Leninist type, Yuri V. Andropov possessed a gift of insight into the sense of developments and the ability to comprehend them, make precise and clear conclusions, rally people together and guide them.

headline: U.S. Sues to Halt Beverly Takeover WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) - The Justice Department brought suit in an effort to prevent Beverly Enterprises, which operates more than 800 nursing homes, from acquiring another nursing home operator. The civil antitrust suit was filed in United States District Court in Macon, Ga., against Beverly, which has headquarters in Pasadena, Calif., and the target of its bid, Southern Medical Services Inc. of Birmingham, Ala.
abstract: The suit charges that the acquisition will violate the Clayton Act because it might substantially reduce competition among nursing homes in four cities in Georgia and Alabama.

headline: U.S. HAILS GRENADA TOURISM
abstract: The White House called a news conference today for a commercial announcement - the resumption of Cunard vacation cruises with stops at Grenada.   Reporters from news agencies and television networks were summoned to the office of a deputy press secretary, Peter Roussel, for an announcement, which appeared to promote the service by the Cunard Steam-Ship Company to the Caribbean island invaded by Americans last October.

headline: Showtime Plans Switch
abstract: Showtime Entertainment, a client of Benton & Bowles since December 1981, asked the agency to participate in an agency review, and it declined.

headline: TACKLING ARGENTINA'S WAYWARD ECONOMY
abstract: BUENOS AIRES BERNARDO GRINSPUN, Economics Minister of Argentina's two-month old democratic Government, describes one of his critics as a ''worker for dictators'' and calls another ''a crystal ball gazer.'' A third, he says, ''doesn't know what he's talking about.''   Mr. Grinspun is what Argentines call a person with no hair on his tongue - he speaks his mind in no uncertain terms. That outspokenness is only one of several traits that set the 58-year-old economist apart from many of his more decorous predecessors. He is also only the third Jew ever to hold a ministerial post in this officially Catholic state, a man of humble origins in a position often held by patricians and an unreconstructed politician doing what in the last decade has been mostly a technocrat's job.   Whether Mr. Grinspun's unusual background and opinionated manner will have any impact on the Argentine economy remains to be seen. But clearly some break with the past is required: Mr. Grinspun and the fledgling Administration of President Raul Alfonsin, whose election last October followed eight years of military rule, are facing the worst economic crisis in Argentine history.  ''All the economic variables are out of control,'' Mr. Grinspun groaned in a recent interview. ''It's a very tough challenge, but what we want now is to slowly put them back together again, into an understandable scheme, without any traumatic moves that could disturb the social peace and democracy Argentines have just won.''

headline: A TRUDEAU MYSTERY: IS HE BOWING OUT OR IN?
abstract: There is much speculation here over a recent disclosure that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who swims exactly 44 lengths each morning in the pool at his official residence, is having a pool installed at his own home in Montreal.    Another question being asked is why the Government's key budget speech, originally scheduled for April, was given in February. And finally, it is asked, what significance is there that six prominent members of Mr. Trudeau's Liberal Party, all known to entertain hopes or illusions of succeeding him as Prime Minister, are heading to Alberta for what would otherwise be a routine political meeting?    Tidbits like these are being traded daily by politicians and Canadian journalists in an effort to establish whether Mr. Trudeau, 65 years old, plans to resign the office he first gained in 1968, and if so, when.

headline: The U.N. Today; Jan. 31, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Commission on Trade Law, Working Group on the New International Economic Order - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 6, 1984:  MONDAY   Airborne FreightNewell CosBaldor Eletric TUESDAY   AMF IncGeneral MotorsAdams-MillisHammermill PaperAmer CyanamidKansas City P & LBemis CoPioneer CorpCentl Ill Pub ServSargent-Welch ScienEmerson ElecTimken CoFischbach Corp WEDNESDAY   Amer Business PrdtsInter North IncBelding-HeminwayMarion LaboratoriesCBS IncRockwell IntlColt IndusU S GypsumGerber Prdts THURSDAY   Carpenter TechFirst Natl State BancpDe Luxe Check PrintMaytag CoDover CorpOwens-Illinois  FRIDAY   Cowles BrdcstgMorrison-KnudsenFederal SignalUnion ElecMcNeil Corp

headline: Coastal Chief's Goal Sparks Stock Fight
abstract: Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Coastal Corporation in Houston, wants very much to acquire a natural gas pipeline company that operates within Texas.   But it looks like he will have to fight very hard to get one.    Mr. Wyatt's current target, the Houston Natural Gas Corporation, would meet his goal better than any other company, analysts say. And so a subsidiary of Coastal is offering to buy 45 percent of Houston Natural Gas's common stock for $68 a share. The $1.28 billion offer, made late last week, would give Mr. Wyatt a controlling interest since Coastal already owns slightly more than 5 percent of the company.

headline: A Nicaraguan Paper Refuses To Publish Over Censorship
abstract: The opposition newspaper La Prensa did not publish today because Government censors rejected more than half the stories planned for the front page, the paper's editor said.   It was the 11th time since March 1982, when the Sandinista Government proclaimed a state of emergency and set up a censorship office, that La Prensa decided not to publish because of censorship.

headline: LONDON'S SUNDAY TIMES SHUT
abstract: The Times newspapers of London canceled publication of The Sunday Times today and suspended 800 more workers in a dispute with unions that began over managerial duties in the news library.   News International, publisher of The Times of London and The Sunday Times, said the future of both newspapers was in jeopardy.

headline: Castle & Cooke Loss
abstract: Castle & Cooke Inc. said today that it narrowed its loss in its second quarter, ended Dec. 31, to $2.8 million, from $10.1 million in the comparable period a year earlier. The diversified grower, processor and marketer of foods said revenues rose to $345.9 million, from $327.6 million.

headline: HYTEK MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CREDIT MARKETS Prices of U.S. Issues Advance
abstract: Prices of some Government securities rose sharply yesterday in active trading. Interest rates fell as professional dealers purchased securities to repackage them for retail clients.   ''All combined, I think the Wall Street community may have bought as much as $1.5 billion to $2 billion in intermediate and longer-dated securities that were used for stripping purposes,'' said Maria Ramirez, money market economist at Merrill Lynch Economics Inc.   She was referring to the practice whereby brokerages buy such securities, ''strip'' their interest coupons from them and then reissue them as zero coupon bonds. These bonds are sold at a substantial discount from their par, or face, values, with all interest paid at maturity. Such bonds are very popular with small investors, who often put them in their individual retirement accounts, or in college programs for children.

headline: EARNINGS Amax Loss Wider in 4th Quarter Amax Inc. announced yesterday that its loss in the fourth quarter of 1983 widened to $367 million from $244 million a year earlier.
abstract: Results for the quarter and for the full year were depressed by a provision of $309 million for losses on properties and investments, principally in molybdenum and copper, the Greenwich, Conn., company said.    Amax, the world's largest producer of molybdenum and a leading producer of base metals, silver, coal, petroleum, aluminum, iron ore and chemicals, said sales in the latest quarter rose 3.9 percent, to $561 million, from $540 million a year earlier.

headline: ZHAO MEETS ROBOT AND SIDESTEPS BOA
abstract: First a small flashing robot stepped on the Chinese Prime Minister's toes. Then a 7-foot Colombian boa constrictor stuck out its forked tongue at him. Then Zhao Ziyang was treated to a slide show of bugs eating fruit and given a chance to examine some dead mosquitoes in a bottle.    Mr. Zhao was on the road in America, seeing unofficial pursuits and ordinary citizens after leaving the high- level talks and cocktail parties of Washington behind him.

headline: South Africa Attacked Civilians, Angola Says
abstract: The official Angolan press agency said today that South African planes had bombed the village of Luiovo, wounding many civilians.   Quoting a Defense Ministry communique, the agency denied South African reports that the attack had hit missile batteries and the main headquarters of Namibian guerrillas fighting for the independence of South-West Africa from South Africa. The Angolan Government says there are no Namibian guerrillas based in southern Angola.

headline: Hazeltine Wins F.A.A. Contract The Hazeltine Corporation of Greenlawn, L.I., was awarded a $90.6 million contract yesterday to begin producing a radically advanced type of landing aid that will enable planes to fly a wide variety of approach paths to airport runways.
abstract: Under the Federal Aviation Administration contract, the agency said, the company will deliver 172 of the new landing aids over a five-year period beginning in the summer of 1985.

headline: Brazil Inflation At 213.2% Rate
abstract: Brazilian inflation rose sharply to 9.8 percent for January, pushing the annual rate to a record 213.2 percent, the independent Getulio Vargas Foundation said today. The foundation said prices in January showed ''a sizable increase in inflationary tendency'' compared with December, when inflation was 7.6 percent.

headline: Plea on Bank Law Updating
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, called today for a swift overhaul of antiquated Federal banking laws to cope with wide-ranging changes in the financial industry.   ''We need action, and we need it this year,'' Mr. Regan told the Senate Banking Committee.   Both Mr. Regan and Mr. Volcker said growing competition among banks, savings and loans and security companies to provide financial services was threatening the foundation of the nation's banking industry.

headline: Israel Adopts Tighter Curb On Currency
abstract: Israel tightened its currency restrictions tonight in a substantial retreat from the liberal reforms introduced in 1977 when the Likud administration took over.    Finance Minister Yigal Cohen- Orgad, in a television interview, said the new rules would repatriate vast sums of foreign currencies held abroad by Israelis and help reduce the $5.1 billion annual deficit in the balance of payments by $1 billion.

headline: U.S.-SOVIET PARLEY ON DIVISIVE ISSUES IS HELD IN SWEDEN
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union met for five hours today to discuss virtually every issue that has divided the two countries.   Against a background of strained relations, this was the first time in 15 months that the two men had discussed a wide range of topics. They met at the United Nations in September 1982. A more recent meeting, in Madrid last September, was devoted mainly to recriminations over the downing of the South Korean airliner.

headline: Murdoch Joins Board
abstract: Rupert Murdoch has been elected a director of the United Technologies Corporation. Harry Gray, the chairman and chief executive officer of United Technologies, said Mr. Murdoch would ''enhance our developing global profile.'' Mr. Murdoch publishes newspapers in Britain, Australia and the United States.

headline: 4 Challenged Ad Claims Are Dropped or Altered
abstract: The National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus ended 1983 without any particular fireworks.

headline: SAUL TO STEP DOWN AS CIGNA CHAIRMAN
abstract: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that Ralph S. Saul would step down as chairman April 25 at the annual meeting of shareholders. Robert D. Kilpatrick, president and chief executive officer of the huge insurance company, will take on the chairman's duties as well.    Mr. Kilpatrick, who is 59 years old, said the change would have a ''minimal impact'' on the company.

headline: EGG INDUSTRY PROBLEMS RISE
abstract: After 50 years in the egg business, 82-year-old Max Ballas last week swept the chicken coops at his Lumber City, Ga., farm, settled accounts with creditors, then sadly, and with some bitterness, said goodbye to his neighbors.    For the last three, painful years, Mr. Ballas watched his egg production slide from 3,000 cases a day to 2,400 a week, and finally was forced to sell to a bigger egg farmer down the road. ''It devastated me,'' he said, ''but I just couldn't hold on.''
