Mr. Ballas is one of almost 2,000 egg farmers throughout the United States who have been forced out of the $9.5 billion-a-year poultry industry since 1980 by a combination of high costs, sluggish demand, and, until recently, low retail prices.

headline: SSC&B Will Buy Vos For Direct Marketing
abstract: SSC&B, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is going to join the pack of agencies with direct marketing capability.

headline: Oklahoma Bank Charges
abstract: A Tulsa, Okla., bank holding company once headed by the new president of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation was charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission today with publicly exaggerating its earnings by underestimating its likely loan losses by millions of dollars in mid-1982.   At the time, Victor M. Thompson Jr., the new head of the quasi-governmental fuels agency, was chairman and chief executive of the Utica Bankshares Corporation and its only bank, the Utica National Bank and Trust Company.

headline: PERSONAL INCOME IS UP AND SPENDING OFF 0.7%
abstract: Americans' personal income rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in February, but for the first time in seven months, their spending dropped, by a like amount, the Commerce Department reported today.   The seven-tenths of 1 percent drop in personal consumption spending last month was led by a falloff in auto sales. It was the first drop since a slight one-tenth of 1 percent dip in August and the sharpest decline since January 1978, when personal spending fell eight-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: 3M in Japan
abstract: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said its 3M Health Care Ltd. and Sumitomo 3M subsidiaries had signed agreements with the Eisai Pharmaceutical Company of Japan to introduce pharmaceutical products in Japan. It said the agreements involve development and marketing in Japan of flecainide acetate, a drug designed to control heart rhythm disturbances.

headline: THAYER RESIGNS TO FIGHT S.E.C. SUIT
abstract: Paul Thayer, Deputy Secretary of Defense, resigned his post one day before the S.E.C. filed an insider trading suit against him and eight other defendants. The former chairman of the LTV Corporation was charged with disclosing inside information about profits, dividends and takeover attempts by LTV, the Allied Corporation and Anheuser-Busch to two of the defendants - a woman with whom he had a ''private, personal relationship'' and a broker with the Dallas office of A.G. Edwards & Sons. The S.E.C. charged that the two in turn passed the information on to the other defendants. In all, the group is charged with making some $1.9 million in stock trading profits. However, the suit did not charge Mr. Thayer with any monetary gain from the stock tips. Mr. Thayer called the charges ''entirely without merit,'' but said he had decided to resign so that he could devote all his time to his defense and could save the Reagan Administration political embarassment.

headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Tire Stocks, Pro and Con
abstract: P RODUCTION is booming in tire plants and, after a lackluster year for tire equities, logic would indicate that prospects for market appreciation should appear bright in 1984.   But the biggest brokerage firm and the largest investment advisory service in the nation take opposite views. Merrill Lynch is relatively sanguine for the coming year, while the Value Line Investment Survey is negative.    Both predict that profits of major tire producers will climb in 1984. Their critical point of disagreement centers on the industry's pricing practices.

headline: Rumors Halt Dome Trading
abstract: Trading in the shares of Dome Petroleum and Dome Canada, its 48 percent owned exploration affiliate, was halted today on the Toronto and American Stock Exchanges after reports from Japan cast doubt on the financing of the Beaufort Sea drilling program.

headline: Rebels in Mozambique Free 12 Soviet Captives
abstract: South African-backed Mozambican guerrillas today freed 12 Soviet mining technicians held captive for five months, fulfilling ''a direct accord with Moscow,'' a rebel spokesman said.

headline: Foreign Steel Curb
abstract: The Commerce Department announced a preliminary ruling today that Argentina, Brazil and Mexico have illegally subsidized their steel exports to the United States.

headline: Using Leverage
abstract: To the Editor:   In their article, ''The Leveraged Buyout - Malevolent or Benevolent?'' Harry and Linda De Angelo make certain assumptions not expressly stated (Business Forum, Jan. 22). The first of these is that the managers on the way up do not perform to their greatest capabilities.

headline: WETTERAU INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRITAIN PROTESTS IRAQI MISSILE ATTACK ON CARGO SHIP
abstract: The British Government protested to Iraq today over a missile attack that damaged a British cargo ship in the Persian Gulf last week.   The protest, delivered by the Foreign Office to Ambassador Wahbi al-Qaraghuli, involved an attack March 1 on the 19,201-ton Charming while she was part of a convoy heading for the Iranian port of Bandar Khomeini. Several crewmen were reportedly wounded in the action, during which crewmen abandoned ship and the vessel ran aground on a sand bank.

headline: SEAGULL ENERGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KOHL'S PARTY WINS IN LOCAL VOTE
abstract: The Christian Democrats retained their majority today in local elections in the southern state of Baden-W"urttemberg. The Green Party made striking gains, establishing itself as the state's third largest political force.

headline: KING HUSSEIN PRODS P.L.O. OVER WEST BANK
abstract: King Hussein urged the Palestine Liberation Organization today to join with Jordan in peaceful efforts to free the West Bank and the Gaza Strip from Israeli occupation.    Addressing Parliament, which he reconvened recently after a 10-year suspension, the King appealed to the ''free and legitimate'' P.L.O., apparently alluding to the organization headed by Yasir Arafat as opposed to the guerrilla insurgents, to help Jordan do its ''duty to Jerusalem, Palestine and its people.''   But a senior P.L.O. leader virtually ruled out negotiations with Israel in the near future to try to work out an end to the occupation.   The P.L.O.'s second-ranking official, Khalid al-Wazir, or Abu Jihad, as he is known, said after the King's speech that it was essential that Jordan and the P.L.O. find a ''common basis for political action.'' But he rejected the plan put forth by President Reagan in September 1982 as a basis for negotiations. The plan called for autonomy for the Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza in association with Jordan.

headline: WHAT INSTITUTIONS ARE SELLING
abstract: Since Individual Retirement Accounts were made available in 1982 to all Americans with earned income, financial institutions of all types have been aggressively seeking new and repeat business from I.R.A. investors with a wide variety of offerings:  Banks and Savings and Loan Associations.  Certificates of deposit for up to five years are widely offered, at fixed rates established when the account is opened or at variable rates tied to some external benchmark and that may change periodically until the certificate matures.   Many also offer money-market deposit accounts with rates that move up or down weekly, as well as regular savings accounts, to their I.R.A. customers. Money market interest rates have been ranging from 8.5 to 11 percent. The more often that interest is compounded, the higher the effective annual yield.

headline: PROFESSIONAL FIELDS TAKE A BETTER TURN
abstract: AFTER languishing for two years or more, the employment market for highly trained professional workers, like scientists and engineers, is improving significantly, and according to authorities this trend seems likely to continue.    Bouyed by the recovery, some companies have lifted hiring freezes on white- collar workers, including scientists and engineers. And according to colleges and employment agencies they are actively pursuing the brightest, most highly trained applicants.   The Reagan Administration's military buildup seems to be fueling the hiring in scientists and engineers; employment prospects in computer sciences are also generally high.   Even in the older nondefense and low- technology American industries, a beleaguered sector that has suffered extensive blue-collar and even white-collar layoffs, there is demand for manufacturing engineers as companies turn increasingly to computer systems and robots to increase productivity. This trend also seems sure to continue, according to the experts.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  AMF Inc., White Plains, a diversified leisure time company, has appointed Carlo A. Bertozzi president of its sailboat manufacturing division, AMF Alcort in Waterbury, Conn.     *  Bankers Trust Company has promoted Carl O. Roark to senior vice president, and head of the Global Syndications and Distribution Group.     *  CP National Corporation, San Francisco, a diversified telecommunications and energy service company, has appointed James C. Roberson executive vice president-corporate development.

headline: Iran Says It Killed 230 In Drive Against Kurds
abstract: Iran said today that it killed 230 rebels and captured 30 villages in a weeklong offensive in Kurdistan on the Iraqi border.   The Iranian press agency said Iranian forces had penetrated six miles into Iraq in the drive against ''counterrevolutionaries.''

headline: Andropov Improving, Top Soviet Aide Says
abstract: A top Soviet official said today that Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, is recovering from his illness.   ''He was ill and is getting better,'' the official, Vadim V. Zagladin, said.

headline: Fed Will Accept Florida Bank Plan
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board said it would not challenge a revised agreement under which the Florida National Banks of Florida would be acquired by the Chemical New York Corporation, the banking companies said. The merger could not be achieved, however, until such interstate acquisitions are allowed by law.

headline: Coleco Phones
abstract: Coleco Industries said it plans to introduce a line of telephones in June aimed at the teen-age market.

headline: COURT SHUNS U.S. PRICE-FIXING VIEW
abstract: The Supreme Court, rejecting the Administration's invitation to relax the prohibition against vertical price-fixing, today upheld a $10.5 million antitrust judgment against the Monsanto Company for conspiring with some of its distributors to fix resale prices.   The vote was 8 to 0.   The Court's refusal, expressed in a footnote, to use the case as a vehicle for a major change in antitrust law turned a potential landmark into a fairly routine antitrust decision.   The Justice Department had recommended that the Court use the case, Monsanto v. Spray-Rite, No. 82- 914, to hold that resale price maintenance was not always a violation of the Sherman Act's prohibition of price-fixing.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Demand Is Strong For Florida Issue A $231 million financing for the Lakeland, Fla., municipally owned electric utility was tentatively priced by Salomon Brothers to yield a maximum of 9 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2012. An insured part of the financing, 9 5/8 percent bonds due in 2012, was priced at 99 1/2 to yield 9.68 percent.
abstract: Strong demand for the issue enabled underwriters to reduce yields on the long-term bonds from the 10 percent level set early yesterday.

headline: Economic Scene; U.S. vs. Soviet Forecasting
abstract: OFFICIAL economic analysis and forecasting in the United States and the Soviet Union have certain similarities. Both are shaped by politicians eager to prove the success of their economic stewardship. Both are marked by internal battles among policy makers. Officials in both systems hate leaks of information, since information is power.   But there are crucial differences. United States official economic reporting and forecasting are heavily constrained by the competition of private economists, analysts, businessmen and reporters, where the Soviet variety can exist in a cloudland of its own.

headline: French Police Ordered To End Truck Blockade
abstract: The Government today ordered the police to break up highway blockades set up by truckers that have stranded thousands of vacationers and villagers in freezing weather across a 20,000- square-mile area of the French Alps.   A police spokesman said the blockade of major roads to the Italian border created ''the worst traffic jam in the history of French motor transport.''

headline: IRAQ WARNS ANEW ON IRANIAN PORTS
abstract: Iraq warned foreign shipping again tonight not to approach Iranian ports in the Persian Gulf. But it said it did not intend to attack the main Iranian oil terminal on Kharg Island at present.   Speaking on the Baghdad radio, an Iraqi military spokesman said the Government had decided on such a course to give the Iranians a chance ''to allow Iraq to make use of its right of navigation in the Gulf.''   ''But if they insist on preventing us from exercising this right,'' he said, ''Iraq will destroy these installations.''

headline: S.&P. Ratings Up For Boeing Debt
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation raised its ratings on about $550 million of outstanding and proposed long- term debt of the Boeing Company. Senior debt was raised to AA- from Ax and subordinated debt was raised to Ax from A. The rating on the aircraft manufacturer's short-term commercial paper was increased to the highest A-1x from A-1.    The rating agency said Boeing's financial condition had not suffered as expected from the financing of customer orders and increased inventories related to developing new planes.

headline: ADVERTISING ;  Addendum
abstract: * TBWA Advertising has opened an office in Rome.

headline: TO REGAIN CRUCIFIXES, POLISH STUDENTS HOLD SIT-IN
abstract: Agricultural students took over their state- run college here today, demanding that crucifixes be put back up in their classrooms.  The authorities ordered the college ''suspended'' late tonight and the area was surrounded by riot police, according to Roman Catholic priests in the neighboring village of Garwolin who talked to students who managed to evade the police lines.  The priests estimated that 400 of the school's 650 students were involved in the strike and sit-in.  A handful of youths told the priests they had tried to march to the Church of the Transfiguration in Garwolin but had turned back when faced with a line of riot police. The strikers were locked in the dormitories, they said, while the police with dogs searched the fields for stragglers or townspeople trying to join the protest.  The local prosecutor had warned them that their demonstration was illegal, the students said, and then the director read an official letter announcing the suspension of the school.

headline: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS TRY TO EASE TRADE CURBS
abstract: The United States and its industrial allies are moving toward an agreement on a new trade pact intended to reduce protectionism now that their economies are starting to recover from the recession, according to Western diplomats involved in the negotiations.    At the annual ministerial meeting in May of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, these countries are expected to agree to accelerate tariff cuts that they are already committed to under the so- called Tokyo Round agreement of 1979, these sources said.   Two Added Goals    In addition, they hope to roll back most of the trade restrictions that all Western nations introduced at the depth of the recession, although details of this commitment are proving more difficult to agree on. At the May meeting, these countries also hope to announce steps to help the poorest countries increase their exports to industrial nations.

headline: APPEALS COURT UPHOLDS S.E.C.'S NEWSLETTER BAN
abstract: An appeals court has ruled that the Securities and Exchange Commission may prohibit the publication of an investment newsletter because the publisher was convicted of crimes.    In a 2-to-1 decision issued Wednesday in Manhattan, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed a lower court, which had ruled that prohibiting such publication violated the First Amendment.   The case involves Christopher L. Lowe, who publishes the Lowe Investment and Financial Letter. The S.E.C. revoked his registration as an investment adviser, barring him from issuing his newsletter. But he continued to publish it, bringing on the court battle.

headline: ALLIES OF SYRIANS IN LEBANON LEAVE FOR UNITY PARLEY
abstract: Leaders of Syria's Lebanese allies left here today for the opening Monday of the new round in the Lebanese unity conference in Switzerland amid signs of continuing political discord.    The Lebanese opposition leaders met here Friday and again today in an effort to agree on a joint negotiating position for the talks, which are to resume in Lausanne. The first round was held in Geneva last November.   As the Lebanese departed, a high- level Soviet delegation arrived in Damascus. It is headed by Geidar A. Aliyev, a First Deputy Prime Minister, who is the first Politburo member to come here since a visit by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in 1980.

headline: Scuffle in British Coal Mine
abstract: An crowd of about 600 miners protesting job cuts today confronted Ian MacGregor, chairman of Britain's state-run coal industry, and he fell over a fence in a scuffle. He was trying to leave the offices of Ellington coal mine here when the crowd reportedly pushed up against him. Mr. McGregor, an American, had come to the mine to make an underground visit, but the protest forced him to cancel his plans.

headline: CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARENS DISPUTES QUATATIONS ON WEINBERGER
abstract: Defense Minister Moshe Arens emphatically denied today that he had made several remarks attributed to him in an article in The New York Times Magazine this Sunday.    He said he had never called Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger ''a prime candidate for psychoanalysis,'' as the article quoted him as saying.   Mr. Arens said: ''I would have to be insane to say these things, even if I thought them. And I don't think them.'' The Defense Minister telephoned Secretary Weinberger today to say that he had not made the reported statements, a spokesman said.

headline: Washington Post Profit
abstract: The Washington Post Company reported today that earnings rose 29 percent in the fourth quarter, to $28.6 million, or $2.02 a share, from $22.2 million, or $1.57 a share, a year earlier.

headline: MARY KAY COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Advest Group Inc., a financial services company based in Hartford, plans to acquire Vercoe & Company a Columbus, Ohio, securities firm. the companies said.     * American Standard Inc. , a building products company, said Trane Inc. had been merged into a subsidiary following approval by American Standard shareholders of the second and final step of a buyout of Trane, an air-conditioner maker based in La Crosse, Wis.     * Canadian Occidental Petroleum Corp.  said it had completed the purchase of the remaining 70 percent of Cities Offshore Production Co. from Occidental Petroleum Ltd. for $96.8 million.

headline: Blast in London Club Reported to Injure 30
abstract: Scotland Yard said an explosive device went off at a night club in central London's Mayfair district early today, and 30 people were reported hurt.   Details of the explosion at the L'Auberge club were fragmentary and the extent of the injuries was not immediately known.   The Press Association, the British domestic news agency, said 30 people were believed to have been hurt in the explosion at the club in Berkeley Street.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Pair of Executives Promoted at HBO
abstract: Home Box Office Inc., the Time Inc. subsidiary, announced two executive changes yesterday.    Frank J. Biondi Jr., president and chief executive, was appointed chairman and chief executive.

headline: SOVIET SAYS IT OFFERED TALKS TO REAGAN ENVOY
abstract: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass today described as a ''deception '' reports from Washington that a private American envoy carrying a personal message from President Reagan to Konstantin U. Chernenko was not given an opportunity to meet with the Soviet leader or any other top Soviet official.   The envoy, Brent Scowcroft, a retired Air Force general, was here earlier this month as a member of a private group of American foreign policy experts attending an informal meeting with Soviet officials.   After Mr. Scowcroft returned to Washington, The New York Times quoted Administration officials as having said that Mr. Scowcroft had made known to Soviet officials in Moscow that he had a letter from Mr. Reagan and some additional authorized comments, but never heard anything back and was never given an explanation.   The message taken to Moscow by Mr. Scowcroft, the sources said, was that Mr. Reagan was prepared for serious and wide-ranging talks and accommodations with the Soviet Union, including suggestions on the stalled nuclear arms talks, if the Russians would return to the bargaining table.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; MEXICO'S MIRACLE OF MIRRORS
abstract: MEXICO'S economic performance in 1983 has been depicted with great optimism. Eager for any favorable omen, Western analysts and bankers have seized on a number of financial and trade developments during the past year as happy evidence of improvement in the Mexican economy.   This positive assessment has been echoed through cheery editorials in the nation's largest newspapers, with headlines such as ''Progress in Mexico,'' ''Mexico's Strength'' and ''Mexico: Cause for Optimism.'' It has also resulted in close to $4 billion in additional loans to Mexico for 1984 at relatively low interest rates from American bankers. Justifying their unaccustomed generosity, the bankers cited positive factors stemming from Mexican President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado's stringent austerity program.

headline: SHORT-TERM U.S. BILLS SET THIS WEEK
abstract: New Treasury financings this week are confined to sales of short-term bills today and Thursday. Government securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce during the week an $8.25 billion issue of two-year notes to be auctioned next week.    In advance of today's regular sale of three- and six-month bills, dealers said outstanding three-month bills were bid late Friday at 8.74 percent and six-month bills were bid at 8.85 percent. Prior to Thursday's sale of new one-year bills, the outstanding one-year bill was bid late Friday at 8.92 percent.

headline: U.S. HOSPITALS TREATING GRENADIAN WOUNDED
abstract: A 6-year- old boy has been treated at a military hospital near here for severe wounds he received near his home in Grenada in the explosion of a grenade he had picked up thinking it was a toy.   A 72-year-old Grenadian civilian died at the same hospital recently of shrapnel wounds received in the fighting that followed the United States-led invasion of Oct. 25.   The two were among 60 wounded Grenadian civilians who were hurt seriously enough to require treatment in American military hospitals, according to the Defense Department. The hospitalization of the 60 Grenadians, who were among 358 civilians wounded in the fighting there, came to light recently after an employee of the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., mentioned in a conversation that a Grenadian boy was being treated there.

headline: MRS. DOLE PROPOSES CUTBACK IN TRUCK TAX
abstract: The Administration, seeking to amend highly unpopular truck-tax legislation passed in 1982, proposed today to sharply reduce the use tax for the heaviest trucks while exempting all other trucks from the tax .  But the proposal also provided for a 6-cent- a-gallon increase in taxes on all diesel fuel.   The plan, which Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole described as neither raising nor lowering the aggregate tax, would redistribute the tax burden to be more closely related to the number of miles a truck is actually driven.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Underground Nuclear Blast Detected in Western Siberia
abstract: The Soviet Union set off an underground nuclear explosion today at a test site in western Siberia, a Swedish seismological institute reported.

headline: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY SHULTZ
abstract: Following is the text of a statement today by Secretary of State George P. Shultz on the death of Yuri V. Andropov:    The President has expressed his personal condolences to the Soviet leadership on the death of Chairman Andropov, and I have sent a similar message to Foreign Minister Gromyko.   At this time of transition in Moscow, let me reaffirm the basic principles of our policy toward the Soviet Union.

headline: Gulf Oil Sells Unit
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Italian refining and marketing operations to the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation for an undisclosed amount. Gulf Italiana S.p.A. owns 75 percent of the 80,000-barrel- a-day Sarni refinery near Milan, along with 1,500 gasoline stations, terminals and aviation fuel outlets, a Gulf spokesman said. Gulf claims a 3.5 percent share of the gasoline market in Italy and a similar share of the petroleum products market.

headline: BRISK TRADE IN GULF PUTS FOCUS ON MESA
abstract: Heavy trading yesterday in the stock of the Gulf Corporation pushed the price up $2.125, to $56.75 a share, and heightened speculation that T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Corporation, may be on the verge of making a takeover bid for Gulf.     The $10 rise in Gulf shares in the last three weeks seems to have convinced Wall Street professionals - who acknowledge they are acting on little more than instinct - that a takeover battle between Mesa and Gulf will erupt before long.    But in what appeared to be a denial of the rumors, Mr. Pickens remarked yesterday, ''That's very interesting; it's the first time I've heard it.''    Almost identical reports circulated last Friday and again last Monday, but nothing happened. Thus, the heavy 1.3-million-share turnover yesterday was read as a sign that Mr. Pickens might now be ready to make his move.

headline: TASS SAYS U.S. ACTS IN PERSIAN GULF IMPERIL PEACE
abstract: Tass, the Soviet press agency, said in a statement today that the Soviet Union did not recognize a restriction on air and sea traffic imposed by the United States in the Persian Gulf. It said the United States actions in the gulf were ''creating a grave threat to peace and international security'' and warned of ''possible dangerous consequences.''    The Kremlin frequently uses Tass to express its views on international issues. However, Tass statements, while considered authoritative, generally do not carry the same weight as a Government pronouncement, which the Kremlin reserves for issues considered to be of primary importance.

headline: U.N. PUTS OFF VOTE ON LEBANON TROOPS
abstract: The Security Council met in closed- door session today to consider a French proposal to authorize sending United Nations troops to Beirut amid indications that Soviet-Western differences might threaten the plan.   After two sessions of informal consultations, the Council decided to put off a vote and meet again Tuesday. In the meantime, the French delegation was expected to redraft its proposals in an effort to incorporate a host of demands made by several sides to the discussion, including the Soviet Union, the United States and a group of third- world countries.   The French proposal has been under discussion in the Security Council since Feb. 15.

headline: Citicorp Paper
abstract: Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 9.677 percent, up from 9.638 percent a week ago. It also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 9.743 percent, up from 9.607 percent. The bank holding company sells 91- and 182-day paper weekly.

headline: Blue Bell Stock
abstract: Blue Bell Inc. said it had acquired 1.1 million shares of its own stock from a Bass Brothers group pursuant to an option granted by Bass last Nov. 17.

headline: Canadian Confidence
abstract: Consumer confidence in Canada dipped sharply in the fourth quarter of 1983 after reaching an 18-year high in the second and third quarters, according to the latest survey by the Conference Board of Canada, a business-sponsored research group. The board's seasonally adjusted index of consumer attitudes dropped to 103.3, base 1961, in the fourth quarter, from 123.3 in the two previous quarters. It is the first decline in the index since it began its rapid upward climb in the third quarter of 1982, the board said.

headline: ON BLEAK ISLES, RESENTMENT OF SEALERS SPILLS OUT
abstract: -AUX-MEULES, Quebec, March 22 - For the 14,000 residents of the windswept Magdalen Islands in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, virtually all of life's necessities must be imported and the only industry is a money-losing, Government-subsidized salt mine. Fully 70 percent of the population is unemployed this time of year.    Now the islands' hardscrabble fishermen cannot even count on the seals they have killed for centuries. A year- old European boycott of seal pelts, a boycott of Canadian fish products by British supermarkets and the beginning of demonstrations at McDonald's restaurants in the United States have dried up a once thriving market.

headline: Retail Sales Off 0.1% in Month
abstract: Retail sales fell $155 million, or one-tenth of 1 percent, in February from the same month a year earlier, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: FED TIGHTENS BANK RESERVE RULES
abstract: The veil of mystery that surrounds the Federal Reserve's monetary policy may become a little harder to see through under a new accounting procedure that begins today.     The change, which affects the way banks account for their reserves, is intended to give the Fed tighter control over the growth of M-1, the closely watched measure of money available for spending.    Actual results may be different, however, since Fed officials have been saying since October 1982 that they are setting monetary policy less according to changes in M-1 and more according to what happens with inflation and the economy as a whole.    In the credit markets, analysts are grinding their teeth because the change could make short-term rates more volatile and make it harder to predict money supply changes and to interpret Federal Reserve policy.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  American Express Co.  announced that Robert G. Moore had joined the company as senior vice president-investments, and that Michael Panitch, vice chairman of its IDS/American Express subsidiary, had resigned.     *  Alaska Airlines Inc., Anchorage, has elected Lawrence M. Hogan vice president-flight operations.

headline: GRENADA RECEIVES AIRPORT PLEDGES
abstract: Grenada has received pledges of $24 million to complete construction of an airport that was begun here in 1980 with Cuban funds and labor, the leader of the island's interim Government said Sunday night.   Nicholas Brathwaite, the interim leader, refused to name the countries pledging the money to finish the airport.

headline: VW-Porsche Split
abstract: Volkswagen of America Inc., a subsidiary of Volkswagenwerk A.G., said it had been notified that Porsche will not renew its importer and license agreement with VW after Aug. 31. A VW spokesman said his company had not been told of Porsche's future plans for its car business in the United States market.

headline: PORTRAIT OF SPY AS GOLDEN YOUNG MAN
abstract: Only 10 days ago, with Secretary of State George P. Shultz here for talks, Arne Treholt was, as usual, close to the action.    Mr. Treholt, as head of the foreign press section of the Foreign Ministry, was in charge of press arrangements for Mr. Shultz's visit.   Personable, industrious and well connected, the 41-year-old Mr. Treholt was widely regarded as one of the golden young men of public life in Norway.   Less than 24 hours later, he was under arrest, charged with spying for the Soviet Union. The Norwegian security police said Mr. Treholt was detained at the airport on his way to Vienna, where he planned to hand over secret documents to his contact from the K.G.B., the Soviet secret police. A week later commentators here were calling Mr. Treholt the greatest traitor to Norway since Quisling.

headline: F.C.C. WON'T BLOCK WARNER STOCK DEAL
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission ruled yesterday that it would not overturn the stock deal that made Chris-Craft Industries the largest stockholder in Warner Communications Inc., thus dealing a blow to Rupert Murdoch's bid for control of Warner.     News International P.L.C., one of Mr. Murdoch's holding companies, had petitioned the F.C.C. to overturn the Jan. 18 transaction on the ground that it violated F.C.C. rules prohibiting overlapping television and newspaper holdings, overlapping television broadcasting and cable television holdings, and that there had been a transfer of control between broadcasting companies, something that would have required F.C.C. approval.

headline: LEBANON INVITES FACTIONS TO SWISS TALKS
abstract: The Government today formally invited Lebanese political leaders to a reconciliation conference that is to convene in Switzerland on Monday.    The purpose of the meeting, long sought by President Amin Gemayel, is to draw together Christian and Moslem leaders, including key members of the Moslem opposition who only recently dropped their demands that the President resign.   The conference is to discuss changes in Lebanon's political system and the formation of a new Government.   The Christian Phalangist militia, which condemned Mr. Gemayel's decision to break the troop withdrawal agreement with Israel, will not attend. The group had no formal representatives at a reconciliation conference that recessed last November.

headline: DEATH HELPS RAISE THE KREMLIN VEIL
abstract: As has happened before, the world is learning more about a Soviet leader in death than during his lifeftime.    For example, the lying-in-state ceremonies for Yuri V. Andropov, who died Thursday at the age of 69, have revealed that he had a living wife, Tatyana. At the outset of his 15- month tenure in the Kremlin many Western reports described him as a widower. Six weeks ago the United States Embassy here was sufficiently doubtful that it asked the Foreign Ministry whether President Reagan's New Year greetings should be addressed to both the Soviet leader and his wife.   Lingering Uncertainty    The answer was affirmative, but doubt lingered until the lying-in-state. In the front row of seats reserved for the dead leader's family, her reddish- tinted hair held in place with a hairclip, sat a woman of late middle age identified as Mr. Andropov's widow. Officials supplied her first name.

headline: Beneficial Issue
abstract: A $75 million issue of Beneficial Corporation 12.6 percent notes due in 1994 are offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The yield on the notes, rated A-3/A, was 56 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.

headline: S.E.C. Staff Backs Ford
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission's staff has upheld the Ford Motor Company's right to ignore a shareholder proposal submitted by a dismissed company vice president who wants Ford to study merging with the Chrysler Corporation, according to documents released today.   The S.E.C. staff sent Ford a letter this week saying that it would not recommend enforcement action if the auto maker chose to omit the proposal of an ousted vice president, Thomas Feaheny, from proxy materials for its May annual meeting.

headline: JACKSON EXTENDS SYRIA VISIT TO HOLD MEETING WITH ASSAD
abstract: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who arrived here Friday seeking the release of a captured American bombardier-navigator, said today that he was extending his stay another day in order to meet with President Hafez al-Assad.    Mr. Jackson, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said at a news conference that he had planned to return to the United States with his party of 14 on Monday but extended the visit when he learned today that a meeting with President Assad had been definitely scheduled for Monday. It was originally scheduled for Saturday, after the delegation's visit with the captured United States Navy bombardier-navigator, Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr.

headline: PLANNING RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SYSCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, JANUARY 28, 1984
abstract: The Economy    The bitter dissent within the Reagan Administration on economic policy has erupted again over a draft of the Economic Report of the President. The report was written by Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers; the discord concerns the same issue that led to his rebuke by the White House in recent months - his emphasis on the budget deficits. (Page 1.)   America's merchandise trade deficit narrowed in December to $6.3 billion from $7.4 billion in November, because of a dip in oil imports and a surge in aircraft sales. But 1983's deficit soared to $69.4 billion, topping the 1982 record by 62 percent. (29.)

headline: American to Offer More Coast Flights
abstract: American Airlines said today that it will increase the number of its nonstop coast-to-coast flights by 73 percent this summer.   American plans to double its New York-Los Angeles schedules to eight round-trip flights a day and introduce two daily flights from Newark to Los Angeles, according to Thomas G. Plaskett, senior vice president-marketing.

headline: VEECO INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New Editor Appointed At Advertising Age
abstract: Fred Danzig, 53-year-old executive editor of Advertising Age, has been promoted to editor.

headline: 2 Candidates in Ecuador Win Spots in a Runoff
abstract: A Conservative and a Social Democrat placed first and second in presidential elections today and will face each other in a runoff May 6. Seven other candidates were eliminated.

headline: CRIMINAL LAW REVISION INTRODUCED IN CANADA
abstract: The Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has introduced legislation that would sweepingly alter Canadian criminal law. It would permit, among other things, life sentences for violent criminals while allowing victims of crimes to seek restitution and punitive damages from offenders.   Other parts of the 306-page bill provide stiff prison terms for drunken- driving offenses and court seizures of money and assets gained through criminal activity. The bill would also expand the meaning of obscenity to embrace anything that degradingly exploits crime, horror, cruelty or violence as well as sex.

headline: People
abstract: Bruce G. Silverman has joined BBDO/West, Los Angeles, as executive vice president, executive creative director.     *  Jeannette E. Paladino has been appointed vice president, advertising director for the Bowery Savings Bank.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Procedure to Fabricate Diamond Heat Sink    A procedure for fabricating a diamond heat sink is covered by a patent received this week by the Martin Marietta Corporation, Bethesda, Md.

headline: Guatemala's Opposition Criticizes High Official
abstract: Guatemalan opposition leaders are calling for the resignation of Interior Minister Gustavo Adolfo Lopez Sandoval, saying he has been unable to halt a recent surge in political violence.   A communique issued on Thursday by the Guatemalan Christian Democratic Party said ''it is evident that the Interior Minister has shown irresponsibility and negligence in the face of the growing wave of violence that has hit the country.''

headline: Younger Executives Rise at Heilig-Meyers William C. Derusha, president of the Heilig-Meyers Company, a furniture retailer in the South, was named yesterday to the additional post of chief executive. The company also announced the retirements of Hyman Meyers, chairman and chief executive, and of two vice chairmen, effective June 30. The posts of chairman and vice chairman are being eliminated.
abstract: In a telephone interview from the company's offices in Richmond, Mr. Derusha, who is 34 years old, said the changes represented the second phase in a management transition. The first phase was in January 1983, when Mr. Derusha, who had held a variety of posts at Heilig-Meyers, was promoted from director of operations to president and chief operating officer.

headline: Philippines Promotes One of Aquino Guards
abstract: A promotion to second lieutenant has been announced for a Philippine Air Force sergeant who was guarding the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. when he was assassinated at the Manila airport last August.   Sgt. Arnulfo de Mesa was among 189 men the presidential palace said were being commissioned ''as part of the buildup of the country's reserve pool in accordance with the National Defense Act.''

headline: Peking Diplomat Defects
abstract: An interpreter at the Chinese Embassy in Gambia, Tai Kang, has defected to Taiwan. Mr. Tai, 25 years old, said at a news conference that he was sent to Gambia in January 1983, learned of Taiwan's prosperity, and decided to defect. He said he came here through South Africa.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: Chemical Bank announced that Louis F. Dempsey had joined it as executive vice president in charge of the bank's International Investment Services division.     *  Commodity Exchange Inc.  has re- elected Oscar Burchard, president of the Ore and Chemical Corp., to another term as chairman.

headline: Cable TV Penetration
abstract: A. C. Nielsen has released its latest quarterly report on the household penetration of cable TV, which has now reached 41.2 percent of the nation's 34.7 million television households. This compares with 37.2 percent in February 1983 and 40.5 percent last November.

headline: Chinese Says U.S. Ties Hinge on Taiwan Issue
abstract: Deputy Prime Minister Wan Li of China, looking ahead to President Reagan's visit here late next month, today ruled out any substantial improvement in relations with the United States until the Taiwan issue is resolved.   ''We welcome President Reagan,'' he told Chinese and Japanese journalists, ''but no significant progress can be made in our bilateral relations before the Taiwan issue is properly resolved.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1984
abstract: International    Argentina's new Government is struggling to solve the nation's severe debt and inflation problems in the face of opposition from unions allied to former military rulers. (Page A1.)   The Common Market, pushed near bankruptcy by disputes over farm subsidies, begins a crucial meeting in Brussels. (A3.)

headline: THE U.S. IS SAID TO TAKE BRIGHTER VIEW OF SYRIA
abstract: A senior State Department official said today that the United States no longer believed that Syria was trying to thwart an agreement on Lebanon.   The official, Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth W. Dam, also said ''events on the ground'' were changing in Lebanon and the United States was ''quite prepared to seek progress'' in talks with the Syrians.   He said Syria's decision last week to release Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr. to the Rev. Jesse Jackson may have been an indication of this new attitude.

headline: STANDARD OIL OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WINDMERE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FIGHT SEEN IN OFFER FOR HOUSTON GAS
abstract: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation is likely do everything in its power to resist an unexpected $68- a-share offer from the Coastal Corporation for 45 percent of its shares, analysts said yesterday.    However, Houston Natural, the nation's largest intrastate pipeline company and a small oil and gas producer, declined yesterday to say how it would respond to Coastal's surprise Thursday night offer.    In a statement, M. D. Matthews, the company's chief executive, said the Houston Natural board would study the offer and act in the ''best interests of both shareholders and employees.''    Counterbid Anticipated    But analysts said they were convinced that Houston Natural would defend itself by seeking a friendly suitor to make a higher bid for 100 percent of its shares, or by some other means. Some suggested that Houston Natural, which as recently as October reported more than $100 million in cash and marketable securities, might respond with a competing offer for control of Coastal.

headline: IRAQ LEAVES DEAD IRANIANS TO DISPLAY TO REPORTERS
abstract: The body of Mohammed Ali Balkhad Abadi is lying in a swamp here, together with the other Iranian soldiers who were killed when Iraq recaptured this village in the border marshes last Tuesday.   Next to the young soldier lay a book of injunctions and encouragements of various ayatollahs that is part of thear issued to the Iranian early teen- agers who are bearing the brunt of battle in this war.   When he died, he had left blank the pages on which the conscripts are invited to note whether there is anything they need.   Even dead, the youth continues to serve in this war. He is one of those that the Iraqi army has left at the edge of the swamp when it removed the hundreds of other dead in this village 62 miles north-northwest of Basra, the Iraqi oil port. They are meant to serve as a target for the cameras of the Western press.

headline: ;  Chrysler Financial
abstract: A $200 million issue of Chrysler Financial Corporation 13 1/2 percent senior notes due in 1991 is offered today at a price of 98.6 to yield 13.82 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes have speculative grade ratings of Ba-3 from Moody's Investors Service and B by Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: PATENTS ; Visual Telephone Aid For Hearing-Impaired
abstract: A telephone receiver designed to produce visual information for persons with impaired hearing has been invented for the General Electric Company by Edwin C. Underkoffler of the staff in Schenectady, N.Y. Patent 4,426,555 was granted this week.

headline: ECONOMIC INDEX UP STRONG 0.7%
abstract: The index of leading economic indicators, which is the Government's main economic forecasting gauge, rose a healthy seven-tenths of 1 percent in February, prompting the White House to assert that the economy was ''still on a roll.''   The Commerce Department, which reported the gain, said February's rise was the 17th in the last 18 months.   Last month's rise was less than the 1 percent January increase but well above December's advance of only two-tenths of 1 percent. The index was unchanged in November.

headline: BONN CHANCELLOR ARRIVES IN ISRAEL
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany arrived in Israel today amid extraordinarily tight security and small, angry demonstrations by Israeli survivors of the Nazi scourge.      He was met by about 100 protesters at his first stop, the Yad Vashem museum and memorial in Jerusalem to the six million Jews who died at the hands of the Nazis. As his armored black limousine sped past the group, a small, gray-haired woman shook her fist and shouted until she nearly wept.   Along the routes of his motorcade, young men tried to tear down some of the West German flags that were flying alongside the Star of David. The police said they arrested a student. Another youth was also hustled into a police car after he purportedly tried to throw a stone at the motorcade. Among the demonstrators were young members of the Herut Party's right-wing Betar movement.

headline: AN EXPLOSION DAMAGES ISRAELI POST IN LEBANON
abstract: An explosion occurred tonight at a Government building in Sidon where an Israeli intelligence post and frontier guard headquarters are located.   Some residents said a shell had been fired at the building in the southern Lebanese port town.

headline: GETTY DEAL COMPLETED BY TEXACO
abstract: Texaco Inc. announced last night that it had reached agreement with Gordon P. Getty, trustee of the Sarah C. Getty Trust, to buy the 31.8 million Getty Oil Company shares held by the trust for $125 a share, or $3.98 billion. This represents 40.2 percent of Getty's shares outstanding and gives Texaco control of the company, subject only to antitrust clearance.     The Justice Department, which said it would investigate the antitrust implications, has about a month to respond. It might ask for additional information, which would take somewhat longer. Antitrust lawyers expect any problems to be minor.   Texaco, the nation's third-largest oil company, said that beginning today it was offering to buy the nearly 28 million Getty shares that it does not yet control, also at $125 a share. It added that it was retaining the right to buy any additional shares that stockholders tender.

headline: Special Situations That May Affect Filing
abstract: EVERY taxpayer has different financial and personal circumstances. Consequently, each person confronts somewhat different problems in filling out a tax return. While it is impossible to anticipate all the different situations that may have important tax consequences, some of the more common items are discussed below.     Income Averaging    Income averaging helps taxpayers whose incomes have suddenly taken a big jump, by spreading the higher income over the previous five years, in effect leaving them in a lower tax bracket. To figure out whether income averaging will help lower your tax, add up your taxable income for the last four years. Then take 30 percent of that figure and, if this year's taxable income is at least $3,000 more than that figure, you can profitably average your income.    ''If you can average your income, you should ,'' said Lester Marks, a partner at Ernst & Whinney. ''It is a privilege that will help you.''

headline: AMFAC TO SELL 12% OF ASSETS
abstract: Amfac Inc., Hawaii's largest company, said yesterday that it would divest itself of $177 million in assets, or 12 percent of the company, and take a $25 million one-time charge against earnings in 1983. Preliminary results indicate that Amfac will post a loss of $68 million in 1983; earnings are to be reported Thursday.     Myron Du Bain, president and chief executive of the 134-year-old diversified company, announced that Amfac would sell its horticulture operations and its 10-store retail operation, Liberty House of California. He said a $15 million after-tax reserve had been taken against the horticulture group and one of $10 million against the Liberty House operation.

headline: Economic Scene; Reagan's Shift On the Deficits
abstract: WASHINGTON   D O deficits really matter? Just a couple of weeks ago, the Reagan Administration appeared to be saying no, they did not; the important thing was the real growth of the economy, the conquest of inflation, the creation of jobs, the raising of productivity. So what if the Administration was submitting a budget with deficits of $180 billion or more for the next several years, coming down, on its own optimistic assumptions, only to $122 billion by 1989?   But, somewhere on the way to President Reagan's opening of his re-election campaign, something happened: Suddenly, the President has decided that deficits do matter, matter enormously. He is stressing that the conquest of deficits is the most important unfinished business of his Administration.

headline: PAYMENT BY VATICAN BANK SEEN
abstract: Pope John Paul II is expected to authorize soon a ''goodwill payment'' of $230 million by the Vatican to help compensate banks for losses suffered when Banco Ambrosiano failed, according to bankers familiar with the negotiations under way with the Vatican.    Such an unusual payment would be part of a settlement of the claims filed by 88 non-Italian banks against the Italian Government liquidators now winding up Banco Ambrosiano's affairs.   Two years ago this June, Banco Ambrosiano's president, Roberto Calvi, who was often called ''God's banker'' because of his close business association with the Vatican, was discovered hanging under Blackfriars Bridge in London, and $1.3 billion of his bank's funds were found to be missing.    Most of the money had been lent to inoperative Latin American companies that were controlled by the Vatican's own bank, Istituto per le Opere di Religione, which had guaranteed many of the loans.

headline: SIDE STREET DENSITY AT ISSUE IN MIDTOWN
abstract: For more than a decade, preserving the relatively low scale of the side streets on the East and West midtown areas of Manhattan has been a key tenet of the city's zoning code.     Now, officials of the City Planning Commission and some East Side residents contend that that goal could be undermined by a developer's attempts to construct apartment buildings larger than the zoning code permits on two Third Avenue sites, at 64th and 32d Streets. They are opposing the developer's petition for zoning variances before the Board of Standards and Appeals.   The developer, Paul Milstein, together with Robert Olnick, has proposed a 51-story building for the 64th Street site, a height that is 14 to 20 stories taller than any other building in the neighborhood. At the other site, he is seeking a 300,000-square-foot increase in space. He asserts that the variances are warranted under the zoning code's ''hardship'' provisions, and that the proposed projects would enhance, not damage, the character of the neighborhoods.

headline: PENTAGON'S PANEL ON PRESS COVERAGE TO MEET
abstract: A newly formed Pentagon panel of 14 military public information officers, former journalists and journalism professors is scheduled to meet in Washington tomorrow to take testimony and begin drafting guidelines on press access to military actions.   The chairman of the group, Winant Sidle, a retired major general and former Pentagon spokesman who is now director of public affairs for the Martin Marietta Corporation, said the panel hoped to complete its work by the end of the month. The panel is to propose written guidelines on issues such as when reporters should be notified of pending military actions and how pools of correspondents can be organized when the military feels it cannot accommodate all the reporters who want to cover an action.   The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., authorized the study in response to complaints from the Congress and the press about the exclusion of reporters from the United States invasion of Grenada.

headline: Western Union's Easylink Outlay
abstract: The Western Union Corporation said its board had approved plans to accelerate expansion of its Easylink network service that call for spending of about $70 million this year.

headline: Amdahl's Earnings Expected to Slide
abstract: The Amdahl Corporation said yesterday that its earnings for the first quarter will be below those of a year earlier.   Amdahl, a manufacturer of mainframe computers compatible with those made by the International Business Machines Corporation, said it was experiencing poorer sales than expected in Europe because customers were postponing purchase of its computers to wait for new models that will be available in large volumes in the third quarter.

headline: West German G.N.P.
abstract: West Germany's gross national product rose 1.3 percent in 1983, adjusted for inflation, the Statistics Office said today. Preliminary estimates had put the increase at 1.2 percent. The rise in 1983 followed declines of 1.1 percent in 1982 and two-tenths of 1 percent in 1981.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Dicomed Corp., Minneapolis, has arranged $7.5 million in financing, through the issuance of 12-year, 12 percent unsecured senior notes.      Common Stock     *  Aequitron Medical Inc.  filed an offering of 917,500 shares, through Bear Stearns & Co. The company also filed to rescind the sale of 1,770,828 shares already offered. It said it was acting because ''sales of common stock were made which may not have been in compliance with the registration provisions of Federal and certain state securities laws.'' The rescission offer applies to common stock sales from March 1, 1981, through Sept. 26, 1983.

headline: ISRAELI BUILDING NEW SUBURBIA ON WEST BANK
abstract: -Occupied West Bank - Maaleh Adumim appears suddenly after a bend in the Jerusalem-Jericho road, a giant futuristic beehive of white apartment houses set in close-packed tiers against the tawny hills of the Judean Desert.   The dark windows of the apartments give it an unlived-in, skeletal look, but the half-dozen cranes sticking up above the housing blocks attest to a pace of building and occupancy so rapid that the settlement's population has jumped from some 60 families in late 1982 to 1,600 now and 2,500 are planned by next December, according to town officials.   This is Israel's new suburbia, settlement planners here say.   The Government's settlement program in the occupied West Bank, once geared mainly toward establishing outposts inhabited largely by religious nationalists and soldiers, has shifted its emphasis to include large-scale ''urban'' settlements meant to draw tens of thousands of Jewish settlers.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  American Southwest Finance Co.  is offering $76 million of its mortgage- collateralized bonds, series 1984-1, through Saloman Brothers.     * Dresdner Bank of Frankfurt is offering $300 million of five-year floating-rate Euronotes bearing interest equal to the London interbank offered rate for three-month dollar deposits.

headline: JAPAN'S WINTER IS NOT JUST A CONVERSATION PIECE
abstract: People here were grumbling this weekend about the taxis.   Fares went up by almost 10 percent. Now it costs $2 just to climb into a taxi, with painfully steady increases after the first 1.2 miles.  This is no small matter in Tokyo because cab- riding is not a luxury reserved for the rich. The taxi is the limousine of the middle-class and a critical form of transport late at night, when the subways shut down and few of the people still about are in a condition to drive home. During the late hours, main avenues are wall-to-wall for many blocks with cabs.

headline: STOCKS DOWN 12.98
abstract: Major banks across the nation increased their prime lending rates a half a point yesterday, to 11 1/2 percent, the highest level since January 1983. It was the first change in the key rate since last August, and some economists and bankers predicted it could go substantially higher.    ''It's a clear response to our increased cost of funds and a signal that there's a crying need to reduce the budget deficit,'' said Alfred Brittain 3d, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company, which was among the banks that participated in the increase.    The news depressed the stock market, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 12.98 points, to 1,171.38. But trading was the lightest it has been this year. (Page D1.)

headline: Improvement At Pepsico
abstract: Pepsico Inc., the second-largest soft drink producer, reported yesterday that fourth-quarter profits totaled $77.2 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier loss of $40.7 million. Its latest results, the company said, were aided by strong performances at the Frito-Lay and food service units.

headline: RULING MAY BE HUGHES GO PUBLIC
abstract: Chancellor Grover C. Brown, Delaware's highest-ranking judge, said today that he would soon appoint a new board of trustees to lead the Howard Hughes Medical Institute because the institute's executive committee had not been empowered by the late billionaire, Howard R. Hughes, to act as trustee.    His decision raised the possibility that at least a portion of the Hughes Aircraft Company, a major military electronics supplier that is owned by the medical institute, could be sold to the public within the next few years, according to Bartholomew Dalton, Delaware's Chief Deputy Attorney General.   ''Modern trust theory says portfolios should be diversified, but whether that is applicable in this situation, I can't say,'' he added in a telephone interview.   A spokesman for Hughes Aircraft, Lee Pitt, declined to comment on the ruling. But he hinted at a possible sale by the institute when he added: ''We have realized for several years that the era of one type of ownership might be ending.''

headline: BUFFTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Reagan and FitzGerald Meet
abstract: President Reagan joined Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland today in calling for an end to terrorism in Northern Ireland and reconciliation between the British province's Roman Catholics and Protestants. Mr. Reagan, who is to visit Ireland in June, spoke at a White House luncheon for Mr. FitzGerald after they held talks.

headline: L.I. CONDOMINIUMS ARE DRAWING FIRST-TIME BUYERS
abstract: Developers of condominiums near the south shore of western Nassau County are finding that new housing can be produced at costs that will make it affordable to households with incomes as low as about $40,000 a year.    It is a figure low enough for many first-time buyers to afford, and their number is substantial among the purchasers. For example, at a 128-unit waterfront development in Island Park called the Yacht Club, where prices range from $97,000 to $152,500, most of the early buyers earn $40,000 to $70,000, according to Richard B. Lituchy, a 30-year-old architect who is a principal in the family-owned development company, the Halandia Group, based in Oceanside.   In Wantagh, a new 185-unit development, called Willow Wood, on the site once occupied by the Dauhrnheim Nursery, at Wantagh Avenue and Jerusalem Avenue, is also attracting buyers at incomes upward of $40,000. The Breslin Realty Development Corporation is the builder.

headline: PATENTS; 'Talking Micrometer'
abstract: A device called a ''talking micrometer,'' patented this week, is able to describe the measurements of objects in words, such as a train of numbers. Jerome H. Lemelson, who received patent 4,437,241, says the instrument will be particularly useful for people who are blind or have poor eyesight, and will offer advantages over conventional micrometers such as reducing eye fatigue and reading errors. Mr. Lemelson, who operates a licensing management corporation in New York, expects to license production of the device.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Former Gimbels Head Chosen as Higbee Chief Robert R. Broadbent, a former head of Gimbels New York, was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the Higbee Company, the Cleveland department store.     Mr. Broadbent, 61, succeeds Herbert E. Strawbridge, 66, who is retiring from those positions Jan. 28. Mr. Strawbridge - no relation to the Strawbridge retailing family in Philadelphia - will continue as chairman of the board's finance committee and will concentrate on long-range planning.

headline: A BIG LOSS FOR MERRILL IN QUARTER
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $42.1 million - its first quarterly loss since going public in 1971 - after setting aside $88 million for repayments to investors who bought annuities from the Baldwin-United Corporation, now in bankruptcy proceedings.   The $42.1 million loss was in contrast to net income of $142.5 million, or $1.74 a share, in last year's fourth quarter - Merrill Lynch's best ever.   Shortly after Merrill Lynch's announcement, Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said that it would make similar reimbursements to clients to whom it had sold Baldwin annuities. It was understood that the reimbursements would cost Prudential-Bache, a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, about $15 million before taxes.

headline: Military Contracts To Convair, Litton
abstract: The Convair division of the General Dynamics Corporation received a $115.2 million Navy contract to produce sea- and ground-launched Tomahawk cruise missiles, the Defense Department said.   In additition, it said two units of Litton Industries had received Navy awards totaling $109.3 million: $60.4 million to Litton Systems Canada Ltd., and $48.9 million to the Litton Guidance and Control Systems division for inertial navigation equipment. The department also said the Northrop Corporation had been given a $90.1 million contract by the Air Force for 10 RF-5E aircraft for sale to Saudi Arabia.

headline: THE LURE OF FOREIGN MUTUALS
abstract: In Australia, there are the media stocks. Sweden has high-growth drug companies. Japan offers the electrical supply companies.    For many stock traders these days, the action is overseas, where a new type of international mutual fund is creating many opportunities for high returns on foreign stock markets. To participate, all an investor needs is $500 - and a willingness to accept a certain amount of risk.

headline: APPROVAL IS GIVEN TO AMENDED PLAN FOR STEEL MERGER
abstract: The Justice Department, ending an antitrust dispute that caused a public split within the Cabinet, today announced its approval of an amended plan for the merger of two large steel companies.    The department said it had come to terms with the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation after threatening on Feb. 15 to take them to court under the antitrust laws if they tried to consolidate.    The revised $770 million deal requires the sale of Republic plants in Gadsden, Ala., and Massillon, Ohio. LTV's Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation is the nation's third-biggest steel producer, while Republic is the fourth- biggest. It was only because the companies agreed to sell these two plants to other producers, a move calculated to maintain competition, that the Justice Department withdrew its objection to the merger.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA SEEKS MILITARY FREEZE IN ANGOLA
abstract: South Africa is pressing for pledges of a military freeze by its foes in southern Angola to accompany a promised one-month withdrawal of its forces there, a senior South African official indicated today.    The official has been closely involved in South Africa's dispute with Angola both over the presence of Cuban soldiers in the former Portuguese colony and over its role as a sanctuary for the South-West Africa People's Organization. The insurgent group is fighting South Africa's control of South-West Africa, widely known as Namibia.   United States officials said Tuesday they had decided to embark on a diplomatic initiative aimed at ending South Africa's rule of South-West Africa in accordance with a United Nations peace plan, along with a parallel withdrawal from Angola of the 25,000 to 30,000 Cuban soldiers there.

headline: Militiaman Allied With Israel Has Lebanese Rank Restored
abstract: Maj. Saad Haddad, the pro-Israeli south Lebanese militia leader who is in a Haifa hospital reportedly suffering from leukemia, officially got his Lebanese rank and rights restored today, the Israeli radio reported.

headline: Chubb to Acquire Volunteer State By Reuters
abstract: The Chubb Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Volunteer State Life from the Monumental Corporation for $82.2 million.

headline: ;  Cable TV Campaigns
abstract: The Council for Cable Information has announced that its board has approved the advertising proposal of its agency, McCann-Erickson, and that the $6 million national effort should begin in January. Its purpose is to promote cable television with consumers. Meanwhile, a campaign to promote it with advertisers, sponsored by the Cable Television Advertising Bureau and created by LPG/ Pon, is under way.

headline: TEMPORARY JOB SCENE STUDIED
abstract: T HE nation's unemployment rate, falling with    surprising speed, reached 8.1 percent last   month, down from its December 1982 peak of 10.6 percent. That might seem bad news for companies that provide office workers and other temporary helpers. But business has been brisk for these companies, thanks to the economic recovery, and profits generally are improving.    ''The prevailing wisdom is that either extreme - very high or very low unemployment rates - adversely affects the temporary help industry,'' noted Judith M. Vale of Ingalls & Snyder. The current rate falls somewhere in the middle and, therefore, is not considered negative.

headline: U.S. PHOTOGRAPHER IS SHOT DEAD COVERING A BATTLE IN EL SALVADOR
abstract: An American photographer for Newsweek magazine was shot and killed today when he was caught in crossfire between Government and guerrilla troops about 16 miles north of here.    The photographer, John Hoagland, a 36-year-old native of San Diego, died moments after being shot once in the back by a large-caliber rifle at about 12:45 P.M., according to a colleague who was with him. It was not known whether he was hit by fire from the guerrillas or the Salvadoran Army.   ''John was on one knee, just about to go down and dig into the dirt, and he yelled he was hit,'' said Robert Nickelsberg, a photographer for Time magazine. ''The dirt was coming all over us from the bullets. He fell, and he expired no more than 15 seconds after that.''

headline: NO RESPECTER OF APARTHEID, DROUGHT SCORCHES ALL
abstract: When the rains came the other day, the feeling among the white farmers was that the downpour, which cracked a sullen sky with cobalt-blue lightning and coaxed a whiff of life from dead earth, had come too late - roughly three years too late. In any event, they said, what little that fell was not enough to moisten their lands.    Since the boom year of 1981, much of southern Africa has been seized with drought that has parched the land to a uniform yellow and stunted the corn that provides staple food.   Ottosdal, 180 miles west of Johannesburg, has been no exception. It lies at the center of a cornbelt that is said to be among South Africa's most fertile. Its existence depends on the 600 white farmers in the district whose land is so highly valued in the good years that most of them are potential millionaires. Most of them, too, come from the Afrikaner stock that provides the spine of South Africa's white minority, a group whose roots lie in husbandry of the land and belief in the teachings of the Dutch Reformed Church.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  A.G. Becker Paribas Inc. , acting as agent for the Sears Mortgage Securities Corp., has arranged the direct placement of two mortgage pass- through certificates totaling about $70.5 million.     * Illinois Power Inc.  is raising $100 million in a 12 1/2 percent eight-year Eurobond, through Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. The bonds, which are priced at par and mature in 1992, are callable after six years at 101 1/2 percent.

headline: Borman Had A Salary Cut
abstract: The salary of Eastern Airlines' chairman, Frank Borman, dropped $59,778, to $282,224, last year as the Miami- based airline suffered its most turbulent year, according to a company proxy statement.

headline: ACTION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Florida Bank Is Shut
abstract: The All American National Bank of Virginia Gardens, Fla., was declared insolvent and closed on Friday, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today. All American National, which had deposits of approximately $11 million, had suffered deterioration in its loan portfolio, the Government agency said. The F.D.I.C. was named receiver.

headline: REBELS CALL VOTE A U.S. DEFEAT
abstract: The political leaders of El Salvador's guerrilla opposition said today that Sunday's presidential elections ''constituted the biggest political failure of the Reagan Administration in El Salvador.''   The leaders said the elections were inspired, financed and directed by the United States Govenrment, which therefore had to bear responsibility for the ''general disorder and administrative chaos'' that prevented many people from voting and cast a doubt on the accuracy of the vote.

headline: G.M. SAID TO WEIGH REVAMPING
abstract: The General Motors Corporation is considering a realignment that would consolidate its five automotive divisions into two groups, one to produce small cars and the other for larger models, according to sources in the company and the auto industry.    The plan would link the Chevrolet and Pontiac divisions as the small car group, the sources said, while the Oldsmobile, Buick and Cadillac divisions would be responsible for larger cars.   Each group would be headed by a group executive, to whom the division general managers, who are vice presidents of the corporation, would report, according to the sources. The division heads now report to a single executive, Donald H. McPherson, the group executive for G.M.'s North America Car Group.

headline: VOLUNTEER AGENCIES PLAYING LARGER ROLE IN U.S. FOREIGN AID
abstract: A host of private and voluntary assistance agencies are playing an increasingly active role in foreign aid.    They are serving as channels for government money in countries where distributing aid might face problems, and they are filling in gaps where there is no official aid, as in Nicaragua and Ethiopia.   A group of volunteer doctors from Iowa, for instance, has set up field clinics for villagers in Yucatan, Mexico. People from Massachusetts have helped 3,000 small dairy farmers in Colombia increase milk production through modern techniques. A group in Michigan has introduced Japanese quail to the Dominican Republic because the birds require less feed than chickens.

headline: PATENTS; A Procedure to Permit Hydroponic Farming
abstract: A method of cultivating plants by placing their roots in liquid fertilizers rather than in soil was patented this week by Richard S. Carlisle of Rye, N.Y. He has said that the hydroponic apparatus and procedure, covered by patent 4,437,264, will allow commercial farmers and hobbyists alike to produce top-quality vegetable and ornamental crops without electricity.   The inventor has recommended that city officials encourage unemployed youths to operate such farms in vacant lots and on rooftops. The system includes a series of pots on the same level, with a supply line carrying the liquid nutrients to them. Mr. Carlisle operates the Methodology Research Company in Rye and has 21 patents in various fields, including medicine.

headline: Another Aide Leaves Amway
abstract: An Amway Corporation vice president said today that he will retire Friday, but that his departure is ''not particularly'' connected to a continuing management shake-up.   C. Dale Discher, 59 years old, said his early retirement was ''amiable,'' and declined to comment further.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: American Cyanamid Co., a drug and chemical company, said its new anticancer agent, Novantrone Mitoxantrone, has been approved by Canadian health officials for use as a single agent in the treatment of advanced breast cancer.     *  Artel Communications Corp., a manufacturer of fiber optics systems based in Worcester, Mass., said it had received a contract from Sanders Associates Inc., a manufacturer of military electronics and systems, for ''several hundred'' fiber optic systems.     *  British Aerospace announced that it had sold 12 Jetstream-31 commuter aircraft worth $28 million to Houston- based Metro Airlines, which is to begin taking delivery of the 19-seat propjets in April for use on a commuter and connecting route to be operated with Eastern Airlines between Atlanta and Houston.

headline: BARGAIN-HUNTING BRITONS FLOCKING TO FRANCE
abstract: The only things that separate the English and the French, some say, are the English Channel and mutual antipathy. Yet any cross-Channel differences are put aside under the banner of bargain-hunting.    Since Britain joined the European Economic Community in 1973, the one- day trip to shop in Calais and Boulogne has become a part of English life.   In December, an estimated 10,000 shoppers a day boarded Channel ferries for an orgy of Christmas shopping in French hypermarkets that have no rival in Britain. They are giant stores that house the equivalent of a large American supermarket and a discount store under one roof, selling everything from fresh foods to expensive electronic goods.

headline: U.S. EXPERTS FAVOR PULLBACK BY EXPRESS FEARS
abstract: Former United States foreign policy officials and others who have dealt with the Middle East said yesterday that they generally felt that President Reagan had no choice but to move the marines in Beirut to ships offshore.    But at the same time they expressed fears about what would happen after the pullback.   Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said he ''would have been very reluctant'' to move the marines from their base in Beirut. And he added, ''I do not think we should bring them all the way home.''

headline: ANTITRUST CHIEF GIVES HIS VIEWS
abstract: The new chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division, J. Paul McGrath, said today that he planned to expand the use of criminal enforcement techniques, such as granting immunity from prosecution, in investigating antitrust violations.     Mr. McGrath said he hoped to form a special group of antitrust and criminal division lawyers to improve the ability to detect and prosecute price- fixing and other offenses. He described price-fixing as his top concern. ''I believe there is a lot of price- fixing that goes on that is not detected,'' he said at his first news conference as antitrust chief.

headline: STRONG DOLLAR STIRS NEW CONCERNS
abstract: Economic   Analysis          PARIS, Jan. 2 - Two conflicting views among economists about the dollar's future are raising doubts about the durability of the world recovery as it enters its second year.  Right now, the dollar is showing phenomenal strength. But some economists fear that international confidence will eventually snap, forcing United States officials to push up interest rates again to halt an inflationary plunge in the dollar's value as foreign capital flees the country. If this were to happen, this view maintains, economic growth in the United States would grind to a halt, and with it, the single most powerful engine propelling the rest of the world toward recovery.   Others, however, fear that without a radical change in United States economic policy, the dollar will remain overly strong, gradually bankrupting a big slice of American industry as it attracts cheap imports and prices United States goods out of foreign markets. According to this scenario, it is support for free trade that would then snap as the United States retreats behind tough protectionist measures.

headline: Buffeting by Storms Blamed For Death of 30,000 Seagulls
abstract: Hunger and stress from constant buffeting by storms killed about 30,000 seagulls that have been washed up along the French Atlantic coast in the last two weeks, French television said today.   In a special report on the mass deaths, thought at first to have been caused by a virus, it said autopsies showed most of the gullls had died from a hemorrhage in the gizzard - the equivalent of a stomach ulcer in humans.
