The birds, already weakened by their migration from Greenland, suffered three weeks of buffeting by gales without being able to land or find food.

headline: U.S. Sailor Killed in Crete
abstract: A taxi driver on the island of Crete was charged today with the murder Thursday of an 18- year-old United States Navy specialist. The victim, James J. Antkowiak, of Peru, Ill., joined the Navy four months ago and was about to join the aircraft carrier Independence at Crete. His badly beaten body was found outside a Canea nightclub.

headline: D.D.B.'s Profit Down 2.7% in Fourth Quarter
abstract: When Victor Technologies, the California computer company, filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 last month, they owed just over $3.4 million to their ad agency, Doyle Dane Bernbach International.    That debt would have caused a sharp drop in the agency's fourth- quarter per share earnings, except for an extraordinary after-tax item of more than $1 million from the over- funding of a pension plan, according to Neil R. Austrian, president and chief executive.

headline: New Delhi Accuses Sikh Leader of Sedition
abstract: The Indian Government accused the country's top Sikh leader, Harchand Singh Longowal, of sedition today and banned the main Sikh student union.   The Press Trust of India, the national news agency, said arrests continued in the Sikh holy city of Amritsar and security officials flew to New Delhi for talks with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

headline: ANTI-MISSIONARY DRIVE PRESSED IN ISRAEL
abstract: Orthodox Jews are pressing a campaign against what they see as a growing effort to convert Israeli Jews to Christianity.   The conversion effort, which began several months ago, appears to be a result of the presence in Israel of thousands of fundamentalist Protestants who have come to live here in accordance with the pro-Israeli tenets of their religion.   It is difficult to obtain a clear picture of how much effort at conversion actually goes on in Israel. The main groups that the Orthodox Jews accuse of missionary activity are the International Christian Embassy in Jerusalem, the Fellowships of Messianic Believers and Project Kibbutz, which places young Christians as volunteers on Israeli kibbutzim.

headline: Warsaw Allows Renewal Of Business With U.S.
abstract: The Government gave the state airline and Polish fishermen permission today to resume business with the United States in areas opened up by the partial lifting of Western economic sanctions.

headline: REBEL FORCE OF 800 SAID TO INFILTRATE NAMIBIA
abstract: Military authorities in South-West Africa say a force of 800 insurgents has infiltrated the territory in recent weeks from bases in Angola.   The reported infiltration coincides with a United States-sponsored ''disengagement'' of South African forces from positions in southern Angola occupied during operations ostensibly designed to thwart insurgent buildups.   The military authorities also reported an increase in insurgent attacks in February, when the ''disengagement'' took shape with the formation of a South African-Angolan Joint Monitoring Commission to oversee it.

headline: 4 British Banks List Bad Debts
abstract: Britain's four largest banks have announced record provisions for bad debts for 1983.   The provisions, totaling almost $1.88 billion, reflect weaknesses in the domestic economy and a more conservative accounting standard than is commonly used by American banks, as well as large losses by the Crocker National Corporation, Midland Bank's 57 percent owned subsidiary in California.

headline: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Top Tampa Yield 9.8%
abstract: About $39 million of Tampa Performing Arts Center bonds were offered yesterday, priced with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.4 percent in 1999 and a maximum yield of 9.8 percent for bonds due in 2008, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. Proceeds of the issue will be used partly to pay for the design, construction and equipping of an arts center to be built in downtown Tampa, Fla.

headline: ISRAELI JETS ATTACK PALESTINIAN POSITIONS
abstract: Israeli jets attacked Palestinian guerrilla positions in the hills east of here today in their first raids in Lebanon since Shiite and Druse militiamen took over West Beirut on Monday.    The Israeli command said the raids, which came a day after three rockets were fired into northern Israel from southern Lebanon, were against Palestinian guerrilla positions in the area of Bhamdun, 12 miles east of here along the Beirut-Damascus highway. The command said the planes destroyed two buildings and several artillery pieces and returned safely to base.   The target area is in the mountain region controlled by Syrian-backed Druse militiamen. Two Palestinian guerrilla factions, the Syrian-sponsored As Saiqa and the Libyan-backed Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command also have offices in Bhamdun.

headline: WARNER 2-WAY TV CUTBACKS
abstract: Warner Communications Inc., one of the strongest proponents of two- way television, has cut back on some well publicized projects in the sector, according to company officials.   The Warner Amex Cable Company, a joint venture of Warner Communications and the American Express Company, said yesterday that it was suspending the 90 minutes of nightly programming carried on its two-way QUBE system.    It was also learned that Warner Communications has halted an advanced two-way service that was to be tested on the Warner Amex cable system in Pittsburgh.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Accounts     * Traveline Inc. to AC&R Advertising.     * Royal Insurance to Phillips/Alogna Associates, Garden City, L.I.     * Taylor Rental, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Stanley Works of New Britain, Conn., to HBM/Creamer, Boston.     * Paquet Cruises Inc., Miami, to Austin Kelley Advertising, Atlanta.

headline: SHELLING RENEWED IN BEIRUT REGION
abstract: Lebanese soldiers and Druse militiamen fought heavy artillery battles today as Donald Rumsfeld, the special American envoy, began talks with Syrian officials in Damascus on ways to separate Lebanon's warring factions.   The Beirut radio said sporadic shelling started early in the day in hills near Suk al Gharb, nine miles from the center of Beirut. The intensity of the shelling, the radio said, increased through the day, and for three hours beginning at 3 P.M. each side subjected the other to a withering bombardment.   At nightfall, eight shells exploded in the Beirut harbor, and others apparently fired from Druse positions landed in predominantly Christian East Beirut. The Presidential Palace and the Defense Ministry building in suburban Baabda also came under attack.

headline: CINCINNATI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CACI GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Article 176011 -- No Title
abstract: The combatants in the battle are giants; the stakes are high; the taxpayers are watching, and Congress has sought to avoid the fray.    At stake is a contract, valued at between $10 billion and $14 billion, to build between 2,400 and 2,600 engines for Air Force F-15 and F-16 fighters. Sometime in the next two weeks, the Secretary of the Air Force will award the plum to either the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft unit of the United Technologies Corporation or the General Electric Company, or to both.   Neither company is a stranger to Pentagon business - the two are the nation's premier manufacturers of military aircraft engines and are the two biggest producers of jet engines in the non-Communist world.

headline: FAMILY DISAVOWED BY EAST GERMANY
abstract: The East German Government said today that Prime Minister Willi Stoph ''had nothing to do with the actions'' of five East Germans identified as his niece and family who took refuge in the West German Embassy in Prague on Friday.    The incident appears to have been a source of embarassment for Mr. Stoph, who is the second-ranking East German, after Erich Honecker, the President and Communist Party leader.   On Sunday the Hamburg newspaper Welt am Sonntag identified the five as Mr. Stoph's niece, Ingrid Berg; her husband, Hans-Dieter; their 7-year old son, Jens, and daughter, Simone, 3, and Mr. Berg's mother, Olga. The family has reportedly refused to leave unless allowed to settle in West Germany.

headline: NICARAGUAN PORT RAIDED BY REBELS
abstract: Rebels in aircraft and speedboats attacked Potosi, the main port in the Gulf of Fonseca, for the fifth time this month, the Nicaraguan Government radio said today. It reported no casualties and little damage.   A Defense Ministry communique said 41 rebels and 10 soldiers were killed in fighting over the weekend in northern Nicaragua, where rebels based in Honduras and Government forces have been fighting for more than a month.

headline: MONTSANTO SURGES BY 53.2%
abstract: The Monsanto Company, aided by a strong showing for farm chemicals, reported yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings climbed 53.2 percent on a 12.2 percent increase in sales.    Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis and is the country's fourth-largest chemical company, said net income in the latest period rose to $72 million, or $1.75 a share, from $47 million, or $1.12 a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter sales rose to $1.65 billion, from $1.47 billion a year earlier.   For the full year, net income increased 14.2 percent, to $402 million, or $9.78 a share, from $352 million, or $8.79 a share, in 1982. Revenues for the year slipped five-tenths of 1 percent, to $6.30 million, from $6.33 billion a year earlier.

headline: F.D.I.C. PLACING CURBS ON DEPOSIT PROTECTION
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, in a change of policy, served notice today that when banks fail and their accounts are shifted to other banks, it may not grant full protection to depositors with balances larger than $100,000.    The change, announced as an experiment, is intended to make investors and corporations more cautious about placing large deposits in small banks that may be weak financially, but that offer generous terms to bring in new money. The action was taken following the failure last week of the Seminole State National Bank of Seminole, Tex., and the Heritage bank of Anaheim, Calif.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Alhambra Mines Inc., a mining and exploration company based in Reno, said its Gold Run Mining subsidiary had received a notice of default from creditors for failing to make a $97.6 million payment due Dec. 15.     *  Bancal Tri-State Corp., holding company for the Bank of California in San Francisco, said its shareholders had approved a previously announced plan to merge into Mitsubishi Bank of Tokyo for $50 a share.     *  Chemie Linz A.G., Austria's state- owned chemicals concern, said it had bought 50 percent of the stock of Gilmore Inc. of Memphis for $4.5 million, and said the two companies would form a venture for producing crop protectives.

headline: Jordan Severs Its Ties To Libya After Attack
abstract: Jordan severed diplomatic and political relations with Libya today over the destruction of the Jordanian Embassy by rioters in Tripoli last week, the official Jordanian television said.

headline: Gap Acquisition
abstract: The Gap Stores Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire The Pottery Barn Inc., a closely held specialty rtailer of kitchen and household wares based in metropolitan New York.

headline: SCHOLARS WILL FOCUS ON LATIN AMERICAN JEWS
abstract: More than two dozen scholars from the United States, Israel and Latin America are gathering here for a three-day conference that is to focus on the future of Jews in Latin America and on the Latin American social situation generally.   ''The Jewish experience in Latin America provides a window on Latin American social reality from the point of view of a minority,'' said Prof. Gilbert Merkx, the director of the Latin American Institute of the University of New Mexico here. The institute is co- sponsoring the conference, which opens Monday, with the Latin American Jewish Studies Association of Ann Arbor, Mich. The last such conference was in 1972.

headline: Halliburton Suits
abstract: The Halliburton Company said it expected to pay $50 million to settle 52 civil lawsuits filed against its engineering unit, Brown & Root.

headline: PRICES STAY IN NARROW RANGE
abstract: Interest rates were mixed but little changed yesterday as the uncertain outlook for interest rates kept prices of short- and long-term issues from moving outside the trading range of the last three months.     Hopes for a decline in rates still hinge on a slowing of economic growth that could lead to an easing in monetary policy and a drop in short- term interest rates. Not all analysts agree that the slowdown in the economy will be great enough to produce that result, however, and many still warn that higher rates are likely this year.    ''It will take some sign that the Fed is shifting gears to move the market out of its recent range,'' said James R. Lothian, an economist at Citibank. Although he favors the view that ''the Fed is more likely to move toward ease than tightness within the next month,'' Mr. Lothian acknowledged that confidence in interest rate forecasts is not very strong right now.

headline: IRANIANS IN SYRIA: SIGN OF CLOSE TIES
abstract: On Thursday afternoons, the Iranian jetliners land at the international airport here. The passengers, most of them women shrouded in black chadors, descend carrying huge bags of pistachios.    Another batch of Iranians wait at the airport to return home. They, too, carry big sacks, but theirs are filled not with pistachios but with a dazzling array of products: plastic cooking utensils, leather sandals, butane water heaters, radios, irons, cloth and trinkets.

headline: LIGHTNING CAN STRIKE TWICE IN SOUTH AFRICAN BUSH
abstract: They burn people here. Not often - only by way of justice, when lightning strikes other people and the calamity is deemed to be an act of sorcery that must be avenged.    Then a witch doctor, using bones or a magical mirror, will detect the person who has brought down the lightning. And that person will first be beaten, then tied to a tree in a frenzy of retribution and doused with gasoline and burned.   In the last two weeks, the lightning has struck six times around here, and six people have been burned. Under one charred and blasted tree, whose blackness distinguishes it from greenery nearby, a visitor can still find a mound of ash and, in it, remnants of human bone. No one remarks much on the somber testimony to a custom that predates a tenuous modernity.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Student Loan Marketing Association said it had committed to buy $40 million of student loans from First National Bank of Commerce, New Orleans, over the next four years. Sallie Mae said the the transaction constitutes the largest forward purchase commitment ever issued in its southern region.     *  Tohoku Electric Power Co.'s 100-million-Swiss-franc issue of 5 3/4 percent bonds due in 1992 was priced at par, through Union Bank of Switzerland. There are about 2.23 Swiss francs to the dollar.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *  Appalachian Co., an oil, gas and coal concern based in Houston, said in a S.E.C. filing that it was interested in obtaining control of Energy Ventures Inc., also of Houston. Appalachian said it holds 37 percent of Energy Ventures' shares outstanding.

headline: ARGENTINA TORTURE: ONE WHO LOOKED ON
abstract: A former Argentine serviceman described today how he had participated in one of the many undercover military units that kidnapped, tortured and assassinated thousands of Argentines in the mid-1970's.   ''There were things you could not bear, things that were unimaginable,'' he said. ''But the tingling I feel on my skin, almost seven years later, still makes me feel sick.''   The former serviceman, Raul David Vilarino, who was a naval petty officer, two weeks ago became the first individual to say publicly that he participated in the campaign against leftist subversion. Officials here said his declaration might have represented the beginning of an unraveling of the common front that the military and the police have maintained in denying that they were involved in human rights abuses.

headline: PRESIDENT AFFIRMS HIS POLICY TO KEEP MARINES IN BEIRUT
abstract: Reagan's letter on Lebanon, page A6.           WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 - President Reagan, in a policy statement on Lebanon, said today that the United States could not withdraw the marines suddenly without raising questions about its commitment to ''moderation and negotiation in the Middle East.''   In a reply to two Democratic members of the House of Representatives who had raised questions about American policy, Mr. Reagan also said the Soviet Union, Syria and Iran were complicating efforts to bring about Lebanese national unity.   He said the marines and the other members of the four-nation force in Beirut were contributing to President Amin Gemayel's ''ability to have a national reconciliation process on a basis that is more Lebanese than Syrian.''

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Norfolk Hospital Bonds Are Priced by Kidder    A $44.1 million bond issue for the Industrial Development Authority of the City of Norfolk, Va., was priced by Kidder, Peabody & Company yesterday with yields ranging from 5.75 percent to 9.40 percent.

headline: SHITE GROUP TIED TO BEIRUT BLASTS
abstract: A Government official said today that United States intelligence specialists were convinced that the truck bombings of American and French military installations in Beirut last October were carried out by a pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem group acting under Iranian direction and with Syrian approval.    The official said the group, known as the Islamic Amal, staged the attacks Oct. 23 in an operation that was run partly out of the Iranian Embassy in Damascus, Syria, and was conducted with the knowledge of Syrian authorities.   Although the official declined to provide many details, his account was the most specific accusation made by an American official about those responsible for the bombings, which resulted in the deaths of 241 American servicemen at the Marine compound and 56 French paratroopers. Administration officials previously had charged Iran and Syria with complicity, but had not pinned blame on any individual group.

headline: FOR FIRST TIME, IRAQIS BOMBARD IRANIAN CIVILIANS
abstract: State Department officials said today that the war between Iran and Iraq had taken a new, more ominous turn.    They cited two developments earlier today: an Iraqi military attack aimed at Iranian civilians this morning, and a subsequent Iranian threat of reprisals Sunday against Iraqi cities.    Both sides appear to be trying to demoralize the other by deliberately bombarding or planning to bombard civilian targets for the first time in the war, officials said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, MARCH 20, 1984
abstract: The Economy    Banks raised their prime rate a half-point, to 11 1/2 percent, the highest level since January 1983 and the first change in the key rate since last August. Bankers cited the increased cost of their funds, and many said the rate may well climb further. (Page A1.)   Personal income climbed 0.7 percent, but spending declined a like amount in February. The drop in consumption spending, the first in seven months, was led by auto sales, which may reflect limited inventories. For the previous month, the Commerce Department report revised upward both income and spending. (D1.)

headline: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane Insurer Funds Protect Policies
abstract: -United Corporation have called attention   to the little-known state guarantee funds that provide an element of protection to policyholders of insurance companies in serious financial difficulty.   These funds are associations established by law in various states and made up of the insurers that write the kind of business covered by such guarantees. Thus, even though there are guarantee funds for property and casualty insurance in all 50 states, there are only 33 such state funds and one in Puerto Rico for life and health insurance. And it is the life and health funds that are coming under more scrutiny these days in light of the Baldwin-United situation, where plans for rehabilitation are now under consideration by courts in Arkansas and Indiana.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1984   The Economy    The Congressional Budget Office said budget deficits would rise in coming years, not decline, as the Administration has forecast. In its first analysis of the 1985 budget, the agency rejected the Adminstration's projection of a decline in interest rates. Release of the study prompted calls by some Democrats and Republicans to cut the projected deficits by even more than the $100 billion reduction sought by Mr. Reagan. (Page A1.) The President said the Democrats were ignoring his calls for bipartisan budget talks. (A1.)

headline: BIG BATTLE ERUPTS IN IRAN-IRAQ WAR
abstract: Iran said today that its forces had begun an offensive against Iraqi border fortifications on the central front and that Iranian soldiers were advancing. Iraq said it had contained the drive.   Both sides said heavy casualties had been inflicted on the other.

headline: 6 in Embassy in Berlin Seeking U.S. Asylum
abstract: Six East Germans entered the United States Embassy in East Berlin Friday, saying they would stay inside until they were granted political asylum in the United States. Today they appealed to President Reagan and said they would not eat until the Communist Government gave them exit visas.   Additional police were stationed outside the building today as American and East German diplomats met to try to resolve the standoff.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Guaranteed Mortgage Corp., a wholly owned financing subsidiary of Pulte Financial Cos., filed to offer $900 million in G.N.M.A.-collateralized mortgage bonds.     * Mitsui Finance Asia Ltd.  is offering $100 million of 12-year floating-rate notes, bearing semi-annual interest at a rate of 1/8 percentage point above the mean bid-offered Libor, through Hambros Bank Ltd.     *  B. F. Saul Real Estate Investment Trust said it is calling all of its approximately $4.9 million of outstanding 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 1990 for redemption on March 15 at a price of 102.22 percent of par plus accrued interest.

headline: LISBON A DIPLOMATIC PORT OF CALL ON AFRICA ISSUES
abstract: Judging from the roll-call of foreign leaders who have dropped in to chat with Portuguese leaders in recent months, it would appear that Portugal has become an important behind- the-scenes player in southern Africa.    Under a more assertive foreign policy being pursued by the Socialist- led Government of Prime Minister Mario Soares, Lisbon is seeking a larger role in world affairs through its former African colonies, especially Mozambique and Angola.   It is involving itself in the tangled search for solutions to armed conflicts, seeking to build up export markets to rectify a dismal balance of trade, and hoping to send off to Africa hundreds of technicians and semi-skilled workers who can't find jobs at home.   All of this comes under the rubric of serving as a bridge - or a ''marriage guidance counselor,'' as one Portuguese diplomat put it - between the two strategically situated Marxist countries and the West, especially the United States.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Hunting Aid  A way for hunters to determine wind direction without alerting their prey has been invented by Dean Hierschede of Cincinnati. Patent 4,423,626, issued this week, covers a process of releasing into the air a powder masking the scent of the hunter with the odor of acorn, pine, apple or cedar. A small cloud of the powder is released to indicate the direction of the wind.

headline: GAZING INTO THE CRYSTAL BALL FOR 1984
abstract: AS Wall Street moves into 1984 on the wave of a    resounding economic recovery, many of its   best money managers are sharply divided over investment strategies. Without doubt, they all see the bull market continuing into the New Year. But most agree that the market will fall short of its stellar performance of the last 18 months, and that selecting the right stocks is an increasingly difficult task.   Stock prices ''will continue rising in the first half of the year,'' said Steve G. Einhorn, vice chairman of investment policy at Goldman, Sachs & Company. But he added that many stocks have already become ''too expensive'' in relation to their expected earnings, and that the market in general ''holds no promise'' of equaling the broad run-up of the last year.

headline: IRAN AND IRAQ FIRE ON BORDER TOWNS
abstract: Iran and Iraq shelled towns on each other's borders for a second day today.   At the same time, Iran described a military drive into northeast Iraq as the start of a major offensive in the 40- month Persian Gulf war.   Iraq said in a military communique that 35 people were killed in border shelling Sunday and today. It said it had retaliated by attacking the Iranian oil city of Abadan, the source of the artillery fire.

headline: DOW OFF 6.91, TO 1,259.11
abstract: Stock prices, which have been mostly declining in the last two weeks, fell broadly yesterday in continued active trading.   Reflecting the weakness, issues that fell on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 1,027 to 578. Turnover on the Big Board amounted to 93.4 million shares yesterday, down from 98.3 million the day before.

headline: DESERTION UNSETTLES GREEN PARTY IN BONN
abstract: West Germany's Green Party was jolted today when one of its most respected legislators resigned from the party in protest over ''intrigues and power struggles'' and what he said was the growing influence of the party's Marxist-Leninist faction.   The legislator, Gert Bastian, a 60- year-old retired general who left the West German Army to protest the planned deployment of American medium-range missiles in Germany, quit after complaining of bitter infighting and ''a strong anti-American undertow'' in the party's foreign policy.   Mr. Bastian's decision to leave the party but to stay in Parliament as an independent reduces the Greens' parliamentary group to 27 members. Should one more lawmaker quit, the Green Party would lose its standing as a parliamentary group, and its government subsidies and right to speak in debates would be reduced.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1984   Companies    Arco is preparing a formal bid for Gulf Oil , banking officials said. Executives close to Gulf said that, contrary to the company's earlier position, it might entertain such a bid, which bankers indicated could reach $13 billion. The report sent Gulf shares up by almost $6 in Big Board trading. But Mesa Petroleum and its chairman, T. Boone Pickens, who is leading an unwelcome effort to gain control of Gulf, are still in the running. (Page D1.)    Crane said that an investors group had offered $357 million for the company, excluding its troubled CF&I Steel unit. Crane's chairman, Thomas Mellon Evans, 74, said that he was stepping down and that he supported the $35-a-share offer. (D1.)

headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS
abstract: Cotton Futures Rally; Grain and Soybeans Up       By The Associated Press    Cotton futures prices rallied strongly yesterday on the Cotton Exchange in New York.   Ernest Simon, a cotton analyst in New York with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the Agriculture Department's report Thursday on export shipments and export sales in the week ended Feb. 23 was a strong supportive factor.   He noted that exports of American cotton have been strong in the 1983-84 marketing year, which began Aug. 1, as other exporting nations have had troubles with their crops and some have been forced to import cotton.

headline: WARSAW PACT PROPOSES CHEMICAL ARMS TALKS
abstract: The Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies proposed to the Atlantic alliance today to negotiate a ban on chemical weapons in Europe.   Western diplomats said the proposal was hazy on the issue of verification, which has hampered previous efforts at a chemical weapon ban. They also noted the timing of the offer, a week before the opening of an East-West conference in Stockholm on security in Europe.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Developer Seeks Thrift Unit Control    Paul Amir, a Los Angeles real estate developer, wants control of the Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association, and has said he hopes to oust the company's top management. Not surprisingly, management is resisting.   Mr. Amir, who is 53 years old, arrived in Los Angeles from Israel in 1960 and has been energetically putting up office buildings and other commercial property since.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: A.M.C. Lifts Prices; G.M. Rise Indicated    DETROIT, March 30 (AP) - The American Motors Corporation today raised the base prices of its Jeeps and four-wheel-drive Eagle cars, the first domestic auto price increases this year on existing models.   Meanwhile, the Oldsmobile and Buick divisions of the General Motors Corporation announced the base prices they will recommend for their redesigned 1985 luxury cars. They will be $70 to $708 above the prices for the models they replace.

headline: Barclays Adds Official At North America Unit
abstract: Edward F. Hill has been named chief operating officer for North American operations of Barclays Bank International Ltd.    B.B.I.L., as it is called, is the international banking subsidiary of London's Barclays Bank P.L.C..

headline: BETTER PROSPECTS SEEN FOR RAISING AID TO SALVADOR
abstract: Some Congressional Democrats, back from observing the presidential elections Sunday in El Salvador, said today that, despite problems, the size of the voter turnout had improved the prospects in Congress for President Reagan's request for more military aid to El Salvador.    The United States Embassy estimated that 1.1 million to 1.3 million Salvadorans cast ballots. That is below both the 1.55 million who voted in the 1982 legislative elections and the 1.8 million total that the Salvadoran Government had estimated would vote Sunday.   The American delegation met this afternoon with President Reagan. Afterward, both the House majority leader, Jim Wright of Texas, and Senator Walter D. Huddleston of Kentucky said they were more inclined to support additional aid for El Salvador despite having seen firsthand some ''bureaucratic difficulties'' with ballot boxes and voter lists.

headline: People
abstract: *  Norman Sherman has been named executive vice president for marketing at Avrett, Free & Ginsburg Inc.     *  Michael J. O'Neill has been named senior vice president, advertising, for CBS Magazines.

headline: ABC Profit Up 20.7%
abstract: The American Broadcasting Companies said its fourth-quarter profits rose 20.7 percent on a 14.7 percent increase in revenues, reflecting the strength of its broadcasting and publishing operations.   The company earned $49.6 million, or $1.69 a share, on revenues of $871.3 million in the last quarter of 1983.

headline: FRENCH SETTLE IN CHAD FOR LONG STAY
abstract: To many visitors, it has been a long time since this war-weary capital has appeared so relaxed.    A new French restaurant, with an arched entrance and languidly revolving ceiling fans, has opened on the Avenue Charles de Gaulle. Not far away, percussive music pours through the open doors of a new night spot.   The offices of Air Afrique and two or three other businesses have been plastered and whitewashed. Like nearly all of the buildings here, they had been pock-marked by machine-gun fire during civil wars in 1980 and 1982.

headline: Houston May Bid For Its Own Shares
abstract: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation, in a new step to fight off a takeover by the Coastal Corporation, said yesterday that it was ''contemplating'' an offer to buy ''a significant number'' of its own shares for more than $68 a share - the price being offered by the Coastal Corporation.    The proposal came in papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with an offer by Houston Natural Gas to buy any and all shares of Coastal for $42 a share, or $924 million in cash.

headline: LTV, Republic In U.S. Talks
abstract: Further signs of progress were seen today as representatives of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation met twice with the Justice Department in an effort to reach a merger plan acceptable to the Government.

headline: SALVADORANS VOTE BUT MIXUPS SPOIL POLLING FOR MANY
abstract: Salvadorans surged to the polls today to cast their vote for President, but their efforts were hindered by shortages of ballots and ballot boxes and by widespread confusion over election rules.   Officials of the Christian Democratic Party charged this afternoon that serious problems existed in about one- quarter of the voting places in the capital - where their party is believed to be strongest - and said they might move to have the elections annulled.   But this evening Julio Rey Prendes, a Christian Democratic leader, said, ''We are not going to challenge the election right now.''   Similar dissatisfaction over the election was voiced this afternoon by officials of the Democratic Action Party. An official of the Central Election Council, in a statement issued tonight, said the results would stand.

headline: WAR ZONE ACCESS BY PRESS AFFIRMED
abstract: A Pentagon panel drafting guidelines on press access to combat zones agreed today that reporters and photographers should have such access ''to the maximum degree possible consistent with the security of the mission and the safety of troops.''   The chairman of the 13-member panel, Winant Sidle, said the group agreed on that principle at a closed organizational meeting this morning, before the start of four days of scheduled public hearings on the issue. The Joint Chiefs of Staff created the panel in response to Congressional and press criticism of the Pentagon's ban on coverage of the first days of the invasion of Grenada last year.

headline: SUBURBAN AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: DEBATERS DIFFER ON HOW TO AVOID ATOMIC WAR
abstract: In a debate this week about nuclear war, two strategic thinkers of opposing points of view cut through other issues to concur that a political agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union might be the only way to prevent a holocaust.   But they vigorously disputed how to reach that agreement.   Roger C. Molander, head of the Roosevelt Center for American Policy Studies, advocated greater communication with Moscow, beginning with a summit conference between President Reagan and the new Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko.   Michael Novak, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, contended that acquiring enough military force to dissuade Soviet leaders from attacking the United States could lead to a political arrangement.

headline: A.M.C. AND CHINA TO START JOINT MANUFACTURE OF JEEPS
abstract: The American Motors Corporation and a state-run Chinese auto manufacturer dedicated a $51 million joint venture today that will make army and civilian jeeps.   It is the first joint venture in vehicle production for China.   A.M.C. says its goal is an inexpensive, exportable four-wheel-drive vehicle to challenge Japanese models that have captured the Asian market.

headline: ISRAEL CALLS JEWISH TERRORISTS ISOLATED
abstract: The chief of investigations for the Israeli national police said today that the Jews arrested this week for attacks on Arabs did not constitute a sophisticated underground terrorist movement, but were men ''on the verge of insanity'' driven by fantasies of what their actions would accomplish.    The investigations chief, Yehezkel Carthy, said all seven in detention had confessed to their crimes. The seven included four American Jews charged with wounding seven Arabs Sunday in an attack with automatic weapons on a bus on the West Bank, and three Israeli Jews charged with trying to plant explosives in January at the Temple Mount, the holiest Moslem site in Jerusalem.   There is no evidence so far, Mr. Carthy said in an interview at his office, that those arrested had anything to do with two other major attacks on Arabs that remain unsolved: the planting of bombs in or near the cars of three West Bank mayors in 1980, and the attack last summer on the Islamic College in the West Bank city of Hebron, which killed three Arabs and wounded 33. Nor was it certain, he said, that they were involved in the recent rigging of booby-trapped hand grenades at the entrances of mosques, churches and Arabs' houses.

headline: Italian Industrialist Is Freed By Kidnappers After a Year
abstract: Kidnappers freed an industrialist in exchange for ransom today, the police said.   The victim, Carlo De Feo, a 40-year- old business executive from Naples, was abducted on Feb. 28, 1983, near Naples.

headline: U.S. GUERRILLA DIES IN SALVADOR
abstract: An American who fought for two years with Marxist-led rebels in El Salvador was killed in action last summer, army and rebel sources said today.    A Defense Ministry communique cited an ''extremist source'' as having said the ''American mercenary Carroll Ishee'' died fighting on the northeastern front.   The rebel radio Venceremos also broadcast a report that Mr. Ishee, 29 years old, a native of Philadelphia, Miss., died, saying his last words were, ''Tell my wife, my daughter and my American people that I have died fulfilling my obligation.''

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation, a unit of the Grumman Corporation, received a $100.9 million Navy contract for work on six EA-6B aircraft, the Defense Department said. It also said that the Navy had awarded a $40.5 million contract to the Raytheon Company for torpedo launching systems and one for $30.9 million to the RCA Corporation for work on the Aegis radar combat system for ships.

headline: European American Acquires a New Chief
abstract: In taking over the European American Bancorp and its two subsidiaries, the European American Bank and Trust Company and the European American Banking Corporation, Raymond J. Dempsey is inheriting an $8.7 billion bank that has encountered many troubles.    European American emerged as a big bank in 1974, when it acquired the remnants of the failed Franklin National Bank, then the 20th-largest bank in the United States. Despite the strength of the six giant European banks that own it, and its strong franchise on Long Island, European American has never thrived. Many analysts contend that a big part of its troubles was the inability of its owners to agree on policy.

headline: A.M.C. Claim
abstract: The American Motors Corporation has won a $2 million claim against Iran, which canceled Jeep orders during the 1979 Islamic revolution. An A.M.C. spokesman in Detroit said the auto maker filed a $5 million claim and settled for $2 million plus an order for $55 million worth of Jeep kits.

headline: Futures/OptionsProfit Squeeze Hurts Brokers
abstract: Trouble is brewing in the booming futures brokerage business. Indeed, the futures brokerage industry may be on the verge of a shakeout, despite the enormous growth of futures and options business in recent years.    In recent weeks, several major futures brokerage houses, all of which shared in the growing futures business, sharply reduced their staffs and operations. A number of other houses are expected to follow suit.

headline: MCDONALD'S IS BATTLING WITH BLACK FRANCHISEE
abstract: Charles Griffis came to California in 1977 when he heard he might be able to buy a McDonald's franchise in Santa Barbara. He had completed a training program for the restaurant chain, but was operating his own gasoline station in Michigan at the time.    It turns out, though, that the store was in Los Angeles, ''on Santa Barbara Street, right in the middle of the ghetto,'' says Mr. Griffis. ''It was an old store in real bad shape.''

headline: Andropov's Son Seen At Stockholm Parley
abstract: Igor Y. Andropov, son of Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, is among Soviet delegates to the European security conference here.

headline: American Can To Sell Units
abstract: The American Can Company said that it had agreed in   principle to sell its Canadian   and British packaging operations to First City Financial   Corporation Ltd. of Vancouver,   British Columbia, for about $232.4 million. The operations involved have   annual revenues of approximately $380 million, and include those that manufacture   metal food and beverage containers in Canada and Britain,   and plastic tubes in Canada.

headline: WHY TIMING IS EVERYTHING FOR INVESTORS' TAX-PLANNING
abstract: FEW things are as discouraging as making a bundle in the stock market and then turning a big chunk over to the Internal Revenue Service. Shrewd investors, however, can more than halve their tax liability, or at least delay the payment of taxes without seeing much of their profit disappear. The trick is planning.  Assuming the alternative minimum tax is not a problem, the goal is long-term gains and short-term losses. With exceptions for certain commodities futures, a gain or loss becomes long-term when the security is held more than one year.  Long-term gains are advantageous because they are taxed at a maximum rate of 20 percent. Short-term gains are treated like ordinary income, taxed at a maximum rate of 50 percent.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1984   Companies    The LTV-Republic steel merger will be fought by the Justice Department. The antitrust division said the combined company would control too much of certain sectors and that the merger was not the way to address problems of having to compete with imported steel. But the department also said the companies were free to seek other approaches that might help them. (Page A1.)    Alternatives that the steel industry might turn to include joint ventures, exchanges of mills and mergers with foreign companies, according to industry analysts and executives. Officials at LTV and Republic said they would discuss with the Justice Department how the companies could meet the antitrust objections. (D4.)

headline: 31 COUNTRIES TO DONATE $9 BILLION TO WORLD BANK AGENCY FOR POOR
abstract: Thirty- one nations agreed today to give $9 billion to an agency of the World Bank that makes interest-free loans to more than 40 of the poorest countries.    The agreement to give the money over the next three years to aid the poor countries, which have 2.5 billion people, was reached after exceptionally difficult negotiations.    The amount was far less than the $16 billion originally sought by the management of the World Bank, which is formally called the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The bank's president, A. W. Clausen, said at a news conference that the decision would mean that assistance for sub-Saharan Africa would be ''gravely inadequate'' and that both India and China would receive less aid than they were counting on.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: Atlantic Richfield Co.  has elected Howard L. Edwards corporate secretary.     *  Continental Grain Co.  has named Rodman Kober senior vice president- transportation in the company's transportation and natural resources group.

headline: Mayer Cuts Prima Stake
abstract: Oscar Mayer & Company has cut its stake in Prima Meat Packers Ltd. of Japan to 10.04 percent, from 24.85 percent, Prima said today. Oscar Mayer, a unit of the General Foods Corporation, sold 14.8 percent of Prima's stock Wednesday to 13 Japanese concerns, including C. Itoh & Company.

headline: IMASCO'S SUCCESS IN DRUGSTORES
abstract: Shoppers Drug Mart last year told its customers ''thanks a billion'' in an advertising campaign that celebrated its first year with more than $1 billion (Canadian) in sales.    The success belonged not only to the drugstore group but also to its parent, Imasco Ltd., a big tobacco company based in Montreal. Imasco acquired Kofflers Stores, the owners of Shoppers Drug Mart, for $65 million (Canadian) in 1978.    Now Imasco intends to build on that success with the friendly acquisition of Peoples Drug Stores Inc., a fast- growing chain based in Virginia. Its offer is valued at $320 million (United States).

headline: HOW THE SOVIET LEADER IS SELECTED BY THE PARTY
abstract: When a new Soviet leader emerges to succeed Yuri V. Andropov, announcements will ascribe the choice to the Communist Party's Central Committee, a body of slightly more than 300 people, mostly party officials, summoned to Moscow from around the country.   If past precedent is followed, the selection will probably be described as unanimous.   The reality is likely to be different. Although the Central Committee is established by the statutes as the party's sovereign body between conventions, or congresses, which are held every five years, the actual power lies in two offshoots of the Central Committee, the Politburo, a consultative group that meets once a week to formulate policy, and the Central Committee's Secretariat, the permanent staff that executes policy.

headline: COPPER QUOTAS ASKED
abstract: Eleven major copper producers today filed a petition asking the Government to place a quota on copper imports that would limit the imports to half the current level.    The petition asserts that the industry, which lost approximately $1 billion in the past two years, has been substantially injured by imports, which rose from 228,000 tons in 1979 to 548,000 tons last year.

headline: U.S. TELLS OF '54 GUATEMALA INVASION
abstract: After a six- year delay, the State Department today published the official documentation on American policy toward the overthrow of the leftist Government in Guatemala in 1954. But all material on the covert role of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Department was omitted.   Many books and articles have been written about the C.I.A.'s role in the invasion of Guatemala from Honduras by Guatemalan exiles who toppled the Government of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman.   The secret American involvement was acknowledged in passing by former President Dwight D. Eisenhower in his memoirs. He noted that he overrode the State Department and approved a request by Allen W. Dulles, then Director of Central Intelligence, to supply bombers to the insurgents led by Col. Carlos Castillo Armas.

headline: Israeli Budget Lists Trims
abstract: Israel's Finance Minister, Yigal Cohen-Orgad, introduced a $22.7 billion budget today and told Parliament that Israeli living standards would revert this year to the level of 1982 because of the need to secure foreign currency. The budget provides for Government spending cuts ranging from 7 percent to 10 percent in development and food and fuel subsidies, as well as in social and economic supports. Mr. Cohen-Orgad said the cutbacks, along with an increase in exports and a sharp decline in imports, would help reduce this year's $4.1 billion payments gap by $1 billion.

headline: The U.N. Today March 8, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: ;  Texas Investor Blocked On Castle & Cook Tie
abstract: Charles E. Hurwitz continues to build his business empire. Mr. Hurwitz, a Texas investor, may have his eye on Castle & Cooke Inc., the big Hawaiian food producer, although his stock purchases so far have been termed for investment purposes only.    Castle & Cooke, asserting that Mr. Hurwitz was attempting a takeover, has obtained a temporary restraining order to block him from acquiring more stock. Mr. Hurwitz and his associates have already acquired more than 11 percent.    Some analysts say that it is not Castle & Cooke's pineapples, bananas, mushrooms, lettuce, sea food and sugar that interest Mr. Hurwitz. Rather, some believe he is after 150,000 acres of Hawaiian real estate owned by Castle & Cooke.

headline: NEW NO. 1 IN PUBLIC RELATIONS
abstract: Harold Burson, the soft-voiced chairman and chief executive of Burson-Marsteller, cannot resist some discreet crowing. After years of being the second-largest public relations firm after Hill & Knowlton, Burson- Marsteller recently edged into the No. 1 spot on the strength of continuing strong gains in revenues.     ''I had always hoped it would happen,'' said Mr. Burson, who got started in public relations as a student at the University of Mississippi.    According to the 1984 edition of O'Dwyer's Directory of Public Relations Firms, Burson-Marsteller's 1983 net fee income rose 26 percent from a year earlier, to $63.8 million, surpassing Hill & Knowlton by $3 million. After-tax profit was about $3 million, Mr. Burson said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Advertising; Agencies Optimistic About 1984
abstract: EVEN the admitted pessimists in the agency business are optimistic about 1984. It may be guarded optimism, as it is in the case of John J. Kinsella, president and chief executive of the Leo Burnett Company of Chicago, but it is optimism all the same. And it is optimism not only for their own agencies but also for the advertising industry as a whole.    And these chief executives are not merely whistling in the dark. Clients' plans have already been made.

headline: Military Tax Review Due WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) - The Internal Revenue Service is considering eliminating a tax break enjoyed by military personnel.
abstract: The I.R.S. said Thursday that military personnel who receive tax-free housing allowances may not in the future be able to deduct mortgage interest payments from their yearly taxes.   Whatever decision is made, the agency said, it will not establish new rules on the mortgage deductions before next Jan. 1.

headline: MINIMUM TAX TO REACH MORE OF THE WELL-TO-DO
abstract: For upper-income Americans who have made generous use of certain tax benefits to cut back sharply on their tax liability, there is a new threat to their pocketbooks: the vastly broadened alternative minimum tax.     This tax, which is intended to make sure that the well-to-do pay a fair share of the income tax, will strike many more people this year than ever before, including some who may not consider themselves at all well-to-do. Moreover, according to tax advisers who have already made preliminary calculations for their clients, it will strike with greater force.    As Herbert Paul, a New York tax attorney, put it: ''I think the American public is in for a rather disturbing awakening on how many of them are going to be affected by the alternative minimum tax.''    Nonetheless, the impact of the A.M.T., as the device is known in accounting circles, will not be as dramatic as one might infer from the anxious conversations heard in executive suites, at cocktail parties and in first-class sections of airliners.

headline: FIELDCREST MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHICAGO BANK DEPARTURE
abstract: Roger E. Anderson, who resigned Monday as chief executive officer of the Continental Illinois Corporation, denied today that his departure had anything to do with allegations of lending abuses by three dismissed officials.    The 62-year-old Mr. Anderson, who said last August that he intended to stay until normal retirement age, spoke at a news conference called by his successor, David G. Taylor, 54.    Mr. Taylor takes over the bank holding company and its chief subsidiary, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, at a time when earnings have been depressed by huge loan losses.

headline: DOW RISES 6.18 POINTS, TO 1,180.49
abstract: Stock prices firmed a bit yesterday after two days of steep decline and finished mixed in continued active trading.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which had dropped almost 40 points in the preceding two sessions mainly because of fears that interest rates will rise, rose 6.18 points, to 1,180.49.    The overall market also improved, but ended lower with declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscoring those that rose by about a 9-to-7 ratio. On Monday, losers were ahead of winners by more than 4 to 1.

headline: Houston Gas Stock Falls After Report
abstract: The stock of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation fell in a rising market today following its report late Friday that directors had decided the company should remain independent.

headline: Chile Expects A Refinancing
abstract: Chile and its international creditor banks will sign an agreement in New York on Friday to refinance $130 million in debts, senior Chilean officials said today.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: U.S. and Japan Eurobonds Up LONDON, Jan. 5 (Reuters)   - United States and Japanese   convertible Eurobonds were   sharply higher in active trading reflecting the trends on   Wall Street and Tokyo stocks,   dealers said. Japanese convertibles   showed sharp gains across the   board with strong and mostly   professional demand for blue-   chip issues.

headline: CHEMICAL ATTACK CHARGED BY IRAN
abstract: Iran charged that Iraq used chemical weapons again today in an attack on its forces on Majnoon Island north of Basra, and wounded ''tens'' of Iranian soldiers. The accusation came as a United Nations team arrived in Teheran to investigate Iranian charges that Iraq had used chemical arms in the 3 1/2-year-old war.   Iraq has denied that it is using chemical weapons and offered to cooperate in any investigation. It did not immediately respond to the latest accusation.

headline: Dow Chemical
abstract: The Dow Chemical Company said it expects its 1984 capital spending to total between $800 million and $850 million, up from $630 million in 1983. Last year's spending was down from $829 million in 1982 and $1.18 billion in 1981, which followed five other years of spending of more than $1 billion. A spokesman said that spending in 1983 was lower than in previous years because heavy spending in earlier years had eliminated the need for new capacity.

headline: U.S. Acting to Curb Money Sent to I.R.A.
abstract: An American effort to curb the flow of money from the United States to Irish republican guerrillas was announced today by the American Ambassador to Britain.   In a speech to businessman during a visit to British-ruled Northern Ireland, the Ambassador, Charles Price, said United States Customs officers had begun using a currency reporting act to confiscate money used to buy arms.

headline: MIDDLE SOUTH UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THOMAS & BETTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Kaiser Meeting Is Subject of Suit FONTANA, Calif., Jan. 16 (Reuters) - The Kaiser Steel Corporation said two of its stockholders had applied for a temporary restraining order to prevent it from holding a shareholder meeting on Wednesday and from voting on or consummating a merger agreement with a group led by J. A. Frates, an Oklahoma investor. The application was filed by the Pearl Brewing Company and the Falstaff Brewing Company, which together own about 5 percent of Kaiser. It said the court for the Central District of California would hear the application on Tuesday in Los Angeles.
abstract: Kaiser also said a Nevada district court had denied an application by a Brazilian mining company, Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, seeking $67 million in damages against Kaiser for breach of a contract to buy iron ore pellets.

headline: REAGAN SUGGESTS RULES BE EASED ON LATIN LOANS
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan suggested today that the Administration might relax regulations requiring that American banks reduce their reported earnings to reflect overdue interest payments from Argentina.     But Federal bank regulators questioned the move.    Argentina faces a deadline Saturday to pay $650 million in overdue interest on loans of $10 billion from American banks. Argentine officials indicated today that they needed at least several days past the deadline to make these payments.  Major American banks are resigned to the likelihood that some of them will have to report sharp drops in earnings as a result of the loans. But they add that the effects of such declines - in lower stock prices, for example - have already been felt and thus the companies' condition will not deteriorate sharply. (Page D6.)

headline: 50 Said to Die in Crash Of Bulgarian Airliner
abstract: A Bulgarian airliner crashed while trying to land at Sofia's airport Tuesday, killing all 50 people on board, the East German news agency ADN reported today.   ADN said the Balkan Airlines TU-134 left East Berlin on Tuesday afternoon for Sofia, normally a three-hour flight.

headline: VOLCKER CITES INFLATIONARY PRESSURES
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested today that the Fed would stick to its commitment to moderate growth of the economy and stable prices.    The Fed has come under pressure from the White House, the Treasury and some members of Congress to resist actions that would force up interest rates and slow the economy's unexpectedly strong growth in the current quarter.    The Administration's concern has been heightened by apprehension over the decisions the Fed faces on Monday and Tuesday, when its 12- member Federal Open Market Committee meets to consider changes in its credit and money supply policies.

headline: G.M. Set to Recall 7,200 Employees
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would recall another 7,200 workers by June, bringing to 90,000 the total number called back by the company since January 1983, the peak month of unemployment in the automobile industry.   F. James McDonald, G.M.'s president, said 2,900 employees would return to assembly plants and 4,300 to component operations.

headline: SOVIET FIGHTS FRAUD WITH CREDIT-CARD GUZZLER
abstract: The Soviet Union, in a tough new drive against a black market in gasoline, is testing a computerized accounting system that does not just reject credit cards, but swallows them as well, if any fraud occurs.    The experimental system, available to truck and bus drivers, but not to private car owners, is part of a conservation effort at a time when Soviet oil production has been leveling off or even declining. With private auto ownership still limited, the official truck and bus fleets in the Government-run economy are by far the largest users of motor fuels.   A Soviet decree published last Dec. 7 called for tighter control over the trucking industry to enhance efficiency and reduce waste of fuel and lubricants.

headline: Mississippi Valley
abstract: The Mississippi Valley Gas Company said it had received a $33- a-share offer from the Yazoo Investment Corporation.

headline: REAGAN PRAISES NAVY FLIER AND JACKSON
abstract: Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr. of the Navy returned to the United States today and met with President Reagan in a White House ceremony that the President called a ''homecoming celebration.''    Mr. Reagan praised the lieutenant, who was freed by the Syrian Government after 30 days of captivity, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who had flown to Damascus to seek his release.   ''This young Naval officer was flying a mission of peace,'' the President said, ''and, both during and after, he exemplified qualities of leadership and loyalty, qualities of so many fine men and women in our military that we're all proud of.''   Mr. Reagan then turned to Mr. Jackson, the 42-year-old civil rights leader and Democratic Presidential candidate who headed a delegation that went to Syria to make an appeal for the flier's release. ''Reverend Jackson's mission,'' he said, ''was a personal mission of mercy and he has earned our gratitude and our admiration.''

headline: Hundreds of Afghans Reported Killed in Month
abstract: Western diplomats said today that Soviet- led forces in Afghanistan killed hundreds of civilians this month in bombing raids on villages north of Kabul, the capital.   The reports could not be independently confirmed.

headline: November Orders Up by 2.2% 812WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) - A big jump in orders for military goods pushed total orders to American manufacturers up 2.2 percent in November, the Commerce Department reported today.
abstract: With manufacturers increasing their shipping even faster, stockpiles of goods stayed about the same - leaving the shipment-to-inventory ratio at its lowest level in 33 years, the department said.    Total orders for new manufactured goods rose to $185.8 billion in November from $181.8 billion the previous month; shipments rose 2.6 percent, to $181.4 billion.   With a gain of only two-tenths of 1 percent in inventories, the inventory- to-shipments ratio fell from 1.48 to 1.44 - the lowest since it dropped below 1.4 in 1950, according to Robert Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist.

headline: British Farm Income Off
abstract: British farmers' incomes fell 15 percent, to $2.18 billion, last year, the Agriculture Ministry's annual review said today.  Of 243,000 farms in Britain, the average farm size is now 294 acres, up from 284 acres in 1978, the report said.

headline: South Africa Sentences Wife Of Ex-Leader of Black Rebels
abstract: The wife of the former secretary general of the African National Congress has been sentenced to four years in prison for singing banned songs and speaking favorably at a funeral about the black nationalist organization.   On Friday Justice T. J. Le Grange of the Krugersdorp Regional Court suspended two years of the sentence for Albertina Sisulu, whose husband, Walter, is the group's former secretary general.   Mrs. Sisulu, a longtime critic of South Africa's race-separation laws, pleaded not guilty to singing songs praising the African National Congress, displaying its flag and distributing its pamphlets and stickers at a funeral in January 1982.

headline: THE ROBOT MAKERS STUB THEIR TOES
abstract: THE American robot industry was to be a star of the 80's, even the savior of smokestack America. The advanced billing attracted an avalanche of companies over the last five years, newcomers that hoped to make money by building machines that could do some of the dangerous, dirty and dreary jobs now done by humans.   But the industry has failed to deliver on its promise. Robot sales have been far below expectations and the resulting competition has produced ferocious price cuts and the start of a sharp shakeout.    Only one American company, Prab Robotics Inc., based in this community 150 miles from Detroit, made money in robotics in 1983, according to the first extensive industry study, conducted by the United States International Trade Commission. Losses for the industry amounted to 49 percent of sales last year, or about $83 million on sales of $169 million. The industry has been losing money since 1979, according to the I.T.C.

headline: Marines Reclassify 241 Killed In Lebanon as Battle Deaths
abstract: The Marine Corps, responding to Congressional pressure, has agreed to reclassify servicemen killed in the Oct. 23 bombing in Lebanon as battle casualties instead of accidental deaths.

headline: Colgate Names Financial Chief
abstract: Paul A. Jones, 55 years old, is   moving to the post of corporate   executive vice president and   chief financial officer of the   Colgate-Palmolive Company,   effective April 1. He leaves the   post of executive vice president   and chief general counsel of the   Kimberly-Clark Corporation,   the big paper and newsprint   company, with which he had   been associated for the last 14   years.  Mr. Jones, who has combined   a legal and financial background, graduated from the   University of Cincinnati in 1951   and then studied law at the   same institution, receiving his   bachelor of law degree in 1955.

headline: GUATEMALAN REPORTS FOILED PLOT
abstract: A Guatemalan security officer said today that the military Government foiled a planned coup this month in which a group of retired generals hired an assassin in Miami to kill the chief of state, Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores.   A Guatemalan Army press spokesman, Edgar Djalma Dominguez, declined to comment on the report.   The security official said in an interview that the generals, who had been forced to retire by a new military law, met in mid-January at a hotel in a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to plan General Mejia Victores's overthrow. The official said they withdrew money from Miami bank accounts to hire a killer and bribe top military commanders to join the plot.

headline: Brazil Predicts Ability To Buil
abstract: Brazil will be able to produce nuclear weapons by the 1990's, Navy Minister Maximiano da Fonseca said in an interview published today.   But Admiral da Fonseca told the Jornal do Brasil that any decision to make a bomb would depend on a political decision by a future government.   ''Through the natural development of research the country will inevitably one day have the material necessary to build the bomb,'' the minister said.

headline: ARAFAT AND HUSSEIN FINISH TALKS ON WEST BANK FUTURE
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, ended a series of discussions today in which they said they agreed on ways of coordinating policies toward regaining the occupied West Bank from Israel.   ''The two sides agreed to continue their discussion on a joint stand based on an organized, firmly established and balanced basis, which will allow them to move together with support of the Arab nation,'' a joint statement said.   The statement said Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization had agreed on ''many steps to reduce the suffering of our people in the occupied territories'' including the revival of a joint committee to support the ''steadfastness'' of the Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

headline: Advertising; Frito-Lay Introduces New Chip
abstract: PEPSICO'S Frito-Lay subsidiary, which can already claim a 42 percent share of the nation's $2.5 billion potato chip market with its Lay's and Ruffles brands, now antes up another chip: O'Grady.    The new brand, which has ridges like Ruffles, comes in regular and cheese flavor.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: System for Detecting Flaws in U.S. Currency    A system for detecting physical flaws in United States currency has been patented for the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, Norwalk, Conn.

headline: Advertising; Carrier's Trade-In Campaign
abstract: T HE Carrier Corporation, the nation's leading producer of central air conditioning systems, will make a new marketing thrust in a $5 million ad campaign starting Feb. 29 in print and television.   Figuring that there were 20 million systems sold during the boom years in the mid-1960's that are just about ready to poop out, the company has decided to go after the replacement market.    In the campaign conceived by Ebb Dozier, director of marketing communications, Carrier will offer to buy anyone's old air conditioner if they buy a new one from Carrier.    That called for the creation of a Blue Book of Air Conditioning (inspired by the Kelley Blue Book, the bible of the used-car business), which runs to 334 pages crammed with the wholesale values for more than 41,000 makes and models of air conditioners made from 1960 though 1980. A quick thumb-through the book shows no trade-ins valued at more than $400, with most under $200.

headline: KISSINGER PANEL, IN A DRAFT, SAYS SOVIET IS A THREAT IN LATIN AFFAIRS
abstract: President Reagan's commission on Central America warns in a draft of its report that the Soviet Union and Cuba are threatening to upset the strategic balance of power in Central America.    The draft calls for a ''new alliance for democracy and prosperity'' in Central America at a cost of $8 billion in American aid over the next five years. Otherwise, it warned, a ''strategic coup of major proportions'' by the Soviet Union may occur.   The commission, led by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, recommends, in the draft, ''significantly increased'' military aid to El Salvador - as much as $400 million in additional funds in 1984 and 1985 - to counter what it depicts as a ''direct threat to U.S. security interests.''   Commission members and aides, in interviews, confirmed that much of the language in the draft, which was still open to revision as of today, would be in the final report scheduled for delivery to President Reagan on Wednesday.

headline: THE SPLITS IN LEBANON GET FINER
abstract: The political situation here, already tangled, is becoming so complicated that Lebanese officials were talking today about two separate cease-fires.    There was also talk about meetings of two unrelated security committees, and negotiations in Syria to settle at least three Lebanese feuds.   One problem is the broad conflict between the Government of President Amin Gemayel, a Maronite Christian, and opposition groups, who are mainly Moslem. For the moment, the major task is to arrange a cease-fire between army troops loyal to Mr. Gemayel and the opposition militias.   Another major source of instability has been the fight in West Beirut beween the Druse militia and a small Sunni Moslem force known as the Mourabitoun. The Sunnis, who have long been dominant in West Beirut, resent the presence of the Druse, whose centers of power are in the mountains overlooking the city.

headline: ;  Former Hutton Man Moves to Rothschild
abstract: James T. Gahan, a former managing director at E. F. Hutton & Company, has joined Rothschild Inc. as president of a newly formed subsidiary, Rothschild Securities Trading Inc.     Mr. Gahan (pronounced GAN) spent 23 years at Hutton. He left 18 months ago, shortly after George L. Ball, then Hutton's president, left to head a new Prudential Insurance Company subsidiary that includes the Bache Group.

headline: THAYER CASE SHIFTS TO DALLAS
abstract: Paul Thayer, former Deputy Secretary of Defense, and eight other people who have been charged with illegally trading stock on the basis of inside information won an important legal skirmish yesterday when a Federal judge in New York ordered their trial moved to Dallas.   In granting the defendants' motion to transfer the trial, Judge Charles E. Stewart Jr. said he was doing so primarily because of the ''convenience of the parties and the witnesses, which point to Dallas as the more appropriate forum.''   The Securities and Exchange Commission, which brought the charges, had opposed the transfer of the trial, arguing that it would be more expensive and inconvenient to litigate the case in Dallas.

headline: KOREANS HOLD SPECIAL STATUS IN MANCHURIA
abstract: The farmers of the Aladi Production Brigade look little different from the Han Chinese of other Manchurian villages set in the low brown hills north of the city of Jilin.   Their carts, pulled by shaggy horses, jolt along the frozen dirt street between snug brick houses that suggest the wealth of the surrounding rice paddies. The teamsters wear the usual Manchurian padded cotton jackets and floppy hats, often lined with dog fur. But on holidays and other special occasions, Aladi's residents break out in the rainbow colors of the Korean costume, with high-waisted dresses for women and baggy trousers for men.

headline: Kaiser Steel Pact With Crocker FONTANA, Calif., Jan. 19 (Reuters) - The Kaiser Steel Corporation said it and the Kaiser Acquisition Corporation, which is taking over the company, had agreed to give the California Pollution Control Financing Authority and the Crocker National Bank two days' notice of the closing of the takeover. Kaiser Acquisition is owned by an investment group led by J. A. Frates.
abstract: In return, the agency and the bank agreed not to begin legal action relating to the takeover before receiving such notice and agreed to seek resolution of their dispute with Kaiser Steel.

headline: Egyptian Court Rehabilitates 2 Opposition Party Leaders
abstract: An administrative court ruled today that two leaders of the New Wafd opposition party could resume political activity that was halted when Anwar el-Sadat, the late President, issued a decree in 1978 banning them from politics.

headline: Guerrillas in Salvador Attack Vital Bridge
abstract: Guerrillas attacked a strategic railroad bridge for the second time in three days today as part of a possible attempt to split the country into two, military sources said. They said a seven-hour firefight between rebels and United States-trained troops of the Atonal Battalion and local ''hunter'' battalions ended before dawn.

headline: THE NOT-SO-GENTLE WOOING OF SALVADOR'S PEASANTS
abstract: The wooden planks of the barn and the trunks of every tree on this farming cooperative are splashed with paint calling on the 600 families who live here to vote for Roberto d'Aubuisson, the presidential candidate of the far right, who has opposed land redistribution.    The messages, daubed in red, white and blue paint, along with demands by bosses of the National Republican Alliance political party on many of the country's 317 cooperatives that the peasants be trucked to political rallies for Mr. d'Aubuisson are examples of the pressures a Salvadoran voter is under during the campaign season.   Under the election process in El Salvador, as in some other countries, citizens are obliged to vote or pay a fine. Often the candidate's campaign styles appear more coercive than suggestive.

headline: CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COMMERCIAL PAPER
abstract: Interest rates rose slightly at weekly commercial paper auctions of Citicorp and Shearson/American Express, the companies announced yesterday. Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 9.352 percent, up from 9.30 percent, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 9.322 percent, up from 9.296 percent. Shearson/American Express sold $50 million of 63-day paper at an average rate of 9.35 percent, up from 9.28 percent.

headline: HIS FOES GATHERED IN SYRIA, DEBATE GEMAYEL'S SURVIVAL
abstract: Lebanese opposition leaders met through the day here with Syrian officials and among themselves today and reportedly remained deeply divided over whether President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon should resign.    This issue and other differences remained unresolved, Lebanese officials here reported. They said no specific decisions affecting Lebanon's future had been made.   President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met for three hours with Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader; Suleiman Franjieh, a Maronite Christian and former President of Lebanon, and Rashid Karami, a Sunni Moslem and former Prime Minister.

headline: 2 EX-DRYSDALE OFFICERS PLEAD GUILTY
abstract: The two top officers of the Drysdale Government Securities Corporation, which collapsed in 1982, pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding the Chase Manhattan Bank of $270 million.     The officers - Joseph V. Ossorio, chairman of the defunct Drysdale Securities Corporation and a director of the Drysdale Government affiliate, and David J. Heuwetter, who owned all of Drysdale Government Security's stock and was its chief trader - made their pleas in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The two had been indicted on the charges last July and originally pleaded not guilty.   Mr. Ossorio also admitted defrauding the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of more than $20 million. He could face an 18-year prison sentence, while Mr. Heuwetter could receive a maximum of seven years.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS: PITFALLS IN 1983
abstract: Investors who loaded up on high- technology mutual funds when the market boom started 18 months ago made a killing in the first half of 1983. But those who failed to bail out by summer very likely suffered heavy losses that often wiped out their earlier gains.    The funds that did well in the last half of the year were heavy in international stocks or more traditional businesses like tobacco and insurance.   Those are the conclusions of the first full analysis of how mutual funds performed last year, released earlier this week by Lipper Analytical Services. The numbers show that despite the overall strength of the market last year, most investors who profited in mutual funds did so by radically redirecting their portfolios by the beginning of the third quarter.

headline: Indian Judge Orders Hanging Of Kashmir Separatist Leader
abstract: An Indian judge today ordered the execution Saturday of a Kashmir secessionist leader, Maqbool Butt, whose release was demanded by the kidnappers of an Indian diplomat who was slain in England last weekend.   The date for hanging the convicted killer was set after President Zail Singh rejected a plea for mercy after the shooting of the 48-year-old diplomat, Ravindra Mhatre.

headline: Banker-Oil Link Reported
abstract: A Chicago banker who managed the loan portfolio of the Davis Oil Company received interests in 78 of the company's wells, according to reports published today.   Marvin Davis, the president of Davis Oil, was also one of the bank's biggest borrowers, The Denver Post reported.

headline: 100 LEBANESE RETURN HOME, TO DESPAIR
abstract: As foreigners were evacuated from Lebanon today because of fighting, a handful of Lebanese returned to their blighted land on boats that provide the only link with the outside world.    The 100 Lebanese, mostly men, were business people who had left the country before the latest spasm of violence that has apparently pushed Beirut's shifting balance of power further away from the Christian community to which most of them belonged.   Before their return today, they had been hundreds or thousands of miles from their homes, in Cyprus, Europe and the United States, frantically seeking reassuring news of wives trapped by shellfire and children sheltering in basements by long distance telephone.   Then, late Friday night, the ferry that runs from Larnaca, Cyprus, to Lebanon and which had previously been unable to brave high seas began to operate again.

headline: PANEL SAID TO URGE SALVADOR TALKS AND U.S. CONTACTS IN NICARAGUA
abstract: A bipartisan Presidential commission was said today to be close to approving a report that urges stepped-up United States diplomatic contacts with Nicaragua and a major new effort to bring about talks between the Salvadoran Government and leftist guerrillas.    During the week, the commission, headed by Henry A. Kissinger, has made changes in a seven-volume draft report to accommodate objections of some Democratic members, commission officials said.   Although the draft report generally endorses Reagan Administration policy, the officials said, it is now ''less hostile'' toward Nicaragua's Sandinista regime.   Mr. Kissinger met with President Reagan for 20 minutes today to outline ''the thinking and direction'' of the 12- member panel. Officials said Mr. Reagan was advised that there was ''a consensus'' in favor of doubling United States economic and military aid to Central America to roughly $1 billion a year for the next 15 years.

headline: COVER-UP CHARGED IN DEATH OF NUNS
