abstract: A classified investigative report prepared for the State Department concluded that there was a cover-up by Salvadoran authorities in the killing of four American churchwomen in December 1980 and that it was ''quite possible'' that the present Salvadoran Minister of Defense was aware of it.    The Minister of Defense, Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, was a colonel and commander of the national guard when the women were murdered. Five men who were in the national guard at the time have been charged with the murders.   The investigation, conducted by a former Federal judge, Harold E. Tyler, concluded that the cover- up began within a day or two of the killings.

headline: Shamrock Sale
abstract: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said its Natomas North America unit had tentatively agreed to sell its United States onshore producing and nonproducing oil and gas properties to the Apache Petroleum Company for $160 million.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

headline: ISRAEL FORESEES A LONG STAY
abstract: Lebanese opposition leaders today rejected an eight-point reconciliation proposal put forward by President Amin Gemayel.   Syria also denounced the plan, with the official press agency describing it as a ''trick that has been unmasked.'' (Page 5.)   Tonight, heavy fighting broke out in the capital and to the east between anti- Gemayel militias and units of the Lebanese Army still loyal to the President.

headline: MANITOBA DISPUTE STALLS ASSEMBLE
abstract: For six weeks, all business in Manitoba's provincial legislature has been at a standstill because of Conservative legislators fighting a bill that would guarantee the language rights of the French-speaking minority in the Middle Western province.   Today, in an unusual parliamentary move, the Canadian House of Commons called upon the Conservatives to suspend their filibuster and allow the bill's passage. The move was unusual in that it was made not by vote but by the endorsement of the leaders of all national political parties.

headline: SALES TO OPEC NATIONS SLUMP
abstract: A sharp drop in revenues flowing from oil-importing industrial nations to OPEC has been undeniably good for the industrial economies. The billions once spent on petroleum are now staying at home, helping to lift personal incomes and finance purchases of more productive goods.    But for the companies that saw the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries blossom into a major market from 1973 to 1981, the picture is quite different.    Sales of heavy equipment, trucks and consumer goods, to name just a few areas, have fallen sharply in the past year because of the falloff in OPEC oil revenues. Data Resources Inc., which does economic analysis, said those revenues peaked in 1980, when the group's current accounts surplus hit $130 billion.

headline: Multinationals
abstract: To the Editor:   Apparently, Kent Conrad is attempting to make your readers believe that most, if not all, of the multinational corporations that file state tax returns evade their proper share of tax through various fraudulent means (Business Forum, Feb. 26). I disagree. For 14 years I have served a varied cross-section of multinational companies that have been and continue to be good corporate citizens, paying their fair share of tax to the states in which they do business.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, MARCH 30, 1984   The Economy    The index of leading economic indicators rose 0.7 percent in February. This was less that January's 1 percent gain, but it was still the 17th rise in 18 months. (Page D1.)    New-home sales climbed a brisk 7.8 percent in February, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 721,000. (D4.)

headline: Market Place; New Hopes Stir for RCA
abstract: IN the late 1920's, Wall Street called it ''Radio''    and the stock was the darling of the investment   world. In more recent years, however, the RCA Corporation has brought little more than disappointment in the form of erratic earnings, paltry dividends and, naturally enough, unimpressive stock action.   The latest blow came earlier this month, when RCA said it would seek shareholder approval for measures to make a takeover of the company more difficult. The shares took another battering, immediately plunging 1 3/4, to 30.

headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS Oil Up Sharply on Fear Of an Iranian Blockade
abstract: International oil prices on the spot market rose sharply yesterday in response to fears of an Iranian blockade of the Strait of Hormuz, one of the main lifelines for the world's oil supply.    In futures trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price of crude oil for April delivery rose by 69 cents a barrel, to $30.79, the biggest one-day jump since the exchange began trading futures contracts a year ago, according to Andrew Lebow, an oil futures specialist for Shearson/American Express.   The price of heating oil for March delivery rose 2.31 cents, to 80.39 cents a barrel, and gasoline for March delivery rose 1.43 cents, to 81.48 cents a barrel.

headline: Lockheed Awards
abstract: The Lockheed Corporation received a total of $79.6 million in Air Force and Navy contracts, according to the Defense Department. It said the company got $68 million from the Air Force for work on TR-1A tactical reconnaissance aircraft and $11.6 million from the Navy for P-3 patrol aircraft equipment. In addition, the Hughes Aircraft Company received a $44.5 million Navy contract for tactical displays systems for ships.

headline: TUNISIA REPORTS MANY ARRESTS IN WAKE OF RIOTING
abstract: The Tunisian Government said today that it had arrested ''a great number of criminals and professional agitators'' in the wake of the rioting that led to the declaration of a state of national emergency on Tuesday. It said that they would be tried but gave no details of the arrests.   President Habib Bourguiba is due to address the nation on Friday. The traditional New Year's reception for diplomats, originally set for that day, has been put off till next week.

headline: SHADES OF 'THE GRADUATE': IT'S PLASTICS AGAIN
abstract: ''THE plastics industry did so much business last year that it was considered astounding,'' according to an expert in the field, and as a result some companies are on a hiring spree that has made job prospects in plastics brighter than they have been for years.    Industry officials say this new job market results primarily from the variety of new plastic consumer products that are increasingly replacing their glass and metal counterparts. With ever-greater skill, chemists are rearranging the loops and chains of carbon, oxygen, hydrogen and nitrogen in plastics not only to create lighter, cheaper, and better protectors of perishables but also to give these materials extraordinary properties: for example, they can be made to conduct electricity or to possess the strength of steel. A surprising amount of plastic is even used in the construction of houses.   This is resulting in such new plastic products as auto engines, tennis racquets, lightweight batteries and packaging materials. ''In five years,'' said Dr. Laszlo Bonis, chairman of the Composite Container Corporation in Medford, Mass., ''you'll hardly be able to find glass or metal in the supermarket.''

headline: Zhao Arrives in New York
abstract: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China arrived in New York yesterday on a flight from San Francisco and was welcomed at Kennedy International Airport by Mayor Koch, Representative Bill Green and Senator Alphonse M. D'Amato. Mr. Koch presented Mr. Zhao with a key to the city and said he would serve him ''authentic American beef stew - the best ever.''

headline: LEBANESE SHELLING KILLS AT LEAST 10
abstract: At least 10 people were killed and 64 wounded today in heavy shelling around Beirut and in the mountains to the east.   At the same time, the special American envoy, Donald Rumsfeld, conferred with President Amin Gemayel for three hours to brief him on his visits to Syria and Israel and to discuss the prospects of a plan that would disengage the rival militia forces and try to stop the shooting. Mr. Rumsfeld declined to speak to reporters after the meeting, which did not appear to produce any breakthrough on the much-debated plan.   The Syrians appear to have decided to tell their Lebanese allies not to support the plan until the Gemayel Government agrees to abrogate the May 17 Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal agreement - which the Syrians contend gives Israel too much political influence over Lebanon. As a result, there appears to be no immediate hope of putting the plan into effect.

headline: TOP BONN MILITARY LEADERS TO DISCUSS GENERAL'S OUSTER
abstract: The Inspector General of the West German armed forces announced today that he had called a meeting for Tuesday of the nation's senior commanders to discuss the removal of one of West Germany's most senior generals on the ground that he was a homosexual.   The Inspector General, Wolfgang Altenburg, said that if the officer, Gen. G"unter Kiessling, was found to be innocent of the charges, ''he must be rehabilitated.''   The announcement came as Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government appeared to be struggling to justify the removal of General Kiessling. Defense Minister Manfred W"orner said he hoped to meet personally with General Kiessling, whom he removed last month from his post as deputy to Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, the supreme commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

headline: CLUETT, PEABODY FORMS NEW 3-EXECUTIVE PANEL
abstract: Cluett, Peabody & Company, which makes Arrow shirts and other apparel, announced the formation of a three-member office of the chairman. It chose Richard Q. Armstrong, former president of the Dr Pepper Company, to be a member of the triumvirate. Mr. Armstrong, who was also named to the new position of executive vice president, will assume his duties Monday.

headline: A Plan to Aid Ambrosiano's Creditors LONDON, Jan. 11 (Reuters) - An agreement in which the 93 creditor banks of Italy's failed Banco Ambrosiano may recover up to 80 percent of bad debts could be in place soon, banking officials said today.
abstract: They said the plan calls for the Vatican to contribute funds toward a total $450 million owed on two syndicated loans made to Banco Ambrosiano's Luxembourg subsidiary.   The creditor group has modified its claim against Banco Ambrosiano's liquidators and its successor, Nuovo Banco Ambrosiano S.p.A, to between 60 percent and 80 percent of outstanding debt, the banking officials said.

headline: Coast Power Issue To Total $1 Billion A $1 billion financing for the Southern California Public Power Authority was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 percent for bonds due in 2022 and 2023 through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Proceeds of the bonds, rated A-1/Ax, will be used to construct power lines between coal-fired power plants in central Utah and southern Californa municipalities that have agreed to buy the power.
abstract: The financing consists of $400 million of notes, divided between an April 15, 1985, maturity yielding 6 percent and a Jan. 1, 1987, issue yielding 6 3/4 percent.   The long-term bond portion was increased to $600 million from $400 million and consists of serial bonds yielding from 7 1/2 percent in 1990 to 9.7 percent in 2004, with 9 7/8 percent bonds due in 2011, 10 percent bonds due in 2022 and 9 1/2 percent bonds due in 2023 offered at a price of 95.087 to yield 10 percent.

headline: SHIFT BY HUSSEIN: A NEW ASSERTIVENESS
abstract: News   Analysis    AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 29 - King Hussein's appeal to the United States for military aid to help Jordan defend Persian Gulf governments in distress is a demonstration of the assertiveness and self-confidence that have characterized the King's foreign and domestic policy statements in recent weeks, Jordanian and Western officials here agree.  Hussein's call for extra aid at a news conference here Saturday was couched in caveats and conditions. His thrust was clear, however: Jordan needs and welcomes military assistance, but will not become a surrogate military presence for the United States.   Jordanian officials said military aid should be provided not because Jordan would act on behalf of the United States, but because the two nations have an overlapping strategic interest in assuring the security and stability of ''moderate'' Arab nations in the Persian Gulf.

headline: SALVADOR VOTE: RISING FEARS ON OUTCOME
abstract: Government and military officials and politicians of various persuasions are becoming increasingly concerned that next week's presidential elections will lead to new instability here.  In the short term at least, these people say, the prospect is for increased tension between rightist and moderate elements and possibly between the civilian and military authorities. The danger is that this could lead to increased political violence or possibly even a military coup.    Reagan Administration officials have privately expressed worry in recent weeks that these results were possible, but the Salvadorans interviewed seemed to consider some increase in instability a virtual certainty.

headline: REGAN CAUTIONS ON ECONOMY
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the economic recovery could be aborted if the Government and the Federal Reserve Board were not careful in their actions over the next six months. Mr. Regan said that deficits had to be cut and that the Federal Reserve had to prevent its policy from being too tight.    ''I would say there is a great deal of risk here on both the fiscal side and the monetary side that we could abort this recovery,'' Mr. Regan told the House Appropriations Committee. ''If we don't do something about the deficits, it really will scare not only the Federal Reserve but also the financial markets.''

headline: D'AUBUISSON DENIES TIE TO SALVADOR DEATH SQUADS
abstract: A right-wing candidate in El Salvador's presidential election has denied accusations that he was involved in the country's death squads.   Roberto d'Aubuisson, the candidate of the rightist Nationalist Republican Alliance Party, also said he still planned to visit the United States Monday, although he has no visa.   Responding to an article Saturday in The New York Times in which a former Salvadoran military officer linked Mr. d'Aubuisson and other high Salvadoran officials to the death squads, Mr. d'Aubuisson said, ''They are not taking into account that I have been busy the past two years writing a Constitution.''   Mr. d'Aubuisson served as president of the Salvadoran Constituent Assembly beginning in April 1982. He resigned that post to run for the presidency.

headline: Ramada Inns Names Officer
abstract: Ramada Inns Inc. said yesterday that it had appointed Jerry Best executive vice president of the company and president of the hotel group.

headline: HEAVY FIGHTING ERUPTS ANEW IN BEIRUT
abstract: Heavy fighting broke out today between Lebanese Army forces and Moslem militias along the Green Line dividing East and West Beirut.    The new violence came as Lebanon's political leaders prepared for the opening of talks among Lebanon's warring factions next Monday in Switzerland.   In the meantime, the leader of the Phalangist militia warned that his group would shell Beirut International Airport if the Moslem leadership in West Beirut tried to open it.   The renewed fighting today involved what the Beirut radio called ''an all-out blowup'' along the line separating predominantly Christian East Beirut and the Moslem western part of the city.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: Tables on foreign exchange trading in the United States were not available because most banks in New York were closed yesterday.

headline: FEBRUARY'S PRODUCTION UP BY 1.2%
abstract: Industrial production rose 1.2 percent in February from January, the second strong increase in two months, offering what one analyst called further proof of ''a superb business expansion.''   The February increase in output by the nation's factories, mines and utilities, reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, indicated the economy was much stronger than many analysts had predicted in December. Last month's production was 15.8 percent higher than a year earlier.   The February increase duplicated the 1.2 percent rise in January, which had been the best since a 1.3 percent jump last September. All figures are adjusted to allow for normal seasonal variations.

headline: SOVIET YOUTHS EMBRACE AN 'INVASION' OF ENGLISH
abstract: ''I'm a khailaifist,'' wrote the 20-year-old, bragging of his American jeans, Japanese stereo, rock music collection and library of science fiction.   The belongings are fairly standard for a pampered member of the ''golden youth,'' the well-to-do offspring of the Soviet elite. But ''khailaifist''?   It turned out, according to the Soviet daily Komsomolskaya Pravda, to be ''high-life-ist,'' a new entry in the ever- expanding, English-derived jargon of Soviet youth that has already enriched Soviet speech with dzhinsi for jeans, dzhaz for jazz, rok for rock, diski for records, kasety for cassette and even striptiz for striptease, shuz for shoes, vach for watch and fazer for father. The English words and phrases are retransliterated from the Cyrillic alphabet, used by the Russians.

headline: People
abstract: *  David R. Ammons has joined Culbertson & Johnson Advertising, Philadelphia, renamed Culbertson, Johnson & Ammons.

headline: WAR IN GULF: NEW IMPASSE SEEMS LIKELY
abstract: The war between Iran and Iraq appears to United States and other Western intelligence sources to be near another impasse, with the Iranians unable to rupture the long Iraqi frontier and the Iraqis unable to exploit their defensive successes.  It is possible, these sources said, that the Iranians, by combining their remaining regular forces and tens of thousands of raw but eager teen-age volunteers, will be able to pierce Iraqi defenses at some point. But reports from representatives of NATO countries with embassies in Teheran, the Iranian capital, say that offensives appear to strain Iran's limited logistical resources.    Two weeks ago, intelligence sources from these countries said, they expected an Iranian attack involving a quarter of a million men to be made from the hills facing Iraq's Missan Province on the central front. But no such offensive developed, the sources went on, largely because the assembly of such a large force and the needed supplies was beyond the capacity of the Iranian Army.

headline: TOP LABORITE FAVORS RETURN OF ELGIN MARBLES
abstract: Greece's Minister of Culture, Melina Mercouri, said today that the British opposition leader, Neil Kinnock, had endorsed her effort to bring the Elgin Marbles back to Greece from the British Museum.    She said Mr. Kinnock, here on a four- day visit as guest of Greece's Socialist Government, had pledged the support of the Labor Party in efforts to restore to Greece the marble frieze from the fifth century B.C. if and when his party comes to power.   Mr. Kinnock met with the Minister of Culture Thursday. He called the Elgin Marbles ''a moral issue'' and said they should be restored to their place of origin on the Parthenon.

headline: 1st Soviet High-Speed Train
abstract: The Soviet Union's first high-speed train has gone into operation between Moscow and Leningrad, cutting travel time from eight hours to five, Moscow newspapers report. They said the ER-200 Express completed its first round trip Friday traveling at speeds of up to 112 miles an hour on the 440-mile journey. The new train, which carries 380 passengers, travels on a conventional track and tickets cost the same as for the regular overnight sleepers.

headline: Advertising; Beginner's Magazine Catches On
abstract: THE beauty of the magazine business is that while the richest,    most experienced practitioners can lay eggs, neophytes can create a quiche.    Time Inc., backed by market research up to here and millions upon millions of dollars, can be humbled by a TV-Cable Week experience. But a Helen Cohen can come along looking for a way to get back into the work force after having a couple of kids and come up with what might be called a viable concept: Sportswise.    Begun in 1980, Sportswise is the umbrella title for a number of regional six-a-year magazines. Each of them is built around a local calendar of amateur sporting events. Although it hardly seems appropriate healthwise, the biggest national advertising category for Sportswise is cigarettes.

headline: IN SPAIN, THE COUP CLOUDS DRIFT AWAY
abstract: Only history will tell whether last Monday's small, ceremonial gathering in a columned room of the Prime Minister's residence was really a turning point. But for the moment, most of the Spanish press and most of the people seem content to think so.    The ceremony was to induct a Chief of Defense Staff, a new position to head the armed forces, and three new Chiefs of Staff for each of the services - army, navy and air force. The change in command structure is to bring it more directly under civilian control and, by lessening the threat of a coup, to make Spain's eight-year-old democracy that much more secure.

headline: IRAN AND THE STRAIT: THREAT IS DISCOUNTED
abstract: United States and Atlantic alliance intelligence officials say they doubt that Iran, now in its 42d month of war with Iraq, will make good on its repeated threats to close the Strait of Hormuz, through which much of the oil for Japan and Western Europe is shipped.  But if Iran tries, the officials say, its ability to block the waterway physically is limited, especially in view of the professed American determination to keep it open and the naval task force the United States has in the area. Iran has warned that it will close the strait if Iraq tries to block Iran's oil-transport system.    ''No rational government would try to close the strait,'' an official said. ''But as recent history has shown, we're not dealing with a rational government, so the possibility exists that they will.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1984   The Economy    Retail sales, led by autos and department stores, rose a healthy 2.2 percent in January after a flat performance in December. Better weather helped sales to post their largest monthly gain since May. (Page D1.) Sales increases at retail stores in the New York metropolitan area were less impressive. (D6.)

headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Those Discount Stockbrokers
abstract: T HE discount brokerage business, aimed at retail customers who want to save commission   dollars, is growing side-by-side with its big- time competition - the full-service firms - and Leslie Quick Jr., a leading executive in the discount brokerage field, sees both sectors prospering in the years ahead. The reason is an expected increase in overall trading volume.    ''In 1975 discount brokerage accounted for less than 1 percent of retail trading,'' he noted. ''Currently, it runs between 15 and 16 percent, and by 1985 I can see this increasing to 20 percent.

headline: REAGAN ENDORSES PROPOSAL FOR AID TO LATIN AMERICA
abstract: A Nicaraguan official announced tonight that elections for a president, vice president and an assembly would be held in 1985. Page 12.         WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 - President Reagan today embraced a proposal for an $8 billion, five-year economic program for Central America and called on Congress to adopt ''a bipartisan spirit'' toward the comprehensive plan the Administration is drafting.   In his weekly Saturday radio address, the President gave his first explicit endorsement of the report from the Presidential commission on Central America, headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, and sought to develop political momentum behind its recommendations.

headline: A.T.& T. MAY TRIM FUTURE PAYOUTS
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will not earn enough money to cover its first-quarter dividend and might have to reduce its payouts in the future because of insufficient earnings, the chairman and chief executive, Charles L. Brown, said in a statement yesterday.     The statement was issued by A.T.& T. as it declared that its dividend for the first quarter, payable to nearly three million shareholders, would be 30 cents a share. That is the same amount predicted by the company last November in advance of the Jan. 1 breakup of the Bell System.    Mr. Brown said in his statement that A.T.& T.'s profits for the first quarter will not be enough to cover the dividend, but the company will pay it anyway to keep the promise made in a November prospectus describing the breakup.

headline: Goodyear Tires
abstract: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it would invest $250 million to convert its Tyler plant's production from bias-ply tires to the more popular radial tires.

headline: Spain Curbs Control Of Schools by Church
abstract: Parliament has approved broad educational changes that will reduce the influence of the Roman Catholic Church in schools and increase the state's control over the curriculum.   The Law of the Right of Education was approved in the Congress of Deputies on Thursday night by a vote of 196 to 96 with 6 abstentions.

headline: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ZHAO SAYS TIES TO U.S. HAVE 'UPS AND DOWNS'
abstract: President Reagan told Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China today that his visit symbolized ''the growing trust and cooperation'' between the two countries. Mr. Reagan said the United States and China shared ''common ground'' in opposing foreign expansionism.   In a 19-gun welcoming ceremony at the White House, Mr. Zhao responded by asserting that relations were ''at an important juncture,'' with ''big challenges and great opportunities'' ahead.   Speaking through an interpreter, he said that, although there ''have been ups and downs'' and ''difficulties and obstacles'' still persist, relations ''have made considerable progress.''  Dispute Over Taiwan    In their two-hour meeting the two leaders talked of the problem of American support for Taiwan.

headline: Cerebral Hemorrhage Strikes Taiwan Official
abstract: Prime Minister Sun Yun-suan underwent emergency surgery for a cerebral hemorrhage today and was recovering in satisfactory condition, officials reported.

headline: Dow Off 8.27 Points in Heavy Trading
abstract: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in continued heavy trading as institutional money managers intensified their selloff of companies that have announced unfavorable developments. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.27 points, to 1,212.31, bringing its net loss for the last 11 sessions to 59 points.   In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 952 to 669. Turnover on the Big Board contracted to 107.1 million shares from 113.5 million on Tuesday.

headline: SANDINISTA PROMISES OPPOSITION WILL GET ELECTION ASSISTANCE
abstract: A high-ranking Nicaraguan official said today that the Government was prepared to grant financial subsidies and guarantee television and radio time to opposition parties in presidential elections promised for 1985.    He also pledged that the army would accept the authority of the winner, even if from another party.   The official, Tomas Borge, Minister of the Interior and one of the nine- member directorate, said in an interview that the Sandinista leadership might lift press censorship completely in the final phase of the political campaign. He estimated the campaign would last four to six weeks.

headline: PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS ON TIES WITH SOVIET IS PRAISED BY ALLIES
abstract: Major European allies today welcomed the foreign policy speech President Reagan delivered on Monday, but commentators were divided on whether the speech's conciliatory tone was directed toward the Soviet Union or the American voter.   The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, said in a television interview that the speech ''represented a change of tone more than a change of direction.''

headline: E.E.C. Policy Meeting in May
abstract: The European Economic Community's finance ministers and central bank officials will meet in May to prepare the group's position before a summit meeting of the world's major industrial nations, a spokesman for Jacques Delors, the French Economics Minister, said today.

headline: West German General Files Suit on Dismissal
abstract: Gen. G"unter Kiessling turned to a West German civil court today to fight his forced retirement, rejecting Government allegations that he frequented homosexual bars and was therefore a security risk.

headline: 3 DOCTORS REPORT ON AFGHAN WAR
abstract: Three French physicians who have worked among rebels in Afghanistan said in New York yesterday that the Soviet-led campaign against the rebels had begun to concentrate on civilian targets in recent months.    ''Even a mountain village of three or four houses is not safe from their bombs,'' said Dr. Pascal Mathey.   Dr. Mathey, 29 years old, and his colleagues - Dr. Laurence Laumonier, 30, and Dr. Philippe Augoyard, 30, - are in the United States for 10 days to raise funds for Aide Medicale Internationale, a French organization that sends physicians and paramedical personnel into countries where traditional humanitarian organizations cannot operate. At the moment, they said, 10 of the organization's doctors are working in Afghanistan.

headline: Changes at Platt Music
abstract: The Platt Music Corporation, a private company that leases space in department stores and sells consumer electronic products, announced yesterday that it had named Michael Glazer chairman and chief executive and Thomas P. Bagan, 40 years old, president and chief operating officer. Mr. Glazer, who is 35, has been with the company since 1972. He succeeds Herman Platt, 74, son of the founder, who becomes chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Bagan comes from Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago retail chain, where he was president and chief operating officer.

headline: ENSTAR SALE IS PLANNED
abstract: The Enstar Corporation, a Houston- based oil and gas producer facing a fight for control by a dissident stockholder, said yesterday that it was putting the company up for sale.     ''Under the circumstances,'' O. Charles Honig, 65-year-old chairman of the company, remarked, ''we recognize that the company must be sold.''    Enstar's problems began last August, five months after Roy M. Huffington, an independent oil and gas producer, also of Houston, was elected as a director of Enstar. He was Enstar's biggest stockholder, with 8.5 percent of Enstar's common stock, and a partner with Enstar, producing liquefied natural gas in Indonesia for sale in Japan. The bulk of Enstar's $349 million in sales last year, or 43 percent, came from the Indonesian venture, Enstar said.

headline: Homecoming, Of a Sort
abstract: A. R. Nielson, chairman of Canadian Superior Oil Ltd. in Calgary, Alberta, will in a sense be coming home if the Mobil Corporation is successful in taking over Superior Oil: Mr. Nielson spent 27 years with Mobil Canada, the last 10 as president of the subsidiary. He left to join Superior in 1977.

headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Tylenol Maker In Doldrums
abstract: D URING October 1982, in the wake of the Tylenol poison scare, shares of Johnson & Johnson sold as low as 38 3/4. Then, thanks to aggressive moves by the company, the stock made a speedy recovery. By December that same year it had registered a record high of 51 1/4.   But the shares have come under renewed pressure lately, and yesterday they traded at their lowest level since April 1982. On the New York Stock Exchange, Johnson & Johnson eased 3/8 yesterday, to 37 7/8, after selling as low as 37 1/4.

headline: RETALIATION THREATENED BY LEADER OF THE DRUSE
abstract: A Lebanese Druse leader said here today that his forces would retaliate against American diplomats and civilians in Lebanon if United States warships continued their ''indiscriminate'' shelling of Druse villages.    ''We will not allow our people to be killed without taking revenge,'' the Druse leader, Walid Jumblat, said in an interview. ''If they want us to be terrorists, we are ready to be terrorists; if they want us to be extremists, we are ready to be extremists.''   He spoke a few hours after the battleship New Jersey had fired 200 shells from her 16-inch guns toward targets in the mountains overlooking Beirut. The bombardment, American officials said, was consistent with President Reagan's new policy of using naval gunfire and air support against artillery positions firing into Beirut from Syrian-controlled areas.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA PACT IRKS SOME BLACKS
abstract: South Africa's newly signed nonaggression treaty with Mozambique has left some blacks here angry and frustrated that the Government seems ready to talk with black revolutionaries beyond its borders but not with their equivalent figures at home.    Moreover, in random interviews conducted in this huge and crowded black township outside Johannesburg, some residents said they felt betrayed by and disappointed with President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique, regarded by South African blacks as a nationalist idol, for signing the treaty last Friday.   The anger, however, was offset in some cases by a professed sympathy for Mozambique's plight after years of economic decline and attacks by South African-supported insurgents.   The thrust of many comments was that, if the Government was prepared to talk with Mr. Machel, a revolutionary who led nationalist guerrillas in 11 years of war leading to independence from Portugal in 1975, it should also be ready to talk to Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned leader of the African National Congress inside South Africa.

headline: POLAND'S POSTPONEMENT IN RAISING THE PRICE OF FOOD IS NOW OFFICIAL
abstract: The Polish Government has put off food price increases scheduled for the beginning of the year until at least February.    After officials had indicated that the increases would be delayed, the Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said at a news conference today that the increases would not go into effect until the ''results of public consultation'' had been published and further modifications made.   When the Government originally announced the planned price increases in the fall, it published several alternative approaches and invited public reaction. Most of the reaction has been critical, the authorities said.

headline: Belgian Inflation Rate
abstract: Consumer prices in Belgium rose eight- tenths of 1 percent from mid-January to mid-February, bringing the inflation rate for the previous 12 months to 7.7 percent, the Government said today.

headline: Brazil Steel Suspension
abstract: The United States said today that it would suspend two trade agreements involving Brazilian steel because of ''serious deficiencies'' in Brazil's compliance.    Brazil is the fourth-biggest foreign supplier to the American market, shipping 1.25 million tons last year, double its 1982 level.

headline: BONN SOCIALISTS FLIRTING WITH NATO
abstract: West Germany's Social Democratic Party, in a somewhat chastened mood after its unsuccessful campaign against American medium- range missiles, is trying to re-establish its credentials as a supporter of the Atlantic alliance and shows signs of returning to more centrist foreign policy positions.   On a visit to Washington last month, the opposition party's parliamentary leader, Hans-Jochen Vogel, carried the message that the Social Democrats' spurning of the American missiles should not be read as a spurning of North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Mr. Vogel conspicously left behind in Bonn Egon Bahr, the architect of the party's reversal of a policy it forged when Helmut Schmidt was Chancellor.   Mr. Bahr, one of the Social Democrats' most adventuresome thinkers, has gone so far as to propose the removal of all nuclear weapons from countries that do not possess them, including West Germany. ''There are no atomic weapons in Norway or Denmark,'' he argued in an interview. ''Are they subject to blackmail? Where does the security of West Berlin come from? It has no atomic weapons.''

headline: Management
abstract: To the Editor:   In ''Second-Rate Management: A Problem Washington Has Yet to Face'' (Dec. 25), Marta Mooney pours forth a litany of United States management and business school inadequacies: overwhelmed managers, a frustrated breed, bogged down by regulations; staffs rampant with self-interest; unsupportive senior management.     She faults business and management consultants for narrow specializations responsible for noncompetitive management theories inappropriate for the transition to a high-tech service economy. She attributes this situation to an archaic government focus on a capital-labor model which ignores the crucial management factor. Her solution is government-sponsored research and development in management processes, and less reliance by management scholars on imported Japanese management thinking. Her problem statement is overly pessimistic and her solutions inappropriate and impractical.

headline: Turkish Trade Deficit
abstract: Turkey's foreign trade deficit widened to $3.5 billion in 1983, an increase of 13.2 percent from 1982.

headline: LABELS IN LEBANON ARE CHAOTIC, TOO
abstract: The ideological terms that are the common currency of politics in many places do not seem to apply in Lebanon, where the meanings of words such as left and right often dissolve into factional slogans.    The very diversity of the leaders who are scheduled to meet on Monday in Lausanne, Switzerland, for talks on national reconciliation indicates the complications of Lebanese politics. The alliances seem to show that if the conflict cannot be reduced to left versus right, then neither can it be described as Moslem versus Christian.   Feudal leaders call themselves socialist, the word nationalist is invoked by nearly everyone, to different ends, and people accused of being fascists say they are social reformers deeply committed to democracy.

headline: RATES ISSUE: ALL EYES ON FED
abstract: On Tuesday, the Government estimated that the economy is growing at an annual rate of 7.2 percent this quarter, far faster than even the Administration says is healthy or wise. And one day earlier, the banks raised their prime interest rate for the first time since August.  With that, a lot of nervous attention - in the marketplace, in the White House, in Congress, in the treasuries of other countries and the counting rooms of industry - turned to the Federal Reserve Board, with fears rising that the central bank is causing or tolerating a new move toward higher borrowing costs.    With industrial activity now running at more than 80 percent of capacity and the economic expansion showing surprising vigor, the Fed is worried that new inflationary forces are building and need to be checked by a slower pace of business growth.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 19, 1984:  MONDAY Horizon Bancorp Sierra Pac Pwr  TUESDAY CPC Intl Joy Mfg Fedl Paper Board Pueblo Intl Firestone Tire & Rub Upjohn Co Hi-Shear Indus   WEDNESDAY Fairchild Indus Service Corp Intl  THURSDAY Amer Medical Intl Richardson-Vicks Boston Edison Viacom Intl Clevepak Corp   FRIDAY   Fay's Drug Co

headline: Iran Denies Sinkings by Iraq
abstract: Iran denied today that Iraq had destroyed four oil tankers and commercial ships near the Iranian oil installations at Kharg Island Saturday. A Greek Merchant Marine Ministry spokesman in Athens said the captain of a Greek tanker at Kharg Island also reported having seen no attack by Iraqi ships or planes. Iraq said today that it would directly attack the Kharg installations if Iran opened a new offensive in the Persian Gulf war.

headline: TV DINNERS SEEK GOURMET MARKET
abstract: The continuing success of low-calorie and so-called gourmet frozen foods has revived a market whose palate was dulled by traditional TV dinners. And this year promises an even broader range of entries as the nation's leading frozen food marketers fight for a bigger chunk of what is now the industry's fastest-growing and most profitable sector.    The industry calls them ''premium frozen meals.'' And so far, analysts say, the three leaders are the Stouffer Corporation's Lean Cuisine, Swanson Foods' Le Menu and Armour Food's Dinner Classics. Weight Watchers' entrees and the Banquet Foods Corporation's Light and Elegant are a somewhat distant fourth and fifth.

headline: UNION CARBIDE SHOWS A LOSS
abstract: The RCA Corporation, bolstered by strong performances in broadcasting, financial services and transportation, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 45.2 percent on a 17 percent increase in revenues.    RCA, a diversified company that has been placing increasing emphasis on its core businesses of electronics, communications and entertainment, said that net income in the fourth quarter rose to $78.4 million, or 75 cents a share, from $54 million, or 48 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenue increased to a record $2.48 billion, from $2.12 billion.   ''Their earnings were to the penny of what I had expected,'' said George J. Podrasky Jr., analyst at Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. ''I am estimating $3 a share for all of 1984.

headline: DOLLAR EXTENDS ITS RALLY
abstract: The dollar extended its record- breaking rally in major foreign exchange markets yesterday.     Traders cited the potential threat posed to the stability of world oil prices by the recent military coup in Nigeria as well as persistent concern over the course of interest rates in the United States.    They also said there was heavy buying of dollars by foreign investors, who were also believed to have contributed significantly to record stock trading yesterday on Wall Street.

headline: Bond Default Subpoenas
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued 18 subpoenas as part of an investigation into the $2.25 billion bond default of the Washington Public Power Supply System.

headline: Merrill Lynch
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company said it had been granted a state charter to operate a bank and trust company unit in New Jersey. Merrill Lynch said, however, that the subsidiary would not take demand deposits, but would offer other banking services, including trust services. The trust company is to be located at the Merrill Lynch facilities now under construction in Plainsboro Township.

headline: ECONOMY GREW 4.9% IN QUATER
abstract: The United States economy grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the final quarter of 1983, the Commerce Department said today.    The figure, higher than the department's estimate of 4.5 percent a month ago, was welcomed by the Reagan Administration but revived concern on Wall Street that continued high growth could result in economic problems later in the year.    These fears were bolstered by findings in the report that net exports of goods and services fell by $5.1 billion in the final three months and that inflation rose to 4.2 percent from 3.6 percent in the third quarter.   Interest rates rose in response to the report, with investors responding to fears that the Federal Reserve may tighten credit availability in response to the continuing strength in the economy. The stock market, sharing those fears, finished moderately lower in slow trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average off 6.07 points, to 1,148.87. It was the lowest close since April 12, 1983.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: People     *  Benjamin B. West and  William V. Haney appointed corporate senior vice presidents of D'Arcy MacManus Masius Worldwide.

headline: Offer for Logan Of $29 a Share
abstract: Richard J. Schwartz, the chairman of Jonathan Logan Inc., and an investment group yesterday offered 29 a share, or about $205 million, for the large apparel company. Logan's board named a committee of outside directors to consider the proposal, which would take the form of a leveraged buyout.

headline: A New Managing Look At D'Arcy MacManus
abstract: The new look at D'Arcy MacManus Masius Worldwide, as you can tell at a glance, means the disappearance of a hyphen, a comma and an ampersand. But that change, and the simple DMM logotype accompanying it, was not the most exciting announcement yesterday from Hal Bay, chairman and chief executive.

headline: Swiss Socialists Won't Quit Cabinet
abstract: The Swiss Socialists decided today to remain in the four-party coalition that has shared the seven ministries of the federal Cabinet for the last 24 years.   By a vote of 773 to 511, delegates to a special party congress in Bern, the capital, rejected the proposal of the party's leadership to withdraw from the coalition.

headline: LAFFER: SIGNS OF HIS 'CURVE' IN THE RECOVERY
abstract: HE was the wunderkind economist of the Nixon Administration, then the guru behind California's 1978 ''tax revolt.'' But Arthur Laffer won fame, and the devotion of supply-side Reagan campaigners, with a parabolic curve first conceived 10 years ago - the story goes - on a napkin over lunch.     The ''Laffer Curve,'' a simple representation of Mr. Laffer's theory that a cut in the tax rate would eventually increase tax revenues, became the standard for supporters of the Administration's 1981 tax-cut bill. The current recovery, Mr. Laffer now believes, ''is exactly what you would expect to see'' following such a tax cut. ''My view was that it would lose revenues for a certain number of years and then pick up, which it did.''

headline: WHY REAGAN IS A FREE-TRADE VILLAIN
abstract: WHEN the 98th Congress came to Washington last year, many feared it would enact major new trade restrictions. It has n't yet. And faced with a tight election-year timetable, it seems unlikely to do so in 1984 either.    But even as concerns about rising protectionism in Congress have faded, American trade policy has nonetheless become more restrictive. The villain, surprisingly, is the executive branch and the President, whose commitments to free trade have been compromised by the politics and legal tangles of Washington. Unless advocates of relatively open markets can mobilize more effective counter pressure, this trend is likely to accelerate. To understand why, it is useful to look back at what happened - and didn't happen - in 1983.

headline: PRIME RATE SPURS 12.98 DOW DROP
abstract: Stock prices slumped yesterday in the slowest trading this year after most major banks increased their prime lending rate.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the session, managed to trim some of its earlier losses and finished down 12.98 points, to 1,171.38. At 2 P.M., the average was down more than 16 points.    Last week, the widely followed market indicator soared 44.60 points, its best weekly gain in nine months, including an advance of 16.96 points on Friday following news of President Reagan's $150 billion budget-cutting proposal.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Stock or Cash Choice Given on Chase Notes
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday announced a new kind of floating-rate note that may pay interest in the form of common stock or cash, at the investor's option.    Interest on the $300 million of subordinated notes due in 1996 will be paid quarterly at a rate equal to 1/8 percentage point above the average rate for three-month Eurodollar deposits in London.   Interest payments, up to an annual rate of 8 1/2 percent, will be made in shares of Chase Manhattan stock valued at the average of high and low prices on the interest-payment date. Interest above an 8 1/2 percent annual rate will be payable only in cash. The minimum interest rate on the notes is 8 1/2 percent annually.

headline: SENATE CHALLENGES HOUSE ON EXPORT CONTROL BILL
abstract: The Senate has thrown down the gauntlet in front of the House of Representatives over the delegation to the President of the power to control exports.    Last Thursday the Senate passed its version of a new Export Administration Act. But the Senate refused to accept any of the language in the parallel bill that the House passed last October, and instead flung the Senate version back at the House.    Usually when one house of Congress acts on legislation that the other has cleared, the earlier bill is resubmitted with the appropriate changes, and differences are reconciled in conference. The Senate's refusal to follow tradition was another indication of the yawning gap between the two chambers on this legislation.

headline: NEW VATICAN PACT PROPOSED IN ITALY
abstract: After 15 years of negotiations, a draft revision of Italy's 1929 concordat with the Vatican was presented today to the Italian Parliament. Under it, Roman Catholicism would cease to be the state religion.   In a nationally televised address, Prime Minister Bettino Craxi said the proposed revisions would overcome what he called the ''unsuitable and anachronistic'' provisions now governing relations between the Vatican and the Italian state.   He said the Government and the Vatican expected to sign the new accord before Feb. 11, the 55th anniversary of the concordat agreed upon by Mussolini and Pope Pius XI. But ratification by Parliament is to be delayed for six months to give a joint commission time to agree on a disputed provision regulating the tax status of religious institutes and charities.

headline: Ulster Prison Official Shot Dead at His Home
abstract: A senior official at the Maze Prison in Northern Ireland was shot dead outside his Belfast home today by gunmen who used a neighboring house for the ambush. The Irish Republican Army assumed responsibility for the attack.

headline: Nicaragua Reports 40 Rebels Were Killed in Raid on Town
abstract: Nicaragua said today that 40 rebels were killed in an attack on a town during a visit there by Adolfo Perez Esquivel, the Argentine Nobel peace laureate   A Defense Ministry spokesman said the rebels attacked San Fernando, a town six miles from the Honduran border, on Sunday.   Mr. Perez Esquivel, who was in San Fernando at the time, said rebels fired mortars at the town from the Honduran border.

headline: Honeywell-NCR
abstract: Honeywell Inc. and the NCR Corporation said they had signed a joint technology agreement that would permit Honeywell to use an NCR 32-bit microprocessor to develop small- and medium-size computers. The agreement is one of several among the manufacturers of large, mainframe computers that are attempting to enter the small office systems business. NCR is trying to make its 32-bit chip, which can process 32 pieces of information at one time, an industry standard.

headline: Oregon Rules On 2 Plants
abstract: The Oregon Supreme Court ruled today that 11 Oregon cities and public utility districts acted legally in 1976 when they agreed to help finance two nuclear plants in Washington state.

headline: I.B.M. LIFTS COMPUTER CAPABILITY
abstract: In an apparent move to counter the expected entry by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company into the desktop computer market, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would make a popular computer operating system, originally developed by Bell Laboratories, available to users of the I.B.M. Personal Computer.    The system - which controls essential internal operations of a computer - is known as UNIX. It is widely used on much larger computers, primarily by engineers and on university campuses, and can permit several computer users to work on a single machine simultaneously, which is not now possible with the I.B.M. Personal Computer line.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 27, 1984:  MONDAY Allen GroupRio Grande IndusBlair (John) & CoWatkins-JohnsonRepublic Corp   TUESDAY Borg-WarnerRevlon IncPalco EnterprisesSouthwest AirlinesMerck & CoWestvaco Corp  WEDNESDAY Conwood CorpPhilip MorrisDeere & CoReading & BatesGeico CorpTextron Inc  THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr SystFieldcrest MillsBeatrice FoodsFirst Mississippi CorpBrown GroupLucky StoresEngelhard CorpRepublic New York Cp  FRIDAY   Bay State Gas

headline: MARINES IN BEIRUT UNDER FIRE AGAIN
abstract: A section of the United States Marine base here came under heavy rifle fire today, fighting broke out in downtown West Beirut and artillery shells exploded in the streets of East Beirut and in the nearby hills. It was one of the sharpest upsurges of violence in the Lebanese capital in months.   The fighting came as Washington's special Middle East envoy, Donald Rumsfeld, was meeting in Damascus with President Hafez al- Assad and other Syrian officials about ways to overcome obstacles to a plan for the disengagement of the warring factions in Lebanon. Neither Syrian nor American officials would discuss the details of the talks.

headline: PERSONALITY CHANGE FOR P.&.G.
abstract: In the 157 years since its founding, the Procter & Gamble Company has become a legend of marketing tenacity. It has been the envy of its competition with its $1 billion-a-year advertising budget, more than any other corporation, and its dazzling line of consumer products. Thoroughness has been its management motto; caution and extreme secrecy, its style.   Recently, however, the ill winds of business have been swirling steadily around Procter's normally calm headquarters here on the banks of the Ohio. Its competitors, for the first time in years, have mounted successful campaigns against a number of P.& G. products with household names, eroding, for example, the commanding market shares of Tide, Ivory, Cheer and Pampers.    The declines have tarnished its reputation, battered its earnings and beat down the price of its stock.

headline: 11 HINDUS KILLED IN PUNJAB UNREST
abstract: Violence erupted again in the northern state of Punjab today as gunmen identified as Sikh terrorists attacked Hindus.    Reports from the state quoted authorities there as saying that at least 11 more Hindus were killed and 27 wounded today by Sikh militants.  The deaths raised to nearly 50 the number of people killed in clashes among Sikhs, Hindus and the police since a general strike was held last week.  Sikhs have been campaigning for political and religious concessions from the central Government in New Delhi.

headline: I.B.M. TO TRIPLE PC OUTPUT
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that shipments of its Personal Computer line this year would be triple the number produced in 1983. The company also said it planned to spend $500 million in 1984 to expand its production capacity and conduct further research and development on small computers.    The statements, at an meeting for analysts held in Boca Raton, Fla., appeared to confirm industry estimates that shipments of the PC, the PCjr home computer and more advanced desktop models would total more than two million units this year.

headline: Australian Output Up
abstract: Manufacturing production in Australia rose 2.4 percent in 1983, the Australian Bureau of Statistics reported today.

headline: BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHEMFIX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, MARCH 9, 1984   The Economy    Martin S. Feldstein predicted 6 percent growth for the economy in the first quarter, well in excess of the 4 to 5 percent annual rate that most economists expected a month or two ago. But the forecast by the President's chief economist was in line with recent strong results for housing starts, auto sales and industrial production. An Administration prediction at this stage is unusual; normally the Commerce Department's ''flash'' report, which comes out in two weeks, is the first official estimate. (Page A1.)

headline: Shipbuilding Fraud Suit
abstract: The Justice Department has filed a civil suit to recover more than $1.8 million from a former General Dynamics manager and two former Frigitemp Corporation executives.   The three have been indicted for offering or receiving kickbacks and for fraud in the awarding of subcontracts for federally subsidized tankers and Navy subcontracts for Trident nuclear submarines and attack submarines.

headline: ON THE CHILLY THOROUGHFARES OF MOSCOW, WARM WORDS FOR A STERN LEADER
abstract: The light was already fading on a bitterly cold afternoon when word spread that Yuri V. Andropov was dead.   Here and there men and women could be heard discussing the news as they waited for buses in the gusting wind, stood in lines at food counters or huddled over a shared bottle in a warm store corner. But when a reporter sought more direct responses most people hunched into their collars, muttered words of regret and hurried on.   Outside the new K.G.B. building on Dzerzhinsky Street, across the road from the looming bulk of the Lubyanka, the old headquarters, a knot of pedestrians watched as a mobile crane hoisted workmen in thickly padded coats to the sixth story. There they fixed 10-foot steel poles to brackets in the facade of gray marble and hung black bunting atop vast red banners that unfurled earthward across four floors.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS BLOW UP BRIDGE, NATION'S BIGGEST
abstract: Leftist guerrillas destroyed El Salvador's largest bridge today after routing several hundred Government troops assigned to guard it.    ''The loss of this bridge was a serious setback for the economic activities of this country,'' the Defense Ministry said, adding that motorists could still cross the river using a nearby dam.   The quarter-mile long Cuscatlan bridge was the last suspension bridge open to motorists traveling between the eastern and western parts of the country.   Army Base Is Overrun Its destruction was the second major defeat for Government troops in less than 72 hours. Two days ago guerrilla forces overran the country's fourth largest army base, occupying it for 12 hours before withdrawing.

headline: GEMAYEL DECISION ON PACT REPORTED
abstract: President Amin Gemayel has decided to cancel the May 17 Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal accord and will probably meet soon with President Hafez al- Assad of Syria, Government and opposition sources said today.   The sources said Mr. Gemayel's decision to scrap the American-sponsored agreement came after the Christian Phalangist Party led by his father, Pierre, agreed on Monday to support him in such a move.   It also followed a visit to Washington last week by his top foreign policy adviser, Wadia Haddad. It is understood that Reagan Administration officials told Mr. Haddad that the United States was no longer prepared to commit its diplomatic or military weight to protecting the Gemayel Government from Syrian and opposition pressures to cancel the accord.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: United Airlines
abstract: Flight attendants at United Airlines have ratified a proposed contract calling for an 18-month pay freeze and a two-tier wage scale for the next five years, the Association of Flight Attendants announced. The union said the pact, details of which had previously been announced, was approved by a vote of 5,532 to 695. The airline is seeking similar concessions from other unions.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: Previous   Year

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; THE FEAR OF CONCENTRATION IS JUSTIFIED
abstract: IF Congress does nothing to stop the   multibillion-dollar mergers  sweeping through the oil industry, free enterprise competition will be further reduced, more economic and political power will be concentrated in fewer hands, and consumers will end up paying a monopoly tax on every gallon of gasoline and heating oil they buy.  A week ago Mobil declared that it was buying Superior Oil for $5.7 billion. This announcement followed closely on the heels of Standard Oil of California's decision to merge with Gulf Oil, Texaco's takeover of Getty Oil and Royal Dutch/Shell's buyout of the remaining 30 percent stake in Shell Oil.   When President Carter decided to decontrol oil prices, it was with the understanding that the additional billions of dollars consumers would be forced to pay in higher gasoline and heating oil prices would be used by the oil industry to explore for more oil and gas in the United States.

headline: Nigeria City Summons Army To Quell Renewal of Rioting
abstract: The Nigerian Army was called in today to quell pockets of resistance from fundamentalist Moslem rioters in the northeastern city of Yola, where 137 people have died in violence this week, a senior police official said.   The police spokesman, David Isang, said the army moved in after the police could not cope with a renewed attack from rioters who had regrouped and were using ''sophisticated weapons'' to defend their enclave.

headline: MOVING SMOKERS TO SNUFF
abstract: T HE only segment of the tobacco    business that is growing is the   moist smokeless tobacco category. Snuff to you.   And that category is all but owned by the U.S. Tobacco Company, Greenwich, Conn., which last year came up with a new version of a revolutionary product that is being used to convert the urban, white-collar cigarette smoker to being a snuff user.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, JANUARY 7, 1984
abstract: Companies    Texaco offered $10 billion for Getty Oil, which approved the deal. If the offer, which values Getty Oil shares at $125 each, is completed, it would be the biggest merger ever. Just two days earlier, Getty Oil approved a complex takeover proposal from Pennzoil and Gordon P. Getty that valued the shares at about $112.50. But Mr. Getty, who controls 40.2 percent of the company's stock, joined the rest of the board in voting for the Texaco offer. Pennzoil said it would sue, and the plan must still clear an antitrust review. (Page 1.) Through its daring merger offer, usually conservative Texaco is seeking to double its rapidly declining reserves at a stroke. (29.)    A.T.&T. said it could cut long-distance rates by more than the 10.5 percent it proposed last fall if a plan to charge monthly ''access'' fees is approved. The company did not specify how much the rates could be cut. It explained that the reductions would be possible because it had overestimated costs by about 5 percent. (29.)

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Filling of Post Aids Flexi-Van Control    At the age of 31, Raymond F. Henze 3d ranks among the youngest executives running the day-to-day operations of a major United States corporation. And his appointment as president and chief operating officer of the Flexi-Van Corporation, while reflecting confidence in a youthful manager, also buttresses the control of David H. Murdock over the New York-based transportation leasing company.   Mr. Murdock, a multimillionaire California financier, is Flexi-Van's largest shareholder through the Pacific Holding Corporation, an investment company he owns. Mr. Henze, an associate of Mr. Murdock since 1979, is a vice president of Pacific Holding and was named to the additional position of executive vice president of Flexi-Van last May.

headline: MCDONNELL TO BUY TYMSHARE
abstract: After backing away from a preliminary agreement two months ago to purchase Tymshare Inc. for $378 million, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a definitive agreement to buy the California-based data transmission company for $307.5 million.     McDonnell Douglas, one of the nation's leading aircraft manufacturers, already has major interests in the computer industry through subsidiaries that provide data processing services and make business computers.    With Tymshare, it would add a vast data communications network that now links 400 cities in 42 countries.

headline: AN AD MAN'S DISTINCT STYLE
abstract: Josef Sedelmaier is probably the hottest producer in the business of television commercials now - and one who has won an unusual amount of control over the ads he handles.     At $7,500 a day he also directs and photographs them himself, and only takes jobs on which he can have a free hand both with the shooting script, that the advertising agency produces, and with the editing process.    Mr. Sedelmaier, began his commercial film-making career with a series of ads for Chun King Chinese foods and went on to spots considered distinctive and often hilarious for Aamco transmissions, Dunkin' Donuts, Federal Express and Kaypro computers among others. He is now shooting the sequel to his highly successful ''Where's the beef?'' ad for Wendy's International.   The new Wendy's ad, scheduled for $11 million worth of air time starting later this week, once again features Clara Peller, the tiny elderly woman who is not impressed with the ''big fluffy bun'' that Wendy's competitors serve and keeps demanding ''Where's the beef?''

headline: FRANCE SEEKS RAIL GAINS
abstract: France asked its Common Market partners today for a 20-year multinational effort to improve railroad service, creating a continent crisscrossed by high-speed trains like the 170-mile- an-hour Paris-Lyon link.

headline: SOVIET ARMS: MORE QUALITY, NOT QUANTITY
abstract: MilitaryAnalysis     Military analysts in Washington and other NATO capitals say that as the Soviet Union moves into the manufacture of more technologically advanced warplanes and naval vessels, production costs are increasing and delivery times slowing.  The new cruiser Slava is one example, the analysts said. The Kommuna shipyard at Nikolayev on the Black Sea needed six years to build the Slava compared with four years for each of the seven cruisers of the Kara class.   The Slava may be intended to counter United States aircraft carrier battle groups. Her main armament is 16 SS-N-12 surface-to-surface missiles with a range of more than 300 miles. But the Slava, like most of the Soviet battle fleet, lacks support ships to keep her operational in distant oceans.

headline: CARIBBEAN INITIATIVE ATTRACTS INVESTMENT
abstract: A number of companies are beginning to rise to the Administration's Caribbean-investment lure.    Makers of electric motors, sporting equipment, pocketbooks, bedroom slippers, food products and even computers are setting up or expanding production in the area. They are acting to take advantage of duty-free access to the United States market for 12 years, an investment incentive provided by the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act of 1983.    That law, passed last July after 17 months of wrangling in Congress, is more familiarly known as President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative, a program of trade, economic and tax measures to help 27 Caribbean countries expand employment and raise living standards.    A Help for Tourism    While duty-free access is the centerpiece of the program, another provision, intended to help tourism, allows tax deductions for the cost of attending business conventions in eligible countries. One result of that provision is an expansion planned by Holiday Inns in Jamaica.

headline: ARRESTS OF NIGERIANS REPORTED
abstract: The new military Government was reported today to have arrested relatives of three leading figures in the deposed civilian administration.   The three figures, who are listed as ''most wanted,'' are Umaru Dikko, former Transportation Minister; Adisa Akinloye, former chairman of the National Party of Nigeria, and Richard Akinjide, former Justice Minister.

headline: ANXIETY STRIKES A STEEL TOWN
abstract: Larry Couch, the third generation of his family to work at the Republic Steel Corporation's mill here, says he has felt lost since Wednesday, when he learned that the mill must be sold as a condition for Republic to merge with the LTV Corporation.    On the way to his job as an overhead crane operator, Mr. Couch, a strapping, bearded man who has worked at the mill for half of his 40 years, said: ''It could work out good. It could work out bad. We just don't know.''

headline: VOLCKER'S OUTLOOK ON RATES
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that Congress and the Reagan Administration could not look to the Fed to block a rise in interest rates this year.   ''What happens to interest rates is going to be determined in large part by what happens in the economy,'' Mr. Volcker told the Senate Banking Committee in the second of three appearances he is making on Capitol Hill. Tuesday he visited the House.   Today, for the first time, Mr. Volcker detailed the size of reductions in Federal budget deficits that the Federal Reserve would consider acceptable to relax the threat he said they pose for interest rates, inflation and the growth of the economy.    The annual deficits, currently running about $200 billion, should be reduced by $30 billion to $50 billion next year, by $75 billion in the fiscal year 1986 and by $150 billion by the end of the decade, Mr. Volcker said.

headline: Greek Officers Assigned To U.S. Military Bases
abstract: Greek military officers were assigned today to each of the four American bases in Greece, as agreed to under terms of a United States-Greek military and economic cooperation agreement that was signed in Athens last September.   A United States Embassy spokesman said that under the terms of the agreement, the Greek officers had access to all areas of the bases except those dealing with cryptography, or classified communications.   Talks are also due to start this week between the two sides on the legal status of the American forces in Greece and on the two relay stations operated here by the Voice of America.

headline: REAGAN REPORTED IN DARK ON TALKS
abstract: Robert C. McFarlane, the White House national security adviser, said today that neither he nor President Reagan had been aware of contacts between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization carried out through an intermediary from August 1981 to May 1982.   Alexander M. Haig Jr., who was Secretary of State during that period, said he had ''probably mentioned'' the matter to Mr. Reagan.   Mr. Haig said that because of the sensitivity of the discussions, which were carried out by John Edwin Mroz, a specialist on Middle Eastern and Soviet affairs who now heads a New York foundation, he did not send a memorandum on the matter to the White House, which would have been the usual procedure. Mr. Haig said he felt that such a memo would be disclosed, embarrassing the Administration.   Some officials said the fact that the White House staff was largely kept in the dark by Mr. Haig on a matter of such potential sensitivity as contacts with the P.L.O. was a reminder of the bitterness that marked relations between Mr. Haig and the White House staff. Since leaving office, Mr. Haig has asserted that senior White House staff members repeatedly tried to undermine him.

headline: Southeast Options
abstract: The Southeast Banking Corporatiion said it had exercised its options to buy about 4.5 million shares of its common from two shareholder groups headed by Jack Burstein, Robert Marlin and Samuel Adler, and by M. Lee Pearce and the Pan American Hospital Corporation. Southeast said that it completed the purchase of about 3.6 million shares today for about $105.3 million and that closings on the remaining shares will take place during the next few months. Southeast, which has about 18.8 million shares outstanding, closed today at $22.625, up 12 1/2 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: BIG BOARD ASKS START ON OPTIONS
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange, in another sign of its increasing aggressiveness, is seeking Government permission to start trading options on individual stocks.   Specifically, the Big Board is interested in trading options on the stocks of the seven regional telephone companies that were spun off Jan. 1 from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Ivers Riley, the exchange's vice president for options and index products, said yesterday in a telephone interview.    Request Opposed by Some    The New York Stock Exchange's request is now before the Securities and Exchange Commission. The request has been opposed by some because it would mean new products for the already dominant exchange and the stocks of the regional phone companies are listed on the exchange. The commission has never permitted an exchange to handle a stock and options on the same stock, largely for fear of price manipulation.

headline: GREECE DROPS PROTEST ON TURKISH SHELLING
abstract: A crisis between two members of the Atlantic alliance suddenly receded today after Greece announced that it had concluded that Turkish warships had not intentionally fired on a Greek destroyer in the Aegean Sea.   The Government here said that as a result of ''clarifications'' by Turkey, it had canceled the recall of its Ambassador in Ankara and would soon call off a military alert imposed Thursday, after it said shells fired by Turkish warships fell near the Greek destroyer Panther and several Greek fishing vessels.  Only a few hours before the crisis receded, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou described the incident as ''the worst provocation against Greece since the 1974 Turkish invasion of Cyprus.'' He had called on NATO to stop tolerating Turkish aggressiveness.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Chicgo Board Planning Municipals Contract    The Chicago Board of Trade expects to announce today a proposal for a new municipal bond futures contract. A spokesman for the board said an application for the new contract would be submitted to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission today, and that details of the contract would be disclosed at a news conference in New York.

headline: U.S. OFFICIALS URGE MORE AID TO HELP THE SUDAN
abstract: Reagan Administration officials urged Congress today to continue the flow of economic and military aid to the Sudan, warning that the Government there faced serious economic problems and military threats from neighboring Libya and Ethiopia.   ''The situation, on both counts, is indeed grim,'' James K. Bishop, an Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, told the Africa subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.   He cited the Sudan's rising debts and the March 16 air attack on the Sudanese city of Omdurman, which Sudanese and American officials have charged was carried out by a Libyan plane. Libya has denied the charge. Mr. Bishop said the Administration was reviewing the Sudan's need for aid in addition to the surveillance planes the United States has sent to the region.

headline: INTERNATIONAL TERRORISTS LINKED TO FRENCH BOMBINGS
abstract: A French Government spokesman said today that the international terrorist known as Carlos had sent a letter taking responsibility for two fatal New Year's Eve bombings in the south of France.    The Interior Ministry official said the letter, received Thursday at the West Berlin office of Agence France- Presse, was signed by the Arab Armed Struggle Organization. But he said West German specialists had concluded that the handwriting was that of Carlos, a Venezuelan whose real name is Illich Ramirez Sanchez.   The news agency said intelligence agencies already had samples of Carlos's handwriting, identified through fingerprints. The agency also said it had learned through Government sources that Carlos is in East Berlin.

headline: TOPS ON JOB LIST: COMPUTER FIXER
abstract: THE man's personal computer quit working and he called for help. Within minutes a repairman arrived, tools in hand, and examined the lifeless machine.    The diagnosis: a cherry gumdrop clogging the works.   ''We've seen it all,'' said Earle F. Humphreys, president of Computer Doctor Inc., the computer-maintenance outfit that made the house call. And while some malfunctions don't involve any more technical know-how than this one, today's computer repairman finds his diagnostic skills more in demand than ever.

headline: U.S. SEEKS WAYS TO BOLSTER AIR DEFENSE
abstract: Military   Analysis      The Air Force is studying means of reinforcing the North American air defense system as a result of intelligence reports that the Soviet Union has developed at least four new long-range cruise missile systems.  Pentagon sources said that behind the study was the question whether the existing defenses were adequate to meet this challenge. The joint United States-Canadian organization for air defense, the sources pointed out, was established to counter Soviet bombers armed with either conventional or nuclear bombs.   Intelligence analysts said they presumed that the cruise missile development was the first and probably the most important move by the Soviet Union to counter the deployment of new American medium-range missiles in Europe.

headline: The U.N. Today; Feb. 9, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   The Commission on Trade Law, working group on the new international economic order - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Organizational session for 1984 - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: 9 Countries to Confer In Ottawa on Acid Rain
abstract: Environment ministers from eight West European countries will come to Ottawa next month to discuss the growing menace of acid rain.   The conference, scheduled for March 20-21, was arranged by Environment Minister Charles Caccia of Canada and a spokesman for Mr. Caccia said today that one of his chief aims was to maintain pressure on the United States to reverse its stand over the problem.

headline: Trade Deficit Record in '83
abstract: The United States posted a record $60.6 billion foreign trade deficit for 1983, the Commerce Department said today.    The latest figures on merchandise trade paralleled a report released 11 days ago by the department that put the country's trade deficit at $69.4 billion, including military trade and the cost of shipping and insurance.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: New York City to Sell $250 Million in Bonds    New York City officials announced plans yesterday to sell $250 million of general obligation bonds in the week of Feb. 27.    The sale, which is to be negotiated with underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, will raise to $525 million the amount of bonds the city has sold this fiscal year.

headline: Apple Pirates Sentenced TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 25 (UPI) - The owners of six local companies were sentenced to eight months in prison for illegally reproducing computer software designs developed by Apple Computer Inc. of the United States, a court source said. The source, who declined to be identified, said the defendants were the first convicted in Taiwan of pirating Apple computer software.
abstract: Taiwan's current copyright law safeguards the legal rights of publications, but does not specifically cover computer software programs.

headline: B.P. Offers to Sell Back Its Holdings in AMAX
abstract: The British Petroleum Company has offered to sell to AMAX Inc. the 4.3 million common shares of AMAX it owns, the American metals concern announced yesterday. B.P. is required to dispose of its stake under a September 1981 consent decree with the Federal Trade Commission.
