The offer by British Petroleum to AMAX was made under a 1980 agreement between the two companies that requires B.P. to offer the shares to AMAX before selling them to a third party. Under that agreement, AMAX has 60 days to respond to the offer. An AMAX spokesman said the company's board would study the proposal.

headline: Victor Gets Loan
abstract: Victor Technologies Inc., which last month filed for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, has won court approval to borrow up to $4.2 million to keep operating through the end of March. The money would come from Security Pacific National Bank, which is Victor's largest secured creditor and which has financed the company's manufacturing and distribution since bankruptcy proceedings began last month. Victor's board is scheduled to consider a proposal Thursday from a British microcomputer company, Applied Computer Techniques, to buy some of the assets of Victor.

headline: Computervision Financial Data
abstract: The Computervision Corporation said its auditors had qualified their opinions on the company's financial statements for 1981 through 1983 in light of the large damages sought by the Perkin-Elmer Corporation in a pending suit. The litigation stems from a suit filed in 1977 by Perkin-Elmer against Computervision's former Cobilt division that charged patent infringement.

headline: U.S. Reports It Erred On U.N. Voting Figure
abstract: The United States Mission to the United Nations said today that figures it presented indicating severe American isolation at the world body in the Carter Administration were incorrect.   At a news conference at the mission Tuesday, the American delegate, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, said that in 1977, the United States voted with the majority only 14.4 percent of the time.

headline: U.S. ASKS DATA ON TEXACO BID
abstract: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission had requested additional information in its inquiry into Texaco's proposed $10.1 billion acquisition of the Getty Oil Company.    In Washington, the commission confirmed the request for more data in its study of the antitrust implications.

headline: THE HUNT FOR AN AFFORDABLE MORTGAGE
abstract: YOU are young and struggling to make ends meet, but you'd like to buy a home. If you are like most young people you probably can't qualify for a loan - particularly in New York City, where real estate prices have put home ownership out of reach for most first-time buyers.   So what advice can financial experts offer recent graduates or newlyweds who want to sink their small nest eggs into a first house, cooperative or condominium apartment?    While the age of the bargain mortgage is over, they say, there are still ways to better one's chances of qualifying for a home loan - primarily by making the monthly mortgage payment more affordable. But although imaginative financing may lighten the load for a while, such deals in the long run can cost as much or even more than traditional packages.

headline: TEXT OF DEATH ANNOUNCEMENT
abstract: Following is the text of the official announcement today of the death of Yuri V. Andropov, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:      The Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, the Presidium of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet and the U.S.S.R. Council of Ministers with deep sorrow inform the party and the entire Soviet people that Yuri Vladimirovich Andropov, General Secretary of the C.P.S.U. Central Committee, President of the Presidium of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, died after a long illness at 16 hours 50 minutes on Feb. 9, 1984.    The name of Yuri Vladimirovich Andropov, an outstanding leader of the Communist Party and of the Soviet state, a staunch fighter for the ideals of Commmunism and for peace, will always remain in the hearts of the Soviet people, of the whole progressive humanity.

headline: Advertising
abstract: Tracking Of New Products    I N the volatile arena of food and   drug marketing, the dramatic   pace of new product introductions in the first eight months of last year slowed considerably in the final four and almost came to a halt in January. Early last year, the gains were running at 26 percent, but this faded to a gain of only 4 percent last month.    These figures are from Martin J. Friedman, the acknowledged expert in the field, but he brightened yesterday when he reported that even on its first day, February is looking up.    Mr. Friedman was being interviewed on the executive floor at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, amid the Art Deco glories of the Chrysler Building. Later he would attend the first of two ''New Idea Genesis'' meetings at the agency where he stood out from his fellows in both age (older) and complexion (tanner).

headline: Suriname's Premier And Cabinet Resign
abstract: Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, Suriname's left-wing ruler, announced tonight that Prime Minister Errol Alibux and his Cabinet had resigned and a new Government would be formed immediately.   The announcement, made in a television address, came only two days after the military Government rolled back a series of tax increases in an effort to stop mounting labor unrest.

headline: BOND PRICES TUMBLE ON RATE FEARS
abstract: Bond prices fell sharply yesterday and long-term yields rose to their highest levels since September 1982 following a new warning by the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, that pressure was mounting to raise interest rates.     In a speech yesterday to the United States League of Savings Institutions, Mr. Volcker repeated many of the points he has made before Congressional committees in recent weeks.    The Fed chairman termed the economy ''very strong,'' reiterated past warnings that strong growth plus huge budget deficits ''puts pressure on rates'' and cautioned that foreign investors could not be expected to continue heavy buying of United States Treasury securities.    View of Economy Spurs Selling    But while the thrust of Mr. Volcker's statements was familiar, analysts said, his portrayal of the economy as ''very strong'' apparently unsettled many securities dealers and speculators, touching off a wave of selling in bond markets.

headline: Venezuela Interest Rates
abstract: The Venezuelan central bank has decided to establish a selective system of interest rates intended to stimulate the agriculture and housing industries, an official communique said.

headline: General Cinema Convertible Bonds A $78.16 million issue of General Cinema Corporation 10 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2009 is offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc.
abstract: The debentures may be exchanged into shares of R. J. Reynolds Industries common stock at a rate of $75 per share.

headline: BANKS SAY ARCO CREDIT IS READY
abstract: Arrangements for a $12 billion credit for the Atlantic Richfield Company were completed yesterday and banks are scheduled to sign the agreement on Monday, according to banking sources in New York and other cities. It would be the largest commercial loan ever made, and the proceeds would be used by Arco in its expected bid to acquire the Gulf Oil Corporation.   Bankers also said yesterday that other oil companies were expected to arrange similar credits to make competitive bids for Gulf. The Standard Oil Company of California is on top of most analysts' lists as another bidder, and the Mesa Petroleum Company is leading a group that seeks to expand its minority holding in Gulf.

headline: SHIPBUILDERS TAKE A NEW TACK IN RACE
abstract: Too many merchant ships are chasing too little cargo in the world, American shipbuilders say. And yet, the nation's shipbuilding industry is trying everything from robots to lasers to build them even faster.    It seems to be a paradox. But the shipbuilders say that if they can produce the vessels faster, they can reduce their labor costs - one of the central reasons American shipbuilders cannot compete with their counterparts abroad. By reducing the cost of labor, they may be able to preserve an industry that some of them say is in its worst state since the Great Depression.   Only two commercial ships were ordered built in the nation's 26 major shipyards last year, compared with 43 vessels 10 years ago, according to the Shipbuilders Council of America, a trade group. Although the number of ships contracted by the Navy increased from 7 in 1973 to 27 last year, the shipbuilders say they have not filled the gap left by the loss of nonmilitary shipbuilding.

headline: B.P. Abandons Well Off China LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP) - The British Petroleum Company said it had abandoned its first exploration well off China after encountering only limited signs of crude oil.
abstract: B.P. is operator for a group of companies that signed the first exploration contracts with the Chinese Government under competitive bidding that began in 1982.

headline: LAST-MINUTE PROCEDURES THAT CAN CUT TAX BILL
abstract: For many people, the urge to search for tax-saving strategies begins to stir only when the tax-filing season is actually upon them. Then, when they sit down with sharpened pencil and calculator and compute their income tax obligation, they belatedly discover a desperate need to scrounge for angles.     The tax-cutting angles available at this late date are, of course, limited. After all, the tax return covers income and expenses for the year that ended Dec. 31, and any significant tax-saving measures should have been executed before then.    But the tax law does provide time for a few transactions and a multitude of decisions that can save an individual hundreds and sometimes thousands of dollars in taxes.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; REFLECTIONS OF A DEPARTING COMMISSIONER
abstract: DRIVING to the Securities and Exchange Commission's offices each day, down Pennsylvania Avenue, one is repeatedly reminded by the granite-etched words in front of the National Archives building, ''what is past is prologue'' and instructed to ''study the past.'' Despite the turnover among S.E.C. commissioners of late (four of us have left our posts in the last 18 months) and the periodic change of leadership in the White House, this aphorism seems still to apply to the regulatory agency whose charge it is to protect the American shareholder.  The Deregulation Myth.  Viewed in the context of its 50 years of existence, the Securities and Exchange Commission, under the chairmanship of John S. R. Shad, has not changed the essential thrust of its policies. Despite some accounts to the contrary, the agency has not been a ''knee- jerk'' deregulator. Of more than 60 major actions taken since June 1981, only 31 involved the removal or lessening of government restrictions, 23 involved the creation of such restrictions, and seven were neutral.  It is impossible to square this record with deregulation as a distinct and paramount goal. This commission's goal, rather, was investor protection. In pursuing that goal, the commission favored the less-restrictive regulatory solution, or the nonregulatory solution. We had a pro- competitive bent. But when competition would not suffice, we were not hesitant to regulate by writing rules to enhance investor protection.

headline: ISRAELI JETS STRIKE LEBANON IN 2D STRAIGHT DAY OF RAIDS
abstract: Israeli war planes today bombed targets of the militant Shiite Moslem organization in the Bekkaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, in the second Israeli air attack in Lebanon in two days, according to Beirut state radio.    As many 16 aircraft struck at about 8 A.M. at three areas near the ancient city of Baalbek, which serves as a base for the Shiite group known as Islamic Amal and a group of about 350 Iranian guards.    An Israeli spokesman in Tel Aviv confirmed that an air strike was conducted near Baalbek this morning, but did not give further details.  The Israelis maintain that the Islamic Amal and the Iranian guards are responsible for much of the terrorism that has been directed at the Israeli troops in southern Lebanon in recent weeks.

headline: ARAFAT MAY MEET WITH KING HUSSEIN
abstract: A close associate of Yasir Arafat said today that the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization would soon meet with King Hussein of Jordan to discuss ways of realizing what he called their ''agreed target.'' The official said the objective was a confederation of Jordan and a sovereign Palestinian state.   Khaled al-Hassan, a member of the central committee of Al Fatah who is known for his closeness to Mr. Arafat - the head of both the P.L.O. and Al Fatah, the largest of its components - said the meeting with the King might take place before the Islamic conference that is scheduled to open in Casablanca, Morocco, Feb. 12. He said he met with King Hussein in Paris some weeks ago to discuss plans for the meeting.

headline: McKinney, Silver Wins Fannie Mae Account
abstract: In competition with about 15 agencies, including some of the biggest, McKinney, Silver & Rockett of Raleigh, N.C., has won the Federal National Mortgage Association account, which bills more than $5 million.

headline: Pole Said to Confess Role in Youth's Death
abstract: The official Polish press agency P.A.P. says an ambulance attendant has admitted striking a young Solidarity supporter who died after being detained by the police.

headline: ROCHESTER GAS & ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOME U.S. AND SOVIET MISSILES JUDGED EQUAL
abstract: A Defense Department report to Congress asserts that the United States and the Soviet Union are now equal in the technological advancement of medium-range ballistic missiles.   The report, issued Tuesday by the Pentagon's research and development chief, Richard D. DeLauer, also said United States technology had surpassed that of the Russians in missile- carrying submarines and in conventional warheads, including chemical explosives.   The comparisons of the levels of technological advancement are made annually in a chart listing various weapons, from intercontinental ballistic missiles to early warning systems.

headline: BUSINESS AND THE FAMILY; WHEN VIOLENCE AT HOME AFFECTS WORK
abstract: WHEN a woman reported for work with facial cuts and bruises for the third time, her supervisors grew concerned. Checking records at the Minnesota company's health maintenance organization, they learned that the woman's teen-age daughter had recently been raped and that her two preschool children had also received emergency room treatment twice within the past six months. The woman steadfastly refused to discuss what had happened to her, but her work was suffering and it was apparent to supervisors and co- workers that there were serious problems within her family, probably from an abusive husband.

headline: FOR THE MARINES, FIRST FLOWERS AND NOW SANDBAGS
abstract: In its 16 months in Lebanon, the United States Marine force went from one that was welcomed by women throwing flowers and that patrolled with unloaded rifles to one that came under frequent and often heavy attack. In the end, the marines were virtually unable to move beyond their sandbagged bunkers at Beirut International Airport.   They were sent to Lebanon with the mission of bringing a measure of stability to a chaotic situation and to give Lebanon's warring factions time to resolve their differences. But, increasingly, they were seen by the Moslem factions as allies of the Government of President Amin Gemayel and his Christian Phalangist Party.   By yesterday, when President Reagan announced that the Marines were being pulled out of the airport and redeployed on Navy ships off Lebanon, 259 marines had been killed in Lebanon.

headline: Banker Out In Venezuela
abstract: President Jaime Lusinchi removed the president of the nation's central bank, Leopoldo Diaz Bruzual, on Monday night, saying that Mr. Diaz had been a ''disturbing'' factor in the development of the Government's economic policies.  Benito Raul Losada, a former president of the central bank, was named to replace Mr. Diaz.  Advisers to Mr. Lusinchi said it was necessary to remove Mr. Diaz to assure foreign bankers that the new Government was intent on serious talks concerning its foreign debt, which totals an estimated $34 billion.

headline: A MOSCOW NEW YEAR: CHAMPAGNE AND ILL-GOTTEN FIRS
abstract: At the stroke of midnight from the chimes of the Kremlin's Spassky Tower, fresh sentries took their places at Lenin's mausoleum and bedlam broke out on Red Square.   Hundreds of Russians popped champagne corks high into the air, set off firecrackers and sparklers and burst into boozy hugging and dancing. It was a curious sight on the vast square, which is usually given to respectful visits by Russians and foreigners, set-piece parades and hushed queues at the mausoleum.   But then New Year's is a curious holiday on the Soviet calendar - a hybrid of the prerevolutionary Christmas and the Western New Year, a family rather than a state occasion, a national holiday with almost no ideological baggage.

headline: Stocks Fall for 3d Day in Row
abstract: Stock prices declined yesterday for the third consecutive session. Trading slowed as some of the recent hectic participation by institutional accounts slackened.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the session, slipped 1.16 points, to 1,277.32. Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that rose by 836 to 789. Few issues moved a point or more.

headline: RIGHTS GROUP SAYS ABUSES IN GUATEMALA RISE
abstract: Human rights abuses in Guatemala have become ''particularly intractable,'' according to a report issued last week by a New York-based organization.   The group, Americas Watch, concluded in a 260-page report that killings and disappearances of civilians in the cities had increased in the five months since Gen.  Oscar Mejia Victores took power in a coup that ousted Gen. Efrain Rios Montt.   The report, the result of a seven- month investigation, added that the Reagan Administration ''shares in the responsibility for the gross abuses of human rights'' by failing to publicly denounce them.

headline: WARSAW CARDINAL TRANSFERS A MILITANT PRIEST
abstract: Roman Catholic Church sources said today that Jozef Cardinal Glemp, under pressure from the authorities, had begun to transfer activist pro-Solidarity priests from their parishes.    The move has come amid Government concern over politically charged lectures given by intellectuals in churches.   One priest, the Rev. Mieczyslaw Nowak of the Church of St. Joseph the Worker, whose parish includes the Ursus tractor factory, once a Solidarity stronghold, received a letter from the Cardinal on Tuesday ordering him to take over the parish of Leki Koscielne. This covers some 4,000 people scattered in 20 villages.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Alaska Housing Finance Corp.  is offering $100 million of 10-year Eurobonds maturing Feb.15, 1994, with an 11 3/4 percent coupon, through Salomon Brothers International.     *  Cannon Group filed an offering of $25 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2009, through E. F. Hutton.      Common Stock     *  Anixter Bros., Chicago, withdrew its proposed offering of 2 million shares because it was unwilling to sell the stock at yesterday's market price of 20 7/8, down 3/4.

headline: FABERGE APPROVES LEVERAGED BUYOUT
abstract: Faberge Inc. said yesterday that its board in a letter of intent had approved a leveraged buyout of the company for $30 a share, or a total of $168.6 million. The members of the investment group organized by Gibbons Green Van Amerongen Inc., a private New York investment banking firm, have not been announced.    The announcement, analysts said, was a setback for Shamrock Holdings Inc., a personal holding company of the Roy Disney family. Shamrock had announced its intention to increase its 13.84 percent holding in the fragrance and toiletries company to more than 15 percent and to seek a seat on the board. Roy Disney is the nephew of the late Walt Disney.

headline: GROMYKO AND SHULTZ CUT TENSION, REAGAN SAYS, BUT DID NOT AGREE
abstract: President Reagan said Friday that the meeting this week between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union ''did not resolve our differences,'' but that it had helped in reducing world tensions.     In a statement after meeting with Shultz for 40 minutes at the White House, Mr. Reagan said that the Secretary of State and his Soviet counterpart ''had a full and serious exchange of views on key global questions'' in Stockholm.   The President also said that the United States and its Western allies would soon propose a long-awaited package of ''practical and concrete measures'' in Stockholm ''to reduce the risk of surprise attack, or war by accident or misunderstanding.''

headline: Medical Buildings
abstract: American Medical Buildings Inc. said its board had approved an agreement in principle to be acquired.

headline: RAIL TRIP FOR GREY POUPON
abstract: -class-    moocher commercials for Grey   Poupon Dijon mustard, you know how important the ambiance of elegance is to their success. And they have been eminently successful.    After the first spot was completed with its handoff of product between identical Rolls-Royce chauffeur- driven limousines, the gang around the Marschalk agency kept asking Stephen J. Kaplan, the art director, and Laurence J. Elegant, the writer, how they were going to top it.    They did it, quite simply, by accomplishing the same kind of handoff with two similar yachts running very close and side by side. The resulting 30-second commercial has words and actions almost identical to the original highly successful Rolls entry, except for the addition of a romantic interest or at least a person of the opposite sex.

headline: European Prices Rise
abstract: The European Economic Community's September retail price index rose 1.9 percent during the month and was up 4.6 percent from September 1982, its statistics office said today.

headline: PURCHASING AGENTS CITE NEW GAINS
abstract: The economy expanded in December for the 12th consecutive month, corporate purchasing agents said yesterday, with the group's composite index rising to its highest level in more than 10 years.    The purchasers' monthly index rose to 67.2 percent, up sharply from 62.9 percent in November and its highest since November 1973. Increases in employment, production and new orders all contributed to the advance.

headline: Gourmet to TBWA
abstract: Gourmet magazine, a Conde Nast publication, has named TBWA Advertising as its agency of record. This is the first time in its 43-year history that the magazine has had an agency. The other two agencies competing for the account were Calet, Hirsch & Spector, and Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss.

headline: OVERSEEING INSURANCE REFORM AT LONDON'S VENERABLE MART
abstract: -generation Lloyd's of London broker who took over as chairman of the famous insurance exchange last week, fretted a bit when invited to pose for a photograph with lanky Ian Hay Davison, Lloyd's chief executive.    ''Just don't make any comments about the long and the short of it,'' he said, managing only half a smile.   Clearly, it is not the substantial height difference itself that concerns Mr. Miller. He has good reason to be wary of scenes that suggest - even subliminally - stark differences between the two, or that Mr. Davison has greater stature at Lloyd's.   Mr. Davison's job of chief executive was created a year ago at the insistence of the British Government, which wanted an outsider brought in to help Lloyd's recover from several scandals that have rocked the three- centuries-old exchange in recent years, and to oversee reforms. The senior partner at the British branch of Arthur Andersen & Company and probably the nation's best-known accountant, the 53-year-old Mr. Davison was recruited to the new, $180,000- a-year-job by Sir Peter Green, then the exchange's chairman.

headline: French Plan On Job Cuts
abstract: The French Government today tentatively approved a national industrial renewal plan that would eliminate up to 60,000 jobs in coming years.

headline: People
abstract: *  Stephen A. Novick named an executive vice president of Grey Advertising.     *  James Cobb appointed executive vice president of administration and finance for the Earl Palmer Brown Companies in Bethesda, Md.

headline: Diplomats Report Iraqi Deal With Kurds
abstract: President Saddam Hussein has signed an agreement with a Kurdish rebel leader, Jalal Talabani, for a cease-fire in the Kurdish region of Iraq and broader autonomy for the 2.5 million Kurds in the area, diplomats said today.   They said the agreement, signed last month, envisaged ''free and democratic elections'' to legislative and executive councils for the autonomous region in northern Iraq.

headline: Reagan Schedules Meetings With Hussein and Mubarak
abstract: President Reagan will confer with King Hussein of Jordan in Washington next Monday and with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt on Tuesday, the White House announced today.   The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, with Mr. Reagan on a speaking tour, said the crisis in Lebanon and the overall search for peace in the Middle East would be on the agenda of both meetings.

headline: Soviet Dismisses 160 Aides
abstract: The Soviet authorities have dismissed 160 Communist Party officials, including senior members of the judiciary, for dereliction of duty in the Urals in the Bashkir Autonomous Republic.

headline: TENSION BUILDS AT OCCIDENTAL
abstract: David H. Murdock, a West Coast multimillionaire, disclosed yesterday that he had increased his stake in the Occidental Petroleum Corporation to 4.8 million shares, or 5 percent, and that he might buy more.     Wall Street professionals interpreted the move as a sign that a long- simmering behind-the-scenes dispute between Mr. Murdock and Occidental's 85-year-old chairman, Armand Hammer, might eventually touch off a fight for control of the big West Coast oil company.    However, unless Dr. Hammer dies or becomes disabled, the 60-year-old Mr. Murdock is prohibited by his contract with Occidental from buying more than 5 percent of the company until 1992. The only way the contract could be broken, Wall Street analysts said, would be for Mr. Murdock or someone else to buy the company.

headline: 50,000 JOIN PROTEST IN MANILA
abstract: About 50,000 anti-Government protesters marched through the city's main thoroughfares today urging a boycott of the National Assembly elections of May 14 and the resignation of the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.   The march, which began seven days ago with one column starting from north of the city and a second from the south, was part of a campaign by some opposition leaders to boycott the elections on the ground that President Marcos has refused to give up his authoritarian powers.

headline: U.S. SAID TO REJECT LEBANON REQUEST FOR FIRE SUPPORT
abstract: The Reagan Administration has turned down an appeal from President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon for increased use of American naval and air power in direct support of his Government, Administration officials and Lebanese sources said today.   They said Wadi Haddad, Mr. Gemayel's national security adviser, met in Washington late last week with White House, State Department and Defense Department officials. He sought an American commitment to come to the aid of the Lebanese Government in case of a major military push by Syrians or Syrian-backed Lebanese across existing military lines near Beirut.   Because of the lack of success by Mr. Haddad in his talks here, Mr. Gemayel is resigned to working out a political formula with the Syrians, State Department officials said.

headline: 8 U.S. Legislators Leave On Trip to Study Heroin
abstract: Eight members of Congress began an 18-day fact-finding mission today into heroin smuggling in Europe, Asia and the Middle East and drug abuse among American servicemen in the Pacific.   The eight legislators, led by Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, left for a two-day stopover in Honolulu before traveling to Okinawa, Hong Kong, Thailand, Burma, Pakistan, Turkey and Rome.

headline: 4TH-QUARTER PROFIT SEEN BY A.M.C.
abstract: The American Motors Corporation, which has lost money for 14 consecutive quarters, will report a profit for the fourth quarter of 1983, Jose J. Dedeurwaerder, the company's president, said today.     Mr. Dedeurwaerder declined to be specific about the financial results for the period, saying only that the company's long string of losses had ended. A.M.C last reported a profit, of $1.3 million, in March 1980. Since then it has had cumulative losses totaling $643.5 million, including $154.1 million in the first three quarters of 1983.   Mr. Dedeurwaerder also declined to flatly predict a profitable year in 1984, but said the company had a ''good chance'' of remaining in the black if sales of small cars stay brisk. Some analysts have estimated that the company could earn between $38 million and $57 million next year.

headline: Canada Delivers Protest To U.S. on Acid Rain
abstract: The Canadian Government delivered a strong diplomatic protest to the State Department today against the Reagan Administration's failure to seek reductions in air pollution believed to cause acid rain.   Ambassador Allan E. Gotlieb said his Government was trying to convince the Administration that acid rain was the most important issue between the two countries and one that threatened to raise ''high-level concerns'' among all Canadians.   The text of the note presented by Mr. Gotlieb to William Schneider Jr., an Under Secretary of State, was not made public.

headline: The U.N. Today Feb. 27, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Nonuse of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Higher Heat Bills Cited
abstract: Americans spent nearly $700 million more than normal to heat their homes and offices in January because of below-normal temperatures in much of the East and South, according to the Government. The January chill, added to bitter cold in December, raised the nation's seasonal heating bill to $35.6 billion, $1.7 billion more than normal for this time of year.

headline: A LEADER IN IRAN ASSAILS STRATEGY
abstract: An Iranian leader has criticized the military strategy being used against Iraq and said victory requires the preparation of ''correct plans.''   This message, a departure from the optimistic reports from Iran on the course of the war, was broadcast over the Teheran radio by Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri, who is considered a possible successor to the 83-year-old revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The statement was one of several by Iranian leaders to mark the Iranian New Year, which began today.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Centel Corp. , a Chicago-based communications concern, said its Business Systems unit had received a 10-year, $45 million contract from the Department of Energy to replace the telecommunications network at the department's test site in Las Vegas, Nev.     * Chesapeake Financial Corp., a Miami-based concern whose chairman is Victor Posner, said it had submitted a revised offer to acquire Peabody International Inc., a Stamford, Conn., maker of pollution equipment, for $15 a share.     *   Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Washington, D.C., and two of its units said in an S.E.C. filing that they had acquired a 7.5 percent stake in Imperial Corp. of America for investment purposes.

headline: Three Clients Await DiGiacomo's Opening
abstract: Although he does not have office space yet, Frank DiGiacomo, who expects to fulfill a dream by opening his own agency around March 1, does have three clients waiting for him to do so.    The 44-year-old senior vice president and group creative director at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners has lined up Office Teleport, a new telecommunications company; Rapid Air Freight, and Patons, an association of Italian shoe manufacturers based in Padua.    Mr. DiGiacomo, who early in his agency career made the transition from account man to writer, has quite a list of previous affiliations that include Scali, McCabe, Sloves; Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson; Carl Ally Inc.; McDonald & Little, and McCann-Erickson.

headline: OIL-HUNGRY SUITORS ON THE PROWL AGAIN
abstract: Merger Fever in the Oil Patch.  More takeover bids emerged last week as prospects in the petroleum industry brightened. Royal Dutch/ Shell offered $55 a share, or $5.2 billion, for the 30.5 percent of the Shell Oil Company of the United States that it does not already own. And rumors that pushed up the stock of Houston Natural Gas all week proved to be true, as the Coastal Corporation said it would seek 45 percent of the pipeline company at $68 a share in a deal valued at $1.3 billion. Another suitor, Damson Oil, offered $24 a share, or $209.8 million, for control of Dorchester Gas, whose board has already approved a competing leveraged buyout. And yet another, Texaco, raised its $10 billion offer for Getty Oil by $3, to $128 a share, settling all litigation with J. Paul Getty's heirs.   Oil earnings were mixed in the fourth quarter of last year. Mobil said profits rose 11.8 percent despite a $98 million write-off for a dry hole in the Mukluk area off Alaska. The first annual profit since 1979 by its Montgomery Ward unit helped brighten the picture. Exxon reported a 10.1 percent gain, Gulf, 31.4 percent, Getty, 38.3 percent, Shell, 25 percent, and Indiana Standard, 10.6 percent. Lower earnings were reported by Texaco, down 16.3 percent, Standard of Ohio, off 30.2 percent, Standard of California, lower by 5.2 percent, Atlantic Richfield, off 3.5 percent, and Ashland, down 6.5 percent.

headline: CUTTING AIRLINE LABOR COSTS
abstract: When Harold Fleming, a member of the cabin maintenance crew for American Airlines at La Guardia Airport, first took the controls of a tractor to move a plane from the gate area, he recalled that ''the fright of pushing a huge aircraft was devastating.''     It was a job that for many years had been reserved only for airplane mechanics. Last March, however, American Airlines reached an unprecedented contract agreement with 11,000 members of the Transport Workers Union that allows the carrier to ''cross-utilize,'' or shift, workers to different jobs.   Thus Mr. Fleming, in addition to the tractor work, now handles baggage and de-ices aircraft, also jobs that in the past could have been done only by certain workers. And now, he said, running the tractor was as natural as driving a car.

headline: Technology; Hurdles Facing An Electric Car
abstract: LONDON     SIR CLIVE SINCLAIR, the man whose pioneering pocket calculator and inexpensive home computers have made him Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's favorite entrepreneur, wants to start manufacturing an electric car by the end of this year as the first step to introducing a range of electric vehicles with mass appeal.   Sir Clive's reputation in the electronics world here is such that no eyebrows were arched when he named his new microcomputer the Quantum Leap, but electric cars are a different proposition. Vehicle and power systems experts believe that, technologically speaking, a quantum leap and then some is just what Sir Clive or anyone else would need to produce an electric car for the masses. Many with more money and experience in the field than Sir Clive have failed.

headline: 6 Islamic Ambassadors In Protest on Jerusalem
abstract: The ambassadors of six Islamic nations today expressed concern to Secretary of State George P. Shultz about proposed legislation to move the United States Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.   The Reagan Administration opposes the legislation, and Ambassador Ejaz Azim of Pakistan later told reporters that ''we got full support'' from Mr. Shultz.

headline: Pizza Time Loss
abstract: Pizza Time Theater Inc. said it would report a ''substantial loss'' for the fourth quarter and that it is not in compliance with certain financial convenants of its bank loan agreements.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 28, 1984   International    The U.S. could relax rules requiring banks to lower earnings reports if Argentina fails to repay overdue interest by the next deadline on Saturday. But this suggestion, by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, was questioned by Federal bank regulators. (Page A1.) Argentina is more than 90 days overdue on $650 million in interest payments to U.S. banks, and accounting regulations require the creditor banks to deduct this amount from earnings. But the banks had expected the repayment delays and do not expect their stocks to be depressed further. (D6.) Argentine officials said they expected to reach a settlement over the arrears by mid-April. (D6.)    Common Market nations again failed to settle differences over finances and farm subsidies. Britain, which wants a refund on its contribution to the European Economic Community's budget, again found itself standing alone against the nine other members. (A1.)

headline: 21 PEOPLE WOUNDED BY 2 HAND GRENADES ON JERUSALEM STREET
abstract: Two hand grenades exploded at the entrance to a small clothing store in downtown West Jerusalem today and wounded 21 people.   In Damascus, the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization, took reponsibility for the explosions. It said the attack was in retaliation for raids by ''Zionist settlers'' on Moslem shrines in Jerusalem.

headline: Capital Practitioner Of Public Relations
abstract: Robert K. Gray, founder of Gray & Company, the largest public relations firm in Washington, will soon take his company public through an initial offering of $5.4 million in stock.    According to the prospectus for the offering filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, proceeds will be used to pay for corporate expansion and diversification into telecommunications technology and international markets. Mr. Gray, who paid himself $401,500 in salary last year, will own 72.4 percent of the outstanding common stock after the offering, the prospectus shows.    Mr. Gray, a 62-year-old Republican from Hastings, Neb., came to Washington almost 30 years ago to serve in the Eisenhower Administration. He has been a prominent player in Washington circles ever since.

headline: MONEY DATA SPUR RATE RISES
abstract: Interest rates rose yesterday, with most of the increases coming late in the day after the Federal Reserve announced that the nation's basic money supply fell by $1.5 billion in the week ended Feb. 27.     Government securities dealers and economists said the drop in prices and increase in rates reflected disappointment among traders that the money supply drop was not greater. Economists, however, said the figure was not significant enough to cause any change in Fed policy.    The decline in the M-1 money supply measure, which consists of currency plus all kinds of checking accounts, was less than the $2 billion estimate that many analysts had made.

headline: U.S. AGAIN LIFTS SOME SANCTIONS AGAINST POLAND
abstract: The United States, citing ''positive developments'' in Poland, has eased two of the economic sanctions imposed in 1981 when Warsaw declared martial law.    In response to an appeal from Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, President Reagan restored the right of Polish vessels to fish in American waters and the right of a limited number of charter flights to land in the United States, according to an announcement today at the White House. Regularly scheduled flights remain suspended.   The President's spokesman, Larry Speakes, said the changes were in response to ''a general improvement in conditions there.''

headline: COURT BARS APPEALS ON GAS PRICING
abstract: In an action that could lead to substantial refunds for consumers of natural gas, the Supreme Court today refused to review a lower court's ruling that invalidated a controversial new pricing regulation for natural gas.   The Court turned down appeals filed by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and 18 major producers of natural gas, including the Exxon Corporation, the Mobil Oil Corporation and Texaco Inc.   They sought review of a ruling last August by the Federal appeals court here that invalidated the energy commission's new approach for measuring the energy content of natural gas.   Rule Retroactive to 1978    The commission adopted the regulation, known as the ''dry rule,'' in 1980 and made it retroactive to 1978. The rule permitted producers of natural gas to charge nearly 2 percent more at the wellhead than Federal price ceilings would otherwise have allowed.

headline: DELHI TENSE OVER SIKH ISSUE
abstract: With more than 3,000 paramilitary troops on guard here, this tense capital was partly shut down today by a general strike called by a Hindu group to protest against violence by Sikh militants.   At the same time, leaders of the Akali Dal, the Sikh political party, symbolically burned or tore up a section of the Indian Constitution that lumps Sikhs with Hindus for purposes of religious identification.

headline: A.T.& T. Acts To Fill Orders
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told Federal regulators today that the company was undertaking a crash program to eliminate a crush of new orders for WATS and private business lines.   The company, in a private briefing for officials of the Federal Communications Commission and in a separate session with reporters, said it would have 750 to 1,000 more employees available by April 3 to process new service orders.

headline: U.S. POST NEAR BEIRUT DRAWS SHELLS
abstract: This mountain town, from which Syrian and Druse artillery positions can clearly be seen, came under two shelling attacks on Wednesday, with four or five shells landing close to a military position occupied by a small group of Americans.    Hours later Wednesday, the United States frigate Sims, which is off Lebanon, fired 20 rounds from its five-inch guns into what an American military spokesman called ''Syrian-controlled territory.'' The spokesman, Col. Edward McDonald, said the ship had acted in defense of Americans, but he would not say which ones or where they were.

headline: BUSINESS DEDUCTIONS COVER A BROAD RANGE
abstract: If tax deductions grew on trees, business and job-related expenses would be among the most prolific branches - and also among the thorniest.     Self-employed business people and outside salesmen have a far greater range of expenses that may be written off than most corporate employees do. But employees may deduct many costs incurred personally for their jobs or to improve their professional standing.    ''It has to be an item that is intended to help you earn income or enhance your income,'' said Leon M. Nad, national director of technical tax services at the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse.   Employees may deduct union dues, the cost of small tools, dues to professional associations, subscriptions to trade journals, the purchase and cleaning costs of uniforms, business phone calls made from home and even the cost of renting a tuxedo for a business-related function.

headline: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUILDING A BUSINESS WITH PARTNERS
abstract: FIVE years ago, a husband-wife team in Fresno, Calif., decided to start a dairy farm.   They had the expertise for such an operation, but lacked the capital to set it up. But with the help of a do-it-yourself tax shelter arrangement they were able to attract investors, and today their farm is rated among the top 10 of its size in the state for breeding and milk production.   The popular image of a tax shelter is a packaged deal offered by a large brokerage house, where investors contribute capital to large limited partnerships set up to drill for oil or construct buildings. But today, more and more entrepreneurs, like these California dairy farmers, are setting up their own limited partnerships.

headline: Senate Votes Shipping Bill
abstract: The Senate today approved a compromise bill to grant shipowners sweeping immunity from antitrust laws.

headline: 2 FILIPINOS, IN U.S., SAID TO ASSERT MARCOS AIDES HELPED KILL AQUINO
abstract: Two Filipinos, an army major and a man who described himself as an intelligence agent, were quoted today as saying that senior military intelligence and security officials in the Philippines helped plan the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr.   Mr. Aquino, a leading opponent of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, was shot to death Aug. 22 at the airport in Manila on his return from three years in the United States. The Philippine Government said the assassin was Rolando Galman, a reputed professional gunman who was immediately slain by security officers at the scene.

headline: Japanese Bank Deal in Chicago
abstract: The Chicago City Council has agreed to allow Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. to provide a letter of credit to guarantee a $259 million short-term borrowing plan.   It had postponed the plan to back the daily tender notes last Friday, after dissenting aldermen expressed reservations about allowing a Japanese bank to take business away from local institutions. Mitsubishi's proposed $1.5 million fee was the lowest bid, however, with First National Bank of Chicago a distant second with a $3 million bid.

headline: Data Bank; March 18, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: GRUMMAN IN THE BLACK
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter rose 25.4 percent from a year earlier, to $80.4 million, or $1.52 a share, from $64.1 million, or $1.17 a share, in the 1982 quarter.   Sales in the fourth quarter totaled $1.8 billion, equaling the level a year earlier.   For the year, earnings were $286.6 million, or $5.30 a share, more than double the $132.8 million, or $2.41 a share, in 1982. Sales for the year totaled $7.15 billion, up 16.3 percent from 1982.

headline: VOTING OBSERVERS LAND IN SALVADOR
abstract: A United States delegation of observers arrived here this afternoon to join nearly 300 other observers from 28 nations who will monitor Sunday's presidential election here.   The observers have no active role in what the Salvadorans are calling their civic fiesta but are intended to lend international credibility to the Government's assertion that the voting will be fair and honest.   Some of the delegations are here to monitor their own concerns as well. ''We support democracy, and what's happening here is important to Belize,'' Victor E. Usher, a member of that country's delegation, said. He added that unless there was a resolution of El Salvador's problems, there would be ''a continuation of refugees from Salvador to Belize.''

headline: A.T.& T. and Inmos in Talks
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it had begun talks on possibly acquiring a large stake in Inmos Ltd., Britain's state- owned semiconductor company.   Such a purchase would be a major step in A.T.& T.'s efforts to expand internationally.

headline: Seoul Pledges Import Aid
abstract: South Korea said today that it would undertake a broad import liberalization program as a big trade mission here announced purchase of more than $2.4 billion of American goods.

headline: U.S. AIDE CAUTIONS AGAINST HIGH HOPES IN SOVIET ARMS TALKS
abstract: A State Department official cautioned today against expecting quick progress in strategic arms talks with the Soviet Union.  An American negotiator had suggested Monday that the two countries could ''make a breakthrough'' if the Russians agreed to a date for resuming negotiations.    The latest statement came at a televised news conference held here by Richard Burt, the Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs.  He was apparently seeking to soften remarks made in Washington Monday by Edward L. Rowny, the chief United States negotiator on reducing strategic nuclear arms.

headline: NICARAGUA'S LABOR MINISTER: MAN IN MIDDLE, PRAISED BY BOTH SIDES
abstract: In a Marxist-dominated Government led by combat-hardened visionaries, Virgilio Godoy Reyes seems an unlikely Cabinet minister.    Mr. Godoy, who has been Minister of Labor in the Nicaraguan Government since the Sandinistas seized power in July 1979, is a scholarly 50-year-old sociologist who is not only outside the Sandinista movement but also president of another political party, the Independent Liberals. He was as surprised as many of his countrymen when he was named to the Cabinet.   ''It happened a few days before the victory,'' Mr. Godoy said in a recent interview. ''Apparently the provisional junta had held a press conference in Costa Rica to announce their Cabinet. One of my friends in the United States read the news story and called me up to say, 'Virgilio! Look what they've done to you!' ''

headline: SIGH OF RELIEF ON VIDEO GAMES
abstract: The feeling this week at the Consumer Electronics Show here appears to be relief that the video game and home computer industry - in which some companies lost hundreds of millions of dollars during 1983 - still exists.   Said William Grubb, chairman of Imagic: ''For this industry, 1983 was the year of humility.''   ''The phenomenon is over,'' said Roger Sharpe, the editor of Video Games magazine. ''The industry dug its own grave by thinking that all you had to do was put something in a box and the public would buy it. The question is where the industry will stabilize.''

headline: The U.N. Today March 26, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Committee Against Apartheid - 3 P.M.   Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: VOLCKER UNSETTLES THE STOCK MARKET
abstract: The Federal Reserve and its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, caused quite a stir last week as the board submitted its annual report to Congress and the chairman made his semi-annual appearance on the Hill. Mr. Volcker's message was, in essence, ''cut the deficit before it's too late.'' While the Fed plans to orchestrate continued steady growth for the economy, he warned that it could not be expected to loosen its monetary policy to block a deficit-induced rise in interest rates, which could easily bring on another recession. The chairman added that Congress and the Administration would have to cut up to $125 billion in the next two years to make any substantive progress. As a result of his warnings, the stock market plunged and it appeared that Wall Street suddenly became concerned about the $200 billion annual deficits. So adverse was the reaction that Mr. Volcker took pains on Thursday to note that his comments had been ''a little blown up'' and that markets had overreacted.

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation won two Navy contracts worth a total of $1.14 billion, the Defense Department said today.

headline: RAID ON NICARAGUA IS TRACED BY U.S.
abstract: An air attack that destroyed a radio command and control center in Nicaragua on Feb. 2 was launched from a Salvadoran Air Force base, according to United States officials here and in Washington.    A United States-backed Nicaraguan insurgent group, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, claimed responsibility for the attack. The Nicaraguan Government initially protested to Honduras over the raid against the radio center, near the Casitas Volcano, about 65 miles northwest of Managua. It also accused the United States of ordering the attack.

headline: N.A.D. Resolves 9 Ad Complaints
abstract: During January, six advertisers whose claims were being investigated by industry self-regulators either changed the claims or dropped the advertising, according to the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.     In the case of the Permalens Extended-Wear Contact Lens, with advertising by Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, the N.A.D. ended up unhappy about the claim ''the world's leading extended-wear lens.''

headline: McDonnell Tender Hits Court Snag
abstract: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said it had issued a restraining order to keep the McDonnell Douglas Corporation from completing its tender offer for Tymshare Inc. It said the order stays ''until further notice'' completion of the transaction as approved by the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: Marriott Sells Theme Park
abstract: The City of Santa Clara, Calif., has decided to buy the Great America theme park from the Marriott Corporation for a total of $101 million. Marriott said that, under an agreement approved by Santa Clara's City Council, the company would receive about $70 million in cash and $31 million in short-term notes in a transaction to be completed in early September.

headline: SALVADOR TALLY MOUNTING SLOWLY
abstract: The Elections Council today continued its slow work of counting the votes from the presidential elections as a right-wing death squad threatened its members.      An unindentified caller phoned a radio station here and read a communique from the group, the Secret Anti- Communist Army, that included the threat to ''punish'' members of the council for ''making a mockery of the Salvadoran people with the disorder'' of the elections on Sunday.   The far-right paramilitary group, founded in 1980, re-emerged last May after a period of inactivity and took responsibility for several assasinations during the summer. In its communique today, the group said it had captured and assassinated a leftist guerrilla called Jamie.

headline: REDIDENTIAL RESTORATION FOR SOUTH STREET SEAPORT
abstract: For some people, the restored South Street Seaport Historic District is more than a vacation stopover or a lunch time diversion. It is home.   Restoration work in the old mercantile neighborhood on the East River, just north of the financial district, has spurred the private rehabilitation of sagging but still sturdy buildings into rental apartments and condominiums, most of them expensive. Although commercial Seaport tenants complain that business at their food stalls and shops has been so poor they cannot pay the rent, developers of residential properties are finding buyers and renters.

headline: Steel Accord Is Sought
abstract: The United States Export-Import Bank, searching for a compromise in a conflict with the Reagan Administration over financing sales of equipment for a South Korean steel mill, may decide to guarantee only a portion of the loan rather than provide a direct credit, Administration officials said today.    An official, who asked not to be identified, characterized such an outcome as ''pretty safe speculation,'' although he stressed that no decision had been made and that several options were being considered.

headline: Telerate Profit Up 75.7% in Quarter By The Associated Press
abstract: Telerate Inc., which provides financial information to institutional customers via computer, said its profit for its fiscal first quarter was up 75.7 percent from a year earlier.

headline: FEDERAL RESERVE PLANS STABLE RISE IN MONEY SUPPLY
abstract: Stock prices slumped for a second straight session in heavy trading.  The Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.72 points, to 1,174.31. Page D1.         By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER    WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 - The Federal Reserve Board said today that it would keep the pace of growth in the nation's money supply stable this year.

headline: McKesson Offer
abstract: The McKesson Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to invest up to $20 million in convertible subordinated debentures to be issued by the Environmental Systems Company.

headline: PACIFIC EXPRESS
abstract: Pacific Express, a commuter airline serving five Western states, has halted operations and filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

headline: HOUSE PANEL VOTES CURBS ON AID TO SALVADOR
abstract: A House subcommittee, saying it wanted to ''send a message'' about human rights to the Reagan Administration and governments in Central America, voted major restrictions today on military and economic aid for El Salvador.   The panel, the subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs, also approved a prohibition on further participation by United States forces in military training exercises in Honduras.   The two decisions, both by voice vote, came as the subcommittee shaped the Central American section of next year's foreign aid bill and forwarded its recommendations to the parent panel, the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The forwarding vote passed, 5 to 1.

headline: Thieves Return Holy Tunic
abstract: The church authorities announced today that thieves had returned a holy tunic that was stolen by a leftist guerrilla group to raise ransom money for the outlawed Solidarity union in Poland. The tunic, believed to have been worn by Jesus, was returned ''in good condition'' this week to the Basilica of St.-Denys, northeast of Paris, the parish priest said.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Burlington Air Freight   BBDO International, parent of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, has become the agency for Burlington Northern Air Freight, a division of the Pittston Corporation. The $5 million account will be serviced by two of=?fices of the company, BBDO Direct in New York and BBDO/West in the Los Angeles market. Burlington Northern, which is in the business of overnight delivery of small parcels, says it is one of the largest freight forwarders on the basis of tonnage.

headline: THE EMPLOYEE BID TO ACQUIRE CONRAIL
abstract: The Federal Government in recent months has stepped up its efforts to sell its 85 percent stake in the Consolidated Rail Corporation, the nation's sixth-biggest railroad in terms of trackage and the most important freight carrier in the Northeast.     Conrail was created in 1976 from the rubble of the Penn Central and six other bankrupt railroads, and nurtured over the years with $7 billion in Federal subsidies, It is only now emerging as an attractive acquisition candidate.   Amid widespread doubts that it would ever be able to run on its own steam, the company first edged into the black in 1981 with a profit of $39.2 million - after cumulative losses of $1.5 billion since its start-up.    Two weeks ago, Conrail reported 1983 net income of $313 million - nearly double its 1982 profit of $174.2 million. The gain came on only a slight rise in revenues, to $3.08 billion from $3 billion.

headline: SOVIET PREPARING TO NAME A LEADER AT PARTY MEETING
abstract: The Soviet Union passed a third day today since the death of Yuri V. Andropov without announcing a successor, but there were growing indications that the Central Committee would name a new leader on Monday.   The reasons for not yet naming a leader remained obscure. Mr. Andropov's appointment as General Secretary of the Communist Party 15 months ago was announced the day after Leonid I. Brezhnev's death was formally disclosed, and the break with this limited precedent suggested that the 12 voting members of the Politburo had been unable to reach a quick consensus.   Party rules empower the full Central Committee, with about 300 members, to elect a General Secretary. But if the Politburo agrees on a candidate, unanimous approval by the full Central Committee is considered automatic.

headline: Video Corp. Offer
abstract: A group led by Reich & Tang Inc., a New York brokerage, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it considers inadequate an offer by the First Capital Holdings Corporation to buy the Video Corporation of America.

headline: ANACOMP OUSTS OPERATING CHIEF
abstract: Anacomp Inc., a software company in Indianapolis that has been suffering losses, said yesterday that it had dismissed its chief operating officer, John Flanigan, and had eliminated the position.     Ronald Palamara, a founder of the company who is chairman, president and chief executive officer, will resume responsibility for daily operations, Anacomp said.

headline: Oil and Mergers
abstract: To the Editor:      Your article ''An Unsettling Shift for Big Oil'' (March 11) reports that it is now cheaper for large oil companies to extend their reserves by buying other companies rather than by increasing their own drilling rates. It suggests, as does Senator Metzenbaum, that such mergers will reduce the capital available for drilling, national drilling rates and our nation's ability to find more oil.   It is not clear, however, that increased drilling rates, such as occurred following the quadrupling of oil prices in the 1970's, leads to the finding of much additional oil. We analyzed United States oil drilling and oil discovery rates from 1946 to 1978 - using yield per effort techniques borrowed from fisheries analysis - and found a strong decline in yield per effort, from 33 to 7 barrels of oil found per foot drilled (Charles Hall and Cutler Cleveland, ''Science,'' Feb. 6). Our results agree with the predictions of Hubbert and Davis made decades earlier based on physical analysis techniques, and do not support the many statements made by various economists and representatives of industry that increased monetary incentives would increase oil finding rates. Of somewhat greater surprise, we found that less oil was found per foot drilled, relative to the downward trend over time, during periods of greater drilling, and the converse. During that approximately 30-year time interval there was no indication that increasing or decreasing drilling rates had any particular influence on the total quantity of oil found in a year, which tended to decrease over time regardless of drilling rates.

headline: Blast Rips Burmese Train
abstract: An explosion ripped through a crowded passenger train today, injuring at least nine people, officials said.

headline: LONDON ROBBERS GET MILLION IN GEMS AT CHRISTIE'S
abstract: Robbers armed with sawed-off shotguns invaded the showrooms at Christie's today and made off with jewelry valued at more than $1 million.    Two of the four items stolen from the international auction house once belonged to the wife of the American railroad tycoon Jay Gould and were scheduled to be auctioned at Christie's New York salesrooms in April.

headline: GLEMP INSISTS ON TRANSFERRING PRIEST WHO BACKS SOLIDARITY
abstract: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Polish Primate, refused today to rescind an order transferring a pro-Solidarity priest to the countryside, but hundreds of the priest's supporters were still gathered in his former church here tonight.    A protest leader told about 500 people standing in the darkened church, ''Our fundamental questions and doubts remain.''   Nine hunger strikers encamped in a room behind the altar vowed they would continue their fast and called for a protest mass on Friday evening.

headline: TROOP-CUT TALKS TO BE RESUMED, SHULTZ DECLARES
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States had agreed to a Soviet proposal to resume negotiations on reducing troops and conventional arms in Central Europe on March 16 in Vienna.   It was the first formal disclosure that an agreement had been reached on any of the major East-West issues during Mr. Shultz's five-hour conversation in Stockholm last week with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union.   But Mr. Shultz repeated that there had been no accord on resuming either the negotiations on reducing medium- range missiles or those on reducing strategic arms.   'Some Positive Things'    ''It depends on what kind of arms control you are talking about,'' he said in discussing the future of such negotiations. ''That's the answer across the board. There are some positive things and some negative things.''

headline: The U.N. Today; Jan. 26, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Commission on International Trade Law, Working Group on the New International Economic Order - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Preparatory Committee for the International Conference on Population - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Saab's Sales At High in U.S.
abstract: Saab-Scania of America said today that it sold a record 25,833 Swedish-made Saab cars in the United States last year, up 42 percent from 18,179 sold in 1982, the previous high.

headline: 4,000 EX-OFFICIALS SURRENDER IN NIGERIA
abstract: Western diplomats reported today that as many as 4,000 officials of the ousted national and state governments had turned themselves in to the police as part of the new military Government's investigation of corruption.    The diplomats said most of the former officials were released, some after their passports were confiscated. But about 400 were reportedly still held under what was described as ''military protection.''   At the same time, the Western diplomats and Nigerian sources said, many of the former officials who were on what the military Government of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari called its ''most wanted list'' have managed to flee the country. Some who were abroad during the military takeover have decided to remain there.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Hospital Supply
abstract: The American Hospital Supply Corporation said it expects to spend more than $700 million in research and product development during the next five years, up from $262 million in the preceding five years.

headline: DIVERSE AFRICAN NATIONS FIND UNANIMITY AT U.N.
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 24 - The 51 African members of the United Nations, though often riven by internal differences and disagreements at home, enjoy an uncanny ability to find a consensus here that binds together every country in the group.   Diplomats and officials say that this unity, a source of pride and sometimes of envy, has become an important feature of political life at the United Nations.   ''There are certain areas where you can't get Africa to speak with one voice,'' Paul M. Rupia, the delegate from Tanzania, said in an interview. He cited the controversies over the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and the situation in Cambodia as examples of issues where the African countries have adopted no common policy.

headline: PatentsStacy V. Jones A.T.& T.'s Conference Call Unit
abstract: WASHINGTON    A TELEPHONE conference system called Parkhold was patented this week for A.T.& T.'s research unit in Murray Hill, N.J. Patent 4,424,418 was obtained by George E. Moore and Vincent A. Muehter, staff members.

headline: Eagle-I.B.M. Settlement
abstract: Eagle Computer Inc., which makes a personal computer compatible with those made by the International Business Machines Corporation, said yesterday that it had agreed to a permanent injunction that ends a copyright infringement suit brought by I.B.M.   Eagle thus became the second major maker of I.B.M. ''look-alike'' computers to be forced by Federal suits filed by the computer giant to stop making a computer program apparently copied from an I.B.M. design. Late last month, Corona Data Systems Inc. entered into a similar agreement in the same court in San Jose, Calif.   The programs involved were the same: the Basic Input/Output System, known as a BIOS, which enables the keyboard, video screen and other parts of a computer to communicate with each other.

headline: U.S. TELLS JORDAN OF ITS COMMITMENT DESPITE PULLBACK
abstract: President Reagan assured King Hussein of Jordan today that his decision to pull back the marines from Beirut did not imply a weakening of his commitment to Jordan and Lebanon in their struggles against Syria.   Mr. Reagan's assurances came at a meeting with the King at the White House that marked the beginning of a round of discussions on the turbulent situation in the Middle East. The President is to follow up the session today with a meeting Tuesday with both King Hussein and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.   Mr. Mubarak and the King had dinner together Sunday night, but an American official said he did not regard their getting together as ''historic'' or ''ice breaking.'' The two leaders had met twice before and the Administration has said their presence in town together is a coincidence.

headline: U.S. Seeks Limits on Ex-Bell Units
abstract: The Justice Department has urged a Federal judge to sharply limit the manner in which the seven former Bell System companies may enter new lines of business and to make it clear they are not going to be allowed into the long-distance market any time soon.   The department, in a strongly worded, 48-page filing, told United States District Judge Harold H. Greene it was afraid the new Bell companies had already lost sight of the fact that the antitrust settlement that broke apart the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was not intended to turn them into competitive entrepeneurs.   The primary responsibility imposed on the Bell companies through the breakup was to operate local phone networks and to improve those networks so that A.T. & T.'s long-distance competitors receive the same access to local customers as A.T. & T., the department said.

headline: JAPAN TRADE BARS WORRY U.S.
abstract: The Japanese Government is considering legislation in two high-technology fields - computer software and sophisticated telecommunications services - that United States trade officials and industry executives say will restrict foreign imports and reduce legal protection for American technology.    Moreover, the proposed laws raise a broader issue. The Japanese Government has long held that since the mid-1960's its industrial policy of selecting and nurturing new industries has not included the tools of protectionism. Yet the pending rules cover two fast-growing industries that Japan has marked as critical for its continued economic advance.

headline: LEBANON AIRLINE, AFTER BRAVING THE WARS, IS PENNILESS
abstract: Lebanon's national flag airline, whose pilots have gained a reputation for getting passengers to Beirut in all but the most perilous of times, is on the verge of bankruptcy after a year of devastating losses.   Salim Salaam, the 61-year-old chairman and president of the line, Middle East Airlines, says the only people flying to Lebanon these days are those who have no choice. And for nearly two months last year even those passengers - mainly Lebanese, but also some foreign journalists and a handful of foreign businessmen - were unable to fly because the war had forced the Government to close the airport here.   ''You don't make money when the airport is closed,'' Mr. Salaam said the other day as he talked about the airline's troubles. ''You only spend money on fixed costs and salaries.''

headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS
abstract: Cocoa Futures Soar; Grains, Soybeans Up       By The Associated Press    Cocoa futures prices climbed sharply higher for the second consecutive day yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.   Mike Paulenoff, an analyst in New York with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, noted that prices had declined last week in anticipation of a larger African cocoa crop than had previously been expected. But, he said, when even higher crop estimates failed to produce additional selling this week, traders who were hoping for a break in prices bought back the contracts they had sold earlier, to cover their short positions.

headline: DEALING WITH OVERSEAS JOB COMPETITION
abstract: LOS ANGELES THE Tandon Corporation is the nation's largest maker of data-storage and retrieval devices for personal computers, a booming business that barely existed five years ago.    It employs about 3,000 workers in Singapore, plus another 3,000 through a contractor in Bombay, India, at wages of about $1 an hour. Those low labor costs have helped Tandon win big contracts from major computer makers, including one worth more than $300 million from the International Business Machines Corporation.   Now, with sales nearly doubling every quarter at a pace that should push Tandon past $500 million this year, the company is transferring still more assembly and test work to Singapore. Sirjang Lal Tandon, the company's Indian-born president and founder, said earlier this month that 1,000 workers at its factory near Los Angeles, making a minimum of $6 an hour, would be laid off the fall.

headline: Libyan Ambassador Dies of Wounds in Rome
abstract: The Libyan Ambassador to Italy, who was shot outside his Rome apartment Jan. 21, died in a hospital today, officials said.

headline: Board Backs T.W.A. Moves
abstract: The Trans World Airlines board of directors has endorsed the airline's decisions regarding several strategic moves. Jerry Cosley, T.W.A.'s vice president of public affairs, said in an interview yesterday that at its meeting on Wednesday the board endorsed the concept that the airline should expand on the international level instead of domestically to improve its profitability.

headline: The U.N. Today; Jan. 13, 1984
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets at 11 A.M. on an issue relating to South Africa.  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission - 10 A.M. and 2:30 P.M.   Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: MRS. MARCOS SETS CHINA ACCORDS
abstract: The Government announced today that Imelda Marcos had concluded cooperative agreements with top Chinese officials during a four-day visit to Peking.   The diplomatic mission was undertaken despite the announcement last September by Mrs. Marcos, the wife of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, that she would retire from public life and subsequent pledges by President Marcos that he would not groom her to be his successor.

headline: 103 Introductions
abstract: Even though January is a slow month for product introductions, Martin Friedman, editor of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, reports that last month saw 103 introductions, a slight improvement over January 1982 and well above the 66 that was the monthly average from 1964 to 1980. Mr. Friedman's count is only for food and nonprescription drugs.

headline: Advertising; A Difficult Market To Crack
abstract: -collar job, makes more than the national average and favors NBC-TV?     No answer?   Then add to the profile: goes to parties and drinks considerably, likes ''Hill Street Blues'' but not ''Falcon Crest,'' likes English muffins but not frozen TV dinners, owns a wok and is heavy on chewing gum but light on laxatives.    Still confused?

headline: NEW BRITISH INSURANCE CARD SPURS QUESTIONS ON PRIVACY
abstract: Britain began issuing plastic National Insurance cards today, despite suggestions by critics that they could be turned into identification cards storing secret information.   The cards were introduced with elaborate assurances that they were not precursors of identity cards. But an opposition Labor legislator, Michael Meacher, said they may be the first step toward an ''Orwellian nightmare in the first few days of 1984.''

headline: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS AND ISRAELIS MOURN HADDAD
abstract: Maj. Saad Haddad, the southern Lebanese militia leader allied with Israel who died on Saturday of cancer, lay in state today in his home town as hundreds of Lebanese and Israelis paid him tribute.   Buildings in this predominantly Christian town five miles north of the Israeli border were festooned with the Lebanese flag and posters of Major Haddad, who broke from the Lebanese Army in 1976 and allied his force of Christian and Shiite Moslem militiamen with Israel.   Major Haddad's widow, Theresa, sat next to his glass-covered coffin as mourners filed through the building which normally serves as Merj 'Uyun's community center. Among the mourners was the commander of Israeli forces in southern Lebanon, who placed a wreath on Major Haddad's coffin and saluted his former ally.

headline: Belgian Officials Seized In Language Squabble
abstract: The Mayor and city councilmen of the Flemish-speaking town of Overijse, near Brussels, were arrested Tuesday night as a conflict over the use of French and Flemish languages intensified.   The police said the officials violated a temporary ban on meetings in Overijse imposed by the Governor of Brabant Province, which surrounds Brussels, to try and stop Belgium's language conflict from spreading.

headline: DOW ADVANCES 0.31 IN A WEAK MARKET
abstract: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in active trading, although the Dow Jones industrial average managed to end with a minor gain after declining sharply in the preceding seven sessions.    In the overall market, equities that fell on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that rose by 931 to 640. The worst performers were some of the technology issues.   The Dow average, which was in the minus column until the last few minutes of trading, rose 0.31 point, to 1,230. In the previous seven trading days, it dropped almost 42 points.

headline: Bonn Sees 2.5% Growth
abstract: West Germany's economy is expected to grow 2.5 percent in 1984, but unemployment will probably remain steady at 2.2 million people, Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff said today at a news conference. He said inflation would be 3 percent this year.

headline: POLICY AFTER ANDROPOV: WASHINGTON FORESEES CONTINUING CONFLICTS
abstract: The passing of a major political leader sometimes creates a sense of opportunity. But as seen by a range of Reagan Administration officials, Yuri V. Andropov's death offers not so much a chance for breakthroughs as a time for gestures that might lead to breakthroughs later on.  There is little evidence that anything fundamental has changed in either Moscow or Washington with Mr. Andropov's passing. Essentially, the same people have been running Soviet foreign policy for five or six years. Mr. Andropov was ill for almost one year of his 15-month tenure. His predecessor, Leonid I. Brezhnev, seemed inactive for his last three years. Soviet policy has been much the same throughout.    Nor is there much evidence that President Reagan is prepared to propose new compromises that might help break the impasses over the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan or the Lebanon situation or the talks on nuclear arms. All that can be seen thus far is a softening of the Reagan oratory on Soviet-American relations in the last two months.

headline: CPC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mobil Prices Up
abstract: The Mobil Oil Corporation said it was raising wholesale gasoline prices on the East Coast half a cent a gallon. The subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation said the increase applied to all areas along the Atlantic coast except New York City and Long Island.

headline: BORENO SULTANATE NOW INDEPENDENT
abstract: This tiny Islamic sultanate on Borneo's northern coast, whose oil and natural gas resources have made it one of the wealthiest countries in the world, became fully independent from Britain today.    The official name of the new nation, the world's 169th country, is Brunei Darussalam, which means ''Brunei, Abode of Peace.''   Nearly a century and a half of varying degrees of British control or influence ended in a solemn, 90-minute ceremony consisting of prayers, chants from the Koran and ritual drumming. They were presided over by Brunei's 37-year-old ruler, Sultan Muda Hassanal Bolkiah, the 29th leader in a line going back five centuries.

headline: REAGAN REPORT PESSIMISTIC ON SATELLITE-KILLER PACT
