abstract: A Reagan Administration report to be given to Congress concludes that a ban on specific antisatellite weapons may be possible to verify but that Administration experts have yet to figure out how to do it and doubt that it can be done, officials said today.     The report, in response to a Congressional mandate to study the feasibility of antisatellite arms control, is to be presented Saturday. It has been several months in preparation, and the final draft was completed only Thursday after what officials described as bitter struggles. State Department officials said they wanted to show Congress that the Administration was trying to study seriously the feasibility of controlling antisatellite weapons, while Pentagon officials made it clear they wanted to close the door entirely on a treaty because of what they said were formidable problems in verifying such agreements.

headline: Barclays Plans $378 Million Sale
abstract: The Barclays American Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $378 million in medium- term notes. The company said the notes would be due from nine months to ten years from date of issue.   Barclays said the terms of each offering of notes would be fixed as the offering came to market.

headline: IMPROVING INDUSTRY'S IMAGE
abstract: Convinced that misleading and untruthful political advertising contributes to the negative image of all advertising, the American Association of Advertising Agencies has initiated a program for monitoring it coast to coast and on all levels.    Exactly what its leadership will do with the results is not definite as yet, but Charles F. Adams, executive vice president of the association, did talk about sending offensive ads to an industry jury that would select a ''dirty dozen'' to be announced, probably after Election Day.   That did not sit well with John E. O'Toole, chairman of Foote, Cone & Belding, the new chairman of the Four-A's and a frequent critic of political advertising. ''I'm not willing to close off the possibility of denouncing advertising in the middle of the campaign,'' Mr. O'Toole said.

headline: 4 Constitutional Changes Signed in Philippines
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos signed into law today the four constitutional amendments approved in a referendum last Friday, among them one restoring the office of vice president.

headline: SOUGHT SUMMIT TALKS, EX-THATCHER AIDE SAYS
abstract: Francis Pym, a former Foreign Secretary, said tonight that he had tried unsuccessfully to persuade President Reagan to seek a meeting with Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, shortly after Mr. Andropov succeeded Leonid I. Brezhnev.   In an interview, Mr. Pym gave further details about an intiative that he first mentioned publicly in a speech Monday night to the English-Speaking Union. He said he had sent a cable or letter - he was not sure which - to Secretary of State George P. Shultz only a few days after the death of Mr. Brezhnev on Nov. 10, 1982. The message urged Mr. Shultz to ''sell'' Mr. Reagan on a summit meeting.

headline: Honda's Output in U.S.
abstract: The Honda Motor Company said today that it would increase production of motorcycles by 70 percent this year at its factory in Marysville, Ohio. The company said it would produce about 70,000 motorcycles with engines of at least 1,000-cubic-centimeter displacement at the plant, compared with 41,000 in 1983.

headline: MARCOS AT RALLY TO OPEN CAMPAIGN
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos officially opened his party's campaign for the May 14 parliamentary elections today at a political rally attended by tens of thousands in Manila's main public park.    The President's wife, Imelda Marcos, announced at the rally that she was firm in her decision not to run again for a seat in the National Assembly. Mrs. Marcos won a seat in the National Assembly in the last parliamentary elections six years ago.   Manila newspapers published front- page reports today speculating that Mrs. Marcos, who is the Minister of Human Settlements in her husband's Cabinet and Governor of Metropolitan Manila, would bow to petitions from her supporters that she be a candidate.

headline: Lloyd's Sets Stricter Rules
abstract: Lloyd's of London today announced new rules to carry out a 1982 law requiring insurance brokers to divest themselves of interests in Lloyd's underwriters by July 22, 1987.

headline: Digital to Offer UNIX System WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (Reuters) - The Digital Equipment Corporation said it would offer an operating system based on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's UNIX software system for its mid- range and high-range Vax computers. The company said it would distribute Ultrex-32 under an A.T.& T. license.
abstract: Last week, the International Business Machines Corporation said it would make the UNIX system available to users of its Personal Computer. That move was seen as upstaging A.T.& T. UNIX is widely used on much larger computers, primarily by engineers and on campuses. It can permit several computer users to work on a single machine simultaneously.

headline: Wilson Debt Plan
abstract: A bankruptcy judge approved the Wilson Foods Corporation's reorganization plan. The company said unsecured creditors would be fully repaid in installments and with interest at 9 1/2 percent over a 48-month period.

headline: Sealaska President Begins Rebuilding
abstract: A recent realignment of management at the Sealaska Corporation of Juneau, Alaska, will provide the opportunity ''to build a foundation upon bedrock'' to carry the native corporation through the decade, says Byron I. Mallott.    As part of changes to broaden management, Mr. Mallott relinquished the chairman's title that he held since 1977 to the vice chairman, Marlene A. Johnson, who is 47 years old. He took the title of president and retained the chief executive role that he assumed in the middle of 1982.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS
abstract: Interest Rates Fall Modestly          Interest rates fell modestly yesterday for most Treasury issues, with most of the declines occurring before the Federal Reserve's late afternoon announcement of a $1.7 billion increase in the basic M-1 measure of the money supply.   By late in the day, Treasury bill rates were lower by a few basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, with the exception of the three- month issue, which rose slightly. In the bond market, the bellwether 12 percent Treasury issue due in 2013 was offered late in the day at a price of 99 6/32, up 17/32 on the day, to yield 12.10 percent. Earlier in the day, the issue had traded around 98 3/8 level, and just before the money supply announcement it was offered at about 98 7/8, to yield 12.14 percent.

headline: CORPORATE BOND PRICES FIRM
abstract: Flush with funds, the insurance industry yesterday gobbled up $425 million of 10-year bonds that were offered by three major financially oriented companies.     The three issuers - Sears, Roebuck & Company, Avco Financial Services and the Beneficial Corporation - took advantage of an unusually narrow difference between what they had to pay for 10-year money and what the Government had to pay for comparable funds.    This spread amounted to only 29 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, for Sears, 68 points for Avco and 69 points for Beneficial. For such companies as Avco and Beneficial, the spread is usually 100 basis points.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: TUESDAY, MARCH 27, 1984   The Economy    Bank regulators approved curbs on brokered deposits, but allowed two years for banking institutions to reduce their dependence on such funds. The approval came despite opposition by the Treasury and Justice Departments and the banking industry. (Page D1.)    The Fed approved interstate mergers among two sets of banks in Massachusetts and Connecticut, signaling a go-ahead for regional banking pacts. Major banks in New York City have strongly opposed such pacts. Citicorp charges that they are unconstitutional because they discriminate on the basis of geography. (D1.)

headline: 3 COUNTRIES PLAN PARLEY ON TRUCE
abstract: The United States, South Africa and Angola have agreed to open talks on Thursday to preserve the current cease-fire between the two southern African countries, the State Department said.   The meeting, which is to be held in Lusaka, Zambia, will bring the three countries together at one table for the first time. It is aimed at laying the groundwork for step-by-step progress in the drawn-out efforts by the United States for an accord, by which South Africa would give up control over South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, and Angola would consent to a timetable for the withdrawal of the 25,000 Cuban combat troops stationed in its country.   As a confidence-building measure, the United States is ready to propose the formation of a joint monitoring commission, made up of Angolans, South Africans and a small group of Americans. The number of Americans would be about a half-dozen, drawn from the Foreign Service and the military, a State Department official said.

headline: Gulf Oil Wins Ruling on Vote
abstract: A Federal judge upheld a shareholder election that gave   the Gulf Oil Corporation the authority to move its corporate   charter from Pennsylvania to   Delaware.  The move will eliminate   cumulative voting rights that   T. Boone Pickens, chairman of   the Mesa Petroleum Company,   had counted on to capture two   seats on Gulf's board of directors by using the 21.7 million   shares he controls. Mr. Pickens is leading an investor group that has spent   more than $900 million acquiring 13.2 percent of Gulf's 165   million shares.

headline: BANKAMERICA, CONTINENTAL NET OFF
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's second-largest bank holding company, and the Continental Illinois Corporation, the seventh-largest, yesterday reported sharp declines in their fourth-quarter net income.     BankAmerica said its net income declined 32 percent, to $53 million, from $78 million a year earlier. On a per-share basis, net income dropped 54 percent, to 22 cents from 48 cents. Net income was substantially bolstered by a gain of $31 million from a swap of debt for equity.

headline: GETTY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Altos Computer Systems, San Jose, Calif., has appointed David W. Hanna president and chief executive.     *  Avis Rent A Car System Inc., Garden City, L.I., has named Jan O. H. Nyquist vice president, international sales.

headline: South Korea Offers To Deliver a Message
abstract: South Korea offered today to meet with North Korean representatives on Friday for the first time in four years and give them Seoul's response to Pyongyang's offer of peace talks.   There was no immediate response from North Korea.

headline: Eastern Airlines
abstract: Eastern Airlines' unionized flight attendants have voted to approve a $367 million financial bailout plan, leaving only the pilots to cast ballots on the proposal negotiated in December.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: Bank of America, San Francisco, has announced the retirement of Thomas A. Deane, vice chairman.     *  Flying Tigers, Los Angeles, has named Lewis H. Jordan executive vice president.

headline: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CLIMBS 32%
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 32 percent. Digital's stock rose sharply last week when it said that its earnings would greatly exceed Wall Street predictions.    Digital was one of three companies whose earnings reports yesterday indicated that the demand for mainframe and minicomputers - refrigerator-sized machines used in offices and research laboratories - surged at the end of 1983.    The Burroughs Corporation posted a profit of $81.4 million in the latest quarter, contrasted with a $15.6 million loss a year earlier. And Prime Computer said its fourth-quarter profit fell to $10 million, down 18 percent from the same quarter a year ago but up considerably from disapointing earnings posted in the first two quarters of last year.

headline: Shell Tax Payment
abstract: The Shell Oil Company has paid Illinois nearly $31 million in back taxes and interest in settlement of a dispute over the Houston-based company's tax liability for a byproduct of the refining process.

headline: Israelis Reported to Consider A New Pullback in Lebanon
abstract: The Israeli military command is considering pulling back to a new line in southern Lebanon between the Zaharani and Litani Rivers, the Israeli radio reported today.

headline: Old Photos of Shaw Are Found in Minsk
abstract: Workers repairing an old building in Minsk have discovered 73 photographs of George Bernard Shaw, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported today.   Tass said some of the photographs showed Shaw listening to a report by Albert Einstein and chatting with Charlie Chaplin and Jo Davidson, the American sculptor.

headline: DOW CLIMBS 4.39, TO 1,175.77
abstract: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in more active trading following the sharp selloff on Monday when rising interest rates weakened the list.     At the conclusion of the session, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 4.39 points, to 1,175.77. In the preceding day, the Dow tumbled almost 13 points after most major banks raised their prime lending rate to 11 1/2 percent, from 11 percent.

headline: Gray & Co. Stock
abstract: Gray & Company, a Washington, D.C., public relations firm, said it was satisfied with its stock offering on Wednesday, even though it had to offer fewer shares than had been planned.

headline: EGYPT ISSUE FAILS TO MAKE CONFERENCE AGENDA
abstract: The hopes of moderate Moslem countries that the Islamic conference opening Monday would lead to the return of Egypt to Arab councils appeared dashed today. The conference organization's Secretary General, Habib Chatti, said the meeting of about 40 foreign ministers to draft a conference agenda had not raised the issue.    However, a participating minister said that Pakistan and Malaysia had tried to place an item on the Egyption question first on the conference agenda. Egypt has been excluded from all Moslem and Arab organizations since it signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979; Pakistan and Malaysia apparently hoped that their move might even permit President Hosni Mubarak to come here and participate in the latter stages of the three-day conference.

headline: SmithKline's Emerson Deal The SmithKline Beckman
abstract: Corporation, a diversified drug and health-care products company, said that it had agreed to sell its industrial products group to the Emerson Electric Company. SmithKline said Emerson would pay cash, but declined to say how much.

headline: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Technology; Network Links For Computers
abstract: M OST major computer manufacturers deny they are in the computer business any more. Instead, they profess to be leaders in the ''systems business,'' selling ''system solutions'' that insure customers will not be left with a bunch of disparate components, unable to communicate with one another.     Despite the reassuring words, however, the most promising systems for tying the hottest-selling desktop and personal computers into truly efficient ''networks'' are still on the electronic drawing board. ''It's one thing to provide people with the wires, the connectors and the jacks,'' said Dixon Doll, president of the DMW Group, a telecommunications consulting firm in Ann Arbor, Mich. ''People are just beginning to realize that these systems require a much higher level of coordination.'

headline: APPLE IS EXPECTING REBOUND IN PROFITS
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. expects its profits to begin rising again ''by the end of the year,'' John Sculley, president and chief executive, said today.    Mr. Sculley's projection drew cheers from many in the crowd of 2,500 shareholders at the annual meeting here. The company is counting heavily on a cluster of four new computers, including the much-discussed Macintosh personal computer, which it formally introduced at the meeting.

headline: SENATE DEFEATS ATTEMPTS TO LIMIT U.S. TROOP USE IN LATIN AMERICA
abstract: The Senate late tonight technically approved the Administration's request for $61.75 million in new military aid for El Salvador, but senators opposed to the bill were promised an opportunity next week to try to cut the aid and impose conditions on the package.    Early in the day of debate that preceded the vote, Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, took the floor to report a Defense Department response to his query about reports that on three occasions since November United States military training teams had come under fire in El Salvador.   Senator Sasser read the response, which said United States advisers in the eastern province of San Miguel came under hostile fire in November 1983 and again in March 1984, when ''a small group of insurgent forces attacked the camp but did not penetrate the perimeter.''   In February, the Pentagon continued, United States advisers at the La Union naval base ''received sporadic sniper fire.'' No adviser was hit in any of the incidents, the Pentagon said.

headline: G.M. SAYS CHANGES WILL TAKE A YEAR
abstract: The plan of the General Motors Corporation to reorganize its automotive operations into small-car and large-car groups will take about a year to accomplish, senior executives said today.    ''We hope to take over the manufacturing operations by the end of the year,'' said Robert C. Stempel, who heads the Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac group. He also said he expected that many decisions on dividing facilities among the groups would be made by June, and added that the transfer of authority would be ''pretty well complete'' by the end of the year.

headline: Quaker Oats Hires Its Ex-Account Supervisor
abstract: Charles E. Decker Jr., for a decade senior management supervisor on the Quaker Oats account at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, has been called by the company to be vice president-advertising for the domestic Grocery Products division starting May 1.     He will be replacing Elizabeth D. Harrington, who informed the company last month that she planned to resign, according to Quaker.    Mr. Decker most recently has been director of sports marketing of the Television Station Representatives, a subsidiary of Cox Broadcasting, New York.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: '14 Wonderful Years'    McCaffrey & McCall which is losing the J. C. Penney national advertising account to N.W. Ayer on Feb. 1, has done an unusual thing. It has taken the back page of the first section of The New York Times today for an ad headed, ''Thank you, J. C. Penney, for 14 wonderful years.'' It is used to list all of the agency's contributions to the client. Yesterday, David B. McCall, agency chairman, also circulated a memo to his people to inform them that while the account may in the future bill $60 million, at his agency it never reached $15 million and, in fact, was not even among the agency's top five accounts.

headline: The U.N. Today; Feb. 1, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Commission on Trade Law, Working Group on the New International Economic Order - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: IN CATALONIA, SCORN FOR MADRID, RESPECT FOR MONEY
abstract: The quarrel between Madrid and Barcelona runs deeper than New York-Washington. It predates Fort Worth-Dallas, is more heartfelt than Los Angeles-San Francisco.  It goes something like this: ''Barcelona has an opera house.'' ''Madrid has the Prado.''    ''In Barcelona, daily life is richer.''

headline: The U.N. Today; Jan. 20, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Parties to the international convention on elimination of all forms of discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Population Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Alcoa, Continental Halt Can Project
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America and the Continental Packaging Company U.S.A., a subsidiary of Continental Group Inc., said they were ending a joint development project designed to demonstrate the economic, technical and manufacturing feasibility of aluminum food cans.

headline: SMALLER CADILLAC MODELS ARE INTRODUCED BY G.M.
abstract: After months of delay caused by production problems, the General Motors Corporation today introduced the first of its new generation of smaller, front- wheel-drive luxury cars.    More than two feet shorter and almost 600 pounds lighter than their predecessors, the new Cadillac DeVille and Fleetwood models are being introduced at a time when larger cars have regained much of the popularity they had lost during the fuel shortage in 1979.   The new Cadillac models share the ''C'' body with the Oldsmobile 98 and Buick Electra models that are to be introduced later this year. All the models replace larger, rear-wheel- drive cars of the same names. However, the large Cadillac will be retained and renamed the Fleetwood Brougham.

headline: Comsat Rate Cut Sought
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission, continuing its bid to inject competition into the international communications field, moved today to force a reduction in the rates charged by the Communications Satellite Corporation, known as Comsat.

headline: Business and the Law; Antitrust Scene Stirs Questions
abstract: FOR decades the main purpose of antitrust law    has been to promote domestic competition   and efficiency. In recent years, however, its function has become increasingly blurred as exports have become more important to the American economy and world competitive conditions have been buffeted by the rise of protectionism and the introduction of floating currency rates.    As a result, business leaders, trade officials and legal authorities have begun to raise questions as to whether antitrust law needs to be updated.    The issue took on new urgency last month when the Justice Department's antitrust division said it would block, on anticompetitive grounds, a proposed merger of the beleaguered steel industry's third- and fourth-largest corporations - the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation.

headline: Ampco Vulcan Bid
abstract: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation said it had proposed to acquire Vulcan Inc. for $12 a share for all the shares it did not already own, or a total of about $22 million.

headline: Libyan Diplomat Shot By 2 Gunmen in Rome
abstract: Libya's top- ranking diplomat in Italy was shot and critically wounded today by two gunmen outside his home, the police said.

headline: Air Force Irish Contract
abstract: The Air Force today awarded a $150.8 million contract to Short Brothers Ltd. of Belfast, Northern Ireland, to supply and maintain for 10 years 18 cargo planes to move engines and other spare parts among United States bases in Western Europe.

headline: Nuts and Bolts
abstract: To the Editor:   Investment analysts and their customers are always searching for the quick solution, whether it be for cars, medicine or home entertainment. Thus, Michael Ward of Jesup & Lamont Securities is probably incorrect when he indicates that Nirvana has arrived with what you term the ''new sophistication that auto makers are building into their machines.''

headline: MESA BIDS TO RAISE GULF STAKE
abstract: In a move to put more pressure on the Gulf Oil Corporation, T. Boone Pickens, head of the Mesa Petroleum Company and of an investor group trying to take over Gulf, announced yesterday that his group would offer $65 a share for 13.5 million shares of Gulf and wage a proxy fight against Gulf's top management for control of the company.     He also announced that the Penn Central Company would invest $300 million in Mesa, thus helping the investor group to proceed with its offer. Drexel Burnham Lambert, an adviser to the group, is understood to have brought together Mr. Pickens and Carl H. Lindner, Penn Central's chairman and 23 percent owner, in the past month.    Mesa added that it would provide 73 percent, or $638 million, of the $877.5 million needed for the tender offer. The rest, it said, would come from other group members: Wagner & Brown of Midland, Tex.; Harbert International of Birmingham, Ala.; the Belzberg family of Canada, and the Sunshine Mining Company.

headline: Israel's Minister of Science Deplores Chemical Warfare
abstract: Israel's Minister of Science and Development says allegations of Iraqi use of chemical warfare against Iran should be of concern to Israelis.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Soap Opera Digest magazine increasing its circulation rate base 3.8 percent, to 675,000, from 650,000, and its advertising rates 8.5 percent, with the June 19 issue.     * Harcourt Brace Jovanovich is acquiring Industry Media's show management operations.

headline: MEXICO ASKS U.S. TO CHANGE POLICIES
abstract: President Miguel de la Madrid, expressing deep concern about the economic chaos and military violence in Latin America, has called on the United States to reappraise its policies for the region in 1984.    ''I feel that North-South relations on the American continent could seriously deteriorate,'' the Mexican President said.   ''I believe that if military violence increases we will not be able to solve the problem,'' Mr. de la Madrid said. ''It's going to grow and multiply. It's going to get out of control, with losses for all. First, for the Central American countries themselves, but also for the security of the hemisphere.''

headline: ARCO BID FOR GULF REPORTED
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company has offered to buy the Gulf Oil Corporation for up to $70 a share, or $11.6 billion, Wall Street executives disclosed yesterday.     Gulf is said to have rejected the idea, at least at this early stage. If the deal took place, it would be the biggest corporate merger in history - bigger than the pending $10.1 billion takeover of the Getty Oil Company by Texaco Inc. Neither Atlantic Richfield nor Gulf could be reached for comment on the holiday yesterday.    The deal would also make Atlantic Richfield, known as Arco, into the nation's fourth-largest oil company, after the Exxon Corporation, the Mobil Corporation and a merged Texaco-Getty. Atlantic Richfield and Gulf had combined sales of nearly $55 billion in 1982, the latest year for which comparable figures are available.

headline: Chilean Exile Is Suicide
abstract: A Chilean seeking refugee status committed suicide before he was to testify at an immigration hearing. The Chilean, Raul Rivadeneira, hanged himself on Monday and left a note asking that his lawyer, John House, send his belongings to his wife and four- year-old son in Chile. Mr. House said Mr. Rivadeneira was dreading the prospect of recounting the torture he was subjected to after being arrested during the military coup in 1973.

headline: AFTER 5 YEARS, U.N. LEBANON FORCE HAS AIR OF PERMANENCE
abstract: The United Nations force that came to Lebanon's southern hills in 1978 was called an interim unit.    Over five years later, it is still here and it has taken on an air of permanence, comfortable in its surroundings, at ease with its mission.   Suggestions that the force be moved to the ravaged urban canyons of Beirut, as currently being discussed at the United Nations Security Council, inevitably raise the question: What would happen in southern Lebanon if the United Nations reduced its presence here to send troops into the capital?   Fear for U.N. Enclave    One fear is that the United Nations enclave in the area - a relatively peaceful place - might again fall prey to forces out to expand their areas of influence, such as the Israeli-backed militiamen being recruited from the local Shiite Moslem population.    ''I think the local people would be very sorry to see us go,'' said Commandant Pat O'Sullivan, the spokesman for the 645-man Irish contingent that is part of the 5,800 troops from 10 nations currently attached to what is officially called the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon. ''They are probably more worried about us going to Beirut than anyone else.''

headline: Paris Gives Tunis Food Aid
abstract: France signed agreements today to give $67.5 million worth of wheat and credit to Tunisia, a former French colony where an estimated 200 people were killed in bread riots last month. France agreed to provide 40,000 tons of wheat, valued at nearly $5 million, $48 million worth of credit to buy French farm products and $14.5 million in loans at 3 percent interest, payable over 25 years.

headline: Hiller Chapter 11
abstract: Hiller Aviation Inc. said that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws and that almost all its employees had been terminated, effective Friday.

headline: Kremlin's Warning to Turkey Brings Response on Missiles
abstract: The Soviet Union has told Turkey that its increased military cooperation with the United States ''is creating a threat again Russia'' and has asked whether Turkey is considering installing cruise or Pershing missiles on its soil, according to Turkish press reports.   In response to the reports, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Nazmi Akiman, said on Thursday that ''Turkey does not want any missiles on its soil.''

headline: Arafat in Iraq for Talks
abstract: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived here today for talks with President Saddam Hussein.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  American Management Systems Inc., Washington, a computer systems and consulting company, has appointed Paul Oliver a vice president.

headline: Toyo Kogyo Study Of U.S. Plant Sites
abstract: The Toyo Kogyo Company, which makes Mazda cars, said today that it is studying three locations in the United States where it may establish auto manufacturng operations.    Yoshiki Yamasaki, Toyo Kogyo's president, said the company would operate the plant on its own, without any connection to the Ford Motor Company, which owns 25 percent of Toyo Kogyo's stock.

headline: Microdot Sold By Northwest
abstract: Northwest Industries, a holding company based in Chicago   that makes industrial products,   said it had sold its Microdot   Inc. unit for $121 million to a   group of investors headed by   Richard P. Strubel, who had   been Northwest's president. The sale of Microdot, which   provides connecting devices for   the automotive, aerospace and   appliance industries, is part of   the initial phase of Northwest's   previously announced restructuring.

headline: American Envoy, Just Back, Meets Gromyko in Moscow
abstract: The American Ambassador to Moscow, Arthur A. Hartman, just back here from talks in Washington on the new leadership in the Kremlin, met today with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko.   The official press agency Tass, which said the meeting was held at Mr. Hartman's request, said it had not indicated any shift in American attitudes that would be more acceptable to Moscow.

headline: Market Place
abstract: Magellan Fund And Its Record      MANY money managers have been selling stocks in recent months to raise cash, often disposing of their more poorly performing issues. But Peter Lynch, portfolio manager of the Fidelity Magellan Fund in Boston, takes the opposite tack: selling stocks whose prices have held up and buying other equities on the way down.   ''Every week I come to work I keep buying stocks that are cheaper,'' he said yesterday in an interview. ''It's like shopping in Filene's basement.''

headline: DOW POSTS SHARP DROP OF 10.57, TO 1,150.13
abstract: Stock prices took another beating yesterday in holiday-slowed trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping sharply and closing at its lowest level in 10 months.    The Dow average ended off 10.57 points, to 1,150.13, as late bargain- hunting erased some of the earlier losses in the depressed blue-chip group. The average had been down almost 17 points at 3 P.M., The close was the lowest in the 30-stock average since April 12, 1983, when it finished at 1,145.32.   The general market was also hard- hit, with declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscoring those that rose by almost a 3-to-1 ratio.

headline: Nonaligned Group Backs 'Information Order'
abstract: The information ministers of the movement of nations professing nonalignment complained today of what they described as hostile propaganda by industrial countries against the 101-nation organization and called for ''a new world information order.''   A declaration approved by a five-day conference, in which 57 countries took part, called on member nations to refuse to allow their press installations to be used for unfavorable reports.   In a separate ''Jakarta appeal,'' the ministers called on the press not to report any news detrimental to the interests of member nations and to avoid all ''tendentious reporting.''

headline: Israel's Rules On Investing
abstract: A spokesman for the Bank of Israel said today that under currency restrictions imposed   Monday, it will not be necessary   for Israelis to repatriate some  $700 million invested in securities abroad. Instead, no new investments will be allowed.

headline: Packwood's Phone Measure
abstract: Senator Bob Packwood, backed by a coalition of consumer groups, vowed today to seek further delay in the introduction of so-called access charges on telephone users.    The Oregon Republican, who is sponsoring a bill to ban such fees for two years, said at a news conference that he did not trust the Federal Communications Commission to block the fees until Congress had reviewed them.

headline: SHIITE AND DRUSE MEET WITH SYRIANS
abstract: Lebanon's Shiite Moslem and Druse leaders met here today with Syrian officials to plan political and military strategy after President Hafez al-Assad's rejection of a Saudi-backed peace plan.    Nabih Berri, leader of the Amal Shiite Moslem organization, and Walid Jumblat, the Lebanese Druse leader, met together privately first and then separately with Syrian leaders in talks on the latest situation in Lebanon.   Mr. Berri said the Lebanese had discussed security matters inside West Beirut, the predominantly Moslem sector that is now under the control of Shiite and Druse militiamen.

headline: LIBYAN CHARGED IN LONDON BLASTS
abstract: Charges were filed today against a Libyan businessman and three other people in connection with a series of weekend bombings that investigators said were directed at critics of Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.   Scotland Yard said that the businessman, Ali el-Giahour, 44 years old, had been charged with conspiracy in connection with bombings that wounded 23 people in London, and that seven other Libyans had been detained for questioning.   In Manchester, the police said three people had been charged with two bombings at a Manchester apartment complex that injured a Syrian couple and their child. The police refused to identify the defendants, but said they were scheduled to appear in court Wednesday on charges of causing an explosion with intent to endanger life.

headline: U.S. MAY DEFY '79 ARMS PACT TERMS
abstract: The State Department left open the possibility today that the United States might decide not to abide by the limits set in the 1979 strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union.   In a statement issued in response to testimony given by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, the department said the Administration had not yet decided what to do when the scheduled sea trials of the seventh Trident-class submarine would give the United States more multiheaded missiles than permitted under the 1979 treaty.   Until now, the Reagan Administration has been adhering to a policy of not undercutting any arms accord even if, in the 1979 pact, it has not been ratified or, in the first arms pact of 1972, it has long since expired.   The State Department said United States policy was set by President Reagan in 1982 when he stated: ''As for existing strategic arms agreements, we will refrain from actions which undercut them so long as the Soviet Union shows equal restraint.''

headline: Lakeside Games
abstract: Some of the troops from Scott Lancaster Mills Atha, a Los Angeles ad agency, were in town for the Toy Fair, since they service Tyco Industries and Gund Inc., maker of stuffed toys.

headline: TRUDEAU HAILS SESSION WITH CHERNENKO
abstract: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau says his talks with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the new Soviet leader, suggested that Moscow might be prepared to accept the Canadian leader's proposal that the five major nuclear powers meet to discuss arms reductions.    The Prime Minister said Mr. Chernenko had commended his disarmament initiative for ''its usefulness and practicality,''   ''Obviously, the initiative begins to live,'' Mr. Trudeau said Wednesday at a news conference in Moscow after meeting with Mr. Chernenko.   In Canada and elsewhere, Mr. Trudeau's disarmament effort has been criticized for reasons ranging from suggestions of political motivations by his ailing Liberal Party to suggestions that Mr. Trudeau is trying to win a Nobel Peace Prize as the cap to a long political career. In the face of such criticisms, the Moscow trip was hailed by Government officials today as a substantive accomplishment.

headline: FRANCE IS MOVING 25% OF ITS TROOPS AWAY FROM BEIRUT
abstract: France announced today that it would remove about 25 percent of its troops serving with the four-nation force here.    The announcement, made simultaneously here and in Paris, added to the nervousness of Lebanese in the capital about the future of the Western presence that is supposed to guarantee their security.   An official statement said that at the end of the month, 482 troops from the 1,750-strong French contingent would be withdrawn from Beirut and returned to French positions with the United Nations force in southern Lebanon.   No Full Pullout, France Says    The reduction, a French spokesman in Beirut said, will not affect the overall number of French soldiers in Lebanon, but the force in Beirut will be cut back by a quarter. The spokesman denied that the move was the precursor of a complete French pullout from the multinational force, also made up of troops from the United States, Britain and Italy.

headline: Canteen's Chief Adjusts To Industrial Change
abstract: With changes in industrial America, the Canteen Corporation has had to look for new mouths to feed. The task has now fallen to Robert A. Kozlowski, who took over Jan. 1 as president and chief executive, succeeding James T. McGuire, who retired at 65.     Canteen, the new chief executive said, has been in business for 54 years selling the four C's: candy, cigarettes, cold beverages and coffee.

headline: IRAQ SAYS ITS FORCES SET FOUR SHIPS ABLAZE IN GULF BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 29 (AP) - A military spokesman said today that Iraqi warplanes and naval vessels had set four ships on fire in an attack at dawn off the Iranian coast at the head of the Persian Gulf.
abstract: The spokesman said Iraqi jets later shot down two Iranian helicopters that had been sent to rescue the crews of the stricken ships, which he identified only as ''enemy naval targets.''   (A Greek shipping company in Athens said, according to Reuters, that its 16,230-ton freighter Iapetos was set on fire at the head of the gulf when a missile struck its engine room and it was bombed from the air. A spokesman for the Stravelakis Company said the 16-member crew abandoned ship and was picked up by a tug.)

headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Stocks Don't Follow Script
abstract: T HE stock market is rapidly rewriting its   script for 1984, a year that generally had been   expected to send equity prices aloft in a renewed burst of investor enthusiasm. After all, this is only the second year of the economic recovery, corporate profits are rising and consumer price inflation has slowed to its lowest rate since 1972.    Moreover, historical precedent indicates that Presidential election years are good for stock prices.    ''The market shifted back into high gear in the early days of the new year,'' the Merrill Lynch Market Letter noted in the second week of January. ''The move could carry the Dow Jones industrials to the low to mid-1,300's, perhaps higher, if issues advancing continue to outnumber declines by wide margins.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Coleco Industries, West Hartford, Conn., a manufacturer of toys and games, has promoted Ralph Lancellotti to vice president-sales.     *  David's Cookies has appointed Stephen A. Stein president and chief operating officer and Harvey Kleinman chief financial officer.     *  Morrison-Knudsen Co., Boise, Idaho, which has construction, engineering and shipbuilding interests, has promoted R. Brien Goodale to vice president of operations, Buildings Group; William A. Hughes to vice president of construction, Power Group; Donald R. Rathburn to vice president of marketing, Mining Group, and David O. Snyder to vice president of operations, Mining Group.

headline: Verbatim Corp. Sees Profit Drop SUNNYVALE, Calif., Jan. 3 (Reuters) - The Verbatim Corporation said results for the fiscal second quarter, ended Saturday, will not be as high as had been forecast Dec. 2. The company said that sales for the quarter, while up substantially from last year, will be below those of the first quarter, and that earnings will trail those of the period a year earlier.
abstract: Verbatim, which develops, manufactures and sells removable magnetic data-storage products, had forecast that profits for the quarter would increase 30 percent. The company said the principal reason for the expected drop in sales was a large product return from a major customer. Verbatim was the most active issue and biggest percentage loser on the American Stock Exchange today, plunging $3.25, to $13.75, on a volume of 730,500.

headline: 2 Bombings in Colombia
abstract: A bomb destroyed the local headquarters of Colombia's opposition party on Friday, nine days before elections that Marxist guerrillas have threatened to disrupt.

headline: EX-IM BANK IS OFFERING 2D MAJOR LOAN SUBSIDY
abstract: The Export-Import Bank, in a departure from the early emphasis of the Reagan Administration, announced today for the second time in two weeks the approval of a heavily subsidized loan to help an American company compete in a foreign market.    The Government agency, stepping up a campaign against what it portrayed as ''predatory export financing by France,'' said it had offered highly subsidized credits to a prospective buyer of American digital switching equipment in Cyprus to help a Florida supplier beat the French competition.    The action, the second aimed at France in nine days, was meant ''to discourage such future action by foreign governments,'' said the bank's president, William H. Draper 3d. ''We are hoping to raise the threshold of pain,'' he added in an interview.

headline: CSX Aide to Step Down
abstract: The CSX Corporation said today that Dennis R. Hendrix, its vice chairman, plans to resign next month to pursue other business interests.

headline: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2.7 BILLION
abstract: The Federal Reserve System reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply declined by $2.7 billion in the week ended Jan. 18, exceeding the $1 billion to $2 billion decline the markets had expected.     As a result, bond prices rose and interest rates on short-term securities dropped immediately after the Fed's report. The Government's bellwether 30-year bond rose a sixteenth of a point, to 102 12/32, from 102 8/32 before the money-supply number was announced. The yield dropped to 11.70 percent, from 11.72 percent.

headline: SYRIANS TAKE JACKSON T SEE CAPTURED U.S. FLIER
abstract: Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., the United States Navy flier being held captive here, met today with the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, the Democratic presidential aspirant. Mr. Jackson arrived Friday on what he said was an humanitarian mission to gain the flier's release.    Lieutenant Goodman spent nearly an hour with Mr. Jackson, his party and a group of reporters. He said that, while he was being treated well, what he really needed was ''a plane ticket home.''

headline: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 5
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PANHANDLE EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, MARCH 23, 1984   The Economy    Factory orders for durable goods fell 1.2 percent in February, the first decline in seven months. But analysts said that, amid the many recent signs of strength in the economy, the Commerce Department report should not be read as an indication that expansion had stalled. Much of the decline came in orders for steel and other metals, though those for household goods also slid. (Page D1.)

headline: Ugandan Guerrillas Free 9
abstract: Nine Red Cross volunteers have been freed by the Ugandan guerrillas who abducted them but two others are still being held, Red Cross sources said today. Freed in Uganda were three Swiss nationals and six Ugandans, who were kidnapped Saturday in the Mpigi district in southern Uganda, the sources said. A French doctor and a Ugandan Red Cross worker were reportedly still being held.

headline: DURABLE ORDERS FELL LAST MONTH
abstract: The Government reported today that factory orders for durable goods fell in February for the first time in seven months, but analysts said the 1.2 percent decline was not a sign that the economic recovery had stalled.   The Commerce Department reported that new orders for durable goods - defined as products expected to last three or more years - fell $1.2 billion in February, to $99.7 billion.    Much of the decline came from an 8.8 percent decline in orders for steel and other primary metals, a category that rose sharply in January. Orders for household goods also fell - by a sharp 11.8 percent - in a possible indication that pent-up consumer demand dating back to the recession has been largely satisfied.

headline: CITY HOUSING COSTS TURN BUILDER TO JERSEY PROJECT
abstract: After a series of renovations throughout Manhattan, Herbert I. Handman is building his first new apartment house. It is a condominium called Handman House, at 22 West 66th Street.    The buyers he has in mind for the customized apartments in this slim, 25-story tower are people ready to pay about $400 a square foot. They can buy either a full floor of about 2,300 square feet - about $920,000 - or half a floor. Half a floor is enough for a two-bedroom apartment that is on the generous side by recent Manhattan standards.

headline: Dow Up 1.57 to 1,213.88; Volume Is Still Heavy
abstract: The stock market was up yesterday, managing one of its few gains in recent weeks. The rise was modest, but trading continued to be heavy.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved mostly in a narrow price range throughout the session, closed up 1.57 points, to 1,213.88.

headline: QUAKER STATE BUYS BACK SHARES FROM RELIANCE
abstract: The Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation announced yesterday that it had purchased 1,962,100 shares, or 8.9 percent, of its own common stock from the Reliance Financial Services Corporation for $24 a share, or a total of $47.1 million.    Reliance Financial Services is a unit of Reliance Group Holdings, a closely held insurance and financial conglomerate led by Saul P. Steinberg, a New York investor. James Fingeroth of Kekst & Company, the public relations firm for Reliance, confirmed the transaction but would not elaborate.

headline: ON GRENADA, SOUNDING OFF AGAIN IN PRINT
abstract: -    ''Dear Editor: I have read the first two issues of The Grenadian Voice and I will never read this paper again.''   ''Dear Editor: I am very apprehensive about the future of Grenada.''   ''Dear Editor: For quite some time now I have been experiencing problems with the Grenada Electricity Services Ltd.''   After years of control under the leftist Government that ended with an American-led invasion on Oct. 25, the people of Grenada are sounding off again in The Grenadian Voice, a revived, low- budget weekly newspaper.

headline: NICARAGUAN REBELS PREDICT SUCCESS WITH U.S. AID
abstract: Leaders of guerrillas fighting the Nicaraguan Government said in interviews over the weekend that with the help of continued aid from the United States, they can bring down the Government in 1984.    Adolfo Calero Portocarrero, leader of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, which is the largest of the rebel groups and is estimated to have as many as 8,000 men under arms, praised the report of the Kissinger commission. The commission, headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, indirectly endorsed United States aid to Nicaraguan rebels and the pressure to negotiate that the commission said the rebels were putting on the Sandinista Government.

headline: Market Place; Gold Investing In Deficit Era
abstract: THE Mercantile Safe Deposit and Trust Company of Baltimore has been moving a bit of its    money under management into gold investments. ''It's an insurance policy in the event nothing is clarified about the Federal budget deficit,'' said James D. Hardesty, chief investment officer of the trust division.   As the oldest and largest trust company in Maryland, Mercantile manages $2.5 billion in personal trust accounts and $1.1 billion for institutions, mainly pension funds. ''Gold investments are in the form of bullion for personal trust accounts and in North American mining stocks for the institutions,'' the money manager said. ''I don't think it's going to happen, but in a 'worst case' scenario you could see gold reaching $600 an ounce later this year, compared with its recent price around $400.''

headline: INTEREST RATES DOWN SLIGHTLY
abstract: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday.     Securities dealers said prices were supported by a major buying program of the Southern California Public Power Authority, which was buying $1 billion of Treasury securities due in four years or less.    Earlier this month, the California authority sold $1 billion of notes and bonds to help finance construction of electric power lines connecting power plants of the Intermountain Power Agency in central Utah with cities in southern California.   The Treasury Department and the Internal Revenue Service frown on purchases of high-yielding Treasury securities by local authorities who have just sold tax-exempt bonds at lower interest rates, but such buying is permissible within limits.

headline: LIBYAN INFLUENCE SAID TO GROW IN NORTH CHAD
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi appears to have begun a campaign to ''Libyanize'' the occupied north of Chad, according to refugees, Western diplomats and Chadian officials.    The Libyan leader has insisted that there is no Libyan military presence in northern Chad, but Western journalists have not been allowed to travel to the area, which is in the Sahara.   Libyan troops, in conjunction with Chadian rebels under the command of former President Goukouni Oueddei, have been in control of the northern third of Chad since August, when they seized Faya-Largeau and Fada.

headline: Mutiny Is Reported Among Afghan Troops
abstract: A Western diplomat said here today that Afghan soldiers had mutinied in and around Kabul, fought their officers and defected in large numbers to Moslem guerrillas in a revolt against a Government decision to increase their period of military service.   The report followed diplomatic assessments last week that spoke of spreading anger among Afghan soldiers in the capital over the order which extends military service for troops based in Kabul from the current three years to four years.

headline: Advertising; Business Flier Star For Braniff
abstract: T HE business traveler, generally   male and much beloved by airlines, car rental companies and hotel chains, will be very much the star of the N. W. Ayer advertising for the resuscitated Braniff, which is due to rise again March 1.    Braniff Inc., now a division of the Hyatt Corporation, is no longer a multihued international carrier, but has adorned its 30 Boeing 727's with a new logotype in red, white and blue.   Ayer is confident that Braniff's new association with Hyatt will help restore some confidence in the airline among the travel trade.

headline: MRS. THATCHER CALLS FOR DEBATE ON WELFARE STATE
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Friday that Britain was sitting on a ''social-security time bomb'' and that she therefore felt it essential to reconsider the whole web of public benefits built up since the end of World War II.   Excepting only some system of basic pensions and a National Health Service of some kind, though not necessarily like the present one, she argued that it was time to begin a public debate on the structure and financing of the welfare state. She said she was looking for ''as many views and disapassionate assessments'' as she could obtain.   The Prime Minister's comments were certain to provoke criticism from the opposition Labor Party, which enacted many of the public benefits into law and defends them fiercely. But she said it was no use for her political and press foes to shout ''scandalous'' every time she proposed change. ''It would be absolutely scandalous if seeing these great problems coming I do nothing about them now,'' she said.

headline: TOXINS ARE REPORTED IN IRAN TESTS
abstract: Laboratory tests show that Iranians fighting in the war with Iraq have been exposed to mustard gas and ''yellow rain,'' according to a doctor treating wounded Iranians.   The doctor, Dr. Herbert Mandl, said that tests by the Toxicological Institute in Ghent, Belgium, revealed ''with certain proof'' the presence of mycotoxins, sometimes referred to as yellow rain, and mustard gas.

headline: BANKS ADD SEABROOK DEMANDS
abstract: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire said yesterday that the commercial banks providing short-term loans for constructing Unit 1 of the Seabrook nuclear power project had demanded that the utility find back-up sources of credit.    The banks said they sought the plan in case the company became ''unable to access the public securities market for any significant period.''   The move appeared to reflect growing uneasiness in the financial community over whether Seabrook 1 will ever be completed. It came only a day after the company yielded to pressure from its consortium partners by conditionally agreeing to scrap Unit 2 if they will meet its demands.

headline: U.S. COMBAT UNITS BEGIN PULLING OUT OF BEIRUT BUNKERS
abstract: The first combat unit of United States Marines withdrew from Lebanese soil today, moving to American ships offshore.   As night fell, the state-run Beirut radio and Lebanese Army officials said American naval guns had opened fire on Syrian positions in the mountains east of the capital.  (Page 12.)   (In Washington, a Defense Department spokesman said the destroyer Caron fired 90 five-inch shells in response to two separate artillery attacks against marines still on the ground.   (Lieut. Col. Bill Hudson, the spokesman, said the ''hostile artillery fire ceased immediately after receiving the return fire.''

headline: ISRAELI ARABS TAKE COMPLAINTS TO PRIME MINISTER
abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir met today with a group of Israel's Arab citizens who complained to him of unequal treatment by the Government and violence by militant Jews.   Mr. Shamir's adviser on Arab affairs, Benyamin Goor Aryeh, said that it was the first meeting on such a scale with an Israeli Prime Minister and that others would follow.   The 27 Israeli Arabs, including 15 mayors and religious, educational and social leaders, told Mr. Shamir that Israel's 17 percent Arab population felt isolated and neglected, said the Mayor of Baka el Garbia, Samir Darwish.

headline: CHINESE PREMIER ON U.S. VISIT
abstract: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China arrived in the United States today to begin a long-awaited visit that both Peking and Washington hope will ease nagging tensions between them and strengthen trade relations.   On the eve of his visit, however, China warned that Mr. Zhao will do no ''kowtowing'' and cautioned American officials to avoid pushing Peking into a reluctant rapprochement with the Soviet Union.   Mr. Zhao, who was to visit Hawaii for 26 hours, will meet Tuesday with President Reagan in Washington and will visit San Francisco and New York before going on to Canada Jan. 17.

headline: JAPAN SEES U.S. ROLE AS EXPERTS
abstract: The most likely role for American representatives in the advisory councils that guide Japan's industrial policy will be as expert witnesses, Japanese officials said today.    The Ministry of International Trade and Industry has agreed in principle to give United States representatives access to the advisory groups, which shape legislation and policy concerning trade and industry.

headline: Market PlaceSpotlight On Takeovers
abstract: T AKEOVERS and rumors of takeovers are instilling life into the stock market these days,   providing investors and speculators alike with some relief from worries over the Federal budget deficit and the possibility of rising interest rates.    Thanks to a good showing on Friday, the market posted its second consecutive weekly advance. The Dow Jones industrial average finished at 1,171.48, up 6.38 points on the week. For the year so far, the indicator is down by 6.92 percent, while the transportation average is off 13.03 percent. But even transportation issues moved ahead last week.

headline: A Premier of Bangladesh Named by Military Ruler
abstract: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the nation's military ruler, today appointed the leader of a small political party as the Prime Minister.   An official announcement said the appointment of the politician, Ataur Rahman Khan, was effective immediately, although he will be formally sworn in on Friday.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  H.F. Ahmanson & Co., a Los Angeles-based holding company for thrift and insurance institutions, said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Sooner Federal Savings and Loan Association of Tulsa, Okla., in an exchange of stock.     *  American Brands Inc.  said its Franklin Life Insurance Co. unit had completed the purchase of Southland Financial Corp.'s Southland Life Insurance Co. subsidiary for $352 million.     *  Big Bite Inc.  said that it had closed its five remaining Big Bite restaurants in the Columbus, Ohio, area, and that it anticipates ''significant'' fourth-quarter writeoffs.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH THE KING OF JORDAN
abstract: Following are excerpts from a transcript of an interview today with King Hussein of Jordan, as recorded by The New York Times:    HUSSEIN: The whole situation is hopeless because it just appears more clearly than ever before that the United States has forsaken its position as a superpower and as a moral defender of the world. It has forsaken its position as a nation that stands by its word and its commitments. It has chosen to disqualify itself as the sole force in the area that could help us all move towards a just and durable peace. The U.S. is not free to move except within the limits of what Aipac, the Zionists and the State of Israel determine for it.   Q. Was it the American withdrawal from Lebanon that persuaded you that the U.S. was no longer reliable as an honest broker?

headline: Polaroid Net Rises Sharply
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation said today that net income in the fourth quarter more than doubled, to $25.3 million, or 82 cents a share, from $9.6 million, or 31 cents. Sales slipped to $391.7 million, from $392.7 million.

headline: Productivity Rate Rose At Slow 1% in Quarter WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) - Productivity in nonfarm private businesses grew at a slow annual rate of 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1983, the Labor Department said today.
abstract: But for the full year, productivity rose 3.1 percent, the biggest one-year rise since that of 3.2 percent in 1976, the department added.    The 3.1 percent increase for the full year reflected a 4.4 percent rise in output and a 1.2 percent increase in the hours of all workers.

headline: Texas Utility Debt
abstract: Ratings Lowered    Standard & Poor's reduced the ratings on more than $2.5 billion of debt of the Texas Utilities Electric Company. It is a subsidiary of the Texas Utilities Company and consists of the old Dallas Power and Light, Texas Power and Light and Texas Electric Service utilities.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: POLISH PRIMATE SAYS REMARKS ON WALESA WERE MISUNDERSTOOD
abstract: The head of Poland's Roman Catholic Church, who was quoted by a Brazilian newspaper as saying that the Solidarity union ''no longer defends the working class,'' said today that the paper had misinterpreted his comments.   An interview published Friday by the newspaper, O Estado of Sao Paulo, also quoted the Polish primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, as saying that ''half'' of the outlawed union's 10 million members ''belong to the Communist Party, which means that its ideals are not the same as the church.'' He was also said to have called Solidarity's founder, Lech Walesa, ''an independent who has been manipulated and who has lost control'' of the union to Marxists and Trotskyists.

headline: MONEY SUPPLY HELD ON TARGET
abstract: The Federal Reserve yesterday published revised money supply data for the last 16 months showing that the average level for all three closely watched money supply measures in January fell within its targets.     The money supply data had little effect in the credit markets, however, where prices fell for the sixth consecutive day, with some long-term issues dropping by 3/4 point.    ''It was a simple case of too few buyers for too many bonds,'' said the head of government securities trading at one New York firm. By late in the day, short-term rates were unchanged to higher by five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, while prices were lower by 3/8 to 3/4 point for Treasury issues due in five years and more.

headline: STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL SCORNS 'OUR EUROPEAN FRIENDS'
abstract: A senior State Department official accused the West European allies today of practicing a ''blame America first syndrome'' in relations with the United States.   The official, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, addressing the National Association of Newspaper Editors in a speech on alliance relations, was particularly caustic toward the Europeans for their response to the American-led invasion of Grenada last October.   He said that, two years ago, the British clash with Argentina over the Falkland Islands ''posed for the United States a more difficult choice than most Europeans yet recognize.''

headline: BRAZILIANS ARE BUYING GUNS IN FACE OF A RISING CRIME WAVE
abstract: An upsurge in crime spurred by a Brazilian economic crisis is frightening people in Rio and Sao Paulo to the point that many are buying guns and guard dogs or hiring bodyguards.   ''Everyone, including me, is scared stiff with all the violence, and I think it is time we start protecting and defending ourselves,'' said Jezebel Tirico Vargas, 26 years old, as she examined her newly purchased gun at a Sao Paulo department store.   Statistics vary, but a recent Gallup survey of 1,207 people in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo found that four of every 10 people had been victims of crime at least once.

headline: ISRAELIS SAY REDEPLOYMENT ISN'T WITHDRAWAL
abstract: Israel is planning to thin out its forces in southern Lebanon and redeploy them away from large urban headquarters as a way of presenting less of a target to guerrillas, well-placed officials said today. But they denied reports that the Israeli Army was prepared to withdraw entirely without a reciprocal Syrian pullout.    The officials said Israel's formal position remained unchanged: Its troops will leave Lebanon as all Palestinians and Syrian forces leave. Syria has not agreed to withdraw.

headline: HOUSTON GAS RAISES COASTAL BID
abstract: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said last night that it was prepared to offer $50 a share, or $1.1 billion in cash, for the Coastal Corporation if Coastal withdrew its offer to seek a controlling interest in Houston Natural Gas.    Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., chairman of Coastal, said last night that that would not deter Coastal's bid.    Coastal, which owns 5 percent of Houston Natural Gas, has offered $68 a share for 18.75 million shares more, which would give it a controlling interest of 50.7 percent. It also offered $60 a share in unidentified securities for the balance. But without details, Wall Street analysts tentatively valued the securities at about $55 a share.

headline: DIRT AND DENIM: YOUTH'S ECONOMIC INDEX
abstract: GROWING up in Bethlehem, Pa., in the early 30's, I learned a couple of economic indexes that I've never seen mentioned in the financial pages of any newspapers: the windowsill index and the denim- fade index. Reading of the layoffs in the American steel industry during the recent recession brought them back to me with the bittersweet nostalgia of a good childhood remembered with almost painful clarity.   Our home in Bethlehem on East Fourth Street was on the right side of the tracks, but just barely: Just beyond our back fence were the tracks of the Lehigh Valley Rail Road. Three blocks away was Bethlehem Steel. My mother's housekeeping chores included a daily assault with dustcloths and a monthly wash of all the curtains.

headline: Iran Again Threatens To Shut Off Oil Flow
abstract: The President of Iran, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, said Thursday that his country would stop the oil flow from the Persian Gulf to the West if the United States became actively involved in the Iran-Iraq war, the Iranian press agency reported.   The agency dispatch, received in London, quoted President Khamenei as having made the threat in an address at an air force fighter base in southeastern Iran.
