headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: Murdoch Seeks List Of Warner Holders       By The Associated Press    Rupert Murdoch asked Warner Communications Inc. for a list of its shareholders to help him decide whether to pursue a proxy contest for control of Warner, one of Mr. Murdoch's companies disclosed yesterday.   Mr. Murdoch, the Australian publisher, already owns about 7 percent of Warner's voting stock and has threatened to start a proxy battle for control of the entertainment and consumer electronics concern.

headline: Demand Helps Sweden
abstract: Strong demand for floating-rate notes in the Eurobond market has allowed Sweden to sell a $500 million issue with the longest maturity ever seen in the Euromarket and with a much lower interest rate than it paid last October.    A reduction in syndicated bank loans has caused many investors such as banks, to invest in floating-rate note issues this year, analysts said.

headline: MARCH 1-10 AUTO SALES ROSE 31.5%
abstract: The nation's six major auto makers reported today that sales in the March 1-10 period surged 31.5 percent from a year earlier, continuing the stronger- than-expected pace that has prevailed since December.   Analysts and industry executives said the early-March figures showed that sales could be expected to remain strong for the remainder of the model year.    The companies - General Motors, Ford, Chrysler, American Motors, Volkswagen of America and American Honda - said they sold 211,240 cars in the period, which had nine selling days this year and last, when they sold 160,617.   The seasonally adjusted annual sales rate was 8.1 million domestic units in the period. Most analysts had expected sales in the first quarter of about 7.5 to 7.8 million domestically produced units, but an 8.3 million rate for the month of January and an 8.5 million rate in February caused some to revise their forecasts for the year and brought about some minor adjustments in production schedules by the manufacturers for the second quarter.

headline: Argentine Government Forces General to Quit
abstract: Argentina's two-month-old civilian Government forced an outspoken air force general into retirement today.   The Defense Ministry announced that Brig. Gen. Alberto Simari, the air force's instruction commander, had presented his resignation and that it had been accepted immediately.

headline: Greyhound's Net Up 2.5%
abstract: The Greyhound Corporation, operator of the nation's largest bus system, said fourth-quarter earnings edged up 2.5 percent, to $24.2 million, or 49 cents a share, from $23.6 million, or 54 cents, a year earlier.

headline: European Oil Stock Plan
abstract: The European Commission is to invite major oil traders and oil companies to participate in a proposed plan to report on European stocks of crude oil and oil products on a monthly basis, officials here said today.

headline: Business and the Law; Commercial Free Speech
abstract: F REEDOM of speech means different things to    different people. To Christopher L. Lowe, it   means the right to publish his three investment-advice newsletters. From 1977 to 1982, Mr. Lowe was convicted of misappropriating funds, passing bad checks and tampering with evidence, and the Securities and Exchange Commission revoked his registration under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and ordered him to stop putting out his newsletters. The agency issued the order even though it conceded he was not giving false or misleading advice.

headline: Interest Rates
abstract: To the Editor:   In the Jan. 22 Letters column, James L. Kochan presents strong evidence of the demand-side pressures on interest rates. However, Mr. Kochan's argument that financial deregulation is     not  a factor in determining the current level of interest rates is less than convincing. His primary target is interest rate ceilings; he does not examine the impact of NOW and Super NOW accounts on the cost of funds.

headline: BEIRUT GUNMEN BADLY WOUND FRENCH ATTACHE
abstract: A carload of unidentified gunmen shot a French cultural attache four times today as he was walking to work in West Beirut.    The French diplomat, Sauveur Gliozzo, was in serious condition at the American University Hospital here after he was struck in the chest, leg, side and stomach. One of the bullets also grazed his head.   Witnesses said the shots were fired from a car by three men who used pistols with silencers. No one took responsibility for the shooting, which came as French troops from the multinational force continued to withdraw from Beirut.

headline: Waffen SS Veterans Plan West German Reunion
abstract: The town director here said today that 800 veterans of Hitler's elite Waffen SS were planning a reunion at this vacation spa, where the event was billed as a conference of economic experts.   ''We are doing everything possible to stop this meeting from going ahead,'' the town director, Horst Voigt, said in an interview.

headline: ISRAELI QUITS CABINET IN A POLICY DISPUTE
abstract: An Israeli Cabinet Minister resigned today, citing disagreements with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's policies on Lebanon and the economy and the failure to form a national unity government.   The resignation of Mordechai Ben Porat, a Minister Without Portfolio, which becomes effective Tuesday, raises new questions about Mr. Shamir's parlimentary majority.   The governing Likud coalition currently has an eight-seat edge in the 120- seat Parliament, 64 to 56. Last Wednesday, the Government survived three no-confidence motions by successive votes of 62 to 56.

headline: THE MARINE MOVE MAY TAKE A MONTH
abstract: White House and Defense Department officials said tonight that it might take as long as one month for American marines to turn over the task of guarding the Beirut airport to the Lebanese Army before redeploying to ships offshore.   The officials, speaking after President Reagan announced that he had asked Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger to draw up a plan for moving the marines to their amphibious ships, said that work on the plan had begun tonight but that they did not know when it would be finished.   The officials said the stages of moving the marines to the ships had not been decided upon, but were part of the plan being worked up tonight. Presumably, units of the Lebanese Army would be fitted one at a time into into places that had been occupied by the marines.

headline: DORCHESTER HITS SNAG OVER BUYOUT
abstract: The Dorchester Gas Company said yesterday that the financing for its proposed leveraged buyout had not been obtained and that the status of the loan described in the company's proposal was ''problematical.''   Dorchester, of Dallas, disclosed in proxy material that its board was studying certain other transactions, including the acquisition of Dorchester by another company.

headline: Streisand Guards Arrested
abstract: Two of Barbra Streisand's bodyguards were arrested today on charges of assaulting a photographer who tried to take pictures of the actress outside a clothing store and a security guard who tried to help the photographer, the police said. A police spokesman said the two men were released on their own recognizance after being charged with two counts each of assault and battery.

headline: China Says Emergency Steps Cut the Crime Rate by 40%
abstract: The Chinese Government said today that it had cut the overall crime rate in late 1983 by just under 40 percent through emergency measures enacted to end a nationwide wave of lawlessness.   ''The masses' feeling of security has been strengthened,'' a report in the official weekly newspaper China Legal System said.

headline: $200 Million Issue From Sallie Mae
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, announced that it is selling $200 million of floating rate notes due Sept. 16, 1984, through various dealers.

headline: TRADE SPECIALIST HEADS A SEARS JOINT VENTURE
abstract: Eugene A. Sekulow, former head of RCA International, has been named president and chief executive officer of Sears Schenkers Services Inc., a new company formed by Sears World Trade and Schenkers International Forwarders. Sears World Trade is a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company; Schenkers is the American unit of Schenkers & Company G.m.b.H., a big West German freight forwarder.    The joint venture, based in New York, opened for business last week, and Mr. Sekulow said it had landed its first contract - for moving prefabricated housing components.

headline: Talking Business with Pierre Gousseland of AMAX ; Pickup Seen In Minerals
abstract: AMAX Inc., a major mineral and energy development company, has responded to recent losses with an extensive diversification program. Indeed, the company now describes itself as the world's most diversified minerals company.     In 1982, AMAX lost $390 million and in 1983, $489 million, with $309 million of that coming from write-offs and write-downs, principally of mining- related properties. The company, based in Greenwich, Conn., is the world's largest molybdenum producer, and mines such minerals as nickel, tungsten, silver and phosphates. It is the nation's third- largest coal producer, has big oil interests and owns half of Alumax, the nation's fourth-largest aluminum company.

headline: ADVERTISING;
abstract: President Resigns At Goldhirsh Group      Neil R. Goldhirsh, president of the Goldhirsh Group of Boston, confirmed yesterday that he had resigned his position because ''it's time for me to move on.''   The 37-year-old executive had joined the holding company that owns the companies that publish both Inc. and High Technology magazines at the behest of his older brother, Bernard A. Goldhirsh, the founder-chairman.

headline: COAST UTILITY'S WRITEOFF ON NUCLEAR PLANT
abstract: The Pacific Power and Light Company, trying to extract itself from its involvement in northwest nuclear plants that have been closed or are undergoing a construction slowdown, said today that it wrote off $228 million in 1983.   The write-off brought earnings down to $71 million, or 45 cents a share, from $197 million, or $4.50 a share, in 1982.

headline: Zairian Leader Greets Israeli With Advice on Mideast Issue
abstract: President Mobutu Sese Seko told the visiting Israeli President, Chaim Herzog, that Israel would have to tackle the Palestinian issue more seriously to win peace in the Middle East, a Government spokesman said today.   He said President Mobutu ''pulled out all the stops'' in a frank welcoming speech to Mr. Herzog today at the start of a three-nation African tour by the Israeli head of state.

headline: JACKSON URGES U.S. NOT TO 'SHUN' DIRECT TALKS WITH SYRIANS
abstract: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, continuing to press his views of United States policy in the Middle East, said today that he had told Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that the Administration should not ''shun'' direct talks with Syria on easing tensions in the region.    The 42-year-old contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination met for a half hour with Mr. Weinberger a day after Mr. Jackson's return from Syria, where his talks with Syrian officials led to the release of a captured Navy flier. The meeting was a followup, Mr. Jackson said, to his meeting at the White House Wednesday with President Reagan.

headline: SHOREHAM STANCE WAS CRITICIZED
abstract: Charles R. Pierce resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the Long Island Lighting Company. No reason was given, but recent reports had indicated that the company's directors were displeased at his handling of problems with Lilco's $4 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant.    Mr. Pierce, who is 61 years old, will be replaced by William J. Catacosinos, a Long Island computer executive who has been a member of Lilco's board for six years. Mr. Pierce's resignation was accepted yesterday at a meeting of Lilco's board in Mineola, L.I.   Mr. Pierce resigned when state and local officials and the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission are approaching crucial decisions on whether to approve operating licenses for the nearly completed Shoreham plant and how much Lilco should charge for its electricity.    The Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, one of Lilco's harshest critics, said he hoped the changes would mean a ''fresh look and a new approach to the Shoreham problem.''

headline: Tenure of Andropov Was Soviet's Briefest
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov's tenure of less than than 15 months as the General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, in effect the nation's principal leader, was the shortest in Soviet history. He was only the fifth person to hold that post in the 66 years since the Bolshevik Revolution of November 1917.

headline: AQUINO BOARD EJECTS COMMUNIST LEADER FROM WITNESS STAND
abstract: An imprisoned leader of the outlawed Philippine Communist Party was abruptly ordered off the witness stand today at an inquiry into the killing of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. last summer.    The leader, 44-year-old Jose Maria Sison, who had been brought to the hearing from his cell at Fort Bonifacio, had been expected either to confirm or deny testimony by Government witnesses that the assassination of Mr.  Aquino was part of a Communist plot to destablize the rule of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.    Instead, Mr. Sison and his lawyer, Juan David, submitted a seven-page analysis of testimony provided by 45 Government witnesses, saying these were ''designed to hoodwink the board.''

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Bank of Boston Corp.  Sets Floating-Rate Note    WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) - The Bank of Boston Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $100 million in floating-rate subordinated notes due in 1996.   The company said interest on the notes would be payable quarterly beginning in May 1984.

headline: 40 YEARS LATER, THE MESSAGE OF MONTE CASSINO: PAX
abstract: Forty years later, when the monks file in silently for Vespers and fill the basilica with the medieval harmonies of Gregorian chant, it is almost possible to forget.    It is easy to imagine that nothing has interrupted the disciplines of Benedictine life since the founder of the order built its first monastery on this mountaintop in 529. Over the centuries the buildings of the abbey have been destroyed four times - twice by invaders, once by earthquake and, most recently, by Allied bombers in the winter of 1944.   Father Agostino, a 74-year-old monk who was christened Agostino Saccomano, is one of four Benedictines who remain who were at the monastery on Feb. 15, 1944, when Allied bombers dropped over 450 tons of bombs on the abbey. Under the pile of rubble lay hundreds of civilian dead.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Seventeen magazine increasing its circulation rate base 3.3 percent, to 1.55 million, from 1.5 million, and its advertising rates by the same percentage, with the August issue.     * Porter, Novelli & Associates, Washington, a Needham, Harper & Steers company, has acquired Charlotte C. Klein Associates, which will now be called Porter, Novelli/Klein.

headline: SALVADOR FREES WITNESS IN SLAYING OF 2 AMERICANS
abstract: Salvadoran Army officials said today that a key witness in the slayings of the head of the country's land redistribution program and two American labor advisers was released from jail last week.    United States officials expressed doubts today over whether the witness, Capt. Eduardo Alfonso Avila, who was released on the condition that he not leave the country, would appear in court to testify in the case of the slain Americans, Mark D. Pearlman and Michael P. Hammer.   They were gunned down in January 1981 in the coffee shop of the Sheraton Hotel here along with Jose Rodolfo Viera, director of the Salvadoran Institute for Agrarian Reform.   The release of Captain Avila comes at an embarrassing time for the Reagan Administration, which is seeking approval for emergency military aid for El Salvador. El Salvador's failure to bring the killers of Americans to justice has been cited by Congressional critics as a reason for opposing more military aid.

headline: SALVADOR FAILS TO ACT ON DEATH-SQUAD OFFICERS
abstract: The Salvadoran armed forces have announced end-of-the-month military changes without meeting United States demands for the exiling of officers suspected of taking part in death-squad activities.    Diplomats and Salvadoran politicians say that the Government is having difficulty complying with the demands to reduce violence and punish offenders that Vice President Bush delivered when he visited El Salvador early in December. People suspected of death-squad activity are apparently refusing to leave the country.   State Department officials indicated last week that they felt the Salvadorans had made progress in complying with the demands. They offered as evidence the arrest of an officer implicated in the deaths of two American labor advisers, a decrease in political killings and the removal of the intelligence directors of two security forces.

headline: CHINA AND SOVIET SIGN $1.2 BILLION TRADE PACT
abstract: China and the Soviet Union signed a $1.2 billion trade agreement today.   The announcement came as the Chinese Government announced the death of Yuri V. Andropov. But it withheld comment on the Soviet leader, whose tenure saw a continuation of the easing in relations between the two countries that had begun under his predecessor, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

headline: Swedes Hunt 3 Frogmen On Isle Near Navy Base
abstract: A Swedish military spokesman said today that military forces hunting a foreign submarine had fired in separate incidents at three frogmen spotted emerging from the sea today on the small island of Almoe.   The latest sightings of frogmen occurred near the place where troops fired at a lone diver Wednesday night.

headline: No Headline
abstract: A Coleman Campaign   If you are an outdoor person, you know the Coleman Company, or at least its products.

headline: JAPAN PAUSES FOR BREATH BEFORE THE '84 RAT RACE
abstract: It was one of those rattle-in-your-boots earthquakes, and had it occurred on land instead of safely out in the Pacific Ocean, there might have been fewer people here to talk about it.   Tokyo buildings swayed for a minute or two and shivered for several minutes more. People felt the jolt across the full length of the Japanese archipelago. At a force of 7.5 on the Richter scale, the quake was bad enough, people said. Coming on New Year's Day, as it did, made it more of a bad sign.

headline: IN FRENCH SHIPYARD TOWN, LEFTISTS ARE CASTAWAYS
abstract: -SUR-MER, France, March 5 - The Mediterranean's pastels, its glistening, leaping light stop at the shipyard gates here. Beyond them is one tough town: a half-dozen bars on Avenue Gambetta, more across the street from the yard, and guys in them, coming off work, talking, their voices lowered, to the quiet precincts of dismay.    Last week, the talk seemed stunned. For the first time since 1919, La Seyne and its 50,000 people across the harbor from Toulon elected a ''bourgeois'' city council, voting out the alliance of Communists and Socialists.

headline: PATENTS;
abstract: Way to Convert Lignite Into Hydrocarbon Fuel    Paul L. Gomory of Bethesda, Md., offered the Phillips Petroleum Company this week, in a patent he assigned the company, a method of converting its billions of tons of lignite into high-quality hydrocarbon fuels.   Patent 4,435,269 describes the conversion of part of the lignite into hydrocarbon oil and then causing a second portion of it to react with the oil, producing fuel oil and gases. A patent lawyer, Mr. Gomory directed patent operations in the Washington office of Phillips Petroleum until his retirement in 1981.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day paper produced an average 9.687 percent yield, up from 9.677 percent last week. The rate on 182-day commercial paper fell to 9.735 percent, from 9.743 percent last week.     * Del E. Webb Corp. , a Phoenix- based leisure, real estate and construction company, said it had filed for an issue of 25,000 units, each consisting of a $1,000 principal amount subordinated note due in 1991 and warrants to purchase common stock through First Boston Corp. Terms of the warrants were not disclosed.

headline: Combustion Will Buy 2 Companies
abstract: Combustion Engineering Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Jamesbury Corporation for $29.25 a share, or $100 million.

headline: CLOPAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: Phibro Gains 24.5% in Period Phibro-Salomon Inc., the international minerals trader   and investment banking concern, reported yesterday that   its earnings in the fourth quarter increased 24.5 percent on a   4.9 percent increase in sales. The company, citing the positive impact of tax credits from   the disposal of unprofitable industrial operations, said net income in the period increased to  $122 million, or 86 cents a   share, from $98 million, or 72   cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: FED'S ROLE IN BANKING NEGOTIATED
abstract: The Federal Reserve appears ready to give up some of its supervisory powers over commercial banks as part of a plan to consolidate bank regulation in a new entity called the Federal Banking Agency.    According to an Administration official who asked not to be identified, the staff of the Administration's Task Group on Regulation of Financial Services has devised a new proposal intended to break a long-standing deadlock over the Fed's regulatory role. He said ''it would surprise me'' if the proposal were rejected.    Under the compromise plan put on the table in recent days, the Fed would have authority over a group of banks with the biggest international operations but would transfer its rule- making authority on what activities are permissible for banks in general to the new agency. The Fed, however, would have the right to veto any of these so-called ''laundry list'' items to which it objected.

headline: Addenda
abstract: Peter Hahn & Associates is a new advertising agency in Armonk, N.Y.     * The public relations company of Alden Taylor & Associates is now called Taylor & Hammond.     * Rogers & Cowan, Washington, has formed a corporate cultural affairs division.     * McCorvie & Partners is a new marketing consulting firm in Westport, Conn.

headline: ISRAEL ASSERTS IT WON'T RENOUNCE SECURITY ACCORD WITH LEBANESE
abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel would not renounce its security agreement with Lebanon.    He said that if President Amin Gemayel did so, it would be ''a blow to Lebanon's own sovereignty, to its people and to their chances of freeing themselves from the Syrian grip.''   Mr. Shamir's remarks, in an address to a meeting of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, came a day after American officials in Washington said President Gemayel had signed an eight- point plan drafted by Saudi Arabia that included the scrapping of the agreement with Israel, which was signed last May 17. The accord provided for the withdrawal of Israeli troops and the maintenance of joint patrols and other security arrangement in southern Lebanon in conjunction with the Lebanese Army.

headline: AVIATION COUNCIL FAULTS SOVIET
abstract: The governing council of the International Civil Aviation Organization condemned the Soviet Union tonight for shooting down a South Korean jet last September, killing the 269 people aboard.   The council adopted a United States resolution accepting a staff report that found Soviet officials did not try hard enough to identify the airliner before downing it and that found no evidence that the plane was on a spying mission, as the Soviet Union contended.   The council accepted the staff report by a vote of 20 to 2, with 9 abstentions. The voting was by secret ballot.

headline: UNHAPPINESS WITH ANTITRUST POLICY
abstract: It seems that no one is happy with antitrust policy. The Justice Department's opposition to the proposed merger of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation is being assailed as inflexible and niggardly. At the same time, a block east on Constitution Avenue in Washington, the Federal Trade Commission is drawing fire for failing to act more vigorously to block the spate of oil mergers.   Where both sets of critics agree, however, is that antitrust enforcement should be concerned with more than whether mergers lessen price competition. They propose that antitrust enforcement should be sensitive to the needs of particular industries, for instance, by taking an industry's financial woes into account.

headline: U.S. AIDES SAY NEW AIM IN BEIRUT IS DETERRENCE OF ATTACKS BY SYRIA
abstract: Senior Administration officials said today that President Reagan's decision to authorize unlimited naval and air strikes against any shelling of Beirut from Syrian lines was made in part to deter Syria from attacking the marines now that they are to be moved to ships off shore.   One State Department official said that ''it is important that the Syrians get the message that they should not try to humiliate the United States by targeting the marines.''   The White House spokesman also warned Syria against concluding that the marines' pullback represented any lessening of the American determination to support the Lebanese Government. The spokesman, Larry Speakes, said the decision was not to ''cut and run'' but to move the marines out of a ''static'' situation for a more effective strategy. (Page A12.)

headline: Taiwan and Alaska Oil TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 24 (AP) - Taiwan could help reduce its huge trade imbalance with the United States if it was allowed to purchase oil from Alaska, a Government official said today. Wu Mei-Tsun, Economic Deputy Minister, said at a news conference that he supported a proposal in the United States Senate to amend a law that currently bans the shipment of Alaskan crude oil to foreign countries. Taiwan had a record trade surplus of $6.68 billion last year, and this has led to United States demands for Taiwan to purchase more United States goods. ;  Bonn Trade Deficit
abstract: West Germany's current account slipped to a 600-million- mark deficit in January from a 5.5- billion-mark surplus in December, the federal Statistics Office said today. The deficit is the equivalent of about $228 million at current exchange rates.

headline: Report Is Dedicated To Senator Jackson
abstract: The 132- page report released today by the President's commission on Central America is dedicated to Senator Henry M. Jackson.

headline: First Peoples Bank
abstract: First Peoples Bank of New Jersey said the Comptroller of the Currency had approved the application by First National Bank of Toms River to acquire certain assets and assume certain liabilities of seven branches of First Peoples Bank.

headline: Norway Isolates Spy Suspect For Safety From Assassins
abstract: Norway has isolated a suspected Soviet spy, Arne Treholt, under heavy guard to protect him from possible Soviet assassins, police sources said today.

headline: BASQUE VOTERS FAIL TO GIVE CLEAR MAJORITY TO MODERATES
abstract: After a violent campaign in the Basque country, the moderate Basque Nationalist Party retained its hold on the regional Parliament today. But it did not gain the clear majority that would allow it to rule unchallenged.    The Socialist Party, which controls the central Government in Madrid, did better than expected, consolidating its position as the second party in the Basque country, the three northern provinces.   The nationalist party, the Herri Batasuna coalition, lost ground. The coalition, which is regarded as the political arm of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. and which campaigned under the slogan ''Punish with your vote,'' came in third.

headline: PETRA CHAIRMAN MOVES TO LARGER BANK AUDI
abstract: Peter J. Tanous has resigned as chairman of the Petra Capital Corporation, an Arab-controlled Wall Street investment banking firm, to become executive vice president of Bank Audi.    Mr. Tanous, 45, thus changes to commercial banking from investment banking.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: SATURDAY, MARCH 17, 1984   The Economy    Construction of new residences surged 11.2 percent in February, to an annual rate of 2.2 million units, the highest level in nearly six years. (Page 29.)    Producer prices rose a moderate 0.4 percent in February , despite large increases in the costs of food and home heating oil. Although the rate of increase slowed last month, prices are running at a pace that would give 1984 the highest inflation in three years. But analysts said the large rise in food and energy prices, which they linked to bad winter weather, would fade this spring. (31.)

headline: IRAN KEEPS ARMY ON HOLD, U.S. SAYS
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that Iran appeared to be trying to wear down Iraq with costly attacks by untrained units to set the stage for a possibly decisive thrust by regular forces.     In support of this view, the officials pointed out that few regular Iranian Army units appeared to have been engaged in the most recent offensive led by untrained Revolutionary Guards and carried out mostly by teen-agers and older men.   These officials were reluctant to try to predict the outcome of the war, which began in September 1980, or to say which side they thought was winning. But they made it clear they felt that Washington, rather than maintaining the more neutral stance that prevailed until about a year ago, was now interested in preventing a victory by Iran.

headline: Vector Stock Deal
abstract: Vector Graphic Inc., the financially pressed maker of sophisticated desktop computers, said it had completed a private placement of 1.8 million shares that brought $2.75 million in additional financing to the company.

headline: Ha'penny Is Done For After Seven Centuries
abstract: For nearly seven centuries the halfpenny was one of the most useful coins of the realm, but it has been shrunk by decimalization, devalued by inflation and rendered nearly useless. Next month the Royal Mint will stop making it.

headline: ON THE NAMBIA FRONT, EVERYBODY SEEMS TO LOSE
abstract: -West Africa - The dirt road that winds to this northern outpost in Africa's last colony does not encourage too much overtaking.    For one thing, the worn tracks of vehicles that have passed this way before provide safe passage through quagmires born of the season's rains. For another, it is wise to follow the tracks of the vehicle in front: If it does not detonate a land mine, the chances are that yours won't either.   Such considerations seem appropriate in northern South-West Africa, where years of conflict have left a heritage that blends fear and anomaly and consumes much South African manpower to contain guerrillas often derided for their supposed ineffectiveness. These considerations also prompt rumination on the applicability of the adage that guerrillas don't win but their adversaries always lose.

headline: FRENCH FARMERS SET UP BLOCKADES IN PROTEST
abstract: Farmers blocked roads across France today with tractors, burning tires and straw, demanding higher prices for their produce and protesting cuts in milk production.   The farmers set up roadblocks in Paris and in the north, east and southwest regions of France using tactics adopted by truck drivers last month during a weeklong blockade of French roads.   The farmers parked tractors across roads, blocked toll booths and slowly drove farm vehicles on major highways, holding up traffic for hours, according to the police.
